PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ANDREW; BLEWETT; BRAITHWAITE; DOWNER; GALLUS; HALL; TRUSS
PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the absolute right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
request the Federal Government to denounce those parts of the Convention which could undermine the parent-child relationship.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 204 citizens), Dr Blewett (from 50 citizens), Mr Braithwaite (from 66 citizens), Mr Downer (from eight citizens), Mrs Gallus (from 20 citizens), Mr Steele Hall (from 68 citizens) and Mr Truss (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is ageing. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 378 citizens), Mr Downer (from 78 citizens), Mrs Gallus (from 22 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 21 citizens), Ms Fatin (from 156 citizens) and Mr Mack (from one citizen).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby;
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights;
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life;
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect;
That in 1989/90 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 69,587 abortions totalling $7.8 million;
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Second Frequency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of N.S.W. and Vic. draws to the attention of the House that the rescheduling of programmes on radio S.B.S. is a divisive measure damaging to a multicultural nation.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House approve a second frequency for radio S.B.S. in order to adequately meet the needs of newly arrived communities without penalising the ageing and minority migrant groups.

La petizione di certi residenti del N.S.W. e Vic. desidera indurre l'attenzione della camera dei deputati sul fatto che la ristrutturazione dei programmi della radio S.B.S. e' un'azione divisoria che danneggia una nazione multiculturale.

I richiedenti percio' desideranno che la camera approvi una seconda frequenza per la radio S.B.S. per poter adeguatamente rispondere alle necessita' delle nuove comunita' senza penalizzare quelle piu' piccole, o quelle che stanno invecchiando.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman (from 50 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 50 citizens) and Dr Harry Edwards (from 36 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of 18 residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the current campaign which is being waged by the Communist Government of Serbia and its agents against the aspiration for independence of the Republic of Croatia.

We particularly draw to your attention the fact that Croatia has satisfied the conditions of international law for independence, and that it has made every effort to enter into meaningful dialogue with its opponents in Serbia. These have been to no avail.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House as a matter of urgency offers immediate recognition to Croatia as a sovereign nation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie (from 18 citizens) and Dr Bob Woods (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Special Purpose Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens call upon the Commonwealth to:
Keep the Disadvantaged Schools Program and Country Education Project as Commonwealth Special Purpose Programs.
Increase funding by at least the Consumer Price Index annually.
Ensure that funding for schools be made available to schools, not diverted to pay Ministry employees.
Ensure guidelines are followed and the State Committee permitted to meet.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Peter Fisher (from 19 citizens) and Mr McGauran (from 10 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Falls in Real Value
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws the attention of the House to the need to redress falls in the real value of the pension relative to wages, and the need to alleviate poverty among low-income Australians.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to,
(1) Increase the basic pension rate by $15 per week
(2) Introduce a $20 pw supplement for pensioners with no other income
(3) Increase rent assistance
(4) Abolish the "deeming" legislation
(5) Extend fringe benefits to all pensioners, and
(6) Remove the $2.50 and other charges for prescriptions, in the 1991/1992 Budget of the Commonwealth
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Gorman (from 28 citizens) and Mr West (from 37 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members in the House of Representatives assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Jenkins (from 20 citizens) and Mr Mack (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: SBS: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House their grave concern and opposition to the rescheduling and networking of SBS 3EA radio programs.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take into account our grave concerns and stop the proposed rescheduling and networking changes to SBS radio.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC Country Hour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The ABC Country Hour radio programme (in particular the state component) is an important and widely used resource for the rural people of South Australia. The proposed cut to the State section will be a severe loss to the rural communities of South Australia.
Your petitioners request that your Honourable House ensure that the ABC is provided with adequate funding to enable this programme to continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: Benalla
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We the residents of the City of Benalla and surrounding districts in the State of Victoria, Australia, draw to the attention of the House the fact that no Medicare office is provided in Benalla and the difficulties this causes our community. The absence of a Medicare office makes it difficult for us to use the national health scheme to its full potential. We experience lengthy delays in claiming rebates on doctors' accounts we have paid because we must either travel to other regional centres to make claims or send claim forms away by post and they must be processed. The system as it operates today encourages people to travel away from Benalla to other regional centres to make Medicare claims, taking important business with them, and we feel this is not in the best interests of our community. We believe our community should have ready and easy access to Medicare claim facilities to speed the payment of accounts.
Your petitions therefore pray that the House will act swiftly to ensure a Medicare office is established in the City of Benalla.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1) Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2) The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3) These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the House, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to remove these services so that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that every abortion kills a baby
that in 1989/90 alone the Federal government paid for 69,587 abortions through Medicare
that to pay for the killing of unborn children is to endorse each such act of killing
that the protection of human life is the first duty of parliament and government

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian parliament will act to protect the right to life of unborn babies in Australia and cease to subsidise the killing of unborn children through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill and in any other way possible.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Nirimba
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth--

That HMAS Nirimba is a vital training facility for the Navy apprentices with training expertise that does not and cannot exist at any other location. The expertise is not just the knowledge which is passed onto the Navy apprentices but the years of goodwill at the facility and the interaction with the community which enhances the education process.
If the proposal for consolidation of Navy's technical trade training at HMAS Cerberus is realised, then not just the Navy, but Australia, will lose a vital centre for training in trade excellence.
Further, HMAS Nirimba is vital to the local business community which services not just the base needs but those of the personnel and their families.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal for the functions of HMAS Nirimba and HMAS Cerberus to be consolidated at HMAS Cerberus.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned concerned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that the Report of the Parliamentary Committee of Public Works of the Forty Sixth Parliament concerning its Inquiry into Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander housing--the Future, should be rejected on the following grounds:

(1) The Committee failed to adequately consult the Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland in order to obtain their views by failing to advise details of existing guidelines for funding of housing, failing to adequately publicise the Committee Inquiry through the established Aboriginal and Islander networks.

(2) The terms of reference were unsatisfactory insofar as they do not address the vital issue of tenant ownership which creates no incentive for self-determination and not enough time was given for the communities to study the recommendations of the infrastructure on Aboriginal housing as addressed by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

(3) Senior Administrator of the Department Housing and Local Government will be delegated the responsibility of expenditure of funds, reinforcing their existing mandate over administration and financial management and vetoing any decisions made by the Housing Advisory Council, who will be responsible to review and advise policy development and implementation and oversee the menial day to day activities such as:
(a) rent assessment
(b) tenancy neglect
(c) tenancy agreement based on cultural differences between land lord and tenant
(e) tenant unions.

(4) No Aboriginal housing trust as exists in other States under the Aboriginal Housing Rentals Program, will mean no economic base or self management for urban and rural blacks and will eventually mainstream tenants and homes, creating further funding under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement and an endless financial resource institution for the Department of Housing and Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Federal Parliament will intervene on our behalf to prevent the State Government from passing legislation through this Report at the Queensland Parliament sitting. We pray the Federal Parliament will act on our behalf because of the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement and that the Federal Government direct the State to hold further consultations with the Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland so that a report may be tabled which genuinely addresses the housing needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Queensland.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the House will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX: Withdrawal of Support
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain Christian citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
(1) that an Australian International Defence Equipment Exhibition (AIDEX) is to be held in Canberra, November 26-28, 1991;

(2) that this private arms trade fair has the official support of the Australian Government and the participation of the Department of Defence and some State Government Departments and instrumentalities;
(3) that it is inconsistent to advocate disarmament while helping to promote the arms trade, and immoral to reduce our trade deficit by developing a competitive arms export industry;
(4) that a trade fair to promote the sale of arms will not help to preserve the peace of our region, but is more likely to destabilise it;
(5) that the basic need of our Pacific and S.E. Asian neighbours is for food, shelter, health care and education, not arms.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:
(1) immediately withdraw all Government support for and participation in AIDEX;
(2) refuse to allow into Australia any arms, including defence components and equipment, destined for display at AIDEX;
(3) express willingness to consider compensation for firms which may already have spent money on AIDEX.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas--for example, health, education and social welfare--but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX 1991. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX 1991, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX 1991.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i) call on the Federal Government to outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.
(ii) call on the Federal Government to lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(iii) Cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the ban on political advertising denies Australians the right to Freedom of Speech, may be unconstitutional, and contravenes Australia's human rights responsibilities. Your petitioners therefore ask the House to reject this legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the readily available range of sex and fantasy audio text services transmitted via Telecom through the use of the 0055 prefix.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to move to disband this `adult' information and entertainment service. Your petitioners are deeply concerned as to what effect these messages have on our youth and Australia's moral standing.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Reception: Springsure
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Maranoa draws to the attention of the House the difficulties currently being experienced by viewers of WIN Television in Springsure, owing to constant interference from another source, thus making viewing virtually impossible.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to approach WIN Television requesting the interference problem in Springsure be rectified.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD, we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said "The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth" and as stated in our Federal Constitution--"humbly relying upon the Blessings of Almighty God. . .
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
(1) The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem--"God Bless Australia" to the tune of "Waltzing Matilda".
(2) The Adoption of a Christian National Motto--"One Nation Under God", for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
(3) The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth IQ.
(4) The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
(5) The retention of "God Save the Queen" for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
(6) The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
(7) Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Telephone Message Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the Telephone Information Services Standards Committee is considering the introduction of hard-core pornographic telephone messages in Australia if public opinion approves.

According to the proposal, access to such a service would be restricted to mature-age subscribers armed with their own pin number. This proposal obviously relies on the integrity of the person who has been allocated the pin number, and does not offer any assurance to the community that young people will be protected from exposure to sexually explicit messages.

We have heard the perpetrators of rape and other sex-related crimes admit that they have been influenced by the proliferation of pornographic literature and videos. We believe that if society is subjected to yet another form of hard-core pornography, we will see an increase in the incidence of such crimes.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to protect the interests of the people of Australia, and to ensure that the proposed introduction of hard-core pornographic telephone messages does not take place.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Telecom has introduced hard core pornographic telephone messages in Australia on its recorded 0055 Information Services.
Although such services will have a personal identification number access, we do not believe that the introduction of such services would be in the best interests of the community in general.
We believe that if our society is subjected to yet another form of hard core pornography, we will see an increase in the incidence of sex related crimes.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take note of our concerns and to request Telecom withdraw this service.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Committee's report entitled Report on the Visit of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to Adelaide July 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In July, the Defence Subcommittee inspected defence facilities in the Adelaide area. These inspections were made in accordance with the tradition of the Defence Subcommittee of conducting familiarisation visits for its members.

SPEECH.PARA: The Subcommittee visited RAAF Edinburgh where it was briefed on the surveillance role of the long range maritime patrol aircraft, the P3C Orions. The visit afforded members the opportunity to gain first-hand knowledge of the patrol's search and rescue function. Members were able to gain some appreciation of the equipment used in carrying out search and rescue, particularly in light of the attempted rescue of the crew of the yacht Rockin' Robin last year. Through discussions with the Commander Maritime Patrol Group, Air Commodore Stafford James AFC, we were also able to obtain a better understanding of the events surrounding the loss of the Orion aircraft in the Cocos Islands.

The visit fulfilled its aim of keeping members up to date with developments in technology and defence equipment. The Subcommittee inspected a P3C Orion at RAAF Edinburgh. It was briefed on the aircraft's computer based sensor system, the Barra sonobuoy and the AGM84 Harpoon missile. This was complemented by a briefing at DSTO on the project for the refurbishment of the Orion.

At RAAF Edinburgh we were also interested to ascertain the percentages of aircraft that were undergoing maintenance and were `on line' at any given time. We gained a clear understanding of the nature of the maintenance program and of the tests conducted on, for example, the FA18 Hornet and the Black Hawk helicopter by the Aircraft Research and Development Unit.

During the visit to the Defence Science and Technology Organisation we were briefed on the impact of the force structure review on DSTO and the approach adopted by the organisation to accommodate the changes to its operations. We also received briefings on a number of major projects in train at the DSTO, such as DORIC, the Kariwara towed array project and the support provided by DSTO to Operation Damask during the Gulf war. We were also interested in DSTO's task of adapting the RBS70 missile system for shipboard use, particularly as our visit to Adelaide included an inspection of the RBS70 at Woodside Barracks.

At Woodside the Subcommittee appreciated the opportunity to inspect closely both the RBS70 missile system and the Rapier Fire Unit missile system which had been set up for the occasion. Members of the Subcommittee are concerned that the number of Rapiers held by 110 Air Defence Battery is insufficient to defend more than one vital asset or one airfield in northern Australia at a given time. We were also concerned to learn that the number of missiles available for use by 110 Battery is inadequate for proving the ability of the equipment to fire. We were told that 111 Air Defence Battery (Light) also suffers from receiving insufficient numbers of RBS70 missiles for proving its equipment. The Battery receives an allocation of only six missiles per year.

Whilst in Adelaide we inspected the submarine project plan at the Australian Submarine Corporation's plant at Osborne. The inspection complemented another element of the Subcommittee's program; that is, of receiving briefings on aspects of defence support at our regular meetings in Canberra. Earlier this year the Managing Director of the Submarine Corporation addressed members on the submarine project. We were therefore interested to monitor progress on the construction of the submarine fleet.

Finally, the visit provided members of the Subcommittee with opportunities for informal discussions with Defence Force personnel. One such occasion was arranged at Keswick Barracks, where discussions with Regular and Reserve personnel from Headquarters 4 Military District, 9 Brigade and 4 Training Group proved most productive. I thank the officers and personnel for that particular meeting. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to say a few words on three aspects of this report. The first is that I was concerned that in our visit to Elizabeth we found that the funds available and the problems associated with long range maritime patrol aircraft, the P3C Orion, are getting to a point where there are going to be difficulties in the future. I think most of us have been conscious that the American production has run out and there are going to be difficulties in maintaining what has been an outstanding aircraft in the long range maritime patrol task.

SPEECH.PARA: The nature of the funding changes to our Australian Defence Force imposes disciplines which, of course, mean that no individual sector can be isolated from them. I had not been aware of some of the problems associated with the continued maintenance of the P3C. I urge the Australian Defence Force to maintain sufficient funding to ensure that it can continue its duties.

The second area that I want to briefly mention is ARDU, the Aircraft Research and Development Unit. There is no doubt that the work undertaken there is outstanding. The aspects of testing and maintaining to the highest possible degree both the technical standards of aircraft in service within the RAAF and the degree to which they can be extended beyond their present bounds by way of add-on equipment, adapting existing equipment and technical devices to them, are really quite important if we are going to get the best value out of the defence dollar.

Over the years, ARDU has done on outstanding job. I was very interested to see the current tests under way with the FA18 Hornet and the Black Hawk helicopter and also some tests that are prescribed for the PC9 and CT4. It has always seemed to me to be unfortunate that we cannot use to a greater degree the general services and facilities there, in conjunction with the requirements for the private sector. The capacity is there and I would hope that at some stage it might be possible to use it more.

The third area, and the most important, concerns the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. I do not think many Australians realise the sophistication and capability of DSTO. It is the prime research unit for the Services; it has an outstanding record; and many achievements have been recorded to its credit.

I was most concerned to find that, in the nature of the cuts now being imposed, there is likely to be a serious reduction in its capability. No body, whether public or private, can ensure continuity. I would not suggest that an area of the Defence Force should be more immune from funding scrutiny than any other field of the public sector. But I am most concerned that, as far as DSTO is concerned, the result of the changes include reducing the civilian staff by some 700 personnel. It seems that as a result some of the highest priorities of research are likely to be seriously prejudiced. Indeed, we were told that some might be jeopardised altogether. I do not believe that is in the interests of Australia. I am sure it is not in the interests of Australia's defence preparedness.

I strongly recommend that the ADF have a look at some of those at `Fort Fumble', at the headquarters of the Australian Defence Force. I see a greater capacity to reduce numbers there at the moment. I believe that we would do much better in areas of research and development were we to ensure maintenance of some technical capability, which in due course flows back to the private sector, than if we were to maintain the services of those who are merely pen-pushers and maintaining the administrative services in the defence headquarters in this city.

For that reason I was most concerned about the visit. I trust that the ADF and certainly the Government register that what it is doing is to a large degree jeopardising skills that are irreplaceable. I am appalled at the consequences and trust that the matter will be examined. I hope that the numbers will in no way be allowed to be so reduced that the threat, which we were told would jeopardise the highest priority areas of research, is in fact realised.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is the first time a parliamentary committee has prepared a comprehensive report on the Australian economy. The report entitled Australia's Current Account Deficit and Overseas Debt not only contains an excellent description and analysis of Australia's position with regard to its current account deficit and overseas debt, but also considers issues that go to the heart of the economic policy debate in our country. Its recommendations are designed to comprehensively address the current account deficit in ways which would also reduce unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Current account deficits have been a feature of most of Australia's economic history. Over the 1980s, however, there has been a marked increase in the relative size of that deficit. At the beginning of the decade the deficit was less than 4 per cent of gross domestic product. By the end of the decade it had risen to around 6 per cent.

There was also a radical change in the nature of the current account deficit during the decade. At the beginning of the 1980s the current account deficit reflected primarily a trade deficit. By the end of the decade the current account deficit was overwhelmingly dominated by our foreign debt servicing obligations. By international standards, Australia's current account deficit, as a proportion of GDP, is amongst the highest of any Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development country.

The current account deficit fell to 4 per cent in 1990-91 and the recent continuing decline is heartening. The improvement in Australia's export performance, particularly in relation to the growth in manufacturing exports, is particularly welcome. The decline in imports, however, has been marginal and the situation concerning our debt service obligations and other income payments overseas has improved to an even smaller degree, despite the severity of the current recession.

The Committee is concerned that the current account deficit will again return to high levels as Australia comes out of the recession. Unless concerted action is taken to address the underlying causes of Australia's high current account deficit, imports and foreign investment in Australia are likely to return to pre-recession levels.

There is considerable risk that Australia could become complacent about the current account deficit because of the reduction in its size over the past year. It must be remembered, however, that it has taken a very severe recession to halt the growth in imports and that further declines in imports cannot be expected once the recession eases.

Australia's overseas debt also grew sharply during the 1980s increasing more than tenfold to over $145 billion by 1989. It now stands at $165 billion, almost 44 per cent of our GDP. While Australia's overseas debt has not yet reached the crisis proportions evident in some countries, it would certainly do so by the end of the 1990s if its debt accumulation were to continue unabated at the rate we have experienced, particularly in the mid-1980s.

In responding to the problems identified in the report, the Committee has rejected the calls made in some quarters for a return to protectionist policies and regulatory controls. In our view, such a course of action would only serve to reduce Australia's ability to adjust to changing global circumstances. Ultimately, a failure to make the necessary adjustments would reduce the living standards of all Australians.

Equally, the Committee has rejected the view that the growing current account deficit and overseas debt is no longer a problem requiring government action, as this debt has been largely incurred--so it said--by the private sector which is responsible for its repayment. While those who have incurred the debt are individually responsible for its servicing and repayment, there can be no question that Australia's vulnerability to global economic changes will be greater if debt accumulation continues unabated.
The market has clearly failed to respond adequately to the situation. In the Committee's view, in the interests of efficiency and equity it is therefore essential for the Government to take the lead.

Against this background, the Committee has recommended a package of proposals designed to comprehensively address Australia's current account and overseas debt problems. The three main thrusts to these proposals are: first, to improve Australia's international trading performance through further reductions in tariff and other universal protectionist measures while the same time implementing a comprehensive package of positive measures to assist the development of Australia's export and import replacement industries, particularly those adding value to our exports; second, to introduce a range of measures designed to increase domestic savings and reduce Australia's reliance on overseas borrowings to finance investment; and, third, to put in place a set of appropriate macro-economic policy settings and necessary micro-economic reforms that are consistent with lowering the current account deficit and levels of overseas debt.

Amongst these recommendations are that real interest rates be reduced so as to encourage investment and also a fall in the exchange rate. There are also recommendations for targeted increases in outlays and reductions of taxation which would simultaneously stimulate growth of exports and growth of employment so reducing unemployment.

The suggested increases in outlays include technical and higher education to improve the skills of the work force, increased outlays on research and development to enhance the dynamism of the Australian economy and to improve the efficiency and extent of our infrastructure of transport and communication in which investment has been declining as a proportion of national income for about 15 years. The proposed tax cuts include an accelerated depreciation allowance for those enterprises adding value to exports or replacing imports.

I am confident that, if implemented, the Committee's recommendations will create the climate and conditions necessary to bring about substantial and sustained reductions in Australia's current account deficit and the level of our overseas debt. I urge the Government to quickly accept and implement the recommendations.

This inquiry was carried out by the Trade Subcommittee of the Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade Committee and I am very grateful to my colleagues on the Subcommittee for their contribution to this challenging task, particularly the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Harry Edwards), the right honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson), the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), Senator Chapman, Senator Beahan and Senator Childs.

I also wish to thank the staff associated with the inquiry: Jane Vincent, the Secretary to the Subcommittee for most of the time of the Committee hearings; our advisers Greg Barrett, Tom Fitzgerald and especially Chris Robinson for his excellent analysis and fine drafting; Margaret Brown, Toni Young and Lesley Cowan who provided administrative support and Jennifer Blood who took over as Secretary towards the end. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-While agreeing with much of what the Subcommittee Chairman, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), has just said, the Opposition members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade have subscribed to a minority report at pages 141 to 153 of the printed version of the report. The minority report is very brief and the major part comprises an extract from the current Treasury Budget Paper No. 1. Of this, we say in the report that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . examines developments in the 1980s; puts the case for relating economic policy more to the medium term; and spells out a comprehensive package of policy and reform, notably labour market and microeconomic reform--to which we would add tax reform--to achieve sustained low inflation economic and employment growth, rising living standards and--
I stress the `and'--
a reducing current account deficit as specified in the terms of reference. It stresses the importance of making significant progress simultaneously on all policy fronts.

We chose to include this extract because in a situation in which we felt some dissatisfaction with the Chairman's draft, constraints of time and resources prevented us from producing a comprehensive report of our own.

The difficulties we faced included: one, a sense that the underlying analytical framework was inadequate; two, partly for this reason there was a surfeit of detailed information on some aspects, for example, merchandise trade, and almost nothing on others, for example, productivity; three, a range of questions of the sort people typically ask about the foreign `debt' are not explicitly addressed. I say now in parenthesis that I used quotation marks there and elsewhere in this speech to connote that I am referring to the total of net foreign liabilities, that is, equity as well as debt in the strict sense, which is arguably the proper focus for issues concerning the relationship of this country to foreign financiers.

The fourth point is that the recommendations in the report are, in our view, excessively interventionist, not to say corporatist and not, in our view, justified by the weight and balance of the evidence presented to the Committee. As we state in the minority report:
In our view Australia needs urgently a comprehensive program of policy reform to effect fundamental change to boost national production, productivity, exports and savings.
We do not believe that this emphasis comes through in the Report.

With reference to the analytical framework, as briefly as one can put it, this would surely be that an excessive current account deficit is basically due to two factors: first, inadequate domestic savings; and, second, inadequate international competitiveness. The first factor might more accurately be expressed as `sustained, too high domestic spending relative to our productive capacity'--to adopt the phrase of Mr Fred Argy, until recently the head of EPAC. That terminology has the advantage that it leads one to ask what were the major factors in the debt build up, whether it was excessive government spending, Budget deficits--I believe it was in the first half of the 1980s--excessive private consumption and/or very high investment, as it was, albeit much of it misdirected, in the second half of the 1980s.

The second factor, inadequate international competitiveness, puts the stress on reducing inflation and increasing productivity as fundamental to increasing competitiveness and thereby reducing the deficit in an appropriate macro-economic framework. It also counsels caution in focusing on the nominal exchange rate, as does the majority recommendation No. 19 on page 134 of the report. As the evidence indicated, the nominal exchange rate is virtually out of the authorities' control in the new era of high capital mobility with the integration of international capital markets and the disappearance of exchange controls. What is important for competitiveness and the balance between the tradeable and non-tradeable sectors is the real exchange rate.

Another aspect of the analytical framework is the loose references to `reducing the current account deficit and the level of overseas debt'. The Treasury piece we have put forward as part of the minority report refers much more circumspectly to, `stabilising the debt to GDP ratio', which will prove difficult enough, but it is a comparatively modest objective as against reducing the actual level, at least where debt is read--as the average reader would understand it--as referring to our overall foreign liabilities, as I previously mentioned.

To reduce the level of foreign liabilities would require the achieving of an actual surplus on the current account not just a reduction in the deficit. That will not happen in any foreseeable future with the net income payable overseas relentlessly mounting--the prospective balance of payments deficit, even for this deep recession year, is projected to be $14 billion, which adds in one form or another to foreign liabilities and further increases the income payable to foreigners. Thus there is no likelihood whatever of surplus in the current account enabling a reduction in the level.

The second main point that I referred to above was that the report does not explicitly enough address the sorts of questions people often ask about the debt, such as: what actually brought about the large and rapid increase in the nation's indebtedness in the past eight to 10 years? There is the question that the Subcommittee Chairman referred to a moment ago, namely that it is often said that because a large proportion of the debt is private rather than public that the overseas debt is not a problem. Is that is a proper view?

The issue I would particularly refer to is that within the general economic objective to generate sustainable low inflation, high employment economic growth, sufficient for rising living standards and to reduce the current account and to stabilise the debt ratio, what are the broad dimensions and over what period of years might this be attainable? We include in our report at page 148 an excerpt of what the Treasury states, namely, that:
This will require a considerable period.

There have been a variety of projections and models, by EPAC and others, that might be looked at in this respect and the assumptions clarified and assessed. Without a formal model I would essay the following: there is something of a consensus that just to employ the work force increasing with population, we need growth in GDP of 3 1/4 per cent, say, 3 1/2 per cent over the medium term, to take up some of the existing unemployment. With imports increasing at much the same rate, a sustained increase in exports in the order of $4 billion each year for five or six years would be needed in order to effect the necessary transfer of resources to net exports to reduce the deficit to the more normal level of the order of 2 1/2 per cent of GDP which would stabilise the debt in terms of the net foreign liabilities to GDP ratio.

To my knowledge at no time in the past has this country achieved such a consistent growth in net exports, that is, exports over and above imports, and in GDP. Perhaps that is why Standard and Poors are at it again as reported in the news earlier this morning! That underlines the magnitude of the challenge before us. As we say in the minority report, this country needs urgently an across-the-board program of reform to effect a fundamental change in attitudes, the law, institutions, attitudes to performance and work. We have to strive in every corner of the land for best international practice, and also reassert what one might call traditional individual and corporate morality.

The process will be a long haul and it will not be easy. Fundamental change never is. But there is no other way. What is at stake is nothing less than an Australia in the future which is a dynamic, prosperous, responsible, compassionate society; a major player in this fast growing Asia-Pacific region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I initially wish to congratulate the Chairman of the Trade Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), for his sustained efforts in bringing this report, Australia's Current Account Deficit and Overseas Debt, to fruition. I join with him in congratulating the staff for the efforts they have put in as well.

SPEECH.PARA: We are all aware that this issue is not only a topic of discussion for major columnists and this Parliament, but within the Australian electorate it is also obviously of great importance. It is increasingly being perceived as the crucial element in a variety of Government policies in other sectors.

To summarise the report, it advocates further tariff reductions and an end to universal protectionist operations. At the same time it advocates positive measures to enhance export and import substitution areas, especially in the value added sectors. Also, it advocates the development of domestic savings to lessen our dependence upon overseas borrowings for major investment requirements, and it sets an appropriate macro-economic policy setting and micro-economic reforms. A crucial ingredient is a reiteration of the need for Government involvement in these decisions--that the Government should play a leading role. That is probably the crucial area of difference between the majority and minority views in this report.

There were 72 submissions to the inquiry, coming from the Reserve Bank, the private sector, the unions, et cetera, and I think it would be acknowledged by all that a large number of those were of a high quality. The accent was on what is, as I say, a crucial problem facing the country. Our current account deficit has averaged about 5 per cent over the decade, which compares to a figure of 2 per cent only for gross domestic product over the previous three decades. Throughout this report various aspects of that debt are dealt with. As has been stated by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), there may not have been enough concentration on productivity problems in this country and there could be quibbling over other aspects of its emphasis, but I would say that the work overall does present a summary of statistical material. However much one disagrees with some of the conclusions, the material included in it certainly provides a firm basis for analysis.

As I indicated, and as everyone realises, the current account deficit has deteriorated over the 1980s. Not only has this been a traditional problem for this country, but the serious fact is that it has deteriorated even further over this period. At the same time we see an overseas debt of $165 billion, which now represents 44 per cent of our gross domestic product. Whilst exports have remained as the same percentage of gross domestic product, having hardly moved since the 1950s, there has been a sustained reduction in the value of rural exports. But at the same time transformed manufactures, by 1987, still constituted only 11 per cent of our exports. I think that is one of the problems that does appear from the report.

At the same time, it is emphasised that the relativity in prices received by the tradeable sector--that is, that sector that competes with imports and is oriented towards export industries--has moved from 102.3 per cent in 1980-81 to over 147 per cent in the December quarter of 1990. That is another factor that the report takes up in its conclusions. The commodities trade balance has moved up by 7 1/2 per cent of GDP, but the manufactures trade balance has deteriorated by 8 per cent.

We also have the question of foreign borrowings by this country, many of them largely in the private sector. We all note the reduction of the government ingredient in this, but net income balance has moved from 2 per cent of GDP in 1980-81 to 4 1/2 per cent by 1990. That is another aspect of this problem. The capital account sees peak foreign investment levels in the 1980s. New portfolio investment, rather than investments where there is 10 per cent of equity in Australian assets, has become the crucial aspect of that investment. At the same time, there have been movements in those countries with that sort of investment. The greatest growth in capital account debts of this country occurs with the Japanese. Within the various sectors of that debt, of course, is the absolute growth of the finance, property, business and foreign debt section.

The Committee came to a number of conclusions, which I will summarise. The Committee, whilst advocating a continuation of tariff reductions and the attempt to increase international competitiveness, concludes that a number of the measures already set in train by the Government should be continued. For instance, the Committee came to the conclusion that the export market development grants, with taxable cash grants for up-front marketing involving promotional literature, travel expenses and overseas expenses, should continue for the remainder of the 1990s.

The Committee advocates that the services provided to exporters by Austrade, which has been investigated by the McKinsey Committee and been asked to orient its requirements more towards Asia and to change its management practices in a major way, be pursued in the remainder of the 1990s. At the same time, the Committee does reiterate the conclusion of the McKinsey Committee that the orientation should be towards Asia and the Pacific rather than towards a number of offices in Florida and other questionable sites.

The Committee has advocated that funding to the international trade enhancement scheme be increased for consortiums, joint ventures and associations to achieve greater efficiency. That involves low interest loans, concessional services, et cetera. There is a call from this Committee that the funding be expanded, not reduced, and that Australia not retract its interests and its involvement in helping companies penetrate overseas markets.

Regarding the development import finance facility, which is aimed at developing countries to facilitate their purchase of Australian products, the Committee does not advocate that this country reduce its support for the export industries that gain from this facility. It actually advocates a doubling of finance.

The Committee has asked that tripartite industry committees, involving government, the private sector and unions, have a greater orientation towards export requirements and actually compile industry reports that seek to maximise the export effort of industries.

The Committee advocates a very great increase in investment in plant, equipment and infrastructure. The major proportion of the Committee's time is spent looking at the question of anti-dumping and countervailing duties systems. We know that in the March industry statement measures were taken, but they are still receiving fairly pronounced criticism for the delays, even after these changes, in ensuring they operate.

As to superannuation, we know that there has been a variety of discussions between the Government and the superannuation funds--at this stage, it must be said, to very little effect. It appears that the persuasive abilities of the Government have not been effective in ensuring that superannuation funds move towards doing something for the national interest. It is all right to talk about the need for the funds to maximise profits for those people in them, but at the same time, it is the overall profitability of this country that counts. If its inability to penetrate overseas markets continues, the superannuation funds might have other problems in trying to ensure their members' long term financial security.

In regards to accelerated depreciation, the Committee has advocated that those sectors that deal with export industries should have a complete write-off over four years. It is stressed that that should not apply to the primary produce industries. In regards to wage policy, we reiterate our continued emphasis on wage restraint in this country, but advocate that it is a bit wider than the average wage earner--that he should not, in summary, carry the whole bag. Essentially, this Committee advocates a more interventionist role by the Government, and it believes that a doctrine has grown up in recent years that there is no role there.
In conclusion, I cite a recent book by Steven Chan called East Asian Dynamism, in which he noted:

In varying forms and to varying degrees, the most successful capitalist East Asian countries have developed powerful government agencies charged with the task of planning, guiding, and coordinating industrial policies. South Korea's Economic Planning Board, Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Singapore's Economic Development Board serve this vital function.
From the Committee's conclusion, that is the emphasis of its report--a more interventionist role by the Government in tackling the problems.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —-First, on behalf of the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) and myself, I extend our compliments to the other members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, particularly the Chairman, and our thanks to the staff, particularly Chris Robinson, for the very considerable efforts put into the production of this report.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) has just stated, the number of submissions received by the Committee, some 72, covering a very wide cross-section of persons interested in our trade and financial well-being, reflects something of the genuine and general concern there is in this field.

Indeed, I find it rather remarkable that the day on which we are talking about this report should coincide with a range of comments by a number of quite diverse people about elements that are, of course, the subject of the report. We have had the report by the Deputy Chairman of Standard and Poors about the extent to which we are still far too dependent upon increasing our overseas debt to fund our continued current account deficit. We have had the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in seeking to address the IMF--I gather that, for reasons that I am not quite certain of, the address was not made--finally acknowledging that this is the worst depression that Australia has faced since the 1930s. We have had the immediate past President of the Labor Party and present Premier of South Australia suggesting that the Federal Government is not spending enough time attending to the problems of unemployment. We have had Mr John Ralph, the Chairman of CRA, in addressing a science and engineering technologists conference here in Canberra, identifying the fact that it is essential that we start removing some of the impediments to progress, some of the Government introduced impediments and some that are, to a degree, the product of scientists and others not perhaps fully evaluating the climates of those impediments, particularly those where it is suggested that development cannot occur because of some consequence that is alleged.

Mr Ralph is suggesting that it is time that we had a look at the way by which those particular arguments are developed and not just accept them on face value. He is suggesting that there is a reason for scientists to look at both sides of the question and for us to accept in Australia that, unless we address productivity and unless we are prepared to look at the elements of how this country is going to progress, then we are going to find ourselves not only in an impossible investment climate but slipping further and further behind. Of course, there are also the comments from the Reserve Bank about the extent to which investment is still foundering.

The report itself, therefore, addresses a subject about which there is absolutely no contention. Indeed, those of us who endorse the minority report also endorse the first recommendation which identifies the problem and suggests that the rising overseas debts is something that needs to be consciously addressed. When we look at the period from 1969 to 1991, which is set out in appendix one, the escalation of that debt is apparent. It has increased from $3,385m in 1969 to $165,704m today. A $165 billion debt is an incredible obligation for this country.

We have several concerns about the majority report. First, even the debt figures, as the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) has stated, do not completely establish the position. It is true that the total liabilities--that is, equity and debt--are very important. Secondly, I do not think many people understand that in recent years we have tended to borrow funds abroad to fund various national developments here instead of investing equity. That may well have advantages. For a long time there was a tendency in this country to accept equity. I believe that was a better course. But we have not really in this report addressed the implications of that. So we really need to look at the total liability that we as Australians have, and not just at the level of debt, to establish what the problems are.

I accept that there are those who believe that the Government should be to a far greater degree interventionist, as the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) has just specified--and I might, if I have time, pick up a couple of those recommendations to which he has referred. But the real difficulty that I have with the majority report--and I think I am on common ground here--is that I do not think there is any quick fix. I am also concerned about the directions and nature of particular intervention. We need to get the broad base right. The reason that we have attached an extract from Statement No. 1 of this year's Budget is that it picks up a number of elements which I think are critical.

The first thing--and I found it quite fascinating that this is one of the few times that I have seen Treasury recognising an aspect of economic management, something which I have long felt has been deficient in this country--is the need to look beyond the annual Budget. We have to start looking at the medium term. On page 143 of the report, the Treasury states:
This points to the advantages of relating policy more to the medium-term and assigning policy instruments to their area of greater effectiveness. Such a framework entails:
monetary policy clearly enunciated and focused on reducing inflation and inflationary expectations but remaining very much alive to the implications of settings for domestic demand;
fiscal policy targeted towards contributing to an appropriate balance between domestic demand and production, particularly through its contribution to raising national savings; and
wages policy aimed at restraining aggregate wage pressures to maximise employment growth and contribute to progress on inflation, while increasing labour market flexibility.

Those three fields are critical in economic management. None of them are subject to the quick fix and tinkering at the edges, which I have felt so many of the majority recommendations do, is not going to overcome the problems.

I have mentioned Mr John Ralph's observations. One of my worries is that in development and investment projects there are so many impediments at a government and quasi-government level that progress is just not being achieved. Yet I was taken by one phrase he used--that the problems of today's management are significantly different from those of his predecessors; that today at every level of government, at every level of authority, there seem to be reasons why we cannot do things, not reasons why we can. Trying to attain and implement productivity gains is not just a matter of award wages and adjustment in conditions, it is far more complex.

To my mind, the fiddle which I see as the product of so many of the majority recommendations is not going to achieve the turnaround that in general we all accept. Indeed, there are obviously real problems in trying to get a turnaround. I would suggest that one other field that is not in that specific quote--taxation reform--is a fundamental part of it.

In other words, we have to look at the whole dimension of government policy and try to remove the obstacles and the restrictions. There has to be a ground swell of change in the altitude of bureaucracy. I was delighted the honourable member for Reid referred to Austrade, because that is part of the trouble. Every time we try to intervene, we create another authority, we create another obstruction.

For a while, I was almost convinced that Austrade was a good thing. I have been Minister in the area and have been responsible for the Australian Trade Commission. I know a good deal about the way in which the old Trade Commission operated. I thought for a while that perhaps the way to go might be to set up an independent authority and allow it to supervise and, to a large degree, commercialise the processes of government. The difficulty is that the processes of government are threefold. The first is in international trade negotiations. To my mind that is not a role that can be undertaken by Austrade. For that reason we have got this complexity of departments, as I have said on a number of occasions. We have the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Department of Resources and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and we even have two Ministers within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade responsible for it. We have got an overlap. Austrade is currently responsible to DITAC. I think it is about to go over to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We have got all this complexity of interlocking departments. People are writing letters to each other and producing paper without getting any results.

I am concerned that we do not just fiddle at the edges. That is my trouble with the superannuation reference, too, as the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) has mentioned in the recommendation here. We have to get a fundamental ground swell of change; we have to address productivity, introduce employment change; and, above all, we have to understand that unless we do change those conditions within which government operates and in which business reacts to government, frankly, we are not going to be able to address the problem. I commend all those responsible for this report and commend it for wider reading and wider understanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The time allotted for this debate has expired. In accordance with sessional order 102b, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The basic thrust of this report involves converting an inflexible administratively based system of spectrum management to one where, for commercial users, spectrum access has become a tradeable commodity. The recommendations that have been made will enable Australia to position itself for rapid technological change. The choice is clear: Australia can be in a position to reap the benefits associated with the communications revolution, or it can lose them. The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure has produced a forward looking report.

SPEECH.PARA: I see the introduction of our approach as a win-no loss position. In other words, the advantage in developing a framework that enables spectrum access to become tradeable is that if there is a rapid growth in demand full advantage can be taken of the opportunities that arise. If this growth does not occur, then nothing is lost. On the other hand, continuation of the existing administrative system is a no loss-lose position. If the existing system is maintained, it will cope if demand does not exceed supply. But if demand does exceed supply, losses in terms of economic growth, productivity and efficiency could be considerable.

The management of the radio frequency spectrum or airwaves is a subject that is of considerable importance. It is a subject that most people do not understand. In fact, to many the radio frequency spectrum is a mystery and, to others, sections of it are sacred. I will not detail the technical characteristics of the spectrum; readers will find them in chapter 2 of the report.

The value of the spectrum lies in its actual and potential exploitation for a range of public, private and commercial information purposes such as broadcasting, mobile communications, controlling and signalling equipment, radio location and navigation, to name but a few. In carrying out this inquiry, the Committee has been mindful of the rapid changes taking place in communications technology and innovations in service provision. The Committee has tried to look forward to consider not only the current problems being experienced in spectrum management but also the impact of increasing demand on spectrum management over the next 10 to 15 years.

The report gives a thumbnail sketch of the sorts of developments that we can expect in communications. The possibilities that technology will offer are limited only by one's imagination. This prospect of change and innovation is significant as communications play a critical role in our daily lives and the conduct of business. While developments in radio communications technology are important, advances in optical fibre and the use of computers in intelligent networks are breaking down the old barriers and expanding the means of delivering all manner of services. Nicholas Negroponte of MIT's Media Laboratory has described this process of change. He said:

What currently goes through wires, chiefly voice, will move to the air; what currently goes through the air, chiefly video, will move to wires. The phone will become wireless, as mobile as a watch and as personal as a wallet; computer video will run over fibre optic cables in switched digital systems as convenient as the telephone is today.

For this reason, it is essential that Australia be in a position to ensure that advantage can be taken of the potential benefits offered in maximising use of the airwaves. The Committee has recommended that the primary objectives of spectrum management should be operational, that is, that management should be flexible and timely in meeting the needs of all spectrum users, and that it should ensure that the most spectrum efficient equipment and practices are in use. The achievement of those objectives would benefit all users.

The Committee also recommended a number of other important objectives, including provision for non-commercial uses, allocation of spectrum to the highest value uses, continued observance of international obligations and a system of government charges that is efficient and fair. Details of these objectives can be found in chapter 3 of the report.

The current approach to spectrum management has evolved over many years and is based on very detailed planning being undertaken by the Department of Transport and Communications, which is responsible for every aspect of planning and for determining who gets access to the spectrum, for what purpose and under what conditions. In the past there has been ample space on the spectrum for all users. However, over recent times the growth in demand for specific frequencies has outstripped supply for a number of desirable uses, for example trunked land mobile services. To deal with this congestion and to allow for the introduction of new services, the Department has had to follow an extensive process of consultation with the existing users to arrange for their relocation to other areas of the spectrum. The problem here is that this process involves the acquisition of new equipment by users and renders existing equipment obsolete. The only way of achieving this is to allow users several years in which to gradually change over to their new spectrum frequencies.

This process is further complicated by the increasingly commercial nature of spectrum use. While it may be possible to agree on equipment costs, the question is: how is the Department to make valid assessments of the costs associated with any loss of business due to a decision to replan and reallocate a band of spectrum to a different use? Under the existing management system, there is no satisfactory method of compensating users for the costs associated with moving on the spectrum. The Committee also found that the Department of Transport and Communications is constrained in its ability to ensure that spectrum efficient equipment and practices are in use.

Turning to non-commercial users--while the current system meets their needs for spectrum resources, a major concern of the Committee was to ensure that they used their share of the spectrum efficiently. The allocation of spectrum to highest value uses is a difficult matter to assess. Obviously, value cannot be assessed only in a commercial sense; safety of life services are essential to everyone's well-being and are therefore of considerable value. But in terms of competing commercial applications, the current system cannot select the most efficient user in situations where demand exceeds supply.
