There is no way of making precise judgments on the comparative values of competing users.

The Committee has also identified major deficiencies in the current system of government charges. Charges are not levied in a manner that enables the individual costs associated with spectrum management to be identified and recovered from individual users. Nor do they provide a means of ensuring the return to government of an appropriate share of economic rents accruing to users from commercial use of the spectrum.

The Committee concluded that the current system fails in a number of significant ways to meet the spectrum management objectives. The Committee considered several approaches to spectrum management. Opinions generally centred upon modifying the current administratively based arrangements or on the introduction of market based principles into the allocation and assignment process. Detailed consideration of these alternatives is covered in chapter 6 of the report.

The Committee considered that modifying the current administrative system would make some improvement in the responsiveness of spectrum management to technological change and increasing demand. A number of changes to current arrangements have been recommended. However, there would continue to be some essential weaknesses. The ability of the spectrum manager to force the pace of change with respect to replanning and reassignment would continue to be constrained.

The Committee also considered the introduction of a market based system as suggested by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics in its paper Management of the Radio Frequency Spectrum, An Economic Analysis. A market based system would allow spectrum to be traded, combined, divided or leased by users. This approach would involve the creation of access rights to spectrum and would require the conversion of existing assignments to a tradeable right, at a minimum cost to existing users. Unused spectrum would be offered through an auction or tender process. There would have to be special arrangements to guarantee continued access for non-commercial users. There is detailed comment on this matter in chapter 6 of the report.

The Committee considered that tradeability would offer significant benefits in relation to both dynamic and technical efficiency, as it would enable users to acquire spectrum or to relocate in response to their changing needs. It would also encourage users to optimise their use of spectrum in order to maximise the return on their investment. It also addresses the problem of compensation.

The Committee identified a number of problems associated with the comprehensive introduction of such an approach at this time, particularly for non-commercial users. The Committee has therefore recommended the development and introduction of a system of tradeable spectrum access rights for commercial users of the spectrum in parallel with recommended reforms to the current administrative system. This approach should be gradual and should apply initially to unencumbered spectrum or in bands where there is high demand. Non-commercial users should have the option of remaining under the modified administrative system or having their access converted to a tradeable resource. Also recommended is a system of regular auditing of spectrum used by public sector users.

One final point is that the Committee believes that the access rights to spectrum should not be perpetual. In order to have a safeguard against the possibility that some users might engage in anti-competitive practices, and also as a means of ensuring any necessary long term planning, the Committee has recommended that access rights be for a fixed term.

Finally, I would like to thank all of those who have made submissions to the inquiry. In particular, I wish to thank the officers from the Department of Transport and Communications, who have responded to all of the Subcommittee's numerous requests. They have been very open and forthcoming in the evidence given to the Subcommittee. I thank the inquiry staff--Mr Christopher Paterson, the inquiry secretary; Mr Malcolm Aldons, the Committee secretary; and Mrs June Murphy--for their dedication and support. Above all, I thank my fellow Subcommittee members--the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman); the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman); and the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott)--for their support and assistance right throughout the inquiry. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gorman Mr R.N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), has already addressed the broad range of matters covered in the report. I would like to make a few short comments in support of what has already been said.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, could I say that the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who is the Deputy Chairman of this Subcommittee, has apologised for his absence from this debate. He has been called home because of the likelihood of bushfires around his and other properties. I hope that he and others will be safe and that their properties will be free from damage.

This inquiry has been a very enlightening process. I have been involved in the inquiries dealing with broadcasting and pay television, and on both occasions the question of the availability of space on the radio frequency spectrum arose. Each time the Committee was confronted with an engineering perspective as to why things could or could not be done. I am not suggesting that the evidence given on those occasions was in any way incorrect or misleading. It is just that we had difficulty in understanding the processes by which the spectrum is managed.

This report removes much of that mystery and will provide the reader with an understanding of the difficulties involved in managing access to the radio frequency spectrum. A simple illustration of the difficulties that the current approach imposes on ensuring that the spectrum is efficiently used is the allocation made for trunked land mobile purposes. This frequency band plan provides for 200 channels. The trunked land mobile is a very efficient use of the spectrum, and access to the band is much sought after by users.

There are two aspects of concern related to the use of this band. Firstly, the use of frequency reservation certificates meant that 80 per cent of the channels were reserved by users but not actually used. At the same time, there were, and still are, waiting lists of prospective users. The Committee has recommended that the use of FRCs be discontinued as they enable spectrum to be tied up and left unused even in situations where others wish to use these frequencies.

The second point of concern is the inability of the Department to make additional spectrum available for this purpose due to the delays inherent in replanning the spectrum. What is more, where demand exceeds supply, revenue is forgone as the annual charges are far less than those for an actual licence. The Committee calculates that in this case almost $500,000 per year was being forgone in lost fees. The Committee saw little prospect that the current system can effectively deal with situations where demand for frequencies exceeds supply. This means that as new technologies are developed we may be deprived of their benefits.

The other point that I would like to raise relates to the conversion of current assignments to tradeable access rights for incumbent users. The Committee was concerned that such users should not be able to make windfall gains by immediately selling the right if it happened to be in the desirable part of the spectrum. It is important that the Department give consideration to ensuring that the capital gains tax will apply in such situations.

This has been a very complex inquiry and I believe that it provides a positive approach to ensuring that spectrum use will be maximised and that the most efficient users will be able to gain access to spectrum resources. I thank those who made submissions. It was obvious that all submitters had given a lot of consideration to the issues raised in the course of the inquiry. I thank the officers from DOTAC who appeared before the Committee, and it was refreshing to take evidence from departmental witnesses who were prepared to discuss the issues in a frank and open manner. I thank the inquiry staff, Chris Paterson and June Murphy, for their assistance in the conduct of the inquiry and the preparation of this report. Finally, I would like to thank the other members of the Subcommittee, including the Chairman, the honourable member for Shortland; the honourable member for Mitchell; and also the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), who stood in for me during my recent illness.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House supports the broad thrust of the recommendations of the report on young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training (the Finn report) and in particular calls on governments to ensure adequate funding to allow implementation of the recommendations so that the targets for access to education and training can be realised by 2001.

Australia is at a crucial moment in its economic history. We have a severe current account deficit and we are about to have the highest level of unemployment for 60 years. I have just tabled a major report which concentrates attention on the current account deficit and our overseas debt, and on policies which can be adopted to ease those problems. The policies that we recommend would also contribute to reducing unemployment through the growth of employment. One of our strong recommendations is that more attention should be given to post-secondary education. It is quite clear that, if we want to improve our international competitiveness, we have to build up the skills of our work force. I was delighted, therefore, to find that the Government commissioned and has received a report from the Australian Education Council Review Committee, chaired by Mr Finn, entitled Young People's Participation in Post-compulsory Education and Training.

Education policy is not my own area of expertise but, as an economist, I was very impressed by this report because it seems to me to get very close to recommending exactly the policies that we should be adopting in the area of post-secondary education. We are going through something of a revolution in this area, because during the 1980s there has been an extraordinary growth in the proportion of school students completing secondary education, and in the proportion staying on well into secondary school.

Those school retention rates are the result of all sorts of factors. They are due partly to improvements in the quality and availability of education and the growth in living standards, which enable parents to encourage their children to stay at school longer. No doubt they are partly due to unemployment and the difficulties people have in finding jobs. They therefore stay on at school to improve their education. No doubt there are many other factors.

But whatever the causes, there is this very welcome development: nearly a doubling in the proportion of students completing school--from about a third at the beginning of the 1980s to nearly two-thirds now. Consequently, there have to be improved opportunities in all the forms of post-secondary education: vocational training, technical education, apprenticeships and university education. This report makes proposals relating to all of those areas of education. At the beginning of its recommendations it states:

Australia as a nation should be committed to providing for all of its young people a program of education/training which prepares them for life as individuals, citizens and workers now, through the current decade and into the coming century.
A long term strategy is being proposed here. The report sets remarkably ambitious targets in comparison with those of the recent past. For example, it states:

. . . by 1995 all young people by the age of 18 should have attained sufficient vocational skills to achieve at least a base-level traineeship (or other vocational qualifications. . . ) or participation in Year 12 or progress towards a higher level qualification.
In other words, it is saying that it is preferable that all young people at the age of 18 still be involved in education. The report states:

. . . by the year 2001 almost all people by the age of 20 should have attained at least a higher-level traineeship (or other vocational qualification. . . ) or progress toward a higher level vocational qualification or a post-Year 12 academic qualification.
That really is a remarkable recommendation. To be setting that sort of standard for most people aged 20 is very ambitious indeed. That is summarised in a sense when the report states that:
. . . by the year 2001, 95 per cent of 19-year-olds should have completed Year 12, or an initial post-school qualification or be participating in formally recognised education or training.
Those targets will be impossible to achieve unless there are many other policy changes. The Committee makes recommendations about resource allocation, which I will come to in a moment.

It also goes on to recommend the kinds of education and training which should be made available. It talks about increasing the diversity of the forms of education and training that are available. It emphasises that curriculums be appropriate and relevant to the full range of students. It talks about allowing for a range of learning styles and so on.

It even attempts the ambitious task of describing key areas of competence which all students should be encouraged to achieve. They include subjects such as language and communication, mathematics, scientific and technological understanding, cultural understanding, problem solving, and personal and interpersonal development.

One aspect I think missing from the report is the need for training in community responsibility and understanding how government works. We should encourage people to be active in the community--what some people used to call civics. In other words, there has to be a dimension which goes beyond just personal development to development as part of society. These personal and interpersonal development skills could well be extended a bit further. I am glad to see that ethics is included in the training. Ethics and values in that training are very important as well.

The Committee recommends that nationally comparable ways of assessing young people's attainments should be developed. That too is a pretty ambitious task because it is hard to assess objectively the skills which people have. One point that I would make is that I hope that that assessment can be done against some educational standard rather than assessing people against one another. There is the problem in education, which is partly inevitable but which partly can be avoided, of simply stimulating destructive competitiveness. While, to some extent, that is inevitable, what we want from our students is the achievement of the kinds of standards that this report is outlining.

The report also talks about the kinds of funds that are required. It talks about the need for equity programs. I regret to say that it recommends cutting out purely recreational courses from TAFE. I think that is a mistake. The report talks about the special needs of disabled students. It goes on to discuss the resources that will be necessary to achieve these goals. I would particularly like to emphasise that it is essential that Commonwealth funding for technical colleges, vocational training and universities be increased. Yesterday I was delighted to see the statement by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that the Commonwealth was offering to take a much larger share of the provision of finance for technical education. I think that is essential.

I do have one or two more sceptical comments to make about the Finn report. The report is not perfect; no report ever is. I think that there is perhaps some conflict about educational philosophy, between scientific and technological knowledge on the one hand and the civilising humanities on the other. I think that both are very important. It is very important that there be cooperation between the TAFEs and the universities. That is emphasised in the report. It is essential to ensure that educational experience is as fulfilling and stretching as possible. Basically, I moved the motion to draw attention to the report in the hope that it will receive support, and to urge the Government to provide adequate funds to implement it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?
—-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am delighted to have the opportunity this morning to respond to the comments of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). I would like to congratulate him on bringing this issue before the House of Representatives. Indeed, the report of the Australian Education Council Review Committee, under the chairmanship of Mr Brian Finn, entitled Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training, is a timely and important document. It is clear in all sectors that today we face a crisis in education across our nation. That crisis extends into and is subsumed by the training sector itself, which is what is largely dealt with in the Finn report.

SPEECH.PARA: The crisis is one of access. We have created a great optimism in the community. We have created a great acceptance, in these beginning years of the 1990s, of the need for high quality and versatile education and training throughout our community and over people's life span. Not only do we need to educate and train our youth, but also we need to realise that education and training will increasingly become a lifelong experience. Therefore, we have a problem with access because many young people are unable to attend university. A report in a newspaper this morning talked about the overcrowding in our universities. Our TAFEs are not so much overcrowded as suffering from such excessive demand and lack of facilities that they have to turn away up to 100,000 potential students a year.

The Finn report states that we need growth in knowledge and skills. In that respect it calls for growth in education and training. On the issue of training there is no-one with whom I have spoken across Australia who does not support the concept that we need to expand the skills base of our people in order to allow them to participate fully in an active and productive working life. So we do need more places in these institutions; we do need more teachers; we do need more trainers; and we do need better systems.

The Finn report sets important targets, both qualitative and quantitative. I have tried to read the methodologies behind the setting of the targets. I am not entirely satisfied that the targets in themselves should be the end rather than the means. It seems to me that we might review the targets either from time to time or more or less continuously so that we determine their relevance as we go through the 1990s. Reaching these targets will cost money; it will cost heaps of money. The question then arises as to where the money will come from: whether the Commonwealth will provide the funds; whether the States will provide funds; whether individuals will contribute to their own training and education; and whether industry also will contribute in this process.

It seems to me that we need to have a greater sharing of the resources necessary to educate our youth. In that context some of the things being done by TAFE in Victoria are really quite exciting. The Victorian State Training Board is devolving responsibility to individual TAFE colleges and their directors and those TAFE colleges will now be allowed to increase next year's fees by up to 40 per cent. In some cases, higher increases will be allowed for individual courses. The TAFEs are now competing actively with one another in the market to sell their products to industry and the community. They are now starting to respond to the marketplace and to answer the needs that people have for training and the needs that industry has for skills at specific levels.

In this context it is also interesting to note that one of the things that the Finn report discusses in great detail is the convergence of general education and skills acquisition for the real world of work. We all know that we have had this great demarcation in the education scene in Australia for a long time. Schools are there basically to provide a general education and to feed the universities, whereas TAFEs are seen to be set aside from that school system and more closely linked to industry but not yet allied with it. In fact, there are some TAFE directors who say that they know better what industry needs in terms of training than does industry itself. I would question such a statement.

In our secondary schools we generally had split-stream education, in which some schools provide vocational training and others teach academic courses suitable for entry to university. However, over the last decade we decided, for whatever reason, that the vocational schools were inappropriate. We did not value their outcomes. In some respects that is disappointing because today we would start from a higher base had we been able to retain that dual-stream system. Nonetheless, we decided that that system was inappropriate. Today, we are faced with the choice of trying to start it up again or to find some other mechanism for making education of real value to young people, particularly in the last two years of secondary school--year 11 and year 12.

The Finn report recommends that increasingly we have vocational courses in senior secondary schools and that we increase retention rates by giving young people real skills and allowing certified credit for those skills so that when they finish school they will have done part of the preliminary training necessary for them to do an apprenticeship or an Australian traineeship and they will be empowered, so to speak, to enter the world of work. That is a very important concept, and I support the Finn report absolutely.

The Finn report talks a great deal about assessment. Assessment testing is a topic on which I have spoken in this place many times. The report says that we must set standards, we must test the standards and we must agree nationally on the standards we want. It says, in effect, that it is no longer acceptable for one State to have a requirement for welding heavy plate and for another State to have a different requirement so that an individual cannot move from one State to another without taking a new course and a new test. It is a nonsense that we must do away with. We have to establish good, high level standards and we must increase those standards over time.

Assessment is important not only in the context of the Finn report, but in the context of primary schools so that we can judge how well the system, which we pay for through our taxes, is performing in producing well-educated young people, particularly in the fields of literacy and numeracy. The Finn report on assessment provides us with an excellent guide for the future.

There was only one disappointing aspect of the Finn report in my view. I was disappointed that the report did not address some of the difficulties that we will have in achieving a uniform education system with pathways, with credit transfer between schools, TAFEs and universities, as long as we maintain the huge union bureaucracy which today controls much of the education and training sector. Until we break down some of that control and allow individual schools under their principals to go their own way and seek their own place in the sun, to achieve their own niche of excellence, it is my view that we will not be able to accomplish the aims of the Finn report because we will not be able to get the diversity of provision that will allow freedom of choice and the provision of excellence. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —- I am extremely pleased to speak to the motion of my colleague the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), which supports the broad thrust of the recommendations of the report on young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training, commonly known as the Finn report. I would also like to take the time to acknowledge the positive contribution of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) in this debate this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I support this motion with a high degree of confidence, although not entirely. I have some misgivings too, but I will mention those later. The Finn report is ideas driven. It suggests congruent mechanisms and has reconcilable outcomes within the guidelines. It is obviously dependent upon resource implications. There are huge costs involved, as the honourable member for La Trobe and the honourable member for Fraser have acknowledged. In other words, the basic trinity of positive government policy--rationale, process and outcomes--is clearly evident.

The Finn report recognises the ideas that both individual and industry needs are leading towards a convergence of general and vocational education. I acknowledge the point made by the honourable member for La Trobe about the loss of technical education in our secondary schools. The dual system was a fine system. Finn notes that internationally there is an increasing realisation that the most successful forms of work organisation are those which encourage people to be multi-skilled, creative and adaptable.

The Finn report states that, in order to serve their clients' needs, both schools and TAFEs will need to change. New measures for participation are clearly stated. Key competencies in the areas of language and communication, mathematics, scientific and technological understanding, cultural understanding, problem solving and personal and interpersonal characteristics, along with the national curriculum principles with implications for teachers, are recognised. In other words, within the Finn report there exists a framework, a process, for effective implementation of goals, and they are all recognised.

I am not too sure that continued reference to buzz words like `pathways' are particularly useful, but on reflection that should not detract from the more important issue of credit transfers between institutions like TAFEs and universities. The Finn report states:
The real level of skills and knowledge acquired by an individual in one educational setting should be given due recognition when that individual moves into a different setting.

I say `Hear, hear' to that proposition. Personally, I am too often appalled at the lack of leadership in education and the feather-bedding of too many--though I admit not all--in higher education at the expense of the TAFE and the school sectors.

The Finn report also states a positive recognition of support for the disadvantaged in suggesting that further work needs to be done on the initiatives in relation to young people with disabilities and suggests beginning points as to how this could be achieved. Congruent with the rationale espoused and the processes indicated, clear targets are made, and they are vicious targets. As I said earlier, those targets have huge resource implications. Specifically the Finn report proposes the following targets: as a minimum, at least a level 1 traineeship or participation in year 12 for all 18-year-olds by 1995; at least a level 2 traineeship or progress towards a higher level vocational or academic qualification for almost all 20-year-olds by 2001; and at least a vocational certificate, level 3, or progress towards a vocational qualification above level 3, or a diploma or degree, for at least 50 per cent of 22-year-olds by 2001. We would all agree that they are incredibly ambitious targets.
In conclusion, the Finn report holds up extremely well indeed. It is ideas driven. It points to appropriate processes. It sets clear targets congruent with the rationale and suggested mechanisms.

One criticism of the report lies with its apparent ignorance of the importance of the foundation years of education, namely, the education that sets the pattern for the future success or failure of all learners at all levels; that is, the education received by the Cinderella sector of education in junior secondary, primary and junior primary schools. Remedy that, enhance the importance of TAFE within a national framework, determinedly foster the relationship between all sectors of education on an equal basis, and we will come to recognise the Finn report as an important watershed and stepping stone. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I have said many times before in this place, education in Australia remains at the crossroads in terms of content, of quality, of policy direction, of administration and, of course, in its dependence on the funding linchpin with its attendant degrees of governmental control. On this side of the House we would argue that this Government in general, and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) in particular have fallen down in many of these areas, at the same time injecting a degree of unparalleled governmental control and political ideology into a policy area which should rise above party politics. Those Ministers stand condemned for their ideological push. Regrettably for this nation their ministries remain some of the most political in the Federal arena.

SPEECH.PARA: Undeniably, basic national literacy and numeracy standards are not improving. Whilst for good reasons many of us have concentrated on the technicalities of Australia's economic ills in the short to medium term, there is little doubt that an increasing consensus is emerging not just that the key to our future prosperity lies in the radical economic reform processes that are necessary if we are to get this nation back onto an even economic keel, but that any future prosperity lies, in large part, in the education and training of our youth.

I would like to think that the old ocker image that ignorance was blessed is disappearing, and that the days are over when two out of three of our teenagers drop out before finishing school and go off to work. Indeed, that ability to work has taken on catastrophic dimensions as a result of this Government's economic failures with one in three of our 15- to 19-year-olds out of work and many ill-prepared and ill-educated to enter a work force which has to be increasingly clever if we are to climb out of our rut. We remain in danger of degenerating into a nation of educational, professional and commercial mediocrity unless we lift our game. Here is where the Finn report can make a vital contribution.
In a very interesting article in the Canberra Times on 25 August, Geoffrey Maslen said:

The turn around in attitudes to education has been extraordinary. As a society we have gone from accepting that only a small minority of teenagers should finish school and aim for further study to the widespread belief that staying to year 12 is a must and getting another qualification is essential. With almost no debate and no compulsion young people are signing up for education just as their great grandparents rushed to join the Army at the start of World War I but the after school signposts have all been pointing the one way. . . Technical and further education has failed to attract the crowds. While the proportion of young people at universities has jumped over the past 8 years from 6.5% to 10.6% of the 15 to 19 year old population the proportion in TAFE has remained the same.

It is on this point, as reflected in the Finn report, that I would like to concentrate a brief comment this morning. That report calls for greater emphasis on user pays student charges and resource sharing amongst training institutions to help defray the cost of the proposed reforms to industry and to the public. It also proposes minimum competency standards, national benchmarks for student achievement, the scrapping of quotas for TAFE and post-year 10, and reciprocal acceptance of credit points to strengthen the ties between schools, TAFE and universities--all in themselves very commendable.

While Mr Finn points out that funding clearly is an issue that needs to be resolved and that he was reasonably confident that Federal and State governments and industry would provide enough money to implement the proposals, his report of itself did not provide the total solution. The questions of the essential skills that young people must acquire, regardless of the education and training pathway that they choose and the desirable balance between the training and education sectors, are left up in the air. Indeed, the Finn report does not address some of the vital structural issues involved in lifting incentives and improving morale in education and training institutions, wherein there must be an agenda of reform to create more autonomous and flexible institutions with the ability to respond to a student market and to industry alike.

It seems to me that, if nothing else, the Finn report will highlight the fact that the willy-nilly push for student numbers on university campuses is not the way to go. Further emphasis is needed in TAFE, which has the prospect of becoming the poor relation should the status quo be maintained. Many of our young people need to realise that not only are they not suited to the pure academic university environment but also that this nation urgently needs large numbers of them to understand that vocational trades are important.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:
(1) acknowledges the right of self-determination of the Ukraine;
(2) notes the declaration of independence and that the declaration is to be put to the Ukrainian people for confirmation in December 1991;

(3) believes that, subject to such confirmation and the Ukraine meeting the criteria for independent statehood, the international community, including Australia, should support its independence by diplomatic recognition; and
(4) calls upon the Australian Government in the meantime to support the aspirations of the Ukrainian people by:
(a) establishing a consulate in the Ukraine;
(b) opening a trade office in Kiev; and
(c) ensuring the Ukraine gets its fair share of the training and management scholarships the Australian Government is offering to the Soviet Union.

We live in very interesting and volatile times, as we have noted particularly in relation to the Soviet Union. The motion that I have moved recognises that the consequences of this are creating difficulties for the world--problems for which there are no easy or immediately identifiable solutions but problems in which we all, to a greater or lesser extent, are involved. These are problems on which we cannot turn our backs.

On a number of occasions in this House we have enthusiastically welcomed the democratic reform in the Soviet Union. For 70 years it had been held together by a brutal and totalitarian regime which created enormous privation and suffering for its peoples. The Ukraine bore the brunt of some of the most vicious assaults on people within the Soviet Union. The collapse of the Russian empire during the First World War resulted in the creation of two independent Ukrainian national republics, which were subsequently defeated by the Bolshevik forces in 1920 and were divided between Poland and the Soviet Union.

The Ukrainian peasantry and intellectuals were decimated in the Ukraine in 1932-33, when over seven million people died of starvation in a Soviet engineered famine--a matter of very real and continuing commemoration within the Ukrainian community because of the hardship that so many relatives and families of those who are here in Australia experienced at that time. Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians, including leading authors, poets and playwrights, were shot in the purges of 1936 to 1939.

When Germany attacked the Soviet Union in 1941, the Ukraine declared independence and became a major battleground between Germany and the Soviet Union. Some six million Ukrainian citizens died. Millions were sent to Germany for forced labour or to concentration camps. The forced repatriation of hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians after the war led to even more deaths and more inmates for concentration camps.

The mortar of brutal repression, however, is now crumbling. This has unleashed amongst many of the Ukrainians a fierce nationalism and a desire to reassert their cultural and ethnic values which have long been denied by Russian and Soviet regimes. With economic and political reform in the Soviet Union, Mikhail Gorbachev has created the ideal conditions for this to occur.

As honourable members are aware, the Ukraine Supreme Soviet voted in favour of an independence resolution on 25 August 1991. The resolution is subject to ratification by a popular referendum on 1 December this year, and presidential elections are to be held at the same time. This declaration envisages nationalisation of all USSR owned enterprises, the printing of a separate currency, and the creation of a Ukrainian armed force. This followed the Declaration of State Sovereignty of the Ukraine enacted by the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine on 16 July 1990, which proclaimed:

the state sovereignty of Ukraine as supremacy, independence, fullness and indivisibility of the republic's authority within the boundaries of its territory, and its independence and equality in external relations.

On 30 August an eight point cooperation agreement was signed between the Russian Federation and the Ukraine. This is acknowledged as being a step forward, in that Russia has conceded the integrity of the Ukraine's independence and borders, and it lays the foundation for cooperative relations between the two states.

We in this place should acknowledge the Ukraine's right to self-determination. Subject to meeting the requirements of international statehood, we should go further and support its independence by diplomatic recognition. But we are obliged to squarely face the difficulties that are associated with this. There needs to be ongoing cooperative arrangements for a sensible and peaceful resolution, particularly of minority interests, as well as the aspirations for independence.

It needs to be recognised that the Soviet Union contains more than 100 national groupings. Fifteen of these constitute over 90 per cent of the population. They, too, are characterised by many religious, cultural and linguistic differences. Russians account for over 50 per cent of the population. The other Slavic groups--the Ukrainians and Byelorussians--form roughly 20 per cent; Moslem nationalities, approximately 15 per cent; and the Christians of the Caucasus, Armenia and Georgia, another 3 per cent.

There are an estimated 60 million Soviet citizens, not all of whom are Russians, who live outside their home ethnic territory. There has been an enormous displacement of peoples within the Soviet Union. This creates enormous difficulties for resolving many of these territorial disputes and claims, as the Soviet Union itself is dismantled. This needs to be understood. It has relevance within the Ukraine, which has a population of 52 million. Of this number, 74 per cent are Ukrainian, 21 per cent are Russian and 5 per cent are Jewish.

Australia has a particular role to play in assisting in giving some insights to the Soviet Union into the way in which in a multicultural society these differences can be resolved to cement a new nation. Bill Jergaro, a prominent Australian, and former President of the Ethnic Communities Council, was recently in the Soviet Union and encouraged Russia to offer invitations to Australian leaders who might be able to give some guidance in these matters; and other people are offering the view that Australia ought to invite leading Soviet citizens to Australia to see how these matters work in this country.

There are in the draft union treaty proposed, on which President Gorbachev was working before the coup, outlined terms for a Union of Soviet Republics, a new concept. That treaty, of course, did not clarify how and under what conditions a republic of the Soviet Union might secede and the way in which the rights of minority enclaves within each of those republics might also seek to obtain self-determination.

These matters are going to occasion a great deal of difficulty and time for resolution, but they are matters which, I think, can be addressed sensibly; and there can be efforts to overcome these obstacles. It is as part of this process that this motion has been put to this House. We in the Opposition recognise the difficulties associated with recognising a new independent state, but these obstacles should be fairly faced and dealt with, particularly as the aspirations for independence are likely to be affirmed when the referendum is dealt with.

These difficulties should not be so daunting as to prevent us from supporting the aspirations of the Ukrainian people. We can do so--and the motion suggests them--in some very positive ways: first, by establishing a consulate in the Ukraine; secondly, by opening a trade office in Kiev; and, thirdly, by ensuring that the Ukraine gets a fair share of the training and management scholarships that the Australian Government is offering to the Soviet Union.

There are enormous benefits for both the Ukraine and Australia in immediately pursuing these measures. The opportunities to participate in the reconstruction of the Ukrainian economy by way of technical assistance and expertise would open up significant opportunities for Australian trade. A consulate would provide many with the opportunity to make contact with families in Australia and to take advantage of Australia's new provisions to facilitate migration from areas of eastern Europe. The establishment of these relationships is an indication that Australia is prepared to accept the realities of a changing Soviet Union.

Whatever path the Ukraine decides to take in the future, whether total independence or part of a reconstructed union, Australia will be in a position to offer a degree of assistance if consular and trade links are already established. For these reasons, I strongly commend this motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?
—-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support the motion and, in so doing, I wish to make a few comments about the importance of the Ukraine and what is happening there, not merely for the Ukrainian people and, indeed, the whole of the Soviet Union, but for the world community. In fact, the way in which the issue of the Ukraine and the independence of the Ukraine is handled will determine whether there will be a repeat of the tragedy of Yugoslavia or, hopefully, a much more sensible and peaceful outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems have some similarity. The outcomes can be different, and there are positive signs everyday that they will be different. One of the most positive signs is, of course, the fact that the independence claims and aspirations of the Ukrainian people are increasingly recognised by the leadership of Russia. Although Russia has a very substantial minority in the Ukraine, it has not panicked or carried on about that minority. It has not sought the redrawing of borders and it has not put armed forces to work, as has been the case in Yugoslavia. On the contrary, the Russian people, under the leadership of Boris Yeltsin, have behaved responsibly with respect to the claims for independence by the Ukraine.

Indeed, everyday Yeltsin makes statements which indicate increasing acceptance of the various aspects of the independence claims. For example, I have heard on the news in the last 24 hours that the Russian Government is now seeking to issue its own currency, as distinct from the Soviet currency. We may find that there will be a currency in Russia and a currency in the Ukraine. This is in response to the claims of the Ukraine to issue its currency. One could image that in a similar context elsewhere the response might have been different. However, in this particular case it is very interesting that Boris Yeltsin has decided to accept the assertion of independence by the people of the Ukraine and also to move to ensure that Russia has its own currency, a move which, of course, will accelerate the process of the independent republics.

The question might be asked: `Is this necessarily a good thing?' After all, it is a bit strange that the Soviet system, confederation, federation--whatever it is going to be--is moving towards a situation where there are going to be separate currencies, whereas, in fact, the European governments are trying to move towards a situation in which they have one currency for the European Economic Community.

One might be puzzled by these apparently contradictory movements in different parts of the world. One ought not to be puzzled, because the fact of the matter is that the circumstances that have allowed the Western European nations, namely, highly developed economic nations, to come together in the European Economic Community and to feel comfortable enough to move towards a common currency do not exist in the Soviet Union as it is today.

On the contrary, there are severe economic problems. If it is felt that one way to resolve those economic problems is through fulfilling the nationalist aspirations of the various republics of the Soviet Union in a peaceful way, together with issuing their own currencies where it is felt necessary to do so, then so be it, because the fundamental issue is not whether there are one, two or four currencies, but whether the fundamental economic problems of the Soviet Union are going to be dealt with.

The failure in the last two or three years, following the promises of glasnost and perestroika, has been the economic failure within the Soviet Union, the failure to actually achieve economic transformation. It is this failure which has now led a number of the republics, not merely the Ukraine, to push not only their nationalist self-determination claims, but also their claims to have control of their own economies and to work with the other republics of the Soviet Union as independent countries in trying to resolve the trading and economic links that they have.

Who is to say that this is not a better approach, given that the other approach has not worked? It might have been desirable for the other approach to have worked better, but the reality is that it has not. That is a severe problem for the Soviet Union, and it is a severe problem for Mr Gorbachev. He is trying to sustain some authority in the emerging confederation of states but, if he wants to retain some authority in that confederation, he has to be ready to recognise, firstly, that these states will be independent states and, secondly, that any confederation in terms of shared powers must be on the basis of consensus between the governments of the various states, otherwise it will not work.

One thing is absolutely clear: the attempt to impose from the centre of the Soviet Union some kind of unity on the basis of an imposed unity--whether it is a military unity, a defence unity or an economic unity--will not work. If there are going to be some common elements of unity amongst those republics, they have to be on the basis of agreements between them.

But what about the issue which has become the big problem in Yugoslavia, namely, the question of the minorities? I was very pleased to see that the President and Government of the Ukraine went out of their way to show to the world that they will be serious about the protection of minorities in the new Ukraine. Mr Kravchuk did this in two ways. Firstly, he apologised to the Jewish people for crimes committed by Ukrainians against the Jewish community during the Second World War or after the Second World War. Secondly, he made it perfectly clear that the new state of Ukraine will place very great emphasis on the protection of the rights of every person, including in particular the minorities, which will be essentially Jewish and Russian.

Let us hope, therefore, that these assurances are taken on board and that the process of independence, which seems almost inevitably to be moving forward, will not result in violence or tragedy, but will result in sensible dealings between the various states, including the Ukraine. Let us hope that a solution will be reached which is acceptable to the people of the various republics, to the Soviet Union as a whole and to the world community. That is the role that President Gorbachev can play in this transition process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In recent times we have witnessed remarkable changes as the old regimes and dictatorships in eastern Europe have collapsed, to be replaced by a new and significantly different order. Nowhere are these changes more obvious than within the former Soviet Union. Of the republics ruled by the Soviet Union for the past 70 years, the Ukraine is amongst those which have suffered most. It has borne the brunt of a civil war, the collectivisation of the peasants, Stalinist purges that have decimated its population, the Second World War and the suppression of pro-independence movements. Understandably, it is also one the republics now attempting to make the transition from Soviet domination to independent statehood. The efforts of the Ukrainian people to throw off the shackles of their communist past should receive our wholehearted support.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ukraine has been described as an industrial and agricultural powerhouse which, in terms of economic muscle, ranks second only to Russia amongst the 12 Soviet republics. It supplies almost 25 per cent of the Soviet Union's food, 25 per cent of its coal, and 20 per cent of its machinery and chemicals. In common with other peoples living in the Soviet Union, Ukrainians have for far too many years been denied their basic right of self-determination. Under the strict and repressive controls formerly imposed from afar in Moscow, they have had no chance to participate directly in the affairs of their own republic.

During the years of Soviet rule, the Ukrainian people's cultural and social heritage has been systematically whittled away. Once productive agricultural land has been ruined by poor management, lack of technical expertise and overexploitation. The Chernobyl disaster is but one notorious example of the appalling manner in which the welfare and well-being of the Ukrainian people have been ignored by Moscow's bureaucrats. Five years down the track, they have still not been told the whole truth about this nuclear accident or the full extent of the impact this disaster has had and will continue to have on their lives.

But now all this is changing. The Ukraine declared its independence on 24 August this year immediately after the failed Moscow coup. On 1 December, its 52 million people will vote to decide whether or not they should ratify that declaration. After years of repression and neglect, the opportunity now exists for the Ukrainian people to directly participate in deciding their future and that of their nation. At last they will be able once again to take control of their own political, social and economic destiny.

It is important that bipartisan support be shown for this motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). The Ukrainian people need to know that, should their declaration of independence receive the popular endorsement that is already widely anticipated and should they also meet the established criteria for independence, Australia is prepared to join with other members of the international community in moving to accept and formally recognise the Ukraine as an independent state. Like all independent states, the Ukraine should be free to determine the nature of its relations and associations with other states without pressures or influence being exerted from outside.

The Opposition believes that the Australian Government must take the appropriate action to acknowledge the changes that are occurring in what used to be the Soviet Union. Such action should include the establishment of closer diplomatic and trade links and improved political relations between Australia and the Ukraine. Already several countries, including the United States and Canada, have set up consulates in Kiev, whilst a number of European countries maintain a diplomatic presence there. We believe the Australian Government should follow these examples and establish its own consulate in the Ukraine. We also believe that the Australian Government should recognise the enormous economic potential of the Ukraine and establish a trade office in Kiev. This latter initiative would undoubtedly help to increase trade between Australia and the Ukraine, providing mutual benefits to both countries and contributing to the reconstruction of the Ukrainian economy.

By taking these initiatives outlined in this motion, Australia will not only be demonstrating its support for the current aspirations of the Ukrainian people to regain control of their own destiny, but will also be making a wise investment for the future. I commend the motion to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As the representative of one of Australia's major concentrations of Ukrainians, in an electorate which also hosts their major religious and cultural institutions, I have pleasure in supporting this motion. I think it must be conceded that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has had a consistency on this issue which far exceeds that of most honourable members. He has for many years campaigned around these issues, and this is but one of his many motions that I have seen on the Notice Paper in my period in the House.

SPEECH.PARA: It is propitious that the motion comes before the House so soon after the commemorations of the massacres in Kiev in relation to Babi Yar. One of the concerns that have grown about events in eastern Europe is that, in the aftermath of the decline of repressive regimes, fairly atavistic instincts have surfaced, and throughout eastern Europe fairly major racial differences, where minorities are greatly threatened within some of the countries seeking independence, can be seen.

The fact that the Ukrainian regime puts such an emphasis on the commemoration of the mass murder of Jews, gipsies and Byelorussians, et cetera, by the Nazi forces with, as has been conceded, some cooperation by elements in the Ukraine, is a good indication that we can be hopeful that this regime will uphold some of the liberal values that it has advocated. I note that in paragraph (iv) of the declaration of state sovereignty of the Ukraine, which has been mentioned earlier, there is the comment that it guarantees equality before the law of all citizens of the republic regardless of their ancestry, social or property status, racial or national identity, sex, education, language, political views and religious beliefs. Obviously the future of the distinct minorities in the Ukraine--half a million Byelorussians, 10 million Russians, half a million Jews, et cetera--is of major concern. It is not really relevant that the Russian movement there has been to some degree state instigated. It is not really relevant that some of those people might have a belief that Ukrainian independence threatens their rights. What is relevant is the support of the values I have put forward.

The espousing of our position today comes at a very timely period. It follows the process of events after the attempted putsch in the Soviet Union in August. While there can be resistance over many decades, as there has been, this development clearly stems from Mr Gorbachev's moves and the founding in 1989 of RUKH, the people's movement of the Ukraine, and its declaration in March 1990 that it would operate as an opposition group advocating independence. It is acknowledged that in July 1990 the Ukrainian declaration went beyond those of the Baltic States in so far as it advocated organising its army and that its internal security and state security operations come under its own control, and moved to veto the transfer of Ukrainian citizens outside its borders.

At that stage it also made demands in relation to gold and currency. We are aware that in recent weeks that particular issue has come to the fore with the moves by the Ukrainians to construct their own currency and the withholding of roubles by the Soviet Union to the point where wages have been delayed in many parts of the Ukraine.

This motion advocates measures with regard to a consulate, to trade ties and to Australia's aid. We are not saying that we recognise independence; we are saying that that should stem from the decision of the Ukrainian people in December. We are talking in this case of a nation that is viable--as has been said, it is a nation of 52 million people. It is a major player in coal to the point where it is seen as the second largest coal area after the Appalachians. It is a major supplier of sugar beet, wheat, iron ore, et cetera. As has been said, some of its production levels have been compared with France and countries in western Europe.

So we are talking about a viable country, a group of people which has obviously displayed cultural cohesiveness and which, from 1917 to 1920, had independence which was recognised by 40 countries. It had won historical interest. Typical of the Ukraine's importance at that stage was that it was on Europe's first passenger plane route, from Paris to Kiev. That is typical of the world's perception of it at that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time for the debate has expired. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Mr Kerr:

That this House commend to the Government the introduction of a scheme modelled on the British tax exempt special savings account in order to facilitate both the growth of domestic savings and the encouragement of Australian investment in Australian domestic industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have much pleasure this morning in speaking in favour of the motion of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) advocating that the Government introduce a scheme modelled on the British tax exempt special savings account, or TESSA, in order to facilitate the growth of domestic savings and the encouragement of Australian investment in Australian domestic industry, research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: While there does not appear to be any great disagreement with the proposal that it would be desirable to have a high level of domestic savings, there has been much debate in Australia--indeed, I would suggest much hysteria--about the supposed decline in Australia's national savings. An increase in Australia's national savings would mean that we could find more investment without the need to draw on the savings of other countries, whether by borrowing their money or selling their equity in Australia's assets.

Australia's level of domestic saving compares poorly with that of other OECD countries. However, Australians are not as spendthrift as is often made out. Most OECD countries are experiencing a similar long term downward trend in savings. It is interesting to consider a number of trends in Australia's national saving rate and to compare them with those trends in the OECD. One popular measure of household saving--net saving as a proportion of household income--has halved, from 12 per cent in the mid-1970s to 6 per cent in 1990-91. Net household saving also similarly has fallen as a proportion of GDP.

There are, of course, problems associated with the use of such savings ratios in getting a handle on just what is happening in this country. First, it often makes more sense to look at the overall private savings rate rather than the more volatile household and corporate rates, as savings in one sector are usually offset by changes in the other. Secondly, when we ignore the spurious savings peak in the mid-1970s--which was caused in part by an excess rate of inflation--we are left with a remarkably stable private savings rate over the past three decades. Gross national savings averaged 24 per cent in the 1960s, it rose to 26 per cent in the first half of the 1970s and has averaged around 20 per cent since the early 1980s.

The Government is currently advocating superannuation as a means of both increasing Australia's national saving and providing for the retirement of baby boomers early next century. The Opposition, on the other hand, advocates a consumption tax as the means of boosting national savings. Both the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), and the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), have made those sorts of claims. Interestingly, again, looking at the OECD shows that experience in most other countries gives no other evidence to support such a contention.

Far from increased savings, many Australians may in fact find increased prices eating into their savings and reducing the value of the savings they have already accumulated--their house, their superannuation and other savings; their nest egg. One does not have to be too bright to realise that the result of that would be somewhat unfair. The evidence from the examination of trends in savings ratios in other OECD countries, many of which have consumption taxes, shows no correlation between tax mix and savings.

Looking at most of those countries it is obvious that since the early 1970s there has been a downward trend in savings; that is, falling savings are not confined to Australia. That is a trend which has been evident, as I have suggested, across the OECD. The fact is that there is no basis for the assertion that a consumption tax will improve this nation's savings effort, a point recognised only two years ago by the Leader of the Opposition when he said:
I don't think a consumption tax is inevitable in the 90s. People overseas who have advocated it to boost savings have been disappointed when it hasn't . . .

I am surprised he has changed his tune now. The catalyst for the honourable member for Denison proposing this scheme is that a scheme was introduced in the United Kingdom in the financial statement and Budget report of 1990-91 by the then Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major. That particular announcement saw a tax exempt special savings scheme introduced, and the British Government published information documents about it. The key points were explained by the honourable member for Denison when the plan was outlined in the House previously, but I will go through one or two of them briefly once again.

The first is that taxpayers are limited to one account. Secondly, no person can open more than one account at a time. Thirdly, husbands and wives can each open separate accounts. Fourthly, one cannot retain tax exempt status if there is a withdrawal of capital, although there may be some access to interest in the account. Once capital is touched, the tax exempt status of the account is lost. Finally, accumulated funds are held tax free at the end of five years. The way in which the scheme has been developed minimises the risk that it will be rorted by individuals who have substantial capital to shift around without any resultant improvement in the overall rate of national savings. The scheme is also commendable on the basis that it would assist in addressing equity issues for small wealth holders.

As honourable members would be aware, the way in which wealth is held has implications for its treatment by the taxation system. Australia's tax system today is far more equitable than the shambles the conservatives left us in 1983. I remind honourable members that under that system high rates of marginal tax acted to encourage the wealthiest sectors of the Australian community to shelter income as capital. Under the Liberal's disreputable taxation system, the wealthy who were able to invest in land or property were sheltered from tax liability. However, a distinction between capital gains and returns on other investments persists today. Under the capital gains tax regime, which this Government introduced, only real returns--that is, inflation adjusted returns--are taxed.

The small wealth holder, on the other hand, does not have at his or her disposal the ability to shelter liquid assets from the taxation of that part of their return which compensates individuals for inflation. It should also be noted, as Australia gets on top of its inflation rate, which it is doing very well at the moment, that this anomaly will become much less significant. Addressing the question of adjusting all returns for the rate of inflation so that only real returns are taxed would result in an expensive and complex regime at odds with fundamental principles of tax law: it should be inexpensive to administer and simple to understand. The issue is one of horizontal equity--to ensure that all savings options are treated similarly. Of course, this will also address issues of vertical equity, since, as I have already noted, the savings options available to wealthy Australians are not available to all.

The TESSA scheme, as proposed in the United Kingdom, is also commendable on the basis that it targets a savings cap. In the UK this cap, as I have indicated, is #9,000. That translates in Australian terms to about $30,000. In this way the scheme is structured to protect the interests of those with moderate amounts to invest. But will it assist in increasing national savings? Schemes to allow unlimited tax free returns on bank accounts are unlikely to address the totality of Australia's national savings. In Britain it appears that the scheme has worked in attracting investment funds into savings accounts. Rates in these accounts are very competitive. Vivien Goldsmith, the money editor of the Independent on Sunday, observed in an article of 20 January 1991:
The TESSA scramble for funds is sending the rates sky high. It has been very popular.
Lindsay Cook, of the Guardian, said at that time:
As Tessamania continues, several institutions have this week improved their tax-free accounts or introduced new ones.

The honourable member for Denison has suggested that any TESSA scheme incorporate measures to ensure that the funds raised be directed at least partially towards Australian industry and Australian development. I wholeheartedly support that statement. I am not arguing that institutions should not be left to invest as they see fit, but I think it proper that funds so raised be directed to targeted investments which will help Australia's industry infrastructure. While I reject the histrionic claim that Australians no longer save, I acknowledge that any increase in Australia's rate of savings would be a welcome development and, accordingly, this motion should be commended and supported.

It is important to recognise that funds are available at present through superannuation funds but that this proposal's being supported, as it is by honourable members on this side of the House, would provide an additional source of revenue, hopefully to some degree targeted to improving industrial development in this country where investment and venture capital is lacking. I would hope that those honourable members on the other side give appropriate consideration to it. I call on the Government to give appropriate consideration to this, as I am sure it will in the passage of time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am surprised that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which is inquiring into the banking industry, has not been able to enlighten me a little more about the effects of this motion. He took some time to once again talk about the goods and services tax. I do not particularly want to get into that debate in detail this morning, except to say to him that there is no doubt in my mind, nor in the minds of most of the experts, that a consumption tax is pro-saving almost by definition to the extent that it discourages consumption. One does not need to be an economist to figure out that, if consumption diminishes, saving increases. We do not actually pretend that that is the No.1 reason for introducing a goods and services tax. There are a large number of very good reasons why Australia desperately needs a new tax system and why it needs as a part of that a broad based consumption tax. It is, nevertheless, pro-saving and there will be a positive saving effect from such a tax. To the extent that that is not evident--I take the point that perhaps there has not been great evidence in some other countries for it--then it is for other reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make the point very clearly in refuting what the honourable member said that a consumption tax is by definition pro-saving and there will be a positive saving effect. It is interesting, if we talk about changing tunes, as he did, to look back to what happened in 1985 when both the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), and the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) were absolutely excited about the prospect of introducing a broad based consumption tax. They knew then--I suspect that if they were honest, they know now--that it was in the best interests of Australia for a lot of reasons.

Having said that, I have no real problem with the sentiments expressed in this motion. We desperately need to encourage saving. There is no doubt that we have a major problem in this country that has been occasioned by a lack of saving. In effect, in recent years we have been a major dissaver. This is largely the explanation for the enormous net international debt of $130 billion which we now have and the prospect if we do not do something about it--in effect, to take measures to encourage people to save--of that debt continuing to grow.

Some models, which are rather frightening, suggest that even by June 1996 that net debt could blow out to $240 billion and be almost 45 per cent of gross national product. In recent years we have lived off other people's savings. Perhaps it is fortunate that there are countries around where people do save. That is all very well. Perhaps to the extent that other people's savings have flowed into investment in this country--there was a great deal of investment going on through the middle 1980s--that is a good thing. But it cannot go on forever. We need investment in this country but to a large extent we have to provide for that ourselves. The only way we will do that is to save.

I heard the honourable member for Macarthur speaking earlier about net household savings as a percentage of disposable household income. I assume that that is what he was referring to. No matter how we interpret these figures, it is a fact that the latest figure for the household savings ratio--4.3 per cent in the June quarter--is actually the lowest on record. Since 1974 there has been a consistent downward trend in household savings--from 15.6 per cent in 1974 to this figure of 4.3 per cent. This has to be lifted if we are to be serious. The way we will do that is to encourage people to save.

The motion envisages a method of encouraging people to save. My concern about the motion in practice is that I believe there are already on the market a significant number of products along the same lines. I cannot see that the motion actually achieves anything that is not already in place. They are generally called open-ended savings plans and they already exist. My only real concern about the motion is whether it is necessary. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Mr Filing:
That the House:

(1) deplores the violence, loss of life and destruction of property that has taken place in Slovenia and Croatia, where more than 30 civilians are reported to have been killed, largely as a result of the attacks of terrorists supplied by the communist-led federal army and attacks by the army itself;
(2) notes the potential for further conflict if aspirations for self-determination expressed through democratic plebiscites in the Yugoslav republics are confronted by military force;
(3) welcomes the efforts of the European Community to act as a mediator to prevent further conflict;

(4) calls on the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav republics which will avoid conflict, achieve the independence which the people of Croatia and Slovenia demand and protect the interests of ethnic and religious minorities; and

(5) further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving, independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic recognition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This motion was moved on my behalf when I was absent attending a Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference in New Zealand. The motion was moved by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) when the crisis in Yugoslavia was escalating. The situation has since deteriorated quite markedly and the Government's response to date, regrettably, has been quite uninspiring.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of what has been said about the violence that continues seems, irrepressibly at present, of great moment and anguish. Countless cease-fires have been breached and it has proved impossible to bring the Yugoslav army, still operating unconstitutionally, under control. Even today, the brokered peace by Mikhail Gorbachev between the Presidents of both Croatia and Serbia, the ninth such occasion on which such a cease-fire has been brokered, has been breached.

This is not the time to add fuel to the fire of ancient animosities. It is a time for constructive and decisive diplomatic action to push for a negotiated peace and to provide much needed medical and humanitarian aid. It is time to look to the future.

It is quite clear that Yugoslavia, as we know it, is falling apart. Reports indicate that Bosnia-Hercegovina has approved moves towards independence. This republic contains three major ethnic groups of which Muslims make up 44 per cent, almost a third are Serbian and nearly one-fifth are Croats. The Serbian deputies walked out before the vote was taken because they wanted to remain in the Yugoslav federation but this was not the case with the other two groups.

Bosnia-Hercegovina borders both Croatia and Serbia. This development has only added to the heightened concerns of negotiators within the European Community that a full-blown civil war is imminent and that it will not be contained within the borders of old Yugoslavia. Clearly, if the dismantling of Yugoslavia is to be achieved in a peaceful and satisfactory way to all parties, the question of ethnic minorities must be settled, and the wish of all of us is that it will be settled without violence.

As I said in my speech on the Gulf war earlier this year, international lawlessness remains a feature of international relations. Underlying acts of aggression is a belief that the rest of the world and its international agencies are impotent to act. I would like to believe that they are not.

Part of this motion urges the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement. The Opposition has constructively led the debate and pushed the Government to take initiatives. It has urged the Government to protest in the strongest terms to the Yugoslav Government. It has called for international intervention, including the involvement of the United Nations. On the day of the Yugoslav invasion of Croatia, the Opposition condemned the use of military force and called for immediate dialogue.

In August, I was acting as foreign affairs spokesman for the Opposition. I urged the Australian Government to support the mission by three European Community Foreign Ministers to try to negotiate a cease-fire. On 6 August, I condemned the Government's inactivity and urged it then to back a role for the United Nations in mediating what was by then an escalating conflict. On 16 August, Senator Hill urged the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for talks on diplomatic recognition of Yugoslavia's evolving independent states. He also moved a motion in the Senate deploring the violence which had taken place in Slovenia and Croatia and called on the Government again to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav republics.

The Australian Government had offered some platitudes but it had taken no real initiatives to support the peaceful transition to the establishment of new independent states. Regrettably, the Government opposed the motion--that is this motion--after changing its mind several times in the Senate. This clearly demonstrated a degree of indifference to the deep concern that the Opposition and the people of this country feel about the future for the peoples of Slovenia, Croatia and the other evolving independent states within the Yugoslav federation. The motion was finally passed with the support of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine.

On 26 August, Senator Hill called upon the Government to press for action by the international community to negotiate a withdrawal of the Yugoslav army from Croatia and to urge the United Nations Security Council to step in to avert disaster. The Opposition also urged the Government to press for the International Committee of the Red Cross to be permitted to help the refugees from its headquarters in Geneva rather than through its office in Belgrade. Clearly, it is unlikely that Croatian refugees or asylum seekers would be able to travel with impunity to Belgrade to seek asylum.

We also asked the Government to give action in the form of relief via the International Committee of the Red Cross. Of course, a week later, the Government did accede to that and announced $100,000 in relief. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) urged the Government to provide humanitarian support directly to Zagreb in the form of urgently needed medical requirements and the provision of consular support in Zagreb so that the Croatian people seeking visas to Australia would no longer have to apply through Belgrade.
