We urged the Government to support the European Community proposal for a peace conference.

We noted the indifference of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) on this issue. It forced the Opposition to approach the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and we urged him to actively support the European Community's proposal that the Government of Yugoslavia take part in a cease-fire and conference. We urged the Prime Minister to press the Yugoslav Government to ensure that all its forces were withdrawn from Croatia.

When the cease-fire was breached in late August, the Opposition again approached the Government to end its inactivity on the crisis and to lodge an immediate protest with Belgrade. Still no action was taken, even after the Opposition's suggestion to back United Nation's involvement. The Prime Minister's indication on national television that he would pursue the matter regrettably did not lead to immediate action on the Government's part. While the Government has remained quiet, the crisis has deepened. There has been a tragic escalation in the loss of life and, increasingly, the possibility that the conflict could spread beyond Yugoslavia. In terms of loss of life, I read today that the number of people who have been killed in this conflict has reached 1,000.

We have repeated our call for the Government to recall the Ambassador so that talks can be undertaken to determine the appropriate timing for Australia's recognition of both Croatia and Slovenia. However, this, and statements by the Chairman of the Yugoslav Presidency, Mr Stipe Mesic, which indicated that the Yugoslav forces were not under constitutional control, still failed to elicit a positive response from the Government. The Prime Minister's response to the clear and immediate concerns of the Opposition was that the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations was keeping abreast of developments.

Throughout this entire crisis, the Opposition has been actively and, might I say, constructively involved in trying to find appropriate solutions to the complex and very difficult problems facing Yugoslavia. Last week, we again had to push the Government to consider taking action in the form of United Nations sanctions and an oil embargo on Yugoslavia. Regrettably, Senator Evans, to date, has refused to commit the Government to this action. In this regard, I would like to quote my colleague Senator Hill:

At a time when all vestiges of constitutional authority have broken down and the Croatian capital of Zagreb is being pounded by Yugoslav forces, it is simply not good enough to say that Australia is still thinking about action in the United Nations.
For the sake of those suffering from the appalling violence being perpetrated in Croatia, Australia should move now.

There is a role for Australia. We cannot determine these matters, but we can play a constructive role. We have large communities here in Australia of people from the Balkans. In this context, I think it is appropriate that we should be seen to be brokers, using the best of goodwill to try to assist, and this motion is put forward in that context.

I would like to say, as shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, that it is a very difficult time for the people from the Balkans--Serbs, Croats and others. It is a time for them to exercise freedom of speech, to participate in informed debate, to help us with advice and counselling, but to do so in a non-violent way and to demonstrate properly. In these matters, we have seen great caution exercised by the communities in Australia, but it is important that that continue and that people not be provoked in what is obviously a very difficult situation.
I hope that the comments that I make and the comments that my colleagues make in seeking to assist in this matter are seen as constructive and sensible comments in what is a very difficult situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At a time when democratisation and a rare sense of goodwill and hope are sweeping through the old Iron Curtain into central and eastern Europe, Yugoslavia stands as one black spot on an otherwise promising horizon. To be more precise, what is being done to the people and the historic and beautiful towns and cities of Croatia is a lot more than just a euphemistic black spot--it is a tragedy of unbelievable proportions which has the potential to escalate into a central European nightmare.

SPEECH.PARA: The tremendously sad part about the war in Croatia is that it is all so unnecessary. We hear much about the historical complexities which have led to the inevitable confrontation. We have also heard, although not from the protagonists themselves, that there are no easily quantified rights or wrongs, only understandable human differences which have developed through competing aspirations of a difficult past. I am sorry to say that I cannot accept such simplistic propaganda.

It is true to say that Yugoslavia is something of a European ethnic melting pot, full of contradictions and paradoxes. Created as an expedient after World War I, it has been a land with highly questionable internal borders, a difficult history during World War II, a volatile religious mix, and economic and political systems which themselves have created mistrust and divisiveness. However, it would be a large mistake for people to believe the propagandists when they say that this dispute has evolved from the existence of ethnically based problems.

I have personally been to Slovenia and Croatia three times in the last two years and I believe, contrary to what other people believe, that I am fairly well versed in the politics and personalities of the region. Make no mistake, this conflict was avoidable. It became a certainty only because of the existence of a Stalinist government in Serbia, which, in the fashion of communism, has dreamed only of conquest and expansion--dreams which have suited the self-interest agenda of the now disgraced generals in the Yugoslav People's Army who have done everything but act in the capacity that should have been their obligation as peacemakers.

In the 10 minutes that I have to speak on this issue, I obviously cannot go into great detail about the reality of politics Serbian-style. The real issues themselves may not be complex, but the machinations of Serbian leader Milosevic and his puppets in Kosovo and Vojvodina would take some time to cover, and we have not got that time today. I can, however, offer something of an overview of my impression of developments in that sad region and indicate my support for the most worthwhile motion moved by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing).

Although all of the five points in the honourable member's motion are worthy of support, I preface my general comments by making two small observations. The first is the obvious reflection that the number of civilians killed has risen dramatically since the motion was moved. As the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has already stated, it is somewhere in the region of 1,000--although it is hard to find some figures, because the deaths have obviously been played down by both sides. Secondly, I would have some reservations about the necessity of recalling the Australian Ambassador for consultations. In this day and age, with modern communication methods, such action is not required to facilitate debriefing. I also feel that taking the Ambassador out of the firing line might limit our ability to collect accurate information. We should subtly convey our desire to see peace initiatives stepped up. As I said before, however, those are minor points. Basically, the motion stands as a commonsense expression of Australia's commitment to democracy, peace, self-determination and negotiation.

As honourable members would know, the current controversy has its roots in the decisions of Croatia and Slovenia to secede from the socialist republic of Yugoslavia. Those decisions, which originally came into effect on 25 June 1991, followed democratic plebiscites which voted for independence. The Croatian plebiscite was supported by 94.7 per cent of voters, and honourable members must admit that that is a tremendously decisive result. Quite frankly, it was my research into this result, my discussions with Croatian leaders and the wording of the new Croatian constitution which convinced me that the new Croatia deserved this chance to stand alone amongst the nations of the world.

To those honourable members who have not read the Croatian constitution I recommend it as excellent reading. It is a document which has taken the best from a range of constitutions, including the Australian Constitution, and which is extremely difficult to criticise. I challenge anybody to find any criticism to offer. Quite frankly, a cursory reading of it quickly destroys much of the argument which has been used by Milosevic to justify his invasion of Croatia, that being that the Serbian minority in and around Krajina would suffer discrimination at the hands of the Croatian majority. It is a claim which has been backed up with all sorts of allegations, such as that the cyrillic alphabet is now banned in Croatia, that Orthodox Croatians are not allowed to occupy public service and other senior positions, and that Orthodox churches are subject to desecration and attack.

If those things are happening, then the Orthodox Croatians I spoke to in Zagreb, Dubrovnik and other parts of Croatia must have been excellent liars. I took the trouble to visit the homes of ethnically mixed couples in cities such as Zadar to get a feel of the level of ethnic compatibility. I found no evidence whatsoever of any victimisation or any animosity towards any minority grouping; however, I did detect a general across-ethnic fear of Milosevic and his stooges.

To be fair to the Orthodox Serbians living in the racially mixed Serbo-Croat towns in eastern Slovenia, such as Borovo, Sello and Vukovar, there exists a genuine belief that future Croatian governments will pursue policies of victimisation. Those people accept the bona fides of the constitution for now, but do not accept that it will hold good in the future. They cannot be blamed for this belief, particularly as Milosevic and his `greater Serbia' allies have played on old animosities and brought in propagandists to spread the message.

As I said before, this dispute has nothing to do with any fears of a free Croatia, but everything to do with the Serbian leader's aspirations for a new Serbia, which in his opinion stretches from the Adriatic in the south-west, through to the heartlands of Bosnia-Herzegovina, into northern Macedonia and on to Kosovo, Vojvodina and into parts of Montenegro. That is the real problem.

It is important for us to understand that the public of Serbia--this is the most important point of my speech--cannot be blamed for the excesses of their government and the Serbian dominated Army. In a sense, they are innocent victims, caught as the Croatian public in a senseless conflict, which at the end of the day can be resolved only by negotiation and compromise. The obvious first thing that needs to happen to end the conflict is for the Yugoslav People's Army to cease its murderous activities. I do not believe it is possible for the Army to supervise a cease-fire, as it is thoroughly disgraced and compromised.

I cannot help feeling that Croatia has every reason to be disappointed that the West has not prized its fledgling democracy rather more highly. Perhaps Croatia was naive to hope for early recognition of its independence declaration, and perhaps it has been that naivety which has cost the republic so dearly. However, should all other means fail, that course of action might yet be the most sensible. After all, the West has a proud reputation of ensuring that bullies do not succeed. I commend the motion by the honourable member for Moore to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —- I commend the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) for his contribution to this debate this afternoon. I will read the fourth paragraph of the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) on behalf of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:

(4) calls on the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav republics which will avoid conflict, achieve the independence which the people of Croatia and Slovenia demand and protect the interests of ethnic and religious minorities;
It seems almost a lifetime since that motion was moved in this House. No-one in this place can obtain any joy from what has happened in Yugoslavia since that motion was moved.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are well aware, the Serbians and the Croatians are well represented in this country. I congratulate them on their peaceful approach to this problem in their adopted country. They have not sought to extend the conflict from their homeland into Australia--into Australian streets or between themselves here--and we can all be extremely grateful for their attitude to date in that regard.

They are however justifiably passionate about what is happening in their homeland. A large number of people from that area but not born there have quite justly taken up the cause with the passion of their parents and grandparents.

I have been approached personally by members of the Croatian community in Ballarat, of which there are a large number. I was fortunate enough to have long and detailed discussions with Mr Ben Duka, who is the head of the Croatian community in Ballarat. He has a sensible approach to this; he is not looking to in any way incite Australia to what is happening in Yugoslavia. But he pleaded with me to ensure that, first, this Parliament is aware of the situation and, secondly, this Parliament does something about the atrocities being committed in Croatia against the relatives of a large number of the Croatian people living in Australia and against their culture.

Effectively, thousands of years of cultural history are being destroyed, and that is to say nothing of the deplorable loss of life that the honourable member for Dundas and the honourable member for Fowler have referred to this morning. I very much doubt whether it is limited to a thousand civilians; I rather suspect that the figures may be far more horrific.

Mr Duka, during our discussions, gave me a couple of videotapes which outlined some of the atrocities that have been committed during this war. I can assure honourable members that I felt physically sick when I saw those. I pray that this dispute will be resolved very quickly.

The argument--it has been used in this House before--that the conflict is thousands of miles away is a total cop-out. In the past this House has shown an ability to appropriately and properly intervene in these sorts of disputes. It is appropriate for this House to address those concerns, as we are doing today.

This dispute will be resolved only by recognising Croatia. The European Community has been very slack in its approach to the matter. I urge it to take a far more active role in addressing this conflict so that we can stop the wanton destruction of both people and heir property. This is a group that deserves protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In this debate I will take an Australian perspective to the attitude that should be adopted by Australia in dealing with the tragedy occurring in Yugoslavia. I and the Government do not have any trouble with the first, second, third and fourth parts of the notice of motion, but I oppose the fifth paragraph, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving, independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic recognition.

The Government will also oppose it if the matter is brought to a vote. It should be opposed for good reasons. The first is that this Government does not recall its ambassadors simply at the invitation or the whim of any group in this country unless there are very strong grounds to do so.

Our mission in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, provides this Government with a first-hand account of developments and assessments of the fighting and the political activities occurring in Yugoslavia. The people at our mission in Yugoslavia also assist Australians in Yugoslavia with consular and other needs that the mission may have the capacity to provide them with. Very importantly, our people in our mission in Yugoslavia maintain the lines of communication with local authorities, political leaders and other embassies that have an involvement in the situation. The mission does this to keep our Government informed as to the situation from day to day. Apart from the general issues in Yugoslavia and in that region of the world, this issue cannot--and Australia will not allow it to--be considered in isolation.

In so far as the call to give diplomatic recognition to these states in Yugoslavia is concerned, let me say this: international law requires four principles to be satisfied prior to a government taking the step of recognising another country as an independent nation. First, it must decide whether there is a definable, independent population; secondly, it must have a definable independent territory; thirdly, it must have an independent government; and, finally, that particular government must have a capacity to deal with domestic affairs and to conduct an independent foreign policy and must be able to exercise the power that goes with the exercise of administering foreign relations.

At present these internal republics in Yugoslavia do not satisfy all those criteria. Until such time as that occurs the Australian Government should not take any unilateral steps. It would be most inappropriate for it to give recognition to these constituent areas known as Croatia, Serbia and so forth, which currently exist in Yugoslavia. I am sure that Australia will be among the first to recognise the republics once they have satisfied those principles of international law.

The Australian Government has repeatedly called on all the parties of the conflict to respect the cease-fire agreement arranged on 20 August between the presidents of the six Yugoslav republics and the federal collective presidency. That meeting on 20 August succeeded in agreeing to a four-point plan involving the recognition of the right of the people to self-determination. It included the cessation of hostilities, respect for the democratically expressed will of all the peoples, equal treatment of all political options without the use of force, and legal implementation of that accord, which was worked out as long ago as 20 August. But there has not been a peaceful resolution of this situation.

I take this opportunity to call again for a concerted effort by the parties involved to reach a negotiated settlement so as to end the fighting which is threatening not only the people of Yugoslavia but also the security of the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being almost 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-About 18 months ago one of the most costly, disruptive and disgraceful episodes ever to be recorded in the annals of Australian industrial relations drew to a long overdue, painful and, in some respects, most unsatisfactory conclusion. I refer, of course, to the so-called pilots dispute. It is not my intention today to rehash the pros and cons of the dispute. Instead, I want to examine some of its after-effects. Although most commentators regard 21 March 1990 as the date on which the dispute officially concluded, in reality for many it has never ended.

SPEECH.PARA: Accurate statistics are not readily available, so the following figures are approximate only, but they give a reasonable picture of the current situation. Only about 25 per cent of the pilots employed by the major domestic airlines prior to August 1989 are still working for their original employers. Of the remaining 75 per cent, a handful have retired; between 50 and 60 are now employed by Compass; about 650 have been forced to leave Australia to find work overseas; and almost 500 have taken other jobs or are still unemployed. A combined total of between 900 and 1,000 pilots are now employed by Australian, Ansett, East-West and IPEC--an overall reduction of approximately 40 per cent. Of the several hundred foreign pilots who entered Australia during the dispute, many have stayed and it is estimated that about 100, maybe more, are still working here.
On 7 December 1989, at a Canberra press club luncheon, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), commenting on the pilots dispute, said:

At no point have I wanted to see the destruction of the AFAP. That would be anathema to my whole life, to talk about destroying a union. I think the airlines almost had to take the action they did and they had our support. But not, from my view, to exact retribution.

Apparently, the powers that be in the head offices of our domestic airlines did not share the Prime Minister's sentiments, at least in regard to exacting retribution, because it seems that that is what they have been doing ever since. As a result, hundreds of the very best, most experienced and most dedicated people in Australia's domestic aviation industry have been thrown on the scrap heap and left to rot. Some have been more fortunate and have managed to find alternative employment despite the discrimination they have suffered, and continue to suffer, at the hands of their former employers.

One of my constituents comes within this relatively more fortunate category. For nine years before joining Ansett my constituent served as a pilot in the RAAF. He was awarded a special commendation for his flying skill and professionalism. During his 11 years with Ansett he served on F27, Boeing 727 and 767 aircraft. By August 1989 he had successfully completed pilot endorsement training on Boeing 737s and had just commenced command training when the simmering industrial unrest which had been plaguing the domestic air service for some months finally boiled over. And so began the most destructive and shameful period in the aviation history of this nation.

When the pilot's dispute erupted, my constituent resigned from Ansett, having received legal advice that it was in his best interests to take this course of action. In doing so, he laid his unblemished record and very promising career on the line. Perhaps had he known then what he knows now he may not have chosen this particular option; but it is always very easy to be wise after the event. Suffice to say that his actions were consistent with those of the vast majority of his AFAP colleagues and were based on what he believed was the best advice and information available at the time.

Early in the dispute he realised that his prospects of returning to resume his career with Ansett were, at least in the immediate future, not particularly rosy. He therefore thought it prudent to investigate other employment opportunities. He applied to, was interviewed and tested by and subsequently was offered employment with two of the leading international carriers. At least he had some choice in regard to his future employment. Despite the fact that my constituent was very pleased and grateful to be employed and was determined to make a success of his new career, he continued to maintain contact with Ansett in an endeavour to keep himself appraised of changing company attitudes.

On 21 March 1990 he was informed by the AFAP that the recruitment ban had been lifted. First thing next morning he went to the Ansett office at Tullamarine and filled out the appropriate application forms and undertakings. Two weeks later he received a letter from Ansett advising that the company did not have an appointment suitable for him at that time. However, it was suggested that, should Ansett advertise publicly for pilots at some future time, he could submit another application.

Over the next few months he wrote several more letters to Ansett emphasising his continuing interest in rejoining the company and updating them in regard to the qualifications and experience he was gaining as a result of his current employment. Each time the response from Ansett consisted of one short sentence:
We acknowledge receipt of your letter. . . and the contents are noted.

In October 1990, aware that Ansett was still recruiting small numbers of pilots, my constituent wrote to a senior Ansett executive whom he had known during his previous 11 years employment with the company, seeking further advice and information in regard to his future re-employment prospects. He included with this letter references from several current and former senior Ansett pilots, including the former Manager Flight Standards and several check and training captains.

The executive concerned stated in his response that he had read the references and could see no reason why he should disagree with any of them; however, as the employment policy of the company had returned to that which applied before the dispute began, he advised my constituent to continue his career with the international carrier. In light of the continuing discouraging and non-committal responses from his previous employer, it was a totally unexpected development when, in November 1990, my constituent was contacted by a firm of consultant psychologists acting on behalf of Ansett.

My constituent was invited, and agreed, to undergo a psychological assessment. These tests were followed by a thorough medical examination and a formal interview with representatives of the Ansett pilot recruitment committee. A couple of weeks later my constituent received a letter from Ansett informing him that it would not be proceeding further with his application for employment.

Because he had been advised by the Ansett doctor that his physical health was excellent, and confident that his qualifications, experience and the references he had provided were beyond reproach, he concluded that his psychology test results must have been unsatisfactory. He contacted the consultants who had conducted the tests and whilst, for obvious reasons, they were not in a position to provide him with a copy of the report prepared for Ansett, he was advised that he had received `one of the highest recommendations to date', and that on the basis of his report there was absolutely no reason why Ansett should not have re-employed him.

My constituent, whose second name could well be `persistence', then wrote to the Deputy General Manager of Ansett seeking some advice or explanation as to why he had been rejected. The Deputy General Manager in his response reiterated that it was not company policy to comment on employment interviews but that there had been a large number of good applicants for a limited number of positions. He concluded by saying:
I am sure you will fulfil the role of an airline pilot most successfully.

This was a strange statement, indeed, from a senior executive of a company which had just rejected my constituent's application. If he had believed what he said and was so confident about the flying abilities of my constituent, why did he not offer him a job? Surely Ansett's employment criteria are based on recruiting people who will be successful pilots? If not, what is the basis of its selection procedures?
For the record, I would like to read just a few representative extracts from the references and reports relating to my constituent. They state:
He proved himself to be a professional and capable operator.
There is no doubt in regard to his command abilities.
Any company having him in their employ will gain immeasurably.
. . . has accumulated an impressive range of aviation experience. . . his aircraft handling ability is at a high standard.

They are not bad recommendations from one's senior colleagues. In so far as his professional flying ability is concerned, the following comment is an extract from the last simulator flight test he completed with Ansett. The extract stated:
He produced a consistent high standard of flight management and manipulation throughout. He showed smooth consistency and excellent command ability which was most pleasing to watch.
The report of his last line check--a test of a pilot's general operational efficiency--which he completed with Ansett, stated:
All aspects of these flights were very well handled. A mature and professional pilot.
His current employers are equally impressed with his performance and have sent him several letters congratulating him on his professionalism, dedication and high personal standards.

It seems very strange indeed that whilst my constituent is held in such high regard by his peers and is acceptable to two of the best--and, from a recruitment point of view, most competitive--international airlines, both of which require the highest standards, he is not considered suitable by Ansett. Why? He knows the answer; I know the answer; and Ansett knows the answer. It has nothing to do with his competence as a pilot, it is because two years ago he stood up for something which he believed at the time was right. That was his crime and Ansett is determined to punish him for it; not for some months, not even for a few years, but for the rest of his working life.

My constituent took no part in the anti-company demonstrations or picket lines; he simply held firm to his beliefs and maintained his loyalty to his union. I know that some honourable members opposite and other people in the community will respond by saying, `The pilots knew what they were doing. They knew the likely consequences of their actions. They brought it all on themselves'. Such assertions may or may not be correct. It can be argued that, if the eventual outcome of the decisions they took had been known to them at the time, the pilots may have changed tack before things got out of hand.

I would remind honourable members that changes of heart, when the unintended consequences of decisions or actions actually start to manifest themselves, are not simply the prerogative of pilots but of Prime Ministers, Treasurers and Ministers, too. The only difference is that sometimes some of them get away with it. But that is not the issue here. The real issue is: how much longer are our pilots going to have to pay for what they did? How much longer are their noses going to be rubbed in the dirt? The dispute is over. Let us get our Aussie pilots back where they belong--flying for Australian airline companies in Australian skies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise not only to grieve for a particular group of young people in our community but also to enlist their aid to ensure that they take notice of the grievance which I am about to pursue.

SPEECH.PARA: As many honourable members will know, currently within our community there is an enormous spate of weddings. They seem very popular and fashionable. The day should be a very memorable occasion for the individuals involved and their families. It is in this context of joy and happiness that I bring this grievance.

A number of my constituents have raised an issue with me which goes to the very heart of what our society and our Government is about; that is, ensuring that consumers' rights are protected from those people who choose to practise in a manner which often is not fair and just.

Many young people choose to hire wedding gowns and garments because they are unable to afford to pay for them. We all know that wedding gowns can cost in the region of a couple of thousand dollars. Such expenditure is beyond the poor and the disadvantaged in our community and so they choose the option of hiring. One would assume that to hire from one of the largest companies in Brisbane, a company called Deons, which has been trading for a very long time, would be a sensible thing to do and that such a firm would ensure that the very best business practices were pursued.

Recently a young lady and her party went to choose some material; in fact, the company was even willing to make new gowns, which would seem to me to be a very sound business practice. The matter was pursued with the staff, and sizes, the cost and so on were all discussed and a deposit was asked for. The young people left feeling quite happy that they had made a reasonable choice in their financial circumstances. They were happy in the belief that another little task was completed and that their wedding would proceed.

A return visit was made to check on fittings and materials. However, a number of problems arose. The bridesmaids' dresses were not the right size and the material was not quite the same as had been chosen and they were asked to come back in a week or two. Again, the wedding party spent more money on train fares and travel to town. They all thought that, this time, they would be able to try on the frocks, but this did not happen yet again.

At this stage other members of the family became involved. Various people suggested that, having paid a deposit, it would be the requisite time to ask whether the dresses would ever eventuate and, if not, whether the deposit should be collected and the party should go to another establishment.

There was at this stage enormous difficulty in getting a decision on whether the deposit was refundable or whether the garments were ever going to emerge. This matter caused enormous distress to members of the party.

The staff member then informed the young people in question that the deposit was not refundable and advised them to read the bottom line in the small print where they would see that this was the case. The young people said, `This is quite extraordinary. Are you saying that you cannot give me exactly what I want in the right size and the right material?'. Usually the company then offers something which is considerably dearer. One of my constituents found that, two days before her wedding, she was charged hundreds of dollars extra for a dress she did not want because her requirements were unable to be met.

The problem with the deposit ensued. Where does one go to in moments such as this? The company concerned is a member of the Small Business Association of Australia and these people decided that their consumer rights could best be addressed by pursuing the matter with that Association. Many associations ensure that their members act in the very best way, that they give business the best name they can and that their consumers are treated in the right way. Of this we have no doubt.

However, there is a difficulty in this case because the President of the Small Business Association of Australia is also the proprietor of the shop. A staff member of the Small Business Association of Australia said, `A complaint can only be made to the proprietor'. A great battle ensued. There were discussions, a number of phone calls, and the people concerned came to my office in distress. The wedding was drawing nearer. I might say that this was not the first time that this had happened with this particular establishment. Matters eventually became quite heated.

I was then written to, and was told that I am a dishonourable member and that the Labor Government needs the Small Business Association more than the Small Business Association needs me. That may well be true and that may be a practice, but the reality of the matter is that I had always been led to assume that small businesses were there to operate for their consumers and their clients. Indeed, I would have thought that there was an unlimited market for wedding clothes. People are happy to spend any amount of money they can afford to make the day a happy one.
This matter did not have a happy ending, but there was a resolution in that the deposit was eventually returned to one of the fathers of the party and the clothes were hired from elsewhere.

This raises a whole series of questions. We hear a great deal of discussion about the role, demands and responses of small businesses in our community and of associations which serve the interests of small business. I suggest that the associations operate in the very best way, but we do need to ensure that their members, their consumer mechanisms and their complaint mechanisms operate in the very best of ways. This certainly does not seem to have been the case in this matter.

It is also interesting to note that many of the complaints that I have had about this establishment have come from the lower socio-economic areas of our community. My own electorate office is situated in the Woodridge-Logan area, which is recognised as having a low socio-economic base. The other major area from which that establishment's clients come is Inala, which is in the electorate of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall). He also received a letter about the difficulty being experienced by these people.

I grieve about the fact that people are placed in this most invidious situation. I say to young people, `Beware of signing contracts and offering deposits. Please ensure that the small business which you go to belongs to an association to which you can complain'.

It seems extraordinary that, if one wishes to make a complaint against a business, the only person in the relevant association to whom one can complain happens to be the person who owns the business. I would have thought that it was incumbent upon the Small Business Association of Australia to ensure that complaints could be dealt with by a number of people because of conflict of interest. Many honourable members on both sides of the House have at various times absented themselves from discussions on a whole range of matters because of what they consider to be conflicts of interest. We understand that. It has been an ethic in the community for a very long time and has been espoused by everybody in this House.

I urge the Small Business Association of Australia to establish complaint mechanisms which enable people to make complaints against a whole range of establishments which are members of it. I urge the executive of that Association to understand the whole notion of conflict of interest and to understand that some people who may wish to complain against proprietors of certain establishments should not be precluded from doing so because the owner of that establishment happens to be the President of that Association.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to address one of the matters that the honourable member for Forde (Mrs Crawford) raised. I think she obviously misunderstands the position of ASBA in relation to its ability to take any of its members to task. It is purely an organisational body, not one that can take any punitive measures.

SPEECH.PARA: What I wish to grieve about today is the gross hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party. I think some members on the other side of the House believe that we get some sort of joy out of coming in here day in, day out and addressing our concerns about the way they are governing the country. The very reason we are doing that is because they are not prepared to accept the sort of policy rationale that they know is going to get the country out of its present state.

I sometimes wonder exactly what motivates members of the Government. The classic example is the performance of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in the last 24 hours. His greatest hypocrisy is to tell the rest of the world--while he is out of the country--that we are in our worst recession for 60 years. He quite simply has not got the intestinal fortitude to come into this place and tell the Australian people and this Parliament what we all know; he had to go out of the country to do so. It is a gross example of a lack of intestinal fortitude. I do not believe the Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Free), who is at the table, could possibly support it and I do not for one minute believe that the members of the Labor Party back bench could support their Treasurer making this statement outside the country.

That is just the start of it. The classic, which was raised this week by Glenn Milne from the Australian, was the perks debate in the last Caucus meeting. This is just unbelievable. I can promise the Minister at the table that every person in my electorate--including the 22 per cent who are unemployed--will know exactly what the concerns of the Caucus are when it comes to the crocodile tears about this so-called caring Government; absolute crocodile tears.

In the gallery at the moment is Councillor Lea Senior and her niece, Melanie, from Ballarat. They know exactly what the plight of the Ballarat people is; they know exactly the extent of the unemployment problem in Ballarat; and they know the havoc the Labor Party has wreaked on the people of the Ballarat region.

Do you know what the Labor Party Caucus members discussed for 45 minutes, Mr Deputy Speaker? They discussed how they were going to get to and from the House; whether they were going to keep their white cars. Do you know how many questions there were on the unemployment level? Two. There were two questions about the worst recession in 60 years. Only two backbenchers bothered raising the state of the country's plight and the number of unemployed in this country. I think that is an absolute disgrace and I can assure the Minister that his candidate in Ballarat, who was pre-selected recently, is going to know about it and is going to have to justify it, as is every one of the Labor Party back bench.

Quite frankly, I find it very hard to understand how Government backbenchers can go home and honestly look their constituents in the eye and tell them that what this Government is doing is in their best interests, because it simply is not. I can assure the Minister who is at the table that he and his Government--and I appreciate that he is a relative newcomer to the front bench--will never be forgiven for this so-called recession we had to have.

Who said we had to have this recession? Did the Australian people have a say in that? Did the 22 per cent of people in the Ballarat region who are unemployed have a say in that? No, they did not. This recession was caused by a government that took out the big wallet in the first three years when it came in--the populist Government--and threw money from one end of Australia to the other. The ultimate reality was that the chooks came home to roost and the Government had to pull in its horns because of its mismanagement. The only people who have suffered the outcome of that are the Australian people, not the Australian Labor Party parliamentary members. No, they are all right; they are still looking after themselves; they are still talking about their perks of getting to and from the House and whether they should have white cars. They are not suffering, but 22 per cent of the population are.

They are never going to be forgiven for the lie that we would never enter into a recession. They will never be forgiven for their lies about what our unemployment levels were going to reach. They will never be forgiven for the lie about what caused the 1982-83 recession. They know very well that that was a drought induced recession; our worst recession in 60 years is totally related to the economic paralysis of the Australian Labor Party.

They will never be forgiven for the record number of bankruptcies in this country. They will never be forgiven for the destruction of the economic and social fabric of thousands upon thousands of Australian families. They will never be forgiven for the destruction of the Australian manufacturing sector as a result of tariff reductions that were not accompanied by appropriate micro-economic reform. I greet with great joy yesterday's news that the manufacturing sector's contribution to the Australian economy has increased. But imagine what it could do if a proper framework was put in place for it. Everyone in this House knows, or should know, that Australian manufacturing has always been competitive, but impediments are placed in front of manufacturers at every stage. If we can remove those impediments, we will see a very strong manufacturing sector.

I think the gross hypocrisy goes even further. There is hypocrisy about the extent of micro-economic reform; hypocrisy in relation to what is being done on the waterfront; and hypocrisy in relation to industrial relations. The sad fact is that this Government is absolutely gutless when it comes to industrial relations. It has not got the intestinal fortitude to make the decisions that it knows must be made because lurking in the background ready to pounce on it wherever it turns is the trade union leadership. I am not referring to the rank and file members of the trade union movement; they have my support. As long as they are members because they want to be members--not because they have to be members; not because they are forced to be members--they have my support. If they want to be members of the trade union movement, I will support them 100 per cent. But I am not prepared to support a trade union leadership that is clinging onto the vestiges of its previous power base.

Those who make up the trade union leadership are a very sad and sorry group of people who are apologists for true Australians. They have not made the decisions that they know are so dramatically affecting the future and the past of their members. Quite frankly, I think they could not give a tinker's curse about their members. That is the only thing that we can glean from their present attitude. They do not care about them. They want to cling to the last vestige of the power base they have left; they will not give it up.

Tax reform is another part of the gross hypocrisy of this Government; total hypocrisy. I would like to go through a few of the quotes in relation to taxation reform. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) apparently has performed again with our press overseas and reduced himself to appalling levels. I would like to bring up some of the matters that he raised in relation to taxation reform.

Before I get to that, I refer to Mr David Charles, a former member for Isaacs. I can say to the House that the Liberal Party member for Isaacs is doing a great job and he will be there for a long time. On 15 May 1985, David Charles said:

. . . tax avoidance and evasion is running at intolerable levels within our community, levels which we are now coming to recognise as crippling to this country's development and the Government's ability to arrange taxation on the most equitable basis possible.
I ask the House to consider this exchange:
Q: Aren't you taking a heck of a risk in advocating the adoption of a consumption tax and is it worth it?
A: Yes, we are taking a risk. What this country has needed desperately for years now is a government which is prepared to face up to what has to be done to get this economy into proper shape.

Was the answer that of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson)? No. It was that of the Prime Minister in 1985. Where has the Prime Minister gone in the last six years? He is running scared about this debate and he knows very well that the only possible way that we can get this country out of the atrocious mess that it presently finds itself in is through the sorts of taxation proposals that the coalition is talking about.

I hark back to the 22 per cent of people in my electorate who have not got work, to those people who are working reduced hours, and those people who have simply given up looking for a job. What hope have they got? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Before I came into the chamber, the previous speaker, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), was discussing the Caucus meeting and the supposed leak from the Caucus quoted by Glenn Milne in the Australian. That is a totally inaccurate report of what occurred in the Caucus meeting.
—-And you were there.

—-As the Minister at the table says, we were there. The people in Caucus were concerned about Commonwealth cars, but they were concerned about Commonwealth car drivers and their conditions of work as well as the efficiency of the fleet. Those matters were discussed at the Caucus meeting, but certainly not for 45 minutes, as Glenn Milne said they were.
