SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak today on a matter of some import to people who have problems with mental health and an organisation which serves those people. In doing so, I refer the Parliament to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs report entitled You Have Your Moments, which reported on the funding of peak health and community organisations in February 1991. I am a member of that Committee, which is very ably chaired by the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins).

As a consequence of the terms of reference given by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), the Committee came down with some recommendations relating to the funding formation for community groups that had a national peak body association. One of the Committee's recommendations reads:

The Committee recommends continued Commonwealth funding for national secretariats of non-government health, housing and community services organisations on the basis that public education, public debate and community consultation assist the development of appropriate policies and programs, especially where disadvantaged groups are concerned.

The Committee further recommended that national secretariats with a primary focus on providing or coordinating direct services should not be eligible for funding under the particular program. It also recommended that the Department of Community Services and Health review any such national secretariats which are currently funded with a view to suggesting they change the balance of their activities, seek a more appropriate source of funding, or withdraw funding if they continue to concentrate on service provision.

In the context of the group that I am speaking about today, GROW, I wish to draw the attention of the House to the fact that a couple of very good individuals are circulating within the House today--they were also here yesterday--to talk to individual members about GROW's funding situation. I totally support--and I am sure most members of this place would--the activities of GROW and its search for funding. Given that it is now not appropriate for it to be funded under the previous regime, it must find funding in an alternative fashion. I am also confident that the Minister and his people will be giving consideration to how GROW may be funded in the future, now that it does not qualify for peak organisation funding.
It is important for people to be aware of the nature of GROW. One of its leaflets states:
GROW is a community mental health movement organised and led by people recovering or recovered from mental illness and from other serious personal inadequacies or maladjustments to life.
I point out to members of the House that a few leaflets on GROW are available. It does some excellent work. The leaflet continues:
GROW began in Sydney, Australia, in 1957 when a number of former mental patients came together after hospitalization for mental illness to find their way back to normal living and happiness.

So many people who attend GROW and are supported by GROW are able to resume a normal life after having fairly traumatic experiences through either the mental health system or other sorts of treatment for mental illness.
GROW's school of life and leadership involves three essential features. They are stated in this document to be:
-- A Program of Growth to Maturity based on natural rules for healthy living and proven steps of recovery and personal growth.
-- A Group Method for problem solving and mutual education which enables ordinary people without professional training to run their own groups.
-- A Caring and Sharing Community, amounting to a network of friendship and trustworthy helpers.

From Australia GROW has spread to New Zealand, Ireland, Great Britain, Canada and the United States of America. GROW came to Hawaii in 1971 and to Illinois in 1978. Of its over 600 groups, more than 100 are in the United States.

In Australia it is still an extremely important organisation for caring and sharing in the community. It is a very important organisation for the help of mental health patients and people who are suffering from mental health problems or who are trying to survive and recover from mental health problems.

I certainly think that the Minister and the Department would be racking their brains to work out a way for groups like GROW, self-help organisations which do not qualify for funding under the peak organisation proposals, to continue to be supported, given that those groups save money for the community and the Government in dollar terms; more important are the costs that they save in terms of human life and the fulfilment of human expectations.

GROW has also produced a document, which John Lizzio has circulated to quite a number of members of Parliament while he has been here in the precincts of the House. One of them is called GROW and its National Secretariat: Sources of Cost Savings to Government Finances Provided by GROW. It outlines a number of cost savings in summary, calculated at the end to total $16,853,902. It goes in more detail into proposals for reductions in government outlays, which I will also outline briefly for the House's information. It reads:
A Reduced Government outlays are achieved through:
1. reduction in hospitalization costs for both public and private patients by reducing the number of bed days per person each year;
2. reduction in use, and therefore costs of professional help sought by Medicare clients;
(exact figure not able to be calculated)
3. reduction in use of medication and consequent reduced costs of National Health Service;
(exact figure not able to be calculated)
4. reduction in benefits paid under Invalid Pensioner and other Social Security schemes when GROW members return to part time or full time employment;
5. saving in labour costs as a result of the thousands of unpaid hours contributed by Growers--
that is, of course, the name for people who are participants in the GROW groups--
and voluntary staff including research and planning and reporting;

It also calculates anticipated increases in Government revenues through tax contributions made by participants in GROW returning to the work force at $3,852,750 and by GROW salaried staff at $284,862. The amount for salaried staff is less because the organisation does not have many salaried staff.

It is imperative that people understand that GROW and groups like GROW have a most crucial role to play in our community, especially in the area of self-help. Many people in our community have problems, not all of which are critical mental health problems. Some have problems of considerable stress; some may not be able to deal with a pharmaceutical drug that has been prescribed for them. They have consequential problems which could be seen to be mental problems or they have addiction problems, many of which are associated with some mental illness. I think that the excellent work that GROW and groups like GROW do cannot be ignored and will not be ignored by the Government.

I know that GROW representatives here today will be going to see the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services and his office helpers to try to ensure that their case is being adequately put, but I thought it was imperative that its case also be put to the House, because it is a very worthy group. It has in fact a unique situation in our society, given that it is an Australian home-grown organisation which has spread worldwide. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My grievance today is about the issue of overseas aid--overseas development assistance--and the nature of the debate in Australia and, indeed, in other parts of the world about how much aid should be provided to developing countries and in what form it should be given.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years there has been a United Nations target of 0.7 per cent of GDP for aid from developed countries to the developing world. There are very few countries which have met that target and those that have are in Scandinavia. Australia falls at somewhere around half of that target and, consequently, it is said that Australia's performance in terms of providing overseas development assistance is, by the standards of the United Nations target, a very poor effort.

The corollary of this is that countries such as Australia that spend about half of the United Nations target in terms of development assistance should substantially increase their spending. If they were to do so, that would, in the first place, raise living standards in developing countries very substantially and, in the second case, gain for that country--let us take Australia by way of example--a reputation for being a more compassionate and caring society than we might otherwise have.

I must say that I regard the measure of compassion in terms of dollars provided for overseas aid as a false measure of compassion. Indeed, the whole debate about assistance to developing countries is, in my view, a debate which is growing increasingly unrealistic and, in a sense, increasingly unhelpful to those countries.

We need to keep in mind that the world economy must operate in a way which benefits all countries, including developing countries. Their low levels of per capita income and the extensive poverty in many developing countries--not quite in all of them--are matters which we all have a responsibility to address. But, if we are going to work out how we will address those problems of developing countries, we first have to ask ourselves the question: why are those countries in economic difficulties? Why is there such widespread poverty in some parts of the world as distinct from other parts of the world?

There are basically three reasons for that. In the first place, some countries through virtue of their location are unlucky. Their circumstances are such that it is very hard for them to achieve successful agricultural industries and manufacturing industries and to develop an internationally competitive economy. Those countries are often the victims of extensive droughts. They are sometimes destroyed or severely damaged by floods and other sorts of natural catastrophes. But that category of developing countries is very small.

Most developing countries fall into the second category. The reason for their economic disadvantage lies in economic policies pursued both within those countries and internationally by the developed world. In many parts of Africa, for example, and certainly in Latin America as well, the overwhelming reason for the failure of those economies lies in domestic economic policies.

For example, after independence was achieved in many African countries, the governments decided to institute, under the banner of socialism, extensive land reform programs. They took the privately owned agricultural sector, such as we have in Australia, in Europe, the United States and so on, and they carved it up. They often handed the land over to people who had little experience of modern forms of agriculture--one could say no experience of modern forms and methods of agriculture in many cases--and they socialised the land so that any earnings from that land were collectivised and socialised and they expected the country to maintain high levels of productivity in agriculture and high prosperity. The reality is that those countries failed to do it because the change in method of land ownership was simply an economic disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As Dick Klugman points out, the Soviet Union had 60 years of bad seasons.

—-I thought the Minister was going to say something profound. I suppose his point that the Soviet Union had 60 years of bad seasons is a very good way of illustrating the point that I am making. With a bit of luck, the Soviet Union's 60 years of bad seasons are coming to an end.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important to understand this point, but it does not, of course, apply only to agriculture. Many developing countries, particularly after they achieved independence, picked up the banner of socialism--much beloved by those on the other side of this House--and rushed around their own countries saying that they would turn their capitalist countries, which had been victims of imperialist exploitation, into socialist nirvanas. Of course, we all know that what socialism actually did was to breed State-run monopolies, often highly protected in terms of tariff and non-tariff barriers. The lack of competition led to a lack of efficiency, monopoly profits and exploitation becoming the norm. Much of those monopoly profits were simply put into the pockets of the leadership of those countries and their economies collapsed.

I think we need to emphasise that one of the reasons that many countries are defined as developing countries is their own domestic economic policies. So that begs the question: how should we assist these countries? The typical answer, as I have already said, is that we should provide development assistance--we should write out cheques in one form or another for those countries.

I believe that is true in the case of the first category of countries that I described--those countries that do suffer natural disasters and have enormous difficulty in trying to construct a modern economy or even a successful agricultural economy because of the unfortunate natural circumstances in which they find themselves. But I do not think that writing out cheques as a form of providing development assistance is the solution to the problems of the vast majority of developing countries. Those countries can be assisted much more by changes to their own domestic policy structure--and it is very encouraging to see that happening now in Latin America and in parts of Africa. But, also--and this is the burden of my remarks--by opening up the international marketplace for those countries, they can capitalise on the comparative advantages that they have, whether those advantages be cheap land, cheap labour or ones of just natural location where particular types of agricultural products or whatever may grow very successfully.

Unfortunately though, this commitment to trade rather than aid is proving to be a very difficult one to achieve. Indeed, a growing proportion of development assistance is directed towards trade in quite a malicious sort of way, that is, in the form of export subsidies for those developed countries that pretend that they are giving assistance. Indeed, they provide what are described as mixed credits, which are just another form of export subsidy, so that German, British, French or American firms or whoever can gain greater access into the marketplace of Indonesia, Malaysia or wherever it may be. That type of aid is phoney aid. That is an export subsidy that in the long term will not benefit the country providing the subsidy and will not necessarily be to the benefit of a successful global economy.

The final point I make is that the best way for those of us who are outside of those countries to help most developing countries is to open up the international trading system. The World Bank has estimated that, if all tariff barriers were dismantled by developed countries, that would add about 3 per cent per annum to the GDPs of developing countries. In fact, the benefit that developing countries can get from aid through reduction in tariff protection is massively greater than the amount of assistance developed countries will ever provide in the form of cheques under the heading of development assistance.

The OECD provides 0.3 per cent of its GDP in terms of aid. If it abolished tariffs altogether and did what the coalition says it will do when it is in government, that is, reduce tariffs to negligible levels in any case by the year 2000, that would be the equivalent of doubling the aid that the OECD currently gives to developing countries. In this country the $1 billion we spend on aid could be doubled, in terms of benefits to developing countries, by eliminating tariffs to negligible levels by the year 2000.

That side of the compassionate debate on helping people in developing countries is the untold side of the debate by the churches, welfare groups and aid lobbies in this country and it is about time that the churches, in particular, thought about the way trade, not just handouts, can help the disadvantaged in the world. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gorman Mr R.N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Today in the grievance debate I take the opportunity to outline some of the fears that have concerned me for many years. Firstly, the gravest fear I hold is that of the current peace pact which has recently been evolving around us with the elimination of the Cold War between the superpowers. I fear that this will cause a depression throughout the world greater than that of the 1920s and 1930s, with crime, poverty, broken homes and all of the other problems that existed during that part of our history.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to regain and remain the lucky country, as members of parliament we must reverse some of the stupid policies that have created the most serious recession since the 1920s and 1930s and caused the largest pool of unemployment in the past 60 or so years. Various figures have been stated on the present percentage of unemployment. A couple of days ago, the CES cited the number of unemployed at being nearly 13 per cent. If one takes into account males whose spouses have positions and are therefore not eligible to claim benefits, plus the thousands who are listed as being involved in training or retraining, I hope the percentage of unemployed does not rise above 13 per cent.

It is very easy for a person to say, `I have the cure for Australia's unemployment problems'. Well, I am claiming to have part of the cure and I put forward the following proposals for the Government to consider. As a priority, we must build a level playing field. I am convinced that, unfortunately, the Ministers' advisers forgot to remove the covers from the theodolites and levels that they used when pegging out the playing field. We must now realise that the playing field which has been constructed by the Ministry is unlevel. In fact, many Australian producers, manufacturers and exporters are playing the game uphill and are continually finding that the departments, who are really referees, blow their whistles and give the importers or overseas companies another free kick, to the disadvantage of our own companies.

This situation must be stopped and the policies must be revamped to ensure that all Australian companies and manufacturers, and particularly our work force, are protected to the extent that we are, in actual fact, on a level playing field. We demand no more and no less. The playing field, that is the policies of government, must ensure that we have similar conditions to those of our overseas competitors, and must include all countries. Assistance to developing countries should be by way of grants of equipment, material, food products, and in some case cash payments--but should never be at the cost our own labour force.

The most important single item the Government must take action on is lowering interest rates to at least those of our trading partners, which I understand have enjoyed rates between 10 and 12 per cent lower than interest rates charged in this country. This now appears to have been a most stupid policy and must be changed so as to make us truly competitive in all avenues of finance.

We must, as a future priority, endeavour to have all export industries work towards having value added to their exports; move away from overseas companies owning large shareholdings in Australian companies; and rescind the current legislation dealing with reduction of tariffs and retain the 1990 tariff rates. The funds raised from tariffs must go to the industries affected by the imports until such time as these industries are fully equipped with the latest state of the art plant and machinery. Naturally, we are very concerned about the plight of other countries but there is an almost forgotten saying: charity begins at home.

This Government was given the responsibility of making this nation a nation that all of us would be proud of. I personally have difficulties in being proud of this Government or this nation until we again create full employment.

As one employment starter for New South Wales, the Government should undertake the fast track construction of Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek, lift the curfew on Kingsford-Smith Airport until the construction at Badgerys Creek is completed and functioning, then replace the curfew on Kingsford-Smith Airport.

Unfortunately for this nation, Ministers and their advisers seem to believe that all knowledge and ability is confined to them; this is very far from the truth. One could go on and on about ways to improve this nation, but enough said.

Another matter I wish to raise today is the future disaster of industrial relations in New South Wales. The State Government's legislation has brought on the astounding industrial and political situation in New South Wales at present. Some of the things happening in that State indicate what the entire nation can expect if the Federal Liberal and National parties were ever elected to power. In New South Wales, Premier Greiner's era will cost every New South Wales citizen very dearly and will far outlive the short fuse that is rapidly burning underneath Mr Greiner.

The Greiner Government has abused its political responsibility in the most cynical fashion. The Public Service has been destroyed and the public have cried,`Enough, enough'. We had not seen a general strike by the nursing profession in 203 years since the first white settlement, yet the Greiner Government has managed to cause one in just 3 1/2 years. The nurses were not engaged in any selfish pursuit of personal gain; they were striking because the Greiner Government has so smashed the New South Wales hospital system that no more can be tolerated. Their strike will be followed by a general strike in New South Wales on 23 October, which will be led by the public sector unions, including the professional classifications under the leadership of their associations and unions.

What has brought about this incredible situation? The answer is simple: it lies in the failed ideology of the Greiner New Right--a failure that is propped up by an obstinate desire to continue the experiment he started early in 1988. Worse than that, as stated by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in this Parliament, the Greiner Government will not only persist in this ridiculous pursuit of the impossible, but also even continue to knowingly implement the failed policies of the Thatcher era which are the real base of its inept attempts at government.

Mr Greiner's repeated failures are lauded by the Opposition in this Parliament. The Federal shadow Minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), openly stated that he will implement identical policies within eight weeks of taking office, should such a sorry day ever be inflicted on the Australian public. Can one really imagine the chaos that Mr Greiner has created in New South Wales being repeated in the Federal system?

When the New South Wales general strike occurs next week, it will signify the utter failure of Mr Greiner to earn any confidence from the people of New South Wales. The general public has had enough of him. Even his own senior MPs have had enough of the experiment. Loyal public servants have maintained the Westminster tradition over the last 3 1/2 years but it has taken this final massive assault on the Westminster system in New South Wales to bring them to this desperate point. They have no choice. They have no alternative under the Westminster system because that system only ever envisaged men of principle in government. That system did not foresee the day when hospitals would be closed by economic rationalists; when Harvard Business School theorists would replace statesmen; when the blatant politicisation of the public service would be not only allowed but legislated for.

Not satisfied with political appointments in the overloaded Senior Executive Service, Mr Greiner now wants total political direction on a day-to-day basis of every public sector employee. He knows their only protection is via unionism and he is seeking to destroy them by destroying their unions. In that way, he destroys the last chance for the public of New South Wales to learn the truth about what is happening in New South Wales.

I am proud to say that I grew up in the Glebe, which is an inner suburb of Sydney. As a youth I knew it was well worth the effort to try to work in the New South Wales Public Service, where service to the public was the key and men of stature led both the political and administrative areas. It was truly a career to be had and, if one could rise to the upper echelons by dint of hard work in the service of the public, great worth attached to the position.

There will be none of the checks and balances that keep the Westminster system in operation. The twist is that Mr Greiner will accomplish this by using a veneer of industrial legislation to mask the real outcomes he needs to maintain the true secret of New South Wales incorporated. There will never again be a chance to undercover the types of dealings that led to the Eastern Creek raceway affair.

Service to the public has been replaced by contracted collectors of revenue under a user pays system, borrowed from the Thatcher era. Mr Greiner's great industrial experiment is not wanted by the private sector employers nor anybody else. That is why he is hell bent on introducing it to the public sector, where the captive guinea pig can be put into the economic rationalist test program.

God help the public service and the trade unions of New South Wales. When New South Wales is in turmoil over the next week or so, we should look to the real causes of that turmoil. We should be objective. Nurses who have struck for the first time in 200 years are not industrial troublemakers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Over the course of the year, the Parliament has received conflicting advice from the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) regarding the extent of the collapse of the rural research effort flowing from the impact on commodity downturns, the drought and the like. This issue raises larger concerns about the long term stability of the nation's agricultural research effort. Consequently, I wish to direct my comments today during the grievance debate to the need for an innovation strategy for Australian agriculture.

SPEECH.PARA: Regardless of Australia's primary industries' continuing important contribution to the national economy, they possess no defined view of their future, let alone a grasp of how that future might be realised. Largely, the agricultural sector has been prepared to trust its hand and hope that it will all turn out for the better. There has been little systematic effort to forge a genuine community of interest across the agricultural sector. Nor has there been a sustained effort to coordinate the sector's various resources and capabilities to enhance its long term advantages. If nothing else, events continue to demonstrate that the fate of the industry cannot be pinned on periodic surges in international price for raw product alone.

The rural sector must work harder on the domestic front to hone its resources and to develop its capacities. Australia's agricultural capacity, however, is more than just a measure of raw commodity production values. It is a reflection of the chain of influences which effect the efficiency and quality of production and determines the ability of the private sector to expand its share of the global market. Importantly, such influences include the resources which make for innovation in agriculture--particularly the educational base to the rural industry--the levels of activity within the organisational structure of the State and Commonwealth rural research effort, and the orientation of the major funding bodies such as the rural research corporations. It is in the effective coordination of these influences that the innovative capacity of the agricultural sector largely lies.

Presently, each of these influences lives independent of the other and overlooks its role within a larger process which could make for improved prospects for agriculture. For example, the debate over the rural sector's levels of educational achievement and access to educational resources has even wider implication than first appears.

This issue bears directly on the receptiveness of the next generation of farmers to the increasing opportunities provided by developments in technology and business management strategies. Until such time as innovation in agriculture is driven by community demand and is more widely appreciated for the long term advantages it yields, rural research and development resources will remain underutilised. Importantly, changes of this order are critical to the approach of the rural research corporations to their research funding strategies. This, in turn, has a profound impact on the type and quality of research pursued in the longer term interest of the rural sector.

In the absence of the rural community's demand for longer term and strategic research, the rural corporations are shunted into accountability practices that can be tested only against short term goals. That is to say that research grants are increasingly evaluated against their capacity to realise immediate returns. This is not a function of corporatisation or conservative risk management strategies. It is a function of a body which largely reflects the interests and climate of opinion in the community it serves. This process has inevitably distanced rural research corporations from the research agencies which undertake research and on whose expertise agriculture heavily depends. As a consequence, there is little effective coordination between grants and research agencies despite their interdependence.

There has been no effort by commodity-based rural research corporations to fund cooperatively research with widespread application. There are no universally accepted guidelines as to the balance between longer and shorter term grants funded research that corporations feel obliged to undertake, despite the importance of such a balance to the continuing access to high quality research. Moreover, research agencies are not regularly taken into the confidence of the corporation as to their business plans and are unable to structure their research programs in regard to projected demand.

What degree of consultation and planning, for instance, has been undertaken in respect of present and pending falls in research funding flowing from the decline in commodity prices? External funding for grains, meat and wool research has all been wound back, but no attention has been given to its effect on core research capabilities. In circumstances such as these, it is imperative that funding and research agencies jointly formulate priorities and work pro-actively to shield vital resources which have been built up over many years. But, if communication and coordination are absent in these respects, they are even more absent in respect of the area of Commonwealth and State support for rural research.

While aggregate Federal funding has at least reached some stability, State-based support for research is threatened. As State governments are the key sources of funding, cuts by them to research and research infrastructure threaten the nation's agricultural capacity more directly than any other concerns. Yet here too there is a vacuum in respect of initiatives to ensure core regional and national rural research needs are maintained. Cuts might be unavoidable, but they must be managed and coordinated in the longer term interests of the rural sector. To be sure, such a blueprint might well contain the risk of some States freeloading on others or on the Commonwealth.

It is necessary to hope that some maturity of understanding might prevail when the longer term interests of a key industry sector is at stake. In view of these and other problems it is difficult to contend Australia's agricultural industries are at all well placed to build their competitiveness beyond keeping their fingers crossed for sustained falls in exchange rates, interest rates and inflation. Governments, nevertheless, can help in filling the policy vacuum and driving change. The matter of the coordination of the rural research effort ought to rightly take precedence at forthcoming Premiers Conferences and should be subject to closer analysis by the Prime Minister's Science Council. While the Premiers Conference might lay down some working principles for cooperation, the Science Council alone provides the forum for building constructive relationships across the rural research effort. If the existing science and technology administrative machinery is to prove its mettle, here is its chance.

Importantly, there must also be a stronger emphasis placed on rural research skills and education. Given the nature of the problems, the cooperative research centre's program must be reviewed in respect of its capacity to provide for a powerful focus to agricultural science related research and training. There is little purpose in robbing resources from pockets of the rural research sector when the overall research and training capability is, at best, unsteady.

The key function of government is to provide for skills development and research training opportunities. This should be pursued on the basis of providing even more extensive opportunities for industry involvement. Currently, the agricultural sector lacks a beacon for training and research. It lacks an institutional vehicle for expressing its capabilities and communicating its future to the secondary school network.

In an important way, the agricultural sector is still to take its own future in hand. Creative administrative solutions to the problem, as outlined, might yield some returns, but substantive change will not grip until there is a community of views across the agricultural sector as to the role of innovation and change. Though it shoulders unfair burdens relative to other industries in the economy, the agricultural sector cannot afford to fall into despair or to neglect the struggle to consolidate its future. That is a struggle which will be won or lost not by bureaucrats or administrators but by those who are now at work within Australia's primary industries.

—-My question is addressed to the Acting Treasurer. Has his attention been drawn to calls for the Government to take further action to stimulate the economy? If so, what is the Government's reaction to those calls? Finally, is he able to give the House an assurance that economic recovery will occur later this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware of calls from various quarters for the Government to take further stimulatory action, stemming apparently from a belief that recovery will otherwise be too slow. I think that involves a number of apparent misconceptions about the forecast rate of economic activity, about the degree of action already taken to produce recovery, and about the ability of other policies to produce more effective results.

ANSWER.PARA: I will refer briefly to those three points. In relation to the forecast rate of economic recovery, some critics have argued that the rate of growth of GDP this year of 1 1/2 per cent is unacceptably low, especially because it is not high enough to increase employment. I think there is confusion here between growth year on year and growth through the year, because growth through this year, from the June quarter of 1991 to the June quarter of 1992, is forecast to be not 1 1/2 per cent but 3 3/4 per cent, a rate of growth which will certainly mean that in the second half of the year we will be into employment growth--and the Budget forecast is for 1 1/4 per cent growth in employment in the second half of the year, giving an increase in employment of 100,000 in that time. Of course, if that were continued through the whole of 1992, we would have growth in employment of about 200,000. So certainly the Budget and Government policy is posited around a return to economic and employment growth in the near future.

In relation to the action already taken to produce recovery, we have had a substantial budgetary turnaround; an $8 billion surplus in 1989-90 has now become a deficit of $4.7 billion this year. Most of that turnaround, of course, is due to cyclical factors. However, it still represents a budgetary stimulus, much of which has yet to impact on the economy. It will impact on the economy only as we go through the year. We have also had a considerable reduction in interest rates. Since January 1990, cash rates have been cut nine times, and by 8 1/2 per cent. The prime rate has come down from 20 1/2 per cent to 13 1/4 or 13 1/2 per cent. Mortgage rates have come down from 17 1/2 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent, and about half of that interest rate reduction has happened within the last 12 months.

So, with the lags that operate in regard to monetary policy, we are still to have the stimulatory impact on the economy of about half of that action in relation to interest rates. Both budgetary and monetary policy settings have changed considerably, and they are both acting to promote economic recovery with considerable impact yet to come.

Thirdly, there seems to be a belief in some quarters that we can easily accelerate economic and employment growth by adopting more stimulatory budgetary and/or monetary policies. In regard to budgetary policy, let me say that moving to pump priming could produce more economic and employment growth in the short term, but it would only be most likely in the short term, and we would risk aborting the now attainable sustainable long term growth. Adverse reactions in domestic and overseas financial markets to policies that they saw as inflationary and diminishing our national savings effort would be likely to produce countervailing results that could arrest the recovery.

In regard to monetary policy, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank has explained over and over again, interest rate reductions that are not based on reduced inflationary expectations--not just reduced inflation but reduced inflationary expectations--will be very difficult to retain and may well prove counterproductive. So, if we want sustainable lower interest rates, both nominal and real, we have to ensure that inflationary expectations are continuing to trend downwards, and any further interest rate reductions, of course, will have their impact in 1992-93, not in this financial year.

Nevertheless, within that budgetary and monetary strategy the Government is not inflexible; it is prepared to take whatever further action is necessary to accentuate recovery. Of course in that respect I have already referred this week to the review of business tax competitiveness and the review of impediments to major projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Does the Acting Prime Minister agree with the Treasurer's admission in a speech to the International Monetary Fund in Bangkok overnight that Australia has indeed experienced the worst recession in 60 years? Can the Acting Prime Minister explain why the Treasurer did not have the courage to make this admission honestly in front of the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —- When one looks at the issue of recession one looks at the question of recovery. One has to--
—-Is that the best you can do?
—-Order! The honourable member for Flinders!

—-One can take an approach which suggests that it is of some value to the Parliament to make some comparison of different recessions, or one can do something which I think is rather more important; that is, look at the strategies that ought to be adopted by a government when it faces economic difficulties.
—-What about some intellectual honesty for a change?
—-Order! The honourable member for Flinders!
—-No-one in this Parliament--
—-Come clean on the statement.
—-I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—-No-one in this Parliament likes to see a period of extended downturn, and one likes to see even less a period of recession with the hardship it entails, which has been acknowledged again and again in the House. I might say that, when one sees hardship, one can take different responses to it. This Government has sought to deal with the question of hardship as it goes with recession in a way which is compassionate, in a way which has taken account of the impact on people, and in a way which is consonant with the earliest return of people to the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: That is why we have gone to some trouble to put into place a strong social security system that supports those who are most in need. There has never been any question on this side of the Parliament that that is what our priorities ought to be, unlike on the opposite side of the House, where Opposition members have to have a full scale debate, have to abort democracy, and have to come into this Parliament, having failed in their own party room to secure a vote in support--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145. The Minister was clearly asked whether he agreed with Treasurer Kerin's statement and speech in Bangkok. It requires a simple answer--yes or no. Will you direct him back to that question?
—-The Acting Prime Minister is answering the question.

—-Mr Acting Speaker, I was referring to the fact that one can see, as one saw in the recession of 1982-83, a situation in which the level of payments for those who are most disadvantaged is cut; one can see a situation in which the failure to develop wages policy means that a recession would continue for a number of years afterwards.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government, in its response to the recession, has sought to continue with a process of micro-economic reform. We have sought to put into place those policies which will ensure sustainable recovery. There has never been a year comparable to 1991 in terms of putting in place sustainable reform. This is a year in which we have seen major changes to tariff policy. That contrasts with the period in which the Opposition was in government, in which it failed to make any of those hard decisions in that industry area. It is a period in which, in terms of cooperation with the States, we are putting into place a number of significant reforms--whether they be in respect of national freight, the National Road Transport Commission or the power grid--that ultimately will improve the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian industry. At the same time, in the course of the last year we have seen, in terms of the Government's concern for those who are unemployed, a commitment to much greater increases in unemployment benefit payments and payments for training programs.

Of course one can make comparisons but the fact is that there is not a great deal of value to doing so. It is a question of what are one's policies and what policies ought to be pursued as one deals with the current circumstances. As the Acting Treasurer pointed out a moment ago, we have seen the impact of the Government's policies translated into a more optimistic approach to business. As I indicated yesterday, we have seen it in the housing industry, with the prospects of revision upwards of the level of growth. And we can see it in terms of some improvement in the area of retail sales. What we can see emerging is a sense of recovery.

For that recovery to be sustainable, the Government is required to adopt overall consistent policies. The coalition Government lost its nerve during the last recession and failed in its capacity to develop coherent policies. This led to the severity that occurred over a period of time and impacted on people. By contrast, our Government has been able to take the hard and the difficult decisions. We have not baulked at them. Indeed, those decisions represent a coherent policy which will ensure that recovery, as it becomes stronger, is sustainable and that employment growth returns in the first half of next year to provide a basis for building a much stronger economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. What is the Government's strategy for family incomes? How is the Government protecting the incomes of low income families? Can he inform the House of the impact of alternative income strategies on low income families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-The question referred in part to a package announced in this year's Budget which will benefit 200,000 families, particularly primary earners. The family allowance supplement threshold will be increased from $18,000 to $19,000. An assets test of $600,000 will be introduced for family allowances to better target the payment. These reforms were included in legislation that passed through the House last night. I referred in a previous answer to the fact that an assets test at a very high level apparently proved to be extraordinarily contentious in the Opposition party room.

ANSWER.PARA: Family assistance is especially important during a time of recession and high unemployment. The fact that unemployment assistance for the unemployed, particularly for families, has been increased in this Budget is very important. Our families policy has very broad support. It has won this support because it is seen as a very well targeted policy.

During a time of recession, people are particularly sensitive about the treatment of those who are unemployed, particularly families. It is interesting that whereas the Opposition can have the degree of contention that we saw yesterday about the family allowance assets test, the Leader of the Opposition, when speaking to the ACOSS general congress only a couple of weeks ago, made it very clear that he felt that the unemployment benefit, which protects the families of the unemployed--and he quoted the extent of increases that had occurred over the life of this Government--was in fact unwarranted expenditure; that it reflected a preoccupation, as he put it to ACOSS, with welfare, rather than with the situation of people in the work force.

This is where we have a contrast. On the one hand we have members of the Opposition seriously suggesting that the threshold for the assets test should be of the order of $2m; on the other hand, when it comes to those who are unemployed, those who are most disadvantaged, the Leader of the Opposition wanders off to ACOSS and makes it clear that the unemployed are on his hit list.

The Government is committed to preserving and improving family assistance as an area of some priority. That is in contrast to the Opposition, particularly in terms of its lack of concern for the most disadvantaged families, and its willingness to go to a consumption tax without being able to provide any guarantee that those most in need will be protected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is again to the Acting Prime Minister. I refer the honourable gentleman to the statement of Prime Minister Hawke on 14 May this year in the Parliament about the recession of 1982-83, and I quote from Hansard:

QUESTION.PARA: There was a recession then. It was the worst since 1930.
In view of Treasurer Kerin's admission that the current recession was indeed the worst for 60 years, was the Prime Minister stretching the truth in this place on 14 May or was he simply wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think one of the characteristics of this Opposition is that when it comes to fundamental strategies, to saying what must be done, that question rarely can find an answer without dividing the party room. As an Opposition, those opposite have failed to come into this Parliament with any set of coherent policies. They come into the Parliament day in and day out and they are not interested in debating underlying policy approaches or in debating alternative strategies; they are not interested, for example, in justifying how the massive effort that is going into the consumption tax might have some benefit to the Australian people, particularly at a time of recession. They come into the Parliament to make some slick debating point, with no interest at all in the fundamental economic issues which need to be addressed. That might be their approach but it will not get a response from us. We are interested in the economic fundamentals that will govern the recovery. On this basis it is clear that Australia is now well positioned for a sustained recovery in investment, employment and activity.
—-That is not so and you know it.

—-The Leader of the Opposition is trying to indicate that somehow that is not true. I would have thought that it was now becoming clear from a number of economic fundamentals that we are beginning to see a recovery. I referred yesterday at some length--and I am prepared to go into it at some length again--to the housing industry. That fundamental is very important in terms of employment in this country. Unlike in the 1982-83 recession, when housing got down to less than 100,000 starts, we are now looking at 137,000 starts this year and 155,000 next year.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not simply those particular areas of the economy. Because we are seeing for the first time in a very long time the possibility of low inflation being sustainable in this country, inflation at its lowest level in 20 years, that then becomes one of the building blocks on which one can build in terms of being able to sustain a recovery. The gross profit share remains close to the historical highs recorded under this Government. It is well above the levels recorded in any year under the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. The Acting Prime Minister, in his opening remarks, dismissed the question that I put to him and he has simply rambled on since. His answer, Mr Acting Speaker--
—-You are not making a point of order. What is your point of order?
—-His answer is therefore clearly out of order because it is irrelevant to the question by his own admission.
—-The Acting Prime Minister is now answering the question.

—-The question referred to a recession. I am taking the opportunity to point out that in terms of what is now occurring in the economy and what will occur over the next few months, we will begin to see, and we are seeing, the process of sustained recovery. I pointed to a number of the fundamentals--not the debating points but the fundamentals--that are there and that will enable that recovery to be sustainable over the longer term.

ANSWER.PARA: As those characteristics become clearer and stronger, we will see recovery occur; and that recovery will be sustainable in the longer term. That is the issue. It is not about some debating point about what comparisons might be made over long periods of time or how they might be interpreted. It is about whether recovery is well based. As the Acting Treasurer pointed out, the recovery is well based in Australia and, unfortunately for those opposite, who spend most of their time going around talking down the Australian economy, trying to predict that some indicator that might be optimistic is not a basis of recovery in this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. I had great hope when you said the Acting Prime Minister was now answering the question. In fact, I think you had that expectation, too. I ask that you direct the Acting Prime Minister to answer the question that was put to him.
—-I believe the Acting Prime Minister has now completed his answer.

—-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would be aware that cattle producers are experiencing significant problems because of the drought and lower than expected prices. The Minister would also be aware that cattle producers and traders have been objecting to the cattle transaction levy, under which they pay $6.25 towards marketing, research and disease control each time they sell an animal. What is the Minister doing to lower the levy rate and change the levy system so that it does not impact so heavily on producers and traders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for his question. I indicate to the House that I had occasion to visit his electorate some two months ago and the cattle producers in that region raised with me their concern about the form and the amount of the transaction levy. Since that time I have had numerous pieces of correspondence from other producers. I see honourable members from the National Party nodding in agreement about that. It is as a result of those discussions--and, indeed, I commend the role that the honourable member for Page has played in bringing it not just to my attention, but to the industry's attention--that I am in a position to make some comments about this today. There are, in fact, two associated problems that have been raised. One goes to the form of the levy; the other goes to the amount.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the form of the levy, the reality is that the levy falls on producers at each transaction. The allegation that is made--and I think with some justification in relation to some aspects of the industry, particularly the small producers and the traders--is that that is inequitable because some people will pay it only once and others will pay it more than once.

Against that background, given that the form of the levy as well as the component amounts were recommended to us by the industry through the Cattle Council and the Meat Industry Policy Council, I have asked those two bodies to conduct a review, which they are currently undertaking and which will be with me in November. That goes to the question of form.

In relation to the amount, which, as the honourable member indicated, is currently $6.25, I am in a position to inform the House today that from 1 January that rate will fall from $6.25 to $5.00, a 20 per cent reduction. This comes about because of the significant success that has been had with the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. We have reached the stage where those diseases are effectively eradicated. The scheme simply now has to move to a monitoring role and agreement has been reached between the States, industry and the Commonwealth as to the future funding. That therefore enables us to give some immediate relief, quite apart from the review that is currently being undertaken.

I simply conclude on this point: this is another demonstration of where this Government is prepared to listen to genuine concerns and come forward with constructive outcomes. I believe it is good news for the beef producers and I hope that that is recognised by all sides of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. It is a simple question to which there can be a direct answer. Are we or are we not in the worst recession in 60 years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Leader of the Opposition wants to reduce politics down to the sharp debating point. He does not want to get down to, he does not reflect on, he is not interested in and he has no concern for a recovery in the Australian economy, for building that recovery on sure foundations or for debating serious policy issues. All he is interested in is debating points, `yes' or `no' answers--not in the substance of the issue.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have been pointing out and will continue to point out, in terms of the recession, which the Government regrets, particularly the impact of the recession on unemployment, we are now beginning to see quite solid signs of recovery. I have indicated those signs of recovery in the very important area of the housing industry, but I could also have pointed to positive signs of recovery in other sectors. For example, the Westpac Melbourne University index of leading indicators, a widely based barometer of early signs of change, suggests that general recovery is imminent. Consumer confidence is now well above the lows experienced in late 1990. The latest statistics for retail trade show promising signs of recovery.

The foundations, then, for a stronger economy have been laid. We have the right policy settings in place. Official interest rates have been cut by 8 1/2 percentage points since early 1990. Wages growth is being held in check by the accord framework. We are maintaining the structural integrity of the Budget. We are, in fact, on top of inflation, and the current account deficit fell by around 30 per cent in 1991 and will fall further in 1991-92. While the September labour force figures were disappointing, we are confident that the large falls in employment are behind us.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that the Acting Prime Minister is not answering the question that was put to him. It was a simple question: whether we are or are not experiencing the worst depression for 60 years. He is reading from a brief that is obviously a brief for another question.
—-There is no point of order.

—-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. On each occasion that the Acting Prime Minister has been endeavouring to answer a question, he has been persistently interrupted by frivolous points of order. I am suggesting to you that, under standing order 302, the actions of the honourable member for Hume and, indeed, previously the honourable member for Farrer constitute disorderly conduct and that you should take action in that regard.

—-Honourable members have the right to take points of order. The Chair is, however, conscious that they should not lapse into taking points of order to the extent that they become disruptive to the proceedings. I also might make the point, with respect to the point of order taken by the honourable member for Hume, that the Chair is listening carefully to ensure that the Acting Prime Minister does not go over material that he has already gone over in relation to previous answers. Until now, that has not occurred.

—-I am going to some length and I am emphasising the recovery essentially because we have a situation which could well be unique. It could well be unique in this sense: in the history of the Australian economy it has often been marked by cyclical booms and busts, by periods of downturn and upturn, and by a lack of long term stability. When I referred to the housing industry a few minutes ago, I was referring to an example of an industry which, for as long as it has been in existence, has always been subject to cyclical movements. What is true there is generally true of the Australian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: What is required--certainly the Government understands this, and one would hope that the Opposition understands it--is fundamental structural change. It is micro-economic reform in a whole range of different areas. It is a comprehensive process of reform. I believe that the recovery is strong and well based, and could well be the strongest recovery certainly in the postwar period, because it is based on a recognition of the international character of the Australian economy--something that Opposition members resisted in their time in government, even with the advice of a learned professor such as the Leader of the Opposition.

This is a government which, like no other government, has been prepared to tackle tariff reform, a government which has been able to reverse the situation with respect to inflation, and a government which has been able to set in place a number of fundamental reforms that will ensure that recovery is sustainable in the longer term. That is what is important: that recovery is sustainable. That is why I have given the answer to the question so much emphasis.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, it is fortuitous that you have given me the call, because the question which I am going to ask concerns a topic which is close to your heart. I address my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can he advise the House whether reports of significant cuts in sports coverage by ABC radio are accurate? Indeed, many ABC listeners in Perth have indicated their concern to my office. I ask also: was the funding to the ABC broadly maintained in the recent Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is genuinely a question without notice, and I thank the honourable member for it--not much! To get to the latter part of his question first, the position with the ABC, of course, is that the Government is treating it, appropriately, with great generosity in terms of maintaining its real expenditures. In the middle of a recession our preparedness to do that is no small achievement.

ANSWER.PARA: This contrasts quite dramatically with the positions adopted by Opposition spokesmen on matters concerning the ABC, when the best outcome they have suggested for it is substantial cuts; and the ultimate outcome they suggest for it, if they ever get into government, is inclusion in their second tranche of privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And SBS.

—-And SBS. The position that we adopt here is that we wish to maintain a strong and effective national broadcaster. One of the things that the ABC does insist on is that its position ought to be such that Ministers, governments and anyone else cannot interfere with the way in which it chooses to do its programming or, for that matter, the way in which it chooses to organise its finances. As a result of that sort of reorganisation, there has been a substantial impact, I think, on ABC sport. I understand that in the case of Western Australia four people were involved in it. That has been cut down to two, and there are a couple going over to news.

ANSWER.PARA: The ABC, of course, has built up a very substantial phalanx of well-known sports broadcasters in this country, and a diminution of their presence on the airwaves would be a worry to a lot of people. However, as I said, the ABC does have control over the way in which it does things. When I have raised this before with the ABC at the behest of other members of parliament, it has pointed out that Western Australia probably has more local programming in sports than just about any other State. Whether that is sufficient, of course, is another matter, but that is, nevertheless, a fact. As far as the ABC is concerned, Western Australia has more access to local sports. Therefore, I suppose we would notice in Western Australia a cut if that were occurring.

I recognise that the ABC has control over its financial affairs. I note that the Government has been generous to the ABC in its funding arrangements this year. But in the final analysis, the ABC will take decisions about its programming as it sees fit. I am constantly assured by the ABC that it takes note of the views of its valued listeners; that, if people do feel as the honourable member feels about the situation related to sport, they will do some good in persistently writing to the ABC and approaching the ABC about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer him to the stated policy of the Government to promote greater flexibility for workplace arrangements within the present industrial relations system. In view of this, will the Government intervene before the Full Bench of the Industrial Relations Commission next Monday to support the application of Metway Bank Ltd and its staff association for approval, under section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act, of their workplace agreement, which, if approved, will demonstrate that there is a significant new area of flexibility under that Act for workplace arrangements without the need for further amendment of the Act?

—-Of course, it is the policy of the Government to develop a much more flexible industrial relations system and much of what we have done in the last two or three years has been very much to that end. In relation to the particular case that the honourable member refers to, I am not familiar with the claim, but I will refer his question to the Minister for Industrial Relations and get an answer for him.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Has his attention been drawn to comments by the Leader of the National Party that Australian overseas aid ends up in the Swiss bank accounts of dictators? Has he taken any action to investigate these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware of the National Party Leader's extraordinary allegations about misuse of Australian aid funds. I think for the benefit of those who did not hear him--this was a broadcast on ABC Radio National--I will just quote what he said:

ANSWER.PARA: There is a case for aid to our region and specialised aid. But pouring aid into certain countries elsewhere in the world, some of which ends up in Swiss bank accounts of the dictators in the areas involved, others of which end up in political agendas of consequence. I feel very strongly about that and we will be cutting back the size of the foreign aid program.
This was not a statement made by some ratbag backbencher from the National Party, this was a statement made by the Leader of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I know that the honourable gentleman did not intend to treat us with such disrespect, but I suggest that that euphemism should be withdrawn.
—-I am certain it does not help the Minister's answer and I am sure he would withdraw the euphemism about the National Party.

—-I am happy to withdraw it because it was a statement made by the Leader of the National Party, a man supposedly of gravitas and authority. Because, as everyone would agree, those are serious allegations, it was naturally my duty to follow them up; I could not leave them unexplained. So I approached the Leader of the National Party and sought to find out whether there were any specifics to the allegations he had made so that I might take whatever action was appropriate. I regret to say that the Leader of the National Party said that he did not know of any specific case in which Australian aid money had been so treated. In so far as I grasped his explanation, he had simply been referring to general gossip that Western aid money was being used in this way.

ANSWER.PARA: In a program so complex and diverse as the Australian aid program, there is almost certainly going to be some misuse of funds, no matter how good our preventive mechanisms are. If any member of the House has a substantial piece of evidence to bring to bear on any aspect of the program, it is my duty to deal with it. I can assure honourable members that if they present me with that hard evidence it will certainly be followed up. But the unsubstantiated claims made by the Leader of the National Party are simply not worth following up. They are simply an irresponsible attack not only on the integrity of the aid program but also on the integrity of our recipients. Moreover, they show an appalling lack of appreciation of how the program works.

With the exception of PNG, which is a country not ruled by a dictator, Australian bilateral aid is very rarely given in cash, it is usually given in the form of goods and services purchased by AIDAB in Australia. It is impossible to bank those goods and services, even in Switzerland. On occasions where cash grants are used, they are invariably accountable grants for specific purposes. We all know why the Leader of the National Party made these absurd allegations. He made them in order to support the claim by the Leader of the Opposition that aid must be cut back. So what we got was simply a contemptible, cheap and baseless attack on the Australian aid program.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It is a very serious question relating to the wool industry. Can the Minister explain why $6m worth of wool has been removed from the Australian Wool Realisation Commission stocks held in bond in Belgium without payment to the Commission? What steps are being taken to obtain payment for the wool removed from bonded storage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am not in a position to respond to the specifics of the question. I will take that point on notice and come back with an answer. It is a serious issue if what is happening is that wool which is being taken out is not being properly paid for and the consequence of that is to take players from the market.
—-But you will follow it up?

—-Of course I will follow it up. I indicate that there have been some concerns expressed about the role that the Realisation Commission has been playing. I have asked the Realisation Commission for reports in the past and I am in the process of writing to it today because I have had responses which would suggest two things. First, there have been something in the order of 135,000 bales sold from the stockpile, 82,000 of them which, in rough figures, were sold in non-selling weeks. All of the bales have been sold at a premium--a premium above the market, in essence because people are prepared to pay for wool out of the stockpiles held overseas for more speedy delivery.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also told by the Realisation Commission that in practically all circumstances the bales were types of wool that do not compete with that which is being sought on the domestic market. If all of that is true, then it clearly cannot have a depressing effect on the prices for wool at the moment--which are seriously down. In the interests of the wool industry, the sooner those prices are raised the better. But the assertion that I think is inherent in the honourable member's question, that the Realisation Commission is acting irresponsibly, is not founded.

TALK.START.PARA: —-No, stolen.
—-Stolen? I am sorry--if that is the case, I will undertake to find the answer to the specifics of that and come back to the honourable member.

—-I direct my question to the Minister for Science and Technology. Can the Minister advise the House of the progress towards implementation of the cooperative research centres program? What are the objectives of that program? Is the Minister satisfied that those objectives are being achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The cooperative research centres program was announced by the Government in March of last year. The program envisages the selection of up to 50 CRCs at a cost to the Commonwealth rising to $100m per year. The objectives of the program include the following: to support long term, high quality scientific and technological research which contributes to national objectives, including economic and social development, the maintenance of a strong capability in basic research and the development of internationally competitive industry; to capture the benefits of research; and to strengthen the links between research and its commercial and other applications.

ANSWER.PARA: It was always intended that there would be three selection rounds for CRCs. The first round saw the selection of 15 centres. These were announced by my predecessor in May of this year. Honourable members may be aware that today I have released a statement indicating funding arrangements for those 15 centres. Those details indicate that the Commonwealth has committed nearly $30m per year to fund those centres. Participants in the centres are providing resources totalling $345m over the contract period. Industry's commitment is almost $60m, with expectations of at least an additional $15m over the contract period. The second round is currently under way and an announcement of the successful second round applicants will be made by the Government in December. The third round will be conducted in 1992.

The program to date has achieved much and is soundly based. Honourable members, however, may be aware of my recent speech at the ANZAAS congress when I said in part that I was not currently persuaded that the program had to date successfully focused on achieving a commercial outcome from research. I am, however, confident that that will occur. The CRC program as a whole must have appropriate and real industry participation and a clear focus on the commercialisation of research, although in some centres the most relevant research users may be Commonwealth and State agencies. I will be meeting tomorrow with the CRC committee as part of the second round process. That process is not a static operation; refinements on the way will ensure the program's success in achieving its objectives.

In addition, consideration is currently being given to the guidelines for applicants for the third and final round of CRCs. These guidelines will be a clear signal to industry that the Government's focus for the program is on industry participation and on the commercialisation of research. That is a signal which industry must pick up. Industry participation in CRCs is a two-way street. So far as the Government is concerned, the signpost is quite clear from our perspective. I trust that industry will proceed accordingly and will take up the initiative. The program is an exciting one in which industry must participate and maximise the national benefits which flow from it. The CRC program is a great initiative of this Government. It has not been easy to implement but constant attention is being given to ensure that it successfully meets its objectives.

I note in closing that, as is quite often the case, the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Gippsland, is behind the pace on this issue. I refer to the September issue of the respected science journal Search, where the honourable member is reported as saying that his main concern was with the heavy emphasis on commercialisation of science, possibly at the expense of basic research in universities. His view is less commercialisation, not more. I trust that in this, as in other areas, the honourable member for Gippsland will continue his tradition of getting on the correct policy line some two or three months after everyone else.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mrs Gallus proceeding to address a question to the Acting Prime Minister--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

—-Has the Minister for Transport and Communications seen comments proposing an agenda for reform on the waterfront, aviation and telecommunications? In addition to the measures already in train, what other action could be taken to further reform those areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have seen references made by the Leader of the Opposition to the area of micro-economic reform. Yet again last night he stood up in this place and gave his usual litany. He said, `We will reform aviation, we will reform the waterfront and we will reform telecommunications'. We have never heard how he proposes to do it. We have some sort of indication on this. We got the notion that he will introduce troops on the waterfront. That is one of his great schemes that he intends to bat on with. That is the sole indication thus far of what changes he expects to see there.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the reforms that we have introduced on the waterfront, we are now getting very good productivity gains--far better than we anticipated, so much so that virtually by the end of this year the performance on our waterfront will be up to the standards that are being experienced now in some European and Japanese ports because the reforms have produced 70 per cent improvements in productivity. Of course, that has been accompanied by a large number of people--1,800 to this point--leaving the waterfront.

There are substantial changes taking place there on the only basis on which changes can effectively take place; that is, they are jawboned--somebody sits down and does the solid, hard yakka of talking his way through with the waterside workers and with the union movement generally. The Opposition has absolutely no view about how that ought to be done. Then we go into the area of telecommunications. All that we have actually heard from the Opposition on reform in the area of telecommunications is a notion of privatising Telecom. Anybody who has studied any of the areas where privatisation of the main carrier has been made the principal focus of reform will know that that principal focus of reform and privatisation inevitably means that decisions are taken persistently over time to favour the main carrier in order to ensure that a proper price is achieved on behalf of the taxpayers' investment.
