TALK.START.PARA: —-For the information of honourable members, I present a report by the Australian Science and Technology Council, ASTEC, entitled Research and Technology: Future Directions.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a statement on the report.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In May 1989 a Government statement, Science and Technology for Australia, set out in a comprehensive manner the Government's approach to science and technology. Following on from this, ASTEC's 1990 report, Setting Directions for Australian Research, recommended that the Government's approach to science and technology policy formulation be continually refined and developed by way of a rolling four year review process through which broad national directions for science and technology policy could be set.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequently, the Government asked ASTEC to prepare an issues and options report which would prepare the way for the first White Paper on Science and Technology, due to be tabled in May of next year. Research and Technology: Future Directions is ASTEC's response to this request.
While providing the foundation on which the White Paper will be built, this report will not be the sole contributor. Others will include:
ASTEC's current review of the need for major national research facilities;
the continuing work of the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology;
discussions at the Prime Minister's Science Council; and
consideration of the conclusions of the two task forces which are examining the commercialisation of research.
I expect to receive the report of the group chaired by Mr Ray Block by the end of the month.

ASTEC's production of Research and Technology: Future Directions has required an unprecedented level of consultation with those who have an interest in the direction of research and technology policy in Australia. This included the review of nearly 200 submissions, meetings in all major capital cities, and an intensive interview program with over 100 top level managers in industry and government. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to ASTEC and its secretariat for their dedication and persistence in carrying through this task. In many ways the consultative process has been as important as the report itself, by involving so many across the nation in considering future directions for science and technology.

Following release of the report, ASTEC has arranged for the consultation process to continue through discussion sessions being held across the nation. The contents of ASTEC's report range widely across all national areas where research and technology can be brought to bear. The principal issues and options fall under five main headings:
research, technology and international competitiveness;
energy and environment;
the quality of Australian life;
managing Australia's research resources; and
the role of the Commonwealth and States in research and technology policy.

This report, and the debate which it will stimulate, will be a major input to the White Paper process of shaping the future directions of research, science and technology policy in Australia. It will have a substantial impact on the future development of science and technology in Australia and at the same time will contribute to lifting the level of awareness of the important role that science and technology can play in meeting national goals.
I urge all honourable members to give consideration to the report and to the White Paper process which will culminate in its tabling in this House in May next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--This report, Research and Technology: Future Directions, represents an enormous investment in time and resources, not just by ASTEC, but by the scientific and technological community, which so generously contributed to the processes which have culminated in the report. A cursory glance at appendix B of the report in fact provides an appreciation of the scope of that participation. It also affords a useful insight into the enormous range of activity across the science and technology related research effort. The report has considerable value. It has distilled a wide variety of concerns across the community in respect of the capacity and condition of the research base.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some who would no doubt say ASTEC's report, as tabled today, has daringly rediscovered the wheel, though only in generalised terms. But there is considerably more to the report than this. The report does confirm some longstanding and continuing concerns on the coalition's part with the structure and balance of the nation's research effort. This is particularly so in regard to the necessity, as outlined in the report, for governments to ensure there is appropriate balance within the research effort between market and knowledge or curiosity driven research, which the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) touched on in Question Time; to provide greater opportunities for coordinating more research programs and resources at the State and Federal levels; to guarantee the research effort has the capacity and the flexibility to respond to changing national needs; and to provide a national economic environment conducive to longer term investment by the private sector in research and development.

The report has also called for closer attention to priority setting processes at the national level. Whether or not ASTEC has been successful in articulating its intentions and designs in this regard will be left for later judgment. Notwithstanding this, the issues of priority setting and balance are important to the scientific and technological community. Unlike small business or the agricultural community, whose role in the life of the nation is relatively easily mapped out, there are a range of expectations about the role of scientific researchers and the like.

In this regard it is necessary that the research effort retain a high degree of flexibility, diversity and autonomy in the nation's research effort. The themes of autonomy, diversity and flexibility are far from simple slogans. They are very tangible characteristics of an effective national research effort.

In times of economic difficulty, when the competition for resources is at fever pitch, there are temptations to reach for simple solutions. In such periods, politicians and bureaucrats suddenly find courage to drag into the main game ideas which once sat listlessly on the boundary of their thinking. For example, channelling resources into pre-specified or administratively predetermined industries for value adding or, in particular, so-called emerging technologies, are cases in point. The capacity of a government driven administrative process for achieving meaningful industry or technology development outcomes is questionable to say the least. Issues such as this finally turn on much deeper structural issues. ASTEC is not unaware of this.

The ASTEC report has conceded that the economic environment in which the private sector seeks to build its competitiveness is critical in determining its rate of adoption of technological inputs. To illustrate the point, I refer the House to page 5 of the report, which states:

The private sector must continue to be encouraged to fund and perform more of the nation's research and technology effort if we are to derive maximum economic and social benefits from our resources in these areas. At present, higher levels of investment by the business sector in research in Australia are being inhibited by the financial environment within which firms operate. Long-term, higher risk investments are discouraged by the structure of the tax system, high interest rates and a poorly developed venture capital market. Removing these and other impediments to achieving a better integrated and more effective research and technology system should be a priority for governments in the 1990s.

I also remind the House that predetermined priority setting processes at the national level do have longer term ramifications for the way in which scientific and technological resources are distributed to objectives. Once the issue of targeting available resources to predetermined industry sectors or emerging technologies is let loose, the larger, traditional roles of science and technology in the community are threatened.

Drawing to a conclusion, the report will also provide an important point of reference within which policy debates will take place in the future. The report is also accessible and structured in such a way as to allow it to infiltrate popular discussions about the role of science and technology in regard to wider economic, social, educational and environmental issues. In this respect, the report will also hopefully serve to raise the awareness across the community, including the business sector, of the very significant and real advantages which Australia's scientists and engineers return to the nation.
