TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--The Uruguay Round is now in its fifth year. It was, and remains, a bold and ambitious endeavour--a unique opportunity to build a fairer and more durable international trading system for the 1990s and beyond. These are difficult negotiations, but to those who say that it is too hard and to those who suggest we should settle for some cosmetic quick fix, let me offer another perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: In the five years that the Uruguay Round has been under way, eastern Europe and Latin America have undergone radical political and economic restructuring. The Soviet Union is set to join them. There have been massive advances in general disarmament, and nuclear disarmament is no longer just a hope but an emerging reality. The environmental protection of the Antarctic has been addressed, with an ambitious outcome, by the international community. Peace is imminent in Cambodia, and the United Nations has again become a force to be reckoned with in world affairs. All of those things have taken place since the commencement of the Uruguay Round.

Some of the most intractable problems of the twentieth century have been resolved with political courage and commitment. Against such a background, no-one can claim with any credibility that reform of world trade is beyond us.

The Uruguay Round now needs its share of political courage and commitment as the negotiations enter a final and decisive stage in the weeks ahead. If the political decisions are not made by mid-November, the Round cannot be completed by March 1992. It would simply drift into 1993, and then the chances of resuscitation would be at best doubtful.

If I may recap for a moment, honourable members will be aware that the Uruguay Round broke down in Brussels in December last year when the European Community failed to seriously engage across the negotiating table. Agriculture became the pivotal issue as the Cairns Group and others declared, `No agriculture, no deal'. After a fragile re-start to the negotiations in February and the extension of the United States' fast track negotiating mandate in May, leaders of the Group of Seven leading industrialised nations took an important stand in July. The Cairns Group had called on the G7 to rise above the rhetoric and ambiguity of its past involvement and make a constructive contribution to the negotiations.

The G7, which includes four key members of the European Community, did so, signalling a clear advance in its attitude to the Uruguay Round. The G7 leaders also pledged to intervene in the process again if necessary, putting their authority and credibility on the line--and their intervention may yet be required. In recent days there has been another encouraging development. The German Government has declared that it will seek to secure much needed elbow room for the European Commission negotiators to achieve an outcome on agriculture.

These important developments must lead to serious and constructive negotiations, particularly those dealing with agriculture. It is time to break out of the `dialogue of the deaf', as GATT Director-General, Arthur Dunkel, has previously described the negotiations. Arthur Dunkel is providing that opportunity. He has laid down a program of intensive negotiations this month which it is intended will culminate in the tabling next month of a paper covering all aspects of the negotiations. In the weeks ahead all participants must look at their negotiating positions and show the flexibility required for Mr Dunkel and his colleagues to fashion credible compromises across all aspects of the Uruguay Round.

If we are to achieve a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round, this paper must contain the essence of an outcome to the Uruguay Round--it must reflect the tough political decisions which are now required. And if the major powers are not capable of making those decisions, the Director-General will have no alternative, if the Round is to have any hope of success, but to table this paper on his own authority on a `take it or leave it' basis. It is now make or break time in the Uruguay Round.

Australia has put much effort into achieving progress in the negotiations and will continue to do so. As honourable members will be aware, I have just returned from leading a delegation to Europe which included colleagues from the other side of the House and the National Farmers Federation. We left no-one in any doubt as to the serious need for a substantial outcome to the Uruguay Round.

I might add that the Government greatly appreciates the bipartisan commitment which exists on this issue. Similarly, our role in the Uruguay Round has been greatly enhanced by the support and involvement of the Australian farm and business communities. My colleague the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has this week told the world's finance Ministers meeting at the International Monetary Fund in Bangkok that there is no more pressing need on the international agenda than a substantial result from the Uruguay Round.

The Treasurer correctly asserted that reconstruction of the economies of eastern Europe and the Soviet Union will be greatly assisted by the reform of world agricultural trade and reductions in protectionism. A failure to achieve this would be a repudiation of their courageous moves towards democracy and more open economies.

Last week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) discussed the Uruguay Round at length with German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Harare this week impressed upon UK Prime Minister, John Major, and his Canadian counterpart, Brian Mulroney, the importance of heads of government taking a leading role in moving the negotiations forward. The Prime Minister stressed to these key leaders the necessity for heads of government to give the Round the necessary impetus required for a successful conclusion. In particular, Arthur Dunkel must have the authority to produce a paper which delivers the major breakthroughs that we are all looking for.

The Prime Minister has informed me that the level of commitment of Chancellor Kohl and Prime Ministers Major and Mulroney to the Round is most encouraging. Indeed, since the discussion with Chancellor Kohl, the German Government has indicated that it will seek to ensure a successful outcome to the Uruguay Round by urging the European Commission negotiators to show the flexibility required to achieve such a result. There is a growing awareness of what is at stake. The Prime Minister will continue to be actively engaged in the Round at heads of government level in the coming crucial weeks.

There is a different atmosphere surrounding the Uruguay Round this year from that which prevailed pre-Brussels. But I must say that while we welcome the signs of flexibility which are slowly emerging, we must also reiterate that only a substantial result right across the Uruguay Round will ensure success. The European Community must move beyond its position at the Brussels meeting last year on agriculture. The Japanese, who have benefited so much from the growth in trade in industrial goods under the GATT, must accept the need for comprehensive reform of agricultural trade. The United States must reconsider its position on services. The developing world must be assured of tangible benefits from reform of textiles trade, agricultural trade and trade in tropical products in order for it to make the commitments required to protect intellectual property rights and secure a services framework.

With our Cairns Group colleagues in the agriculture negotiations, we stand ready with the flexibility we have shown throughout these negotiations to strike a deal which will deliver long term gains to the nation's farmers. But that deal must include some fundamental elements. The corruption of world agricultural markets caused by export subsidies must be turned back. Those markets and products which have escaped this iniquitous trade distortion must remain free of export subsidisation.

Border protection must only be delivered through tariffs and be subject to firm reduction commitments. Market access must increase over time. The link between internal support and production must be broken and support delivered in a way which will not encourage the production of surpluses which are then subsidised into international markets. Such a fundamental restructuring of agricultural support and protection should ensure that, over time, world market prices start to influence production decisions, and efficient and competitive farmers like those in Australia have a fair go in the international marketplace.

Lest there be any illusions that Australia is a single issue country preoccupied with agriculture, I would like to comment on several other aspects of the Uruguay Round negotiations. An agreement on trade in services will provide some much needed ground rules by which this growing area of economic activity, both for Australia and for the world, can be conducted with certainty and an equality of opportunity. As such, the integrity of a services agreement must not be undermined by a weak application of the `most favoured nation' principle, and we look to the United States to take a more forthcoming and forward looking stance on this issue.

Most favoured nation treatment is a fundamental principle of the GATT which ensures that access granted to one country, in this case to provide services, is granted to all countries. Australia was amongst the first countries to table an offer in the services negotiations. We agreed to maintain existing access to, and not introduce further regulations in, those service industries covered by our offer. After much consultation with industry and State governments, we are now preparing a revised offer which will be among the best on the table in Geneva.

But this offer on services will only remain on the table if other countries are forthcoming with offers of value to Australia. We have made requests on 21 of our key trading partners for the lifting of impediments to the growth of Australian service industries overseas. These cover such activities as financial services, tourism, telecommunications and professional services.

As Australia becomes more of a clever country it will benefit from the stronger protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights being negotiated in the Uruguay Round. Breaches of copyright on sound recordings, for example, are already costing Australians millions of dollars annually in export income. The protection of patents to retain the benefit of Australian design ingenuity is also dependent on a good outcome in the TRIPS negotiations. Patent applications lodged in foreign countries by Australia have grown from 5,000 in 1983 to 17,000 in 1989.

In the more traditional GATT activity of market access negotiations, Australia is also strongly placed. In an effort to stimulate much needed industry restructuring in Australia, the Government has dramatically cut tariffs on two occasions during the course of the Uruguay Round. While these tariff cuts benefit foreign suppliers, the ultimate value to our trading partners is the extent to which Australia is prepared to give a commitment that tariffs will not rise again in the future.

Put another way, Australia has accumulated significant `negotiating coin' in being able to decide at what levels it will bind its tariffs in the GATT--and that decision will only be taken when our trading partners have shown their hand. Australia has far exceeded the Uruguay Round target for a bound one-third cut in tariffs but to date only about 10 countries have reached that mark. Many countries are waiting for advances in the agriculture negotiations before exposing their manufacturing industries to greater import competition.

Achievement of that one-third tariff cut goal would save Australian exporters about $750m in import duties alone--even before taking account of the improved market access which would flow from such an outcome. Australia's requests for tariff cuts range from zinc alloy into the United States, car parts and breakfast cereals into Asia-Pacific markets and toothbrushes into Thailand, to mention just a few.

Elsewhere in the Uruguay Round, Australia continues to resist efforts to prohibit certain industry policy measures which have a local content criteria or are linked to export performance. Australia has argued that such policies can complement industry restructuring and that only the trade distorting effects of trade related investment measures--or TRIMS as they are known--should be addressed in the GATT. The likely outcome of those negotiations is as yet unclear.

Australia is also active in negotiations dealing with GATT rules and institutions, arguing for further improvement to the GATT dispute settlement procedures. Our objective is to reduce the capacity of countries to impose their own solutions to trade problems to the detriment of the multilateral trading system.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have highlighted several aspects of the Uruguay Round negotiations to indicate that Australia has interests which extend well beyond agriculture. But the key to a satisfactory outcome to the Uruguay Round remains agriculture. It is vital in the weeks ahead that our negotiating partners take the initiative in this area in order to bring this most important round of negotiations to a successful conclusion.

We have come a long way in the Uruguay Round but there is much difficult terrain yet to be negotiated. The Round will not be a panacea for all our trade problems but it is a rare opportunity to take a big step towards a more open trading world. It offers opportunities and benefits not only for countries like ourselves but also for those which have taken the bold steps towards political and economic reform. And to the extent that some industrialised nations might be inclined to stand in the way of reform, they should be put on notice that their credibility and integrity is on the line. The reform of world trade, particularly agricultural trade, must not be put in the too hard basket. It is now time to get on with the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--The coalition welcomes the statement on the Uruguay Round that has been made by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett). As the Minister pointed out in his statement, we have given our strong support to Australia's role in pursuit of a successful outcome of the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations.

SPEECH.PARA: I want the Government to remember that it should not underestimate the value of bipartisan support on an issue such as this. When one goes out into the Australian community, one finds that people are profoundly sceptical, one could say cynical, about the Uruguay Round. We could have made cheap political capital by criticising the emphasis of the Government's trade policy on the Uruguay Round.

Nevertheless, the truth is that the Uruguay Round is the main game in international trade. Our resources must overwhelmingly be devoted to ensuring a successful outcome. It would have been very much to our discredit if we had done anything but what we have done, that is, given our strong support to the efforts of the Government in this area. When the Government may not have thought of initiatives, we have tried to produce creative ideas and proposals. For example, we put forward the proposal for bipartisan delegations--one to the United States in the context of the export enhancement program and another recent one to the European Community. Last December we asked whether we could participate in the Australian delegation to the Brussels final conference and, after careful consideration, the Minister decided that it would not be appropriate. We were disappointed at that, given the strong support we had given to the Government's position. We hope that the Government will change its position if a ministerial delegation is to participate, as inevitably it will, in the final throes of the Uruguay Round.

On this side of the House, as is the case with the Government, we well and truly recognise that the Uruguay Round is the most important single issue on the international agenda. I might say very briefly that it disappoints me that there are only four members in the House--and three or four people and a school group in the gallery--to take note of a discussion on an issue as fundamental as this to the future of our country and the global trading system. The fact is that this is the most important single issue on the international agenda. I acknowledge the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). He is one of the members who have taken a particular interest in this issue.

Let me say that we should not underestimate the enormous cost to the international community of failure in the Uruguay Round. It could be the trigger that will lead to the creation of hostile trading blocs. It could lead to substantial increases in protection tariff and non-tariff protection. It could lead, and almost certainly would lead, to the exacerbation of the already very damaging trade wars through the process of using export subsidies. It could even lead to the collapse of the GATT system. There is no doubt that if the Uruguay Round does collapse--and there is a danger that that could happen--it will be an economic catastrophe for the whole world, in particular for developing countries, the countries which in my view have the most to gain from a successful outcome from the Uruguay Round.

As the Minister pointed out, from Australia's point of view at the heart of the Uruguay Round is agriculture. When one looks at the state of international agriculture and its impact on Australia, it is clear why that is the case. The OECD's annual report on international farm policies for 1991 said that farm subsidies rose by 12 per cent in 1990 because a number of industrialised countries, in particular the European Community countries and the United States, had failed to adopt meaningful reforms.

The report argued that the downward trend in farm subsidies during 1988-89 had been only temporary. The previous year's OECD report found that farmers in the world's 24 richest countries received $2 in every $5 they earned by way of aid in one form or another. Farmers in Australia and New Zealand, however, received less than 10 per cent of their income in assistance, compared with 75 per cent in Japan, 38 per cent in the European Community and 27 per cent in the United States. But the European Community's farm assistance is more insidious than Japan's, because the European Community's assistance to farmers affects third markets in a way that the Japanese assistance does not. A 1988 study by the European Commission found that agricultural subsidies cost the equivalent of over $US14 billion in national payments alone, while EC-wide payments cost a further $US36 billion. Indeed, EC export subsidies for wheat are now higher than the underlying value of the product.

These farm subsidies distort international trade and make it essential for countries like Australia, New Zealand and other Cairns Group countries to continue to seek multilateral solutions to the levels of agricultural protection existing in other countries. For that reason, Australia and other Cairns Group countries have had to push very hard on the issue of agriculture in the context of the Cairns Group. Estimates vary as to the gains that could be made from a worldwide liberalisation of trade in agriculture, but it is said that the liberalisation could bring price rises of between 27 and 61 per cent for dairy products and 15 to 27 per cent for beef. It has also been said that there would be a higher level of production in response to higher prices--which I think is fairly obvious--but that higher levels of production would take place where the comparative advantage lay, in efficient agricultural producing countries such as our own, and not in such countries as those in the European Community, where high levels of production are maintained through trade distortion.

It is, then, very unfortunate that the European Community has not readily recognised the obvious advantages to the international trading system of making meaningful concessions in the area of agriculture. Nevertheless, Australia must retain the position that it has taken since last year, and which the United States and the Cairns Group have taken, that without a deal on agriculture which is meaningful and of substance, there can be no successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round. That is a message that the Europeans in particular must well and truly understand.

I actually believe that the Australian Government and the Cairns Group have tried very hard in almost every way imaginable to achieve that result. The Government produced a booklet which was distributed around the European Community recently. It antagonised some of the European governments, but I thought it was a good small step to take in trying to highlight the damage that the Europeans were doing to their own consumers and to Europe's position in the world. I have already mentioned the bipartisan delegation, and I would add to what I have said on that, that we were disappointed that the Government would not agree to heads-of-government level delegations but instead took lower-level delegations.

I welcome the comments the Minister has made about the goodwill that has been expressed by the British Government. Indeed, Britain's record has always been good through the Uruguay Round on the issue of agriculture. But goodwill is now also being expressed by the Germans, and such goodwill has traditionally been expressed by the Dutch. The moment of hard decision on agriculture, however, is imminent. When the European Community finally does come back with its offer, it will put all of us in the very difficult position of having to assess whether we can accept that offer or say that the European Community clearly is not serious about concluding the Uruguay Round. The fact is that it will be a hard moment of decision, and I hope that the Government will consult the Opposition very closely on the nature of the offer from the Europeans, because clearly it would be preferable if the response to that offer could be of a bipartisan nature; otherwise, it may indeed place Australia's position in some difficulty. But, of course, the responsibility for that rests ultimately with the Government. That is an advantage of being in government, no doubt.

The Minister referred to other areas of importance in the Uruguay Round, and there is no doubt that Australia has been right to take the position that it was not a single issue country. We have worked hard in the area of mineral resources trade to try to get better access for our coal into the German, British and Japanese markets. I think the Government has done a credible job in the field of services, recognising the importance of the service industries to our own country and the potential that we have there. It has given high priority to intellectual property. As the Minister said, we have great gains to make with a successful agreement on intellectual property in areas such as sound recordings, literature and computer software.

The issue of market access has always been an important one to us. We may argue that the Government has not given a strong enough commitment to reducing tariffs between now and the year 2000 and that those tariffs should be reduced to negligible levels across the board, but one cannot complain about the fact that the Government is heading at least in the right direction. In the context of the Uruguay Round, our offer is amongst the most intelligent and the best.

This is one of the areas where we believe that the Government--I almost choke on the words--has done a good job. It was certainly a success to play its part in bringing together the Cairns Group some years ago. That Group has certainly taken up the bipartisan hand that we have extended to it in the context of bipartisan missions, and I think it has had some limited success. It has helped to make Australia's point. I think that the way we have been able to address the Uruguay Round as a national effort rather than as a partisan effort has been very helpful to our country and to the cause that we have been pursuing in the Uruguay Round.

I approach the last few months of the Uruguay Round--I believe that they are the last few months--with some optimism. I think there is a good chance that the Europeans will recognise the challenges that lie ahead of them and the benefits that could accrue to Europe from a successful outcome of the Uruguay Round. It is important for the whole world that the Uruguay Round succeeds, and I wish the Government well in its endeavours over the next few months to ensure that we play our part as a middle ranking power in obtaining a successful resolution to those problems.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bill was returned from the Senate without amendment:
Family Law Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The gross economic mismanagement of the Government which has resulted in Australia's worst recession for 60 years.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Ever since the last election this Labor Government has subjected the people of Australia to a farrago of lies and deception in its vain attempts to deny the existence of the recession that it created as a deliberate act of government policy. It has taken only 3 1/2 months for the new Treasurer (Mr Kerin) to put himself into his predecessor's league. While the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) will be long remembered by the Australian people as the Treasurer who had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the precipice of honesty in relation to the recession that he had engineered, the present Treasurer will be remembered as the man who did not have the courage to stand in the Australian Parliament to address the Australian people and tell them honestly about the state of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer has branded himself a coward by his own act. What he said last night is of great significance to the future of this country. In one simple sentence, without equivocation, the Treasurer admitted for the first time that we are in the worst recession that this country has faced for 60 years. That is an important statement. It is important because we will not have the change that we need in this country unless people have a sense of the gravity of our circumstances. As long as this Government continues to deceive people about what is wrong with this country, it will delay the changes that so obviously are necessary. As the Government delays the changes for its own political ends, it simply ensures that the damage caused to the Australian economy will be very great indeed.

Mark my words, the Government will scar this generation and the next generation of Australians for decades to come unless it wakes up to itself about the gravity of the crisis that it has inflicted upon this country. This country is literally drifting, as the demand and need for change passes this Government by and as the Government, in an introspective way, concerns itself with one thing: the job of the Prime Minister instead of the jobs of nearly one million unemployed--one million unemployed as a result of the Government's policy.

This country is going to have to make some changes. We either make them now ourselves and minimise the costs or we wait until a greater adjustment is literally forced upon us as a result of our circumstances deteriorating further. This country has a chance to consider its circumstances, realistically assess where it is and then drive on for the changes that will the Australian people some glimmer for the future.

Our problem today is that this country's leadership is gripped by complacency. We have two sectors in the Australian economy. The government sector, and all the apparatus that surrounds government, is controlling and making the policy and living off the second sector, the free enterprise sector, upon which the great majority of Australian men and women and families depend for their living standards. The Government, as a deliberate result of its policy, which it has admitted publicly, has set out to crush the private sector to the great disadvantage of those very families.

So this admission by the Treasurer last night is critical. It is an admission that the reality of our circumstances is that there is the chance to build up a consensus, a gathering, a momentum for change in this country, which it so desperately needs. It is a chance to inject a sense of urgency about what has to be done in this country in the future. Does it not rather remind honourable members of the banana republic statement of 1986? That was one of the few good things the last Treasurer did. In one frank moment--one crack, as it were, in the facade--we got an honest statement about what needed to be done. Since then, we have had nothing but a litany of lies about where this country has been going.

First we were told that there would be a soft landing. The Minister for Finance and Acting Treasurer (Mr Willis), who is at the table, was in the business of peddling that untruth to the Australian public. Then the Government had the gall to say, `There will be no recession'. It constantly pounded away with the words, `There will be no recession'.

When we got to the election in 1990, the Prime Minister said, `There is no reason to fear a recession'. Do honourable members remember those words, along with the untruth about there being no deal with the ex-Treasurer about the leadership of this country? The Government went from, `There is no need to fear a recession' to the arrogance of the former Treasurer, who said that he would not let there be a recession. That was a classic. That one, of course, disappeared into history.

When the figures had proven beyond doubt that the country was in a recession, the former Treasurer had the gall to say, `This is the recession we had to have'. For heaven's sake, what gullibility does the Government ascribe to the Australian people? What a cheek. What an impertinence to imply that the Government had some sense of control over the Australian economy. Now we have, `Not as bad as 1982-83'--another one of the Government's favourite lines. Have we not had that one rammed down our throats?
The former Treasurer, not one to mince his words--when he was standing shoulder to shoulder with the Prime Minister, honourable members might remember--on 30 May 1991, said:
So it is not true to say that this is the worst recession in 60 years, because the worst recession in 60 years was in 1982-83. There it was, and there are the statisticians' figures to prove it.
That is not true. He ought to be in here as the second speaker in this debate to defend the allegation made against him that he in fact deceived the Australian people.

The Prime Minister is not too bad on hyperbole as well. He has been running the line for months and months that the recovery is coming. In December last year he was talking about the recovery and the pick-up in the housing sector. He was saying the same thing nearly 12 months ago that he was saying just last week before he went off to CHOGM. In December 1990 he said:
All those statistical facts show that the recessed condition of the Australian economy at this time is nothing like what it was in 1982-83.
That is not true. That is clearly untrue. That is a falsehood.That is clearly deceiving the Australian public about the state of the economy.

I must say that I was taken aback by the Acting Prime Minister today. We asked him a very simple question--`Do you agree or don't you agree with the Treasurer that Australia is in the worst recession for 60 years?. Are we or aren't we?'. Do honourable members know what he said in his answer? He said, `When I think of recession, I think of recovery'. It is a classic. When someone confronts him with the problem, his natural thought, coincidently, is to start talking about the recovery; to deny the existence of that which the Government itself has created.

By all means, let us look to see whether there is a recovery. It is true that housing has picked up a bit. The other one the Acting Prime Minister mentioned was retail figures. They have picked up a bit. I think it was the Managing Director of David Jones who said the other day that the reason they had picked up was that people had been selling at low prices just to keep themselves in business. Do honourable members notice how the Government avoids the fundamental things in our economy?

TALK.START.PARA: —-Investment.

—-Investment--as the honourable member for Bennelong rightly says. The Government itself is pretending that it is going drop by 10 1/2 per cent. Private sector forecasters say that it is going to drop by 17 or 18 per cent. The propensity of Australians to save is at an all-time record low. I say to the Minister that one does not need an economics degree to know that unless we have investment for the future in this country there will be no sustained recovery. It is as simple as that. The ANZ Bank's figures show that job ads are down 3 per cent. The latest bankruptcy figures are up 55.4 per cent. The latest unemployment figures are 10.2 per cent and rising, even on the Government's own figures. And it is not just 872,000 who are unemployed; nearly 1.4 million Australians are unemployed or underemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer himself said that there is a depression in parts of rural Australia--and there is. Only today and last night the second message came from afar. Mr Chambers, of Standard and Poor's, talks about one of the fundamentals which we have to get right in this country. He is quoted in the Australian Financial Review this morning as saying that he termed Australia as one of the greediest consumers of foreign capital and one of the highest indebted countries in the world. He said:
This is clearly not a sustainable position. . . Australia must simply undergo a significant transformation to reduce its exposure to the whims of the international capital market".
What is the Minister's line? His line is that we fixed the problem. That is patently untrue. It is just another deception--one deception after another.

We are in a rolling recession. This country has to realise that things are tough and they are going to get tougher unless we start to make the changes that will give people higher living standards in the future. We critically need a set of national objectives. We need a clear, realistic assessment of the problems. We need a clear set of solutions. We need the people to implement those solutions. We need a strategy for implementation.

When the Treasurer gets back to this shore, the first thing he ought to do is call a press conference and have the decency and honesty to say frankly to the Australian people what he was prepared to tell some foreigners but was not prepared to say here in Australia. The second thing that ought to happen is that the Prime Minister ought to make clear whether or not he endorses the view of his Treasurer, because unless we have the leadership which has been so sadly lacking in recent years, there is little hope for the major change that this country seeks and desperately needs.

This country has faced difficult times--the worst recession for 60 years. It is clearly worse than 1982-83, by any reasonably objective criteria. Taking out of the calculation one of the seasonal factors that affect the rural industry--the drought in 1982, during the last Government--and looking at gross non-farm product for 1982-83 and 1990-91, we see that in 1982-83 GDP fell by 1.2 per cent. In 1990-91, from the September quarter 1990 to the June quarter 1991--and this recession is not yet over--that non-farm GDP fell by 2.7 per cent. It fell by 1.2 per cent in 1982, and that was the end of that recession. This time it has fallen 2.7 per cent, and the recession is not yet over.

It is no good talking about recovery, it is no good talking about better times, when things still remain to be done. The trouble with Labor people is that they have long prided themselves about creating jobs. The embarrassment for them, of course, was sharpened when the unemployment figure went through the 10 per cent barrier, because they promised that the figure would never go above 10 per cent. What afflicts these people is that they have been stunned by that. There is a psychological barrier that they have difficulty facing. They have difficulty facing the honesty of the fact that they have created this recession and they now sit there paralysed, unable to make the changes that this country needs.

There are many things to be done. We in the Opposition expect to win the next election, and the Government's factional infighting will, I suppose, cement those prospects for us, but quite frankly a lot of people are going to go broke in the meantime. So it is that I say to the Minister for Finance that there are changes that the Government could make. If the Government gets the changes right, we will support it. It should not be running a scare campaign on tax reform when we know that the abolition of one tax system, the wholesale sales tax system, is going to provide a tremendous boost for business, which is going to mean jobs for people. The Government should not run a scare campaign; it ought to support something which five years ago it was prepared to support and which it then backed off.

The Government ought to change the industrial relations system, because one in three young people basically cannot get a job today. There could be jobs for young people but for the fact that the Government is not prepared to confront its mates in the trade union movement. That is a disgrace which the Government will live with throughout its political life.

It ought to go ahead with privatisation. The Russians will have privatised Aeroflot before these guys gets on with a decent privatisation program in this country. It is time for change--time for change now. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We have just listened for a quarter of an hour to a speech about how we need to have change in this country. Of course, if nothing was happening and if there had been no change in recent years, I suppose that that would be a fair enough plea. There are two remarkable aspects about that general theme: firstly, of course, there has never been a time in the history of this country in which there has been so much structural change; and, secondly, the reason we need this structural change is that for the 33 years before we came into office those opposite were in government and there was created in this country a structure of economic development which was patently wrong and which, the conservatives now agree, should have been way over the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: The conservative parties of this country developed this country in the post-war period. They governed the country from 1949 to 1972 and from 1975 to the beginning of 1983--for 30 of the 33 years before we came into office. The structure of the economy that needs the change which it is now getting is one which the conservatives developed, an economic structure which, like eastern Europe, is now quite clearly and patently unsuited to the future of the nation.

We see--as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) crawls out of the place, unable to face his Party's responsibility for the fact that this country needs so much structural change--that the conservatives in this country are in an extraordinarily hypocritical position: they are condemning this Government for not undertaking enough structural change, whereas it is undertaking a vast array of structural change and needs to do so because it was the conservatives who developed a highly protected economy, one which was patently non-internationally competitive, one which had a totally uncompetitive economy compared to those of our trading partners, and one which gave us a Third World pattern of exports.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made reference to the comments of the gentleman from Standard and Poor's. Of course, what that gentleman said was that the most important concern he had about Australia was the structure of its exports because it was so patently dependent on commodities. Why is that the case? That is the case because the whole development of this country in the post-war period was such that the only things that we could export were the things that we grew or dug up. We had a manufacturing industry, nurtured behind exceedingly high tariff walls and import restrictions, which was patently incapable of developing markets overseas and needed enormous protection against imports. Of course, the conservatives gave us this highly difficult economic structure and put us in peril in respect of our balance of payments.

Of course, all that became obvious by the time the Fraser Government was going out of office. Despite the fact that we had all these mineral developments through the 1960s and 1970s which put off the evil day when we had to confront the realities of our economy and its limitations, by 1980-81 we had a balance of payments current account deficit of 6 per cent. So the problem was starkly obvious then. It went down with the recession, of course, but it came back to be a problem which this Government has had to deal with. This Government has been dealing with that in a way that no previous Government has ever done, undertaking a vast array of structural change which is making this country a much more competitive country.

That is quite clear in a host of industries where competition is being developed, making it a lower wage cost country in respect of its competitors; producing a lower rate of inflation; making us much more internationally competitive--our international competitiveness is about 18 per cent higher now than it was when we came into office; and giving us the capacity to develop manufacturing exports and to get that highly imbalanced pattern of exports put onto something which is much more respectable and much more akin to a developed industrialised country. That is what we see being achieved by what is happening to manufactured exports. Manufactured exports, as the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) explained to the House at Question Time yesterday, have been growing to a startling degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —-So have the imports.
—-So have the imports! What an idiot comment.
—-Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask that the Minister withdraw that word.
—-Do you find that offensive?
—-Yes, of course I do.
—-The Minister will withdraw.

—-If the honourable member finds the word offensive, I withdraw it. What a stupid comment. The fact is that manufactured exports have increased very rapidly and are now giving us something like a 40 per cent higher proportion of exports than they were when we came into office. Of course, that is building from a low base; we all know that. That is the low base that those opposite left us. But what we are certainly doing is getting a much more developed structure of exports than we have ever had in our history.

SPEECH.PARA: This will, as time goes on, give this country a much greater capacity to withstand the swings of commodity prices and to deal with the problems of vulnerable countries, as we have been, in a way in which other industrialised countries do; that is, it will give us the ability to maintain exports at times of downward swings of commodities because of the importance of manufactured exports.

Of course, the Opposition, having moved from extreme protectionism to the other side, is now saying that we should deregulate everything and that we should completely abandon tariffs, and do it sooner rather than later, despite the fact that there is a clear pattern of reduced protection in place which is at, I think, the bearable rate for industry, giving those companies within the industries affected that are capable of becoming efficient a chance to do so and to withstand foreign competition. But the policies pursued by the Opposition, which say, `Let us abandon the graduated approach, let us go hell for leather', would, of course, mean that those industries would just fall over.

Generally, our industry accepts that the policies being pursued by this Government are such that our manufactured exports are likely to be developed and our manufacturing industries are likely to be much more competitive. We will shift resources from those areas which do not have the capacity to face imports and develop exports to those areas that do. We will, therefore, develop higher levels of productivity and real income and get away from the pattern of low income growth which the conservative governments gave us all through the 1950s, 1960s and their period in office in the 1970s and early 1980s, which led us to the point where we were faced with extraordinary adjustment difficulties, as we are today.

This Government has not shirked the issue. The allegation from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and others that we have shirked the issue on change is a complete and utter falsehood. I ask honourable members opposite to tell me of any other time in our history when there has been anything remotely like the degree of structural change which is now taking place in this country. There has been nothing like it. Look at telecommunications, which is a monopoly industry that has been put on a much more efficient basis even before competition is being brought in. It has a CPI-minus-X regime which means that prices are falling by 5 1/2 per cent less than the consumer price index each year. As well, competition is being brought in by the sale of Aussat and by the development of a competitor to Telecom at every level of its activities.

In the domestic aviation industry, we deregulated the previous government's highly regulated industry and since deregulation, of course, we have seen considerable falls in prices and increased competition. In the shipping industry, there has been a remarkable change in work practices, resulting in greatly increased productivity and a fall in the average number of crew per ship from 33, as it was when we came into office, to 21 by the end of this year. That is a fantastic change and one clearly indicating very large increases in productivity in the shipping industry.

As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) was saying at Question Time, we are seeing the waterfront industry develop now enterprise based arrangements in the major ports. Sydney and Melbourne already have those arrangements concluded and most of the other major ports have them almost concluded. A total of 1,800 waterside workers are out of the industry ahead of schedule and another 400 are to go shortly. All of that is leading to considerably increased productivity on the waterfront. Already we have been seen a 70 per cent improvement in productivity in grain handling and, with the enterprise arrangements now in place, we have the likelihood of 70-plus per cent increases in productivity in the non-bulk area of the waterfront.

In those important areas we are seeing major changes taking place. Of course, across all industries, we are seeing the major changes coming from the industrial relations system--an industrial relations system which has worked infinitely better under this Government than any other in terms of wage outcomes. It is giving us wage outcomes of about 7 1/2 per cent at the maximum, which has been the highest level of any year and which was the lowest of any year under the Fraser Government. They are wage outcomes which altogether are almost half those that occurred under the previous government. So we are seeing a much better capacity to handle wages.

We are also seeing increased flexibility in the way in which wages are set and, as a result of the case which is now before the Industrial Relations Commission, we expect that we will move more rapidly into enterprise bargaining for wage increases from November on. That will mean, of course, that there will be greater flexibility in wage setting, which is generally agreed to be a good thing--so long as, of course, it is within the context of a containment of the overall wages outcome. With the accord, we have the assurance that we will continue to contain the overall wages outcome and not have enterprise bargaining leading to wages blow-outs, as occurred under the previous Government when it had an 18 per cent wage increase in 1982. Of course, if honourable members opposite had enterprise bargaining without the accord, they would certainly find that, as soon as the economy got some movement going, they would have considerable wage blow-outs again. They would not have the accord, no assurance, no wages policy in an agreement with the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We have a wages policy, you dummy.
—-We not only have that assurance--
—-Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—-But we also have the unions' assurance that they will work with us to achieve inflation outcomes that are no greater than those of our major trading partners. That, of course--
—-They should have made him Treasurer.
—-So convincing.
—-Mr Deputy Speaker, will you shut these couple of parrots up?
—-I only said they should have made him Treasurer; that's all.
—-Order! I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—-As I was saying, we have the assurance from the ACTU and the accord--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Downer interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

—-We have the assurance from the ACTU and the accord that they will work with us to achieve wage outcomes which are comparable with those of our major trading partners. That is something that the trade union movement has never given any previous government as an assurance on wages policy. Of course, the important point in the context of the recession is that the Opposition, whilst criticising us for there being a recession, advocates policies which would make the recession worse, because its policy, as explained by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Budget debate, is to reduce the deficit to have at least a balanced Budget, thereby contracting budgetary policy, thereby creating less stimulus to the economy from the Budget, thereby pushing us into higher levels of unemployment in the short run. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says, `But we would balance that with interest rate reductions'. Of course, we all know that there are great lags on interest rate policy. That has been shown quite clearly in recent times, and that would mean that the stimulus that came from any interest rate cuts would be further out.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, in the policies being pursued by this Government, there is a responsible stimulus from the Budget. In other words, we are not pump priming. We have allowed the automatic stabilisers to operate--that is, for the loss of revenue and the increased expenditure which comes automatically with increased unemployment to take place--and for the stimulus that comes from that to have its impact, and through that the provision of some assurance that the economy will shortly start on a clear recovery path, as the Budget forecasts show. So, in respect of budgetary policy, we are clearly in a position where our policies are much more suited to employment growth than the Opposition's. In respect of monetary policy, we have shown our preparedness to cut interest rates responsibly over the last year and a half, in which there have been 8 1/2 per cent reductions in official rates. In the future, as we are able responsibly to do so, we will certainly bear in mind the need to take advantage of the opportunity to do so. Finally, of course, in relation to tax reform, we have Opposition members pursuing a course which would put inflation back into double digit figures, and they would give us double digit inflation and double digit unemployment, as they did when in government in 1982-83. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The first thing I suppose one would say about the speech of the Acting Treasurer (Mr Willis) is that, in failing to address the topic that is before the House, he does not deny that we are now in the worst recession for 60 years. Not ever does he even attempt to address that issue--as though it does not matter that there are 10 per cent or nearly one million people unemployed.
—-You had 10 per cent in 1982.
—-He is quite relaxed about that; quite relaxed about nearly one million people queuing up for the dole.
—-Do you remember 1982, when there was 10 per cent unemployment?
—-Order! The Minister!
—-But he goes further--
—-He forgets about it.
—-Yes; but the Minister was complaining about it, and now he is a hypocrite going on by behaving in exactly the same way. It is about time he pulled himself together.
—-Order! The honourable member for Mayo will withdraw that remark!
—-Which one, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—-To call a member a hypocrite is unparliamentary.
—-I will replace the word `hypocrite' with--
—-No, the honourable member will not. He will withdraw it.
—-I will withdraw it and replace it with the words `inconsistent' and `incoherent'.
—-No. The honourable member will not replace it. He will withdraw it if he wants to continue his speech.

—-I withdraw it. The Minister is completely inconsistent and incoherent in his approach to this debate, let alone to economic policy. One of the things he does and the Labor Party loves to do is say, `Well, look, this terrible recession--nearly a million people out of work', and brush that aside. He did not even mention them, did he? He says, `It does not really matter about that'. But he blames the conservative parties; he says it was all their fault. Is that not amazing? It is all our fault; the Menzies Government did it. Did the Menzies Government ever have a rate of growth as appalling as the rate of growth that this Government has now? No, never. Did the Menzies Government ever have the inflation record that this Government has had? Did it ever have the balance of payments crisis--and it did have a balance of payments problem in 1961--
—-Do you remember 1961?
—-But was the crisis ever as great as it is now?

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! We have reached the stage that one speaker at a time is sufficient. I would ask the Minister to listen in silence and I suggest that honourable members on my right listen in silence.

—-They have got a lot to listen to, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am glad you have drawn it to their attention. I thought I might mention the Menzies Government's record on unemployment because those opposite do not like to talk about unemployment; they do not think there is a problem. Did the Menzies Government ever have nearly one million people out of work? Ever? Were nearly one million people out of work when Sir Robert Menzies was in the Lodge and God was in His sky? Certainly not! When those opposite complain about high rates of tariffs, the beauty of their complaints is that the Labor Party in its very first election in 1901 came in on four different platforms, and one of them was an increase in tariff protection. So for the Labor Party to come into this House and complain about high tariffs is, as you would acknowledge, Mr Deputy Speaker, simply risible. It is a joke.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us compare the way this country was going with the rest of the world during the Menzies and Fraser years and the way it is going now. The fact is that through the stable years of conservative governments this country was one of the richest in the world. Throughout the time of those opposite the world has gone through great changes; I am not arguing with that. There have been great changes in economic policies and thinking around the world, but there has not been here; that is the extraordinary thing. We are not arguing that the Menzies Government should be brought back with exactly the same policies in a completely different world, which is what those opposite pretend we are arguing.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I never said you were.

—-The argument of the Minister is a little hard to follow, I must admit, but I think that is what he is arguing. What we are saying is that the world has changed and we have got to change with the world. Those opposite have the oldest living industrial relations system in the world. It was introduced at the turn of the century and they are still running it. They are proud of it, and the Minister at the table, the Acting Treasurer (Mr Willis), is a child of it. Those opposite also have the oldest living consumption tax that the world knows. It is the grandfather, the great-grandfather even, of all consumption taxes.
—-Who introduced it?
—-Is it not interesting? The party which now says it is opposed to a consumption tax introduced it in the time of the Scullin Government.
—-When was that?
—-That was in 1930.
—-In the last depression.
—-By the way, while we are on this point--
—-Order! If the honourable member for Mayo wants the protection of the Chair from members on my right, he ought also ask his Deputy Leader to remain silent.

—-Mr Deputy Speaker, it is your job to keep the order of the House, not mine. The point is that in 1930, during the other Great Depression, the recession that was as great as this one, the Labor Government introduced a broadly based consumption tax. Do honourable members know that the Scullin Government's consumption tax, at 2 per cent, had only six exemptions?
—-The sales tax.

—-Yes, the sales tax. That consumption tax had only six exemptions. I know it is 650 now, but it was only six when the Labor Party introduced it. So where is the Labor Party? The Minister claims that manufacturing exports are suddenly booming. This is a great Labor boast. I was in Whyalla two weeks ago. I went to the BHP steelworks there. They told me their exports had increased. I thought, `Gosh, that is good. That is really encouraging'. I asked, `Why?', and they said, `So we can keep the blast furnace going. We can't sell at a profit. We are just dumping the steel into the international marketplace, not at a profit but to keep the blast furnace going'. If those opposite think that is successful manufacturing export, they are wrong. BHP is in the export market because the Government throttled the domestic market to death.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the policies that have been introduced by this Government have been ones which have deliberately hurt people. There is no better example than its tax policies. I mentioned earlier the oldest living consumption tax in the world--the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax. What has the effect of that been during Labor's years in office? Low income earners pay, in relative terms, 1 1/2 times as much of their income in wholesale sales tax as the rich do on all goods. For example, the 10 per cent of people on the lowest incomes, the lowest decile, pay 5.3 per cent of their income in wholesale sales tax while those in the highest decile pay 3.5 per cent.

Let us have a look at how those opposite have gone over the years since 1984-85. Those opposite go on and on about the terrible consumption taxes. Let us see what those opposite have done. Not only did their party introduce Australia's consumption tax and not only is it regressive, as I have just explained, but it has become more regressive since they have been in office. They have no shame. They go around saying that the Liberals and the Nationals are going to introduce this terrible consumption tax, but all the time bearing one awful secret--that in 1984-85 the lowest decile paid 4 per cent of their income in wholesale sales tax and the highest decile paid 2.8 per cent. That is regressive. But remember that the lowest decile now pays 5.3 per cent. That is even more regressive. When we have a look at the Government's income tax system, the regression is still there.

Remember those men in the boat off the Western Australian coast? Laurie Connell, Alan Bond, Bob Hawke--was that them? Was there anyone else in that boat? There was somebody rowing it, I suppose. The person rowing it was probably on average weekly earnings. I do not doubt he was squirming at the thought that those people, who were at least then on very high earnings, were people who had received--if we take taxation in terms of average taxation--substantial tax cuts during the life of the Hawke Government. Their average tax was 42.5 per cent when the Hawke Government came to power; it is 39.2 per cent now. So they have got tax cuts. But the bloke rowing the boat, the bloke on average weekly earnings, was paying 17.9 per cent average tax when the Fraser Government went out of office. He is now paying 20.4 per cent. Funny, isn't it? For the bloke on average weekly earnings tax has gone up, and the rich guy's tax has come down. The bloke on average weekly earnings has been slugged even further by the Government's consumption tax while the rich guys have got away scot-free.

It is funny that the party that boasts that it cares about low income people is the party that has put nearly a million people out of work and which has a regressive taxation system which is contributing to lower living standards. The pain of the recession being felt by low income earners is so much greater than it is for higher income Australians. So the Government's old-fashioned industrial relations system, its great-grandfather of all consumption taxes, its much beloved wholesale sales tax, makes this country a laughing stock around the world.

Everybody else is modernising. Even the Congo and Mali are introducing goods and services taxes. Even Indonesia is. I suppose those opposite think Indonesia is imposing a wicked impost. Even Thailand is introducing one, as are all the countries of the European Community. There is Fiji, and the list goes on and on. They are introducing goods and services taxes, but those opposite will not modernise. We are sticking with the old 80- or 90-year-old industrial relations system and the great-grandfather of all consumption taxes, the one introduced during the last depression that the Labor Party plunged this country into. What a great record the Labor Party has. Whenever it has been in power it has stuffed up the economy of this country--every single time. There was the Watson Government, the Scullin Government, which was thrown out when it destroyed the economy, and the Whitlam Government--and the Hawke Government is the worst of them all. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) confirms for us yet again that the Liberal and National parties put theatrics, noise and mock indignation ahead of policy, substance and fabric on every single occasion. That is exactly what the honourable member for Mayo did in his speech on this matter of public importance today. It was the same with the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). When it comes to the actual task of selling the consumption tax, the first thing the Liberal and National parties will have to do is to get a couple of different advocates. Based on what we have heard today, clearly the backbench of the Liberal and National parties would have every reason to be anxious about the selling of the consumption tax.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the economy and look at what the needs of Australia are today and compare that with what the two Opposition speakers in this MPI have said, it shows that they have no sense of purpose and no sense of direction. They seek to gloat about the needs of the unemployed and those in need in Australia but offer no solutions or alternative policies. Indeed, they have no understanding of the needs of ordinary Australians. It is very clear, if we analyse their policies--or as much as we know about what their policies stand for--that, as the Acting Treasurer said in his contribution, they would make conditions worse for the vast majority of Australians than the difficulties they have had to endure in recent years.

All of that proves that the legacy that we got in 1983 of Fraser, Howard and Hewson and the legacy of double digit inflation and double digit unemployment would be the same strategy that the Opposition would pursue, although it would pursue it with greater gusto this time around than it did in 1982-83. The people of Australia realise that the alternative strategies that are being talked about by the Liberals offer no solutions, no leadership and no direction.

In contrast, the position adopted in this year's Budget, and the strategy of the Government over recent times, has been to ensure that we expose the Australian economy to the winds of international competition and change that is so vital and so long overdue. Much of the problem we have today, as the Acting Treasurer said, is because of all those years when there was no thought given to how we could make Australia internationally competitive. There was no thought given to how we would develop industries that involve more than the extraction of raw materials or the selling of commodities.

We know from experience that change can occur because of either climatic conditions here or international prices in those particular areas. What we need to do--this Government has been doing this--is create the structure so that we can create long term sustainable jobs and long term industries that benefit all Australians.

When we discuss an MPI such as this it is realistic to talk about what has been achieved in areas such as micro-economic reform. Those on the other side would say that they are the only ones who have any answers as far as micro-economic reform is concerned. As the Acting Treasurer said in this debate, we have only to look at the area of aviation to see what has been achieved by this Government. It has introduced reform in the key area of domestic aviation. We saw deregulation after so many years of members of the Opposition sitting on their hands when they controlled the Treasury bench.

Deregulation has produced real results, real achievement and real benefits for the people of Australia. Those benefits will be ongoing because they flow across a lot of industries. The tourism industry is one of the key beneficiaries of that. It is an industry created by this Government. It is a major export earner, a major generator of foreign exchange, and offers even greater potential for Australia. This year it is projected that something like 2.4 million tourists will come to Australia, with the potential for that to grow to five million over the next five years. It is a great opportunity for Australians, for small business and for industries across the nation. That has been achieved through a lot of different initiatives. One of the areas has been the deregulation of aviation. Another key area is where we have taken the steps to promote Australia overseas through investment in tourism promotion around the world.

What is the Opposition's response when it is asked whether it would maintain that sort of funding commitment to promote Australia? The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has said several times that he does not see that as an area where governments should necessarily be spending taxpayers' money, anyway. The support, the interest and the export income that it brings to Australia is completely forgotten in the mad ideology that the Liberals pursue. It is an industry that has developed and has achieved real sustained improvement for Australia over the life of this Government. It highlights what can be done in terms of industry policy.

Telecommunications is another key area where there is so much opportunity for Australia because of changes introduced by this Government to create advances in telecommunications technology that we can then export to the Asian region, in particular. The most savage indictment of the Liberal and National parties is that, during all those years when we should have been harnessing our strategic advantage into Asia, they did not bother about Asia. All they were concerned about was dealing with the colonial relics. They were never interested in opening up the telecommunications opportunities that we have had to develop in Asia.

As a result of the changes that this Government has introduced in telecommunications--the competitive environment we are creating for telecommunications in this country and the industry opportunities that offers to us, both to develop industry here in technology and, more importantly I would suggest, to export that technology to the growing demand areas of Asia--we will ensure that that whole area of industry development is generated in a way that would have been unheard of under the Liberal and National parties because clearly they do not see those sorts of objectives as ones that should be pursued by a national government.

Then we come to the question of tariffs. Some of the Liberals that we hear talking about these issues around Australia are not nearly as convinced about this New Right ideology. The Leader of the Opposition in Victoria seems to have a bit of difficulty coming to grips with the line of the shadow Treasurer--to the extent that we can develop a line from what the shadow Treasurer says--

TALK.START.PARA: —-It's not easy.

—-As the honourable member for Fowler rightly points out, it is not easy. To the extent that we can, it is clear that many people in the manufacturing States, such as Victoria, have real difficulty appreciating the need to develop a strategy that makes us competitive but at the same time recognises the human aspect of that restructuring process. The people who sit on the Opposition benches in this place seem to be incapable of understanding the human face of what they talk about when they refer to restructuring Australia. That is something that we should be concerned about. It is all very well to say that we are concerned about the level of unemployment. I dare say that everybody would share our concern and real commitment to ensuring that the level of unemployment is reduced as part of sustained economic recovery as quickly as is humanly possible.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, it is important to ensure that we have policies that have a human and compassionate face, and that if people are out of work or lacking in means we have the social infrastructure to cope with that. This Government has that social policy in place. The Liberal alternative is to suggest that those sorts of things do not matter. It wants to take the dole off those who have been out of work for nine months. Some in the Liberal Party say that that is all right because they will introduce a discretionary payment that does not give any protection and does not give any underlying income security or family security to people at all.

This year's Budget took some important initiatives towards the extension of the family income supplement, the extension of arrangements to deal with training, the extension of arrangements to ensure that the labour market programs were enhanced and, most importantly in terms of coming out of the economic recession that we have had, to maintain the skills base. What will mark the recovery from this recession as being different from what occurred in 1982-83 is the fact that so much of the skills base was lost in the 1982-83 recession.

No-one wishes to have economic hardship imposed on anybody in this country. One of the important things is to ensure that as we move out of that period of economic difficulty, Australians have opportunities to attain employment and have the skills to actively move into that employment. This Government has ensured that that skills base is retained. It has ensured that there is also a process that ensures sustainable long term recovery, both in terms of lower inflationary expectations and because we have been committed to ensure that the level of interest rates can be sustainably lowered over time.

All of those measures will ensure that this country is more competitive, more international looking, more internationally resilient and has the broad range of industry and infrastructure that ensures that Australia as a whole comes out of the economic problems we have which, in my view, are not as difficult as they were in 1982-83 simply because there has been an underlying policy fabric and strategy on the part of the Government to ensure that we deal with those problems and that we understand the needs of Australians. We are committed to ensuring that the policies we develop as a government are designed to ensure the well-being of Australians through the 1990s and beyond with a great, forward-looking Australian economy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I present the thirteenth report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are now being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.
