PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The States Grants (TAFE) Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 provides for initial grants to the States for TAFE for 1992 and for supplementation to 1991 grants to reflect increases in price levels.

The Bill implements the Budget decision to provide for a real increase of 5 per cent in Commonwealth recurrent grants to TAFE. This is in line with the recommendations of the 1990 Deveson report into training costs. Overall levels of funding for TAFE will be reviewed further in the context of the consideration by State, Federal and Territory Ministers of the findings of the recently released Finn Committee report.

The effect of the changes is that the Bill provides for $157,385,000 for recurrent funding and $215,528,000 for capital funding in 1992 and an additional $1,660,000 for recurrent funding for 1991. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, which provides for Commonwealth grants of financial assistance to the States, the Northern Territory and higher education institutions for higher education purposes.

The Bill provides funds for higher education amounting to some $3.6 billion in 1994, that is, the third year of the new funding triennium, 1992-94. This amount takes into account the Government's decisions to provide, in 1994, some $44m for 2,845 additional student intakes, some $277m for capital works and additional funds amounting to just under $75m for a new funding program to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education. These decisions were announced subsequent to those on higher education which formed part of the Government's 1991-92 Budget. Before addressing the Budget decisions I would like to elaborate on the Government's initiatives concerning quality assurance in higher education.

The Government's new funding program to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education is one of a number of initiatives to promote quality and diversity in the development of higher education through the 1990s. The focus of the Government's new policies is a comprehensive set of measures to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education teaching and provision. The extra funds will be used to reward institutions for making the best use of all their available resources.

The Higher Education Council has been asked to explore the characteristics of quality in higher education. After the Council reports on this reference, and following wider consultation with the higher education sector, a national structure, independent of government, will be established to report on the application and effectiveness of quality enhancement measures developed by institutions.

A National Centre for Teaching Excellence in higher education is to be set up next year to examine and disseminate information about good teaching practices. Funding will also be made available for a pilot credit transfer project, under the aegis of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, which the Government hopes will lead to the establishment of a national credit transfer agency. In addition, a comprehensive review of modes of delivery in higher education will be conducted to look at how technology can best be harnessed to improve access to, and the quality and efficiency of, higher education. With these measures, the Government is taking the lead internationally in providing a funding incentive to institutions, over and above funding for student load, to promote the highest possible level of quality in higher education.

I would like to stress that institutional participation in the new quality assurance arrangements will be voluntary and the allocation of normal operating grants will be unaffected. It is certainly not the Government's intention to use the new arrangements to redistribute operating grants to institutions on the basis of comparative quantitative performance indicators. These quality assurance initiatives will be developed hand in hand with all of the main interest groups within the higher education system.

It is worth emphasising also that the Government's approach to quality assurance balances institutional autonomy with public accountability. It is based primarily on self-assessment by institutions rather than relying on external assessments of quality. It relates the monitoring of quality to the goals of individual institutions. It involves assessments which include both qualitative and quantitative indicators. It allows for comparisons to be made against the different circumstances of institutions, including the composition of their student population, and their performance over time. It should therefore encourage diversity and innovation while confirming public confidence in the higher education system and reinforcing its international reputation.

The Bill also includes provisions to widen the definition of higher education capital projects to encompass other than simply building projects. This will enable the Government to support major investments in course material and equipment which are genuine capital substitutes. The wider definition recognises the potential for new technologies and alternative delivery modes to improve delivery of, and access to, higher education.

The Bill provides for the Government's Budget decisions aimed at addressing enrolment and overcrowding pressures being felt in higher education institutions. To this end, just under $10m has been allocated for additional student intakes next year with additional funds to take account of the pipeline effect of these intakes. As well, an additional $54m is being provided for capital projects next year to alleviate pressures of overcrowding, of which some $24m is funding originally earmarked for 1994. About half of these funds will be used to assist institutions to refurbish and renovate existing space. These funds will be provided on a matching basis with institutions.

A pilot scheme will begin next year which will see the Government and employers sharing the costs of providing a number of additional student intakes, with the Commonwealth's share at 60 per cent. The Government has allocated just under $3.5m for up to 600 new student intakes in 1992 and some $4m for 700 intakes in both 1993 and 1994, with additional funds for the pipeline effect of these intakes.

The Bill provides funds for a Commonwealth program to establish three advanced engineering centres in partnership with host institutions and industry. The focus of the centres will be on advanced undergraduate and postgraduate education and training. However, the centres will also provide courses for industry and technical and further education teachers. They will also provide professional retraining for experienced engineers and applied research and design services for industry. The Commonwealth is providing just under $10m over the triennium for the establishment and ongoing costs associated with this initiative.

The Bill provides extra financial assistance amounting to some $31m over the triennium for additional Australian Research Council grants and provides over $10m in additional funds for support programs for Aboriginal students. Increased funding amounting to some $350m over the period 1991-93 is also provided in accordance with the Government's arrangements for cost supplementation of institutions' operating grants. A major component of this is funding to fully supplement pay rises awarded to academics by the Industrial Relations Commission in its decision of 23 July 1991.

To enable Victoria's share of the responsibility for funding the higher education program at the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture to be transferred to the Commonwealth, the Bill includes a financial adjustment to the maximum grants for higher education institutions. This will mean that the college's program is funded fully through the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 as from 1 January of next year.

A complementary amendment to the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1991 has been introduced by the Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Free) which will have the effect of reducing the financial assistance grants in the case of the State of Victoria. Taken together, these amendments will have no net effect on total Commonwealth outlays and are being introduced at the request of the Victorian State Government.

As announced in the Budget, the Bill also provides for an increase in the annual course contribution under the higher education contribution scheme. From next year, the annual course contribution for a full time student undertaking a standard program of study will increase to $2,250--an increase of $144 above the normal indexation increase--to help fund further expansion of the higher education system.

The Government has committed itself to spending some $12.9 billion on higher education over the 1992-94 triennium. Continued growth in the system will provide expanding opportunities for Australians to participate in higher education and, with the Government's new measures to further enhance the quality of higher education teaching and provision, Australian students can expect to receive a higher education the standard of which continues to be the equal of any in the world.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Snowdon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: -Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an omnibus Bill amending seven Acts administered, either wholly or partly, within the transport and communications portfolio. While none of the proposed amendments are highly significant, they are important for the functions of the transport and communications portfolio. Details of the major amendments follow.
Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983

Part 2 of this Bill amends the Australian National Railways Commission Act to ensure that the Commission has the power to enter into a number of financial management risk or hedging transactions. Many government business enterprises routinely make use of such transactions, as do many private business organisations, to minimise their exposure to adverse interest rate variations.
The need for such an amendment was highlighted by a recent decision of the United Kingdom Court of Appeal, which raised doubts about the power of similar government enterprises in the United Kingdom.
Civil Aviation Act 1988

Part 3 of the Bill makes a number of amendments to the Civil Aviation Act. In the first place, the Act is amended in the same way as the Australian National Railways Commission Act mentioned above. Secondly, the Bill gives effect to certain recommendations contained in the second report of the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force. The Task Force highlighted a number of serious offences currently within the regulations and recommended that they be elevated to the Act in order to highlight their significance to air safety. In particular, the task force noted that flying an aircraft without registration or a certificate of airworthiness attracted a maximum penalty of $5,000. Such a breach constitutes a fundamental risk to air safety and the Task Force recommended its inclusion in the Act with a much more substantial penalty. The Task Force recommended that other more serious offences should be identified in the Act and maximum penalties be prescribed for each offence.

The Task Force also expressed concern about the courts' powers in relation to a breach of the Act or the regulations. At present, courts may only impose a fine or a term of imprisonment. Often this is not a sufficient deterrent. The Task Force recommended that the court be empowered to suspend or cancel any licence, authority or certificate issued to the person under the regulations as a punitive alternative to the usual sanctions in serious cases. The Bill introduces a procedure whereby persons convicted of offences against the Act or the regulations may be excluded from any previously authorised activity.

Finally, the Bill makes a number of minor amendments which clarify the Authority's liability to pay income tax and its powers in relation to statutory liens, and remove any legal doubt about the Authority's power to delegate certain air safety functions under the regulations to industry bodies.
Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986

The principal purpose of this amendment is to enable the Commonwealth to transfer undeveloped sites which have been acquired for airport development to the Federal Airports Corporation and to empower the corporation to construct airports at those sites. This is achieved by introducing into the Act the concept of a `Federal airport development site' which may be declared prior to its establishment as a Federal airport.

This is a technical amendment which in no way derogates from the Commonwealth's primary responsibility for the national planning of airports, including the investigation of and the need for additional Federal airports and their location. The Bill also clarifies an earlier amendment that the Authority is liable to pay income tax.
Navigation Act 1912

The Bill proposes a number of amendments to this Act. The most significant amendment places fishing fleet support vessels outside the ambit of the Act when not on an overseas voyage. Fishing fleet support vessels are presently trading vessels for the purposes of the Navigation Act, although the fishing vessels they serve are not. The Bill will correct this anomaly.

An agreement was recently reached that in certain parts of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park area, certain types of ships must carry a pilot. The Bill makes provision for the issue of appropriate pilot qualifications for this purpose.

Finally, there are a number of other amendments of the Navigation Act of a general `housekeeping' nature. In particular, the limits of the Australian jurisdiction in marine casualty inquiries are clarified; certain offence provisions are brought up to date; and some drafting errors are corrected.
Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946

The purpose of the amendments to this Act is to extend the privileges and protections afforded to radio broadcasts of parliamentary proceedings, firstly, to television broadcasts of proceedings and, secondly, to radio and television broadcasting of proceedings of parliamentary committees.

The amendments give effect to recommendations contained in the recent report of the select committee of the House of Representatives on televising titled The Eyes Have It. The select committee recommended that the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 be amended to provide for televising the proceedings of the Senate, the House of Representatives and their committees.

The amendments will also have the effect of exempting television broadcasters of proceedings of the House of Representatives and the Senate, and radio and television broadcasters of the proceedings of parliamentary committees, from the operation of section 117 of the Broadcasting Act 1942, which requires broadcasters to announce particulars of who authorised the broadcasting of political matter. This extends the existing exemption which applies to radio broadcasts of proceedings.
Trade Practices Act 1974

Part X of the Trade Practices Act 1974 provides shipping conferences with some limited exemptions from the competition provisions of part IV of the Act. Among the various obligations imposed on conferences in exchange for these exemptions is the requirement to publicly register their anti-competitive agreements. Fees are charged to recover the administrative costs associated with processing such registration applications.

It has recently come to the Government's attention that the agreement registration provisions of part X extend to the freight rates charged by the conferences. This means that every time conference members change even one of their many hundreds of freight rates, they would have to register a varying conference agreement. The imposition of such an administrative and financial burden serves no useful purpose, as conference freight rate schedules are already publicly available. This Bill will remove the need for conference members to register their freight rates and their subsequent variation.

As I have already mentioned, fees are charged for administrative services provided under part X. These fees are set by regulation. The fees currently charged are at or near the maximum levels stipulated in section 10.90 of the Act. This Bill will increase those maximum levels to enable appropriate regulations to be made to fully recover the costs incurred in providing the part X services.

In addition, the new maximum fee levels provide scope for future cost increases to be recovered, which will make it unnecessary to amend section 10.90 again for some years to come. The Bill also provides for a fee to be charged for the registration of a change to the particulars of an ocean carrier agent.

Finally, the Bill repeals sections 150 to 153 of the Act, which relate to transitional provisions following the replacement of earlier legislation by the previous part X of the Trade Practices Act 1974. With the repeal of the previous part X in 1990, sections 150-153 became redundant. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Snowdon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: -Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959. The main purpose of the amendments are: to enable ratification of Additional Protocol No. 3--Montreal Protocol No. 3--and Montreal Protocol No 4; to ensure that the Montreal Protocol No. 3 passenger limit applies immediately to Australian international air carriers engaged in carriage to which the Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol apply; and, to convert the Poincare gold franc limits of the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol to Australian dollars through the medium of the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Right, SDR.

The major reasons for amending the Act are twofold. Firstly, it is considered that the carriers' liability limits currently applying to the international carriage of passengers by air are insufficient. These are currently around $14,000 to $28,000 depending on whether carriage is covered by the Warsaw Convention or the Hague Protocol. The proposal to ratify Montreal Protocol No. 3 and immediately apply its 100,000 SDR passenger limit to Australia's international airlines will go some way to redress this situation. One hundred thousand SDRs, when converted to Australian dollars, is consistent with the domestic carriers' liability limit of $180,000. Australia has international obligations under the Warsaw Convention and is only able to increase passenger liability limits, without dissociating itself from the international aviation community, that is, by denouncing the Warsaw Convention, by ratifying Montreal Protocol No. 3.

Secondly, since the abandonment of the internationally set price of gold in 1973 and the introduction of a fluctuating market price, there has been no agreed means of determining the Australian dollar equivalent of the Poincare gold franc and the courts have often called on the Government to resolve the problem. The conversion of the gold franc limits to SDR equivalents resolves this problem.

Given that the amount of passenger compensation encompassed by the 100,000 SDR limit may be considered insufficient, the Government is examining other options to provide equitable compensation to international airline passengers which will not affect the carriers' liability limits fixed by international instrument. This includes examination of the feasibility of a supplemental compensation scheme, perhaps similar to one under consideration in the United States.

Montreal Protocol No. 4 is specifically cargo oriented and introduces more modern cargo handling terminology and procedures, including the use of electronic data interchange, EDI. While the passenger limit of Montreal Protocol No. 3 will be applicable immediately to Australian international carriers, the Protocols will only become generally applicable to airlines engaged in carriage to which they apply when they enter into force internationally.

It is my understanding that should the United States Senate accept the supplemental compensation scheme--called the S-Plan--referred to earlier, then it will support United States ratification of Montreal Protocols No. 3 and No. 4 by the President. It is also my understanding that this ratification may be accompanied by a denunciation of the Warsaw Convention. Unless Australia also ratifies the Montreal Protocols, this action could expose Australian carriers, particularly Qantas, to unlimited liability in the United States.

Since it is our firm belief that US ratification of the two Protocols will lead to their early entry into force, they will in the not too distant future apply to carriage between Australia and the majority of countries. I understand that the US Senate may be voting on the Protocols in the near future.

I turn now to a brief description of the Bill. Since the Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol will no doubt continue to apply to certain international carriage even after entry into force of the two Protocols, the Bill fixes their Poincare gold franc liability limits in SDRs. The Reserve Bank provides a SDR/Australian dollar conversion rate on a daily basis so enabling the courts to easily convert the limits at the time of judgment. The gold franc limits will have the following SDR equivalents:
Warsaw Convention
Passenger death/injury:
125,000 francs = 8300 SDR
Registered baggage/cargo:
250 francs/kg = 17 SDR/kg
Personal cabin baggage:
5000 francs = 330 SDR
Hague Protocol
Passenger death/injury:

The registered baggage and cargo and personal cabin baggage limits were not changed by the Hague Protocol. The limits as fixed by the Bill in SDRs are consistent with the move to ratify Montreal Protocols No. 3 and No. 4 with their SDR limits. The SDR equivalents of the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol liability limits will apply to actions involving international carriers which occur on or after the date the Bill receives royal assent. Actions pre-dating this will still be covered by the current Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol gold franc limits, irrespective of the date of judgment.

Next, the Bill specifies that for Australian carriers engaged in carriage to which the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol apply, the Montreal Protocol No. 3 passenger liability limit of 100,000 SDR will apply. This is consistent with Article 22 of the Warsaw Convention which permits the voluntary increase of liability limits.

Finally, the Bill inserts two new parts IIIB and IIIC into the Act covering carriage to which Montreal Protocol No. 3 and Montreal Protocol No. 4 respectively apply. These parts will become law on dates no earlier than the entry into force of the Protocols. For ease of reading, consolidations of the convention as amended by successive protocols have been prepared and included as schedules. The amendments will have no effect on government revenue or expenditure. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Wilson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Price, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Prime Minister and Cabinet Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 contains amendments to a number of Acts administered within the portfolio of the Prime Minister and to Acts containing provisions which relate to Public Service matters.
Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981

An amendment to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 will make it possible, where the Ombudsman or the Internal Investigation Division of the Australian Federal Police are investigating a complaint, for the Ombudsman to refer a question to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for an advisory opinion. The Ombudsman is already able to recommend to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police that such a question be referred.
Governor-General Act 1974

This Bill also amends the Governor-General Act 1974 to remove a limitation on the entitlement of the surviving spouse of a retired Governor-General to an allowance. The surviving spouse currently loses the entitlement to an allowance on remarriage. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that a similar limitation in the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 is inconsistent with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 as it discriminates on the basis of marital status.
Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986

Three amendments are proposed to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986. Two of these are administrative in nature, and are intended to bring the Office of the Inspector-General into line with other statutory bodies. Provision is now made for the appointment of an acting Inspector-General in the event of the absence of the Inspector-General or of a temporary vacancy in that office. A second amendment ensures that should a person appointed to act as Inspector-General also hold a judicial office that person may continue to enjoy the rights and privileges of that judicial office while acting as Inspector-General.

The final amendment provides the Inspector-General with right of access to the annual or periodic reports of the intelligence and security agencies, and to ministerial directions or guidelines given to the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and the Defence Signals Directorate of the Department of Defence. Although the agencies have voluntarily provided the Inspector-General with copies of such documents in the past, it is considered expedient to formalise access in legislation. This will further enhance the Inspector-General's ability to monitor the activities of the intelligence agencies, to ensure that they act within the law, with propriety and with regard for human rights. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 already provides the Inspector-General with the right of access to directions or guidelines given to ASIO by the Attorney-General.
Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973

This amendment to the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973 is intended to implement an interim decision of the Public Service Board in 1987 that a woman on maternity leave without pay should not become an unattached officer without her consent.
Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984

Three substantive amendments are proposed to the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984. The first of these is designed to give the agency flexibility in the manner in which it conducts meetings. It is often inconvenient, or unnecessary, for agency members to meet in person to conduct the agency's business. The amendment will enable meetings of the agency to be conducted by electronic means--for example by conference telephone.

The other amendments are proposed in consequence of findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in April 1988. The amendments will enable a pecuniary penalty to be imposed for breach of an order of a Disciplinary Appeal Committee or of a Retirement and Redeployment Appeal Committee prohibiting or restricting the publication of evidence. The merit protection regulations enable the Committees to make such orders.
Ombudsman Act 1976

A number of minor amendments are made to the Ombudsman Act 1976 by the Bill for the purpose of clarifying the Ombudsman's powers. One of these amendments will mirror the amendment made to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act previously referred to, empowering the Ombudsman to refer questions to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for an advisory opinion.

Other amendments to the Ombudsman Act will clarify the powers of the Ombudsman by specifying that a claim of legal professional privilege cannot be used to deny the Ombudsman access to information, and ensuring that the Ombudsman's role is not exhausted by the presentation of a report to Parliament about an investigation, by providing that the Ombudsman may discuss any matter to which the report relates with the principal officer of the department or authority concerned in order to resolve the matter.
Public Service Act 1922

The Bill makes a number of substantive amendments to the Public Service Act 1922. The amendments are being made ahead of action being taken to bring forward in due course a Bill for a modernised Act aimed at simplifying and integrating procedures and practices. The major amendments reflect the Government's agreement under the structural efficiency principle to restructure the senior executive service (SES) into three bands and introduce the SES (specialist) category. Other amendments relate to the role of the Public Service Commissioner in the termination of SES officers on probation and the extension of fixed term appointments.

A new three band structure for the SES came into effect on 4 January 1990. One of the aims of the structure was to enhance the optimum use of resources by providing secretaries and heads of agencies with flexibility in the allocation of SES resources and budget to meet changing priorities and issues at a particular time. The amendments proposed will enable secretaries and heads of agencies to transfer SES staff across positions within the same band irrespective of the salary points involved. Under current provisions, it is necessary for such filling action to be subject to a full selection process, as the movement to a higher salary point in such circumstances is currently regarded as a promotion.

During 1990 a separate SES (specialist) category was established within the senior executive service. Movement to the broad SES group from SES (specialist) positions by promotion or transfer is on the basis of merit competition. The amendments proposed reflect the establishment of the new category and the role of the Public Service Commissioner in filling related positions.

An amendment is also included to enable the Public Service Commissioner rather than a secretary to terminate probation of SES officers. This is consistent with the Commissioner's existing powers in relation to appointment, promotion and retirement for SES officers.

Another proposed amendment will enable the Commissioner, on the recommendation of a secretary or head of agency, to extend the term of a fixed term SES appointee to a maximum period of 5 years. Currently, it is not possible to extend an initial engagement where the period concerned is of lesser duration. In addition to the amendments relating to the SES, the Bill makes a number of other technical and procedural amendments to the Act.
Public Service Reform Act 1984

The Bill also repeals a provision of the Public Service Reform Act 1984 which is unproclaimed and is no longer required. This repeal is in accordance with the view expressed by the Senate Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills that unproclaimed provisions should be repealed.
Statutory Authority Legislation

The Bill also provides for the removal of the requirement for a number of government agencies and authorities to obtain approval from the Public Service Commissioner for terms and conditions of employment for staff--or, in some instances, certain categories of staff only. Under the Administrative Arrangements Act 1987, the Public Service Board's statutory approval role became a role of the Public Service Commissioner. In accordance with the proposed administrative arrangements following abolition of the Board, officers of the Department of Industrial Relations are currently performing the function under delegation from the Commissioner.

This amendment is consistent with initiatives throughout Australian Government employment to devolve to agency management greater autonomy, and to make managers more accountable for their actions. Nonetheless, all statutory authorities will still remain covered by the Government's general industrial relations coordination arrangements, which ensure the consistent application of the Government's wages and industrial relations policies.
Resource Assessment Commission Act 1989

The Resource Assessment Commission Act 1989 is to be amended to remove the Administration of Norfolk Island from the definition of `Commonwealth authority'. The Norfolk Island Government is deemed to be a `Commonwealth authority' by reason of its status as an incorporated body. As a result, a decision by the Norfolk Island Government on a resource matter can be referred to the Resource Assessment Commission. However, it was not intended that the Resource Assessment Commission be able to inquire into decisions of the Norfolk Island Government. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill, and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hawker) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments--
No. 1-- Clause 4, page 2, at end of clause, add the following paragraph:
"(c) by inserting after subsection (3) the following subsections:

`(3A) Where a person fails to comply with a requirement in a notice served on the person under subsection (1), the Tribunal may make application to the Federal Court for an order under subsection (3B).

`(3B) Where, on an application under subsection (3A), the Federal Court is satisfied that the information or documents required to be produced by the notice are necessary to enable the Tribunal to exercise any of its powers, or perform any of its functions or duties, under this Part, the Court may order that an acquisition of interest, to which the information or documents relate, not occur until the information or documents have been produced in accordance with the notice.'.".
No. 2-- Clause 5, page 4, proposed paragraph 90HA(3)(c), line 16, omit "10 days", substitute "21 days".
No. 3-- Clause 6, page 8, proposed paragraph 92EA(3)(c), line 15, omit "10 days", substitute "21 days".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Senate has agreed to three amendments to this Bill which the Government feels are unnecessary. The first provides that the ABT may seek Federal Court orders if a person fails to comply with a notice under section 89X of the Broadcasting Act 1942 to provide information. Section 92P, which is proposed to be amended, already gives that power to the ABT since failure to comply with the notice would be a contravention of section 89X and therefore within the scope of section 92P(1)(a). Unnecessary amendments of this nature simply increase the complexity of an already labyrinthine Act and confuse its interpretation.

However, I accept the statements by Senator Powell in the other place that the amendment is intended to be in addition to existing powers. On the basis that the amendment is not intended in any way to diminish the operation of section 92P, the Government is willing to accept it. Were it to be interpreted in any other way, it would in fact limit the scope of the ABT in approaching the Federal Court on matters related to its investigatory requirements in this area. So we are prepared to accept that the mover of the amendment had no intention of doing that and to agree with that interpretation for the purposes of the passage of the Bill.

The second and third amendments increase the minimum period for prior notification of acquisition of prescribed interests from 10 to 28 days. The Government is mindful of the fact that the vast majority of acquisitions notified to the Tribunal will be perfectly legitimate and we have no wish to hamper those acquisitions beyond the extent necessary to examine their bona fides. We feel that 10 days would give the Tribunal adequate time to determine whether a contravention is likely to arise from an acquisition.

We must not forget that we are dealing with the right of individuals to dispose of their own property, and that the public interest in an issue must justify an intrusion on those rights. I have to say that we have a rather spectacular case on these matters before the Tribunal at the moment, and this has perhaps inspired people to move these sorts of amendments. But I must say that, under the changes that we have made, many propositions will be obliged to be reported to the ABT, virtually none of which will have quite the same degree of spectacular attention as this one has. We are a little concerned that we may be unnecessarily jeopardising people's business arrangements. We thought that 10 days struck an appropriate balance, and the ABT agreed that it could perform its functions in that time.

However, this sitting concludes tonight and these matters are of immediate interest to the ABT. Given the urgency, we are not prepared to oppose the amendments. When we come to the Broadcasting and Services Bill later on in the year, we may choose to revisit this issue, but now is not the time and these are not the circumstances for us to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-When this Bill came through the chamber some weeks ago, I indicated that the Opposition's view was that it should be allowed to pass. We took the view that there would be some value in having the complexities of this Bill subject to scrutiny by the Senate under normal procedures. There was some toing and froing about when that might be done, but it has been done expeditiously, as I outlined in my speech and also in my press release, in recognition of the fact that this Bill does have an impact on a substantial commercial matter.

SPEECH.PARA: To pick up the points made by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), the timing period is always a matter of balance. But, of course, we do not have to go out to the 21 days if it can be done before then, and the ABT has indicated--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am sorry, I should have said 21 days, not 28.

—-Yes, 21 days. The Minister will be aware that in the Senate we joined with the Government on the 21 days, rather than agreeing to the 28 days, to try to find that balance between the necessity to meet commercial requirements and giving the ABT adequate time to gather the information that is necessary to underpin any application to the Federal Court.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister made the point that this is a very complicated piece of legislation, and most certainly it is. I and the Opposition share with him the hope that the Broadcasting Services Bill, which he will bring in in due course, can be dealt with in a somewhat more sober climate than the current one with all the toing and froing that is going on. That will give an opportunity for a revisit to this whole area.

The Minister also made a point about proposed subsection 92P. I have had detailed discussion with the Australian Democrats on these matters, and their intention is not in any way to hinder the operation of 92P. Of course, that is our understanding as well. I am sure that if, at some future time, people look back to the Hansard to try to get some guidance as to what is meant by this particular Bill, the comments that we make now will have a material impact, and I think it is important that I echo that view now. Certainly this particular proposed subsection is trying to provide that, where information is sought by the ABT and the people from whom it is sought do not provide it, there is a mechanism by which the ABT can pursue its requirement under its Act to determine actual control. That is its primary test: how does it get the information? This measure provides the opportunity to seek that information and to seek enforcement of its right to get that information from the Federal Court. I think that, without that provision, it could be put in the position where it knows that there is a problem but cannot get the information.

So this measure is intended to put into the hands of the ABT a rather inexact power. It is not the most desirable of powers, but it is one which is very limited in scope and which is designed to make sure that the Tribunal can deal with the matters that it is charged to deal with in that broader function of determining actual control. In that sense, we thought it appropriate to allow this particular amendment to pass.

I might also say that, during the Senate committee discussions last evening with the Department and also the Chairman of the ABT, other matters were canvassed, and we are happy with the answers that we received from the ABT. I might say also, as I did during the second reading debate, that this piece of legislation does have an impact on the current Fairfax matters. In our view, it is unfortunate that it has all come together at the one time. There are other reasons for that, I am sure, but it did mean from our point of view that it should be dealt with under normal circumstances wherever that was possible. We had the opportunity to have the Committee look at it. It did deal with it expeditiously. It was unavailable to deal with it on the Friday because apparently it had a hearing in Brisbane about Cape York. So all parties finally were able to agree on a time.

We feel satisfied that the opportunity for the Senate to look at the matter in an independent way and to receive that additional advice has meant that these particular amendments will make this very difficult Act a slightly better one. But, in the broad, it is still a very imperfect piece of legislation which, I am sure, will give the Government more headaches. This is probably not the appropriate time to enter into more debate about the Fairfax matter. We have had a good go this week. In any event, this is certainly a matter of some moment. It will be interesting to see how the print media inquiry impacts on this matter and what questions arise as witnesses come before it and as the matter develops further. The Opposition will allow this measure to pass. Following negotiations with the Government and the Democrats, these two amendments are supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am grateful to my colleague for correcting the remarks I made about the length of time for consideration by the ABT. I got it wrong; it is 21 days. The Liberal-National Party side of the Opposition eventually agreed with us on an amendment that took us back from the Democrats' position of 28 days to 21 days.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly these issues will be revisited, probably in a number of forums--certainly in the consideration of the Broadcasting Services Bill when it ultimately gets here, and hopefully with the print media inquiry. One envisages the sorts of things that it is likely to come out with as impacting on the Trade Practices Commission and corporations law area, in which case the issues will be manifestly a problem for the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), or on the foreign investment area, in which case they will be manifestly a problem for the Treasurer (Mr Kerin). And no-one will be more delighted than I if that turns out to be the case.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Mr Free:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Opposition does not oppose the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1991. This is a traditional machinery Bill which implements the decisions agreed at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting held on 31 May 1991. The Bill provides for general purposes assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in 1991-92 totalling $13,743m. The amount of funds paid by the Commonwealth to the States and the Northern Territory is based on a formula set out in the Bill. The formula is recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission and is based mainly on a weighting for population. Payments to the ACT are presently covered by the Appropriation Bill (No. 2), because the ACT, which has only recently moved to self-government--and some government that is!--has not yet generated the statistical base for funding on the Grants Commission formula.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget estimate for general purpose funding for the States and the Northern Territory under this Bill is, as I have said, $13,743m, about 13 per cent of estimated Commonwealth outlays in 1991-92. The amount may be adjusted if the consumer price index in March 1992 is different from the estimate made at the time of the Premiers Conference. Total net payments from the Commonwealth to and through the States in 1991-92 are expected to be $26,965m, including $12,129m of current specific purpose payments, as distinct from general purpose payments; that is, the payments under this Bill amount to about half of the total payments to the States and the Northern Territory. This Bill reflects the agreement at the Premiers Conference that the real level of general revenue assistance would be maintained for the three years from 1991-92 to 1993-94. The Bill makes provision for a special revenue assistance grant of $40m to the Northern Territory. This payment is funded by reducing the amount otherwise available to the States.

This legislation raises the very important issue of the relationship between the Commonwealth Government and the State governments. That relationship has become a very important national issue since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) decided that it would be put on the national agenda and called a series of Special Premiers Conferences to consider that relationship.

There has been support on both sides of the House for an improvement in the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States because of a range of problems that have emerged in that relationship. I will go into those a bit later. Suffice it to say at this stage that there are problems of duplication between the two levels of government. There is a lack of responsibility in many cases by one department or agency, and there is a clear lack of policy coordination in many areas where that may be a concern. It is not true that the policies always need to be coordinated. Sometimes, as I will point out later, it is a good thing to have a degree of competition between the different States.

Above all, we now have a system in Australia of increasing fiscal centralism. In 1990-91 the States received more than 50 per cent of their revenue from the Commonwealth Government, if one takes into account the tied grants. The Commonwealth Government raised 80 per cent of all government revenue raised in Australia and spent just 54 per cent of all outlays of all levels of government.

It is clear from those figures that there is a substantial degree of imbalance in the way our federation works. It is true to say that the way our federation works today is a very distant cry from the intention of how it would work by the founding fathers of the Australian Constitution nearly 100 years ago. The problems now with our federation are such that accountability in particular has been taken away from a range of different policy areas which, whilst administered by the States, are in many cases funded by the Commonwealth.

I can think of areas in my own electorate, as all honourable members can, of Federal funding where the details of the allocation of those funds are determined by the States. When constituents complain about the way those funds are allocated, it is very hard to identify who is ultimately responsible for the way in which those policies operate. For example, the grants for local government funding come from the Commonwealth and are distributed by States grants commissions to the different local councils. When local councils are unhappy about the distribution of those grants, or when there is perceived to be an inequity in the distribution of those grants--as there has been in the Stirling Council in my electorate--it is never entirely clear who is ultimately responsible for that apparent or alleged maldistribution in the grants.

TALK.START.PARA: —-A fiery issue.

—-As the honourable member for Sturt points out, it is a fiery issue--in more ways than one. That is the problem of accountability that we have in the way our federation works today. From the point of view of constituents of mine living in the Stirling Council area, it is a matter of inconvenience and irritation--perhaps more than that: it is a system that is not working terribly well.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of this is that State governments are inevitably less responsive to community concerns and demands than they might otherwise be, because they are not responsible for raising the money that they spend. It is easy for them to be inefficient, it is easy for them at times to be unresponsive, and it is often very easy for them to avoid responsibility altogether.

The Commonwealth also imposes priorities from time to time, particularly through tied grants, which do not reflect regional priorities. There are different concerns in different regions. Different policies do not necessarily suit different regions equally well. All honourable members will have seen illustrations of that in their own electorates; for example, a particular Commonwealth policy which is implemented through the tied grants scheme--and, therefore, in practice on a day to day basis--carried out by the States. But it does not work as well in our own local areas as it might in some other local areas and, consequently, the national interest is not best served.

I mentioned earlier the problems of duplication. This is a much debated issue in the context of Commonwealth-State relations. It is remarkable, despite the fact that it is continually debated, that so little has been done to eliminate the duplication between the different levels of government.

The other aspect of the imperfection of our federation at the moment is the way our taxation system works. We all talk a lot about taxation in this House nowadays, and this is another aspect of our taxation system that needs to be given a great deal more thought. I suppose it is being given more thought through the process of the Special Premiers Conferences, although we are not seeing very much coming out of it yet.

What we have, effectively, in Australia is a revenue cartel. The Commonwealth raises the bulk of the revenue--as I said earlier, about 80 per cent of all government revenue raised in Australia. That does take away the alternative, which is to provide competition in revenue raising between the States. Where competition exists, there obviously is pressure on the States to keep taxes low. Where there is a cartel or a monopoly--there is in the case of the Commonwealth and, when it comes to competition, it needs to think of other countries--the pressures of competition are not as great as they are between the States. There was a very good illustration of that when the Bjelke-Petersen Government initially abolished death duties. There was much outrage on the part of the Labor Party. It opposed the abolition of death duties in Queensland by the Bjelke-Petersen Government. I am sure honourable members would remember that.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do indeed.

—-The honourable member for Forde remembers that. The Wran Government, I recall, thought this was an awful and terrible thing. I do not know whether there were any other Labor governments in Australia then, but certainly the Labor Party generally thought this was terrible. But the pressure of competition eventually made Labor follow suit, regardless of the fact that it did not like it. So the Bjelke-Petersen Government--and this must really pain the Labor Party--led the way.

SPEECH.PARA: Not everything the Bjelke-Petersen Government did was necessarily good--you, Mr Deputy Speaker, must be pleased to hear this little yarn--but the fact is that it led the way. The point I am making is that the competition did lead to what we on this side of the House would regard as an extraordinarily beneficial outcome: even the Wran Government was not able to keep in place one of the totems of Labor policy--death duties. Finally, at the Federal level, the Fraser Government abolished the Federal death duties, something it does not get enough credit for these days. That is one important aspect of the problem that exists by creating a monopoly of revenue raising through the Commonwealth.

The States, therefore, are left with a very narrow range of taxes that they can impose. It is interesting to reflect on those taxes in the context of the current national tax debate, which to some extent is a debate about whether taxes are regressive or progressive. I think there is broad agreement in the Parliament that a taxation system should be a fair system and should be seen to be a fair system. We on this side of the House argue that our total tax reform package, as people will soon see, is fair; it contains significant benefits for lower and middle income people, not just great hand-outs for the super-rich. It is a general view, on the part of the Labor Party as well, that we should have that sort of tax system.

When one looks at the way the Federation has affected State tax systems, one sees that those systems are, in fact, extraordinarily unfair and regressive tax systems. It is curious that there is not a debate in State parliaments about the regressive nature of their tax systems. Take my own State of South Australia: about one-third of all the tax revenue raised by the South Australian Government is raised through the payroll tax. Everyone here must agree that the payroll tax has to be one of the most regressive of all taxes, particularly at a time when nearly one million of our people are out of work.

It is a tax which effectively discriminates against the unemployed, because it is a tax on employment which gives employers less capacity to employ than would otherwise be the case. It is also a tax that reduces the competitiveness of our economy, because it is passed on in higher prices for export products or higher prices for products which have to compete with imports. In any case, it is regressive in the sense that the group in the community it discriminates against the most harshly is the group that we all ought to be worrying about the most, that is, the unemployed.

The South Australian Government is very dependent on taxes such as stamp duties, motor vehicle registration taxes, and the like. Those types of taxes are, of course, regressive. The petrol tax and taxes on liquor are big revenue raisers for the South Australian Government. Again, they are very regressive. As a matter of fact, they are consumption taxes which are levied on individuals, as is the Government's wholesale sales tax, regardless of their prosperity, regardless of their income.

As the Government knows, we on this side of the House believe in a goods and services tax and the Government believes in the wholesale sales tax. So the Parliament does actually agree that we should have consumption taxes of some sort. I think the Federal Parliament also basically agrees that the income tax system should provide the progressive elements of our taxation system.

The interesting thing about State taxes is that there is, of course, no income tax system--and has not been since the 1940s--so there is no progressive element in the South Australian Government's taxation system. The richest irony of all is that Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, loves to run around the State saying that he is opposed to a consumption tax, whereas the only taxes he himself administers are consumption taxes. The payroll tax is a possible exception; I suppose that one would not describe it as a consumption tax. All the other taxes he administers are effectively consumption taxes.

To add irony to irony, John Bannon, unlike a lot of the Premiers, who have been much more circumspect in their public comments on this issue, says that he is opposed to any income taxing powers being passed back to the States. The one opportunity Mr Bannon has to make his taxation system in South Australia a progressive taxation system is spurned by him in hysterical public statements, such as his statements to the Sunday Mail newspaper on 7 September. The implication of what he said is, `Please do not give me, John Bannon, a progressive tax system. Give me the regressive system that I have at present. Please leave me with my payroll taxes, my stamp duties, my liquor, tobacco and petrol taxes and so on. Please leave me with consumption taxes of that kind with no offsetting benefits from a progressive income tax system. Leave me with those consumption taxes'. Then he hopes that the cameras will change to another scene, and when they flick back to him again he says, `And, by the way, I am opposed to the Liberal Party's consumption tax'. History will judge this argument and it will see that people like that are not fair dinkum. People like that are just not telling it as it is.

It is a great shame, I think, that leaders of some of our governments in this country cannot face up to the problems of our tax system and talk about them in a constructive and mature way rather than descending into hysterical rhetoric. There we have it: a taxation system in South Australia which is extraordinarily regressive and which discriminates against low income and unemployed South Australians.

I will just add one other thing. I think it is important that organisations like SACOSS, the South Australian Council of Social Service, the churches and other welfare organisations in South Australia examine in much more detail the regressive nature of the State tax system and perhaps look with a great deal more sympathy and with more interest--I believe they have not really looked at it at all--at the possibility of introducing some more progressive elements into that State tax system. They really ought to be leading the debate there, but they tend to be extraordinarily conservative in continually batting for the status quo.

What are the solutions to these problems? There are solutions which are supposed to be subject to discussion at the Special Premiers Conference. A range of propositions has been put forward. Working groups have been established where the Commonwealth and the States are looking at the sorts of issues that I have been talking about. But I am actually very doubtful that anything of any real meaning, of any real importance, will come out of this Special Premiers Conference process, which the Prime Minister describes as historic, visionary and so on. There are a couple of reasons why I think that: first of all, the Labor Party here in Canberra, the Federal Labor Party, the Caucus, is becoming very nervous about the Special Premiers Conference process. I read with a lot of interest the article on the front page of the Australian Financial Review yesterday which described a meeting of 25 mainly left wing members of the Caucus who had met the previous day, on Tuesday, to consider the Special Premiers Conference process. They expressed concern about two things: first of all, that they were not being kept informed as to the progress taking place and that the only information they had came from newspapers; and, secondly, they expressed very real concern at the loss of centralised control of a range of policy areas. The two identified were Aboriginal affairs and what the Labor Party loves to call social justice. I suppose that a wholesale sales tax is social justice! The Labor Party is absolutely terrified of losing control of this social justice agenda which, if one takes the words `social justice' literally, must include a gigantic range of policy areas.

The implication of the views of the group of 25 is that they believe that the new federalism process that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is supposed to be undertaking is one that should not proceed any further. That point is actually as good as proven by the fact that one of the 25 people at the meeting was none other than the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). They were not all from the Left of the Party, although some of them were rather obviously sucking up to the Left of the Party. I see that the honourable member for Blaxland said not a word at this meeting. He sat at the back of the room with his pencil, taking notes of all that was said.

That is quite interesting, because the Australian Financial Review article went on to say that the whole issue of the new federalism--or the `new new federalism', since the Fraser Government had new federalism--is, `fertile ground for the Keating leadership push'. Why else would he have been there at the group of 25 meeting on Tuesday?

So, it is clear that the issue of leadership in the Labor Party is now intervening in what I think was, in fact, a very responsible process of trying to get our federal system working more smoothly and more efficiently. The fact that the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, is now taking the view that he must do everything he can to try to stop this new federalism process, presumably on the grounds that the Prime Minister is a supporter of it and the Left of the Labor Party does not like it, leads us to the obvious conclusion that the process will ultimately be scuttled on the grounds that the Prime Minister simply will not have the numbers or the courage to go ahead with it.

The second area of concern comes from the Premiers themselves. Some Premiers, such as Mr Greiner, are very positive about this process and are making a very valuable contribution to it. Interestingly enough, some Premiers are not. No Premier is making a smaller contribution than the Premier of my own State, Mr Bannon. Again, I refer to the article in the Sunday Mail of 7 September. In that article he attacked the proposition that the States may get income tax powers offered back to them. That was strange, considering that he had agreed in October 1990 to the establishment of a working group of officials to look at that whole proposition. It was strange, bearing in mind that on 30 July at the Special Premiers Conference there was agreement that income tax powers being passed back to the States was at least a possibility. They did not make a decision, of course, to do it, but they agreed that it was something that mechanically could be done and should be subject to further examination.

By all accounts, Mr Bannon, his advisers and staff are working very harmoniously in these working groups and, behind the scenes, are very comfortable with the idea of looking at the possibility of providing the States with a more progressive tax system than they currently have. But when it comes to public pronouncements, he is taking a completely different view--I guess out of political expediency, really. A man whose popularity is now plunging in his own home State has every good reason to look at some politically expedient stunts, and this may be just one of them. But he is claiming that, if income tax powers were passed back to the States at least in some form or another, this would lead to a flight from South Australia; that South Australia would somehow become a basket case as a result of it. That is a self-confession, if ever I have heard one.

Mr Bannon admits that, without massive subsidies, a State under his administration is simply completely uncompetitive. But of course he also omits to tell the public of South Australia that the principle of fiscal equalisation is not a principle that anybody has at this stage proposed to disband. I am sure, given the pathetic and crippling state of the South Australian economy, South Australians would be unwilling to see the principle of fiscal equalisation disbanded. So it is a pity that somebody like Premier Bannon is taking what we might call a `little Australia approach' to this extremely important view.

My heart here, unusually, goes out to the Prime Minister, who has quite rightly identified the need to do something in this area. The last thing we want is State Premiers, for reasons of domestic political expediency, torpedoing something which should be an important national effort. We do not want people here in this Parliament doing the same thing. We do not want the honourable member for Blaxland suddenly pretending to be a member of the Left of the Labor Party or trying to ingratiate himself with the left of the Labor Party, going to the group of 25 meeting and sabotaging also this process. That is a matter of understandable concern for all Australians when this process is important.

So, in conclusion, we on this side of the House do take seriously the Special Premiers Conference process. We do think all these types of issues that I have been discussing should be closely examined. We are not prescriptive about it, but they should be closely examined. There should be cooperation between the Commonwealth and the States in putting together a much better Federation. We are really at the point where our federal system, as a system, is grinding pretty much to a halt. We have to decide what we are going to do. Will we simply try to disband our federal system altogether in all but technical terms and effectively end up with one all powerful central government? If we do not think that is either desirable or practical, the onus is on this Parliament and the other parliaments of Australia to make sure that that federal system operates more efficiently and effectively.

The reality is that, whatever our views, whether we are centralists or decentralists--and members of this House have different views on that issue--the written Constitution is unlikely to be changed by the Australian people in favour of the centralists, so we may as well work a lot harder than we have done over the last few years to try to make sure that that federal system we do have works a lot more efficiently than it does currently. I am very sorry that some people--and this is not pertinent to all people in the Labor Party; there are plenty of people of goodwill on this issue--who are using it for malicious internal and external purposes, and that is threatening to sabotage the whole process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to support the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), has raised a number of interesting points, in particular the whole notion of federalism and the current state of play as to the role between the Commonwealth and the States. Indeed, Government members are pleased to hear, as will be many of our colleagues, that there is an amount of goodwill for the whole process. Perhaps one should alleviate his concerns about those being expressed by some people as to the delivery of services which are currently overseen by the Commonwealth and as to whether the States will continue to be responsible for some of them.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill puts in place one of the very interesting changes that are brought about by the Special Premiers Conference, that is, the transfer of moneys and, indeed, the transfer of the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture to the Commonwealth, with the agreement of Victoria. Yesterday we also heard the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) discuss the proposal that he will place before the Premiers tomorrow, which is that the whole TAFE infrastructure be funded by the Federal Government, with the result that an extra 100,000 places will be created within our TAFE sector for young Australians.

I think many of us who were around in 1974 saw the move of the universities to the Commonwealth as something which was worth while and good, and something that enabled whole universities to develop in their own way and style. Many people opposed that move, wanting to keep universities very closely behind confined State borders, as they saw terrible consequences arising from that dreaded States rights issue.

All of us now would understand that Australia is very much more a national country. State borders, over which people move for jobs and which separate areas that recognise or do not recognise educational qualifications, really become meaningless in that context. This Bill gives us a very practical and real example of the way in which the Special Premiers Conference and the kinds of moves which are currently being made by the education Minister in the area of TAFE can apply. This means that a student studying at a college of agriculture in Victoria will be able, perhaps at the end of the first or second year when his or her family moves to north Queensland or Western Australia, to have acknowledgment for the work that he or she has done and, with national accreditation standards that are being pursued through the Special Premiers Conference, have his or her qualifications recognised.

Many of us have taught in places where there are children who have come from all round Australia or who have been moving to all parts of Australia. So in terms of education the State boundaries become very artificial. One nonsense that has grown up within Australia is different State handwriting systems. We can all tell the House of the nonsense of children being forced to change their handwriting and so on simply because they happened to cross what is a recognised State boundary. Fortuitously, over a long period we have seen a movement away from that and we now have--good heavens!--an Australian standard of handwriting, which has alleviated enormous problems and pressure for numbers of young students.

We have also seen the emergence of the national schools document from Hobart--the Hobart Declaration on Schooling--in which our education Minister has acknowledged that there was a need to look at what is being taught throughout Australia and to attempt to take the very best of that and develop national curricula. Instead of seven or eight resources being duplicated throughout six States, those resources would be put to the very best use and certain States would take control of areas of the curriculum in which they were the best and other States would look at the other areas. In this way, we would be able to pool the very best of our resources and develop a program of national curricula which could, in fact, be emulated throughout Australia.

The Special Premiers Conference also looks at a whole range of duplication and the different ways in which we have service delivery. We already have the development of the National Rail Freight Corporation, which will enable freight to be shifted throughout Australia without having to be moved from gauge to gauge to gauge with the associated costs that ensue from extra handling. That is very real and tangible and will, in effect, bring about an enormous amount of reform as well as save the Australian taxpayers an enormous amount of money. We acknowledge that to establish a National Rail Freight Corporation, there is a requirement to develop infrastructure, and that will require money. However, in the medium and long term that will enable us to save enormous amounts of money, to bring about efficiency and, indeed, to move further down the path of acknowledging that we are all Australians and not simply members of States.

One of the other things which has emerged from the Special Premiers Conferences is the creation of a national power grid. It seems quite extraordinary that some of our States can produce excess energy while others have difficulty in doing so. It seems absolutely and eminently sensible that we should work towards ensuring that energy which we as Australians use is looked at in a national way and addressed as a national issue. That has developed out of these Special Premiers Conferences.

A whole range of agreements are currently being pursued by Ministers in areas such as child-care, the development of refuges, and aged care and in a whole range of services, including the Commonwealth-State agreement on housing. All of us want to ensure that money is spent in the best way and that, no matter where we live in Australia, we can be assured that a service will be delivered to us. Under the national child-care scheme the Federal Government has attempted to ensure that people are entitled to a child-care place, irrespective of whether they live in Perth or Mackay. In fact, the Government has worked very hard, through developing its centres in regional areas, to provide, hopefully by 1995, child-care places for 250,000 Australian children. That is a national program which has a national thrust and which sets national standards.

While the States per se set regulations that govern the kinds of health requirements and space in child-care centres, they have never been largely involved in the total process of child-care. So that is something which needs to be worked out and controlled because the States have traditionally had a role to play in children's services--be they wards of the state or foster children. They provide a range of services. In particular, they provide education through the compulsory years. So the States have a role to play there. It is incumbent upon us all to ensure that these services are not depleted through our quest to dispel fears over duplication.

The same I guess can also be said in respect of any of the services in which the Commonwealth has played a reformist role. In the aged care area, the Commonwealth has been involved with the development of hostels, nursing homes, a charter of rights and nursing home standards. It is important that we continue to ensure that standards do not fall but that any duplications are cut out. The Federal Government and the States have a role to play in these issues.

Housing is something which has been at the forefront of discussions within Special Premiers Conferences. Housing is also an important indicator of economic reform. We have already heard today the Acting Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Howe) talk about housing starts being a key indicator. The Burdekin inquiry has looked at youth homelessness and the demands on our community to provide youths with a roof over their heads. Indeed, much of what the Burdekin inquiry threw up on youth homelessness could be directly attributed to the States. Over a half of the young people in our refuges have been wards of the state. As soon as they turn 16 the state throws them out and the Federal Government needs to pick them up. Surely this is not in the best interests of anybody.

A coordinated and integrated program would deliver a service. It would ensure that young people who have, through no fault of their own, become wards of the state, would be given an opportunity to live a much better life than simply being thrown out on the street as soon as the state decides that it has finished with them. We are very hopeful that the Special Premiers Conference will come to grips with some of those coordinating problems so that a better delivery of service can be made available to many of our people.

As well as that, special purpose grants and general purpose grants are part of the whole issue of funding and financing. As an Opposition spokesperson has said, we need to look at the whole notion of the supposedly fiscal imbalance which some of our State Premiers are talking about. As people would know, the Queensland Premier is also one of those who do not want changes in that area. But it is also important to look at the way in which Commonwealth moneys--that is, Australian taxpayers' moneys--are spent by our State colleagues and the way in which they are used. We need to determine whether they are used in the very best ways; whether they are used for the purpose for which they were given and targeted. This leads us to the whole argument of tied grants, whether we are quite certain that Australian taxpayers' money is being spent in the best possible way and whether we should maintain that process.

Accountability has always been a keynote of this Government. The Government has established many procedures through many of its funding proposals to ensure that public funds must always, and are always, accounted for in the very best of ways. So it is not unreasonable to expect that Australian taxpayers' money which is handed over to the States should not also be accounted for and attested to in that kind of way.

Indeed, we have had a wide-ranging debate on the issues which the Special Premiers Conferences have thrown up. Throughout the community there has been a great deal of support for an end to duplication in services and the costs that go with that. However, we have to ensure that the community is provided with the best services by the best service providers. I guess in some areas we would argue that that is the national government. If we are going to set national goals and national standards, it is our Federal Parliament and our national Government that should be pursuing them. That, of course, is a matter for debate.

This Bill addresses a particular example of that in the field of education. I can only wish the Minister For Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) well in his discussions tomorrow as he moves TAFE into the Federal arena. I am also pleased to hear those opposite talk about the crucial and central issue of balancing the demands of States against the rights of the nation and the rights of people within the nation to be treated equally. That is a tension which emerges in any federal system. It is something which needs to be addressed carefully by the Special Premiers Conferences.

We have already seen the establishment of the National Rail Freight Authority, a national grid and the movement to a national system for TAFE, which we hope will come about tomorrow. We need to look at the creation of national standards in a whole range of services which we hope will continue to develop. The States will maintain a defined role in the kinds of things which they do well. But it will be the role of the Federal Government to ensure that those things which are important to all of us as of right, and as Australians, are maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.
