TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to support the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and, in particular, the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture. I was delighted that the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) referred to that very eminent college in Victoria. Whilst I do not quite agree with her sentiments about national standards and national curriculum, I appreciate her sentiments about that very good college. I declare my interest in the college in that I have been associated with it for a number of years. I am presently on the council of the VCAH and have been associated with agricultural education for the last 15 or 20 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I compliment the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) and his Department for solving this problem which has been around with Victorian and Federal governments since about 1978 or 1979. Historically, Victorian agricultural colleges were funded by way of a tortuous and strange path. Funds made available to the Department of Agriculture flowed on to the various colleges. Back in 1979-80, a number of us approached the then government in order to try to solve this problem, but to no avail. It was always too hard; it was always too difficult; and nobody made any real progress.

As Victorians would be aware, in March 1983 the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture came into existence, forming an independent educational institution away from the Department of Agriculture and relating to the Education Department in that State. Even though this independent institution was formed, this funding problem remained. Successive submissions to the Federal Department came to no avail. I compliment the Minister and the Department for actually solving the problem by allowing the Federal funding to flow direct from the Commonwealth to the college and for removing the State from the funding program.

The formation of the VCAH, as it is known in Victoria, combined a multicampus institution at Glenormiston in the western part of Victoria; Gilbert Chandler in the Werribee region, which looked after the dairy farmers and the technology of dairy factories; Longeranong in the northern north-west part of the State; Burnley, which was particularly interested in the horticultural area; Dookie, which is in the north-east part of Victoria; and McMillan rural studies, which is in Gippsland. All of those campuses make up the VCAH as a multicampus operation providing advanced courses of education and TAFE programs.

The college is unique throughout Australia because there is only one other college that I am aware of--the Darwin college--which provides advanced programs and TAFE programs under the one umbrella. The key feature of the VCAH is that the staff and the students are very close to the industry they serve. The staff who are employed in the advanced education area work in very well with those staff who teach TAFE programs. There is a very good utilisation of resources in terms of the capital structures and in terms of the way in which the teaching staff operate in the multiprogram, multicampus operation. The TAFE people have different approaches to the training of skills compared with those in the advanced area who provide the normal teaching operations.

The simple figures are that at the higher education level we have 765 students. At the TAFE level about 10,000 participants take part in programs over the 12-month period, varying from one to two days to 40 half-day programs in the sheep and wool industry and in the dairy industry. Often these are off-campus programs. The programs themselves are often taken to the farmers or members of the community in their own location. Those 10,000 participants in the TAFE programs make up 1,300 EFTs, to put it in the technical jargon. We think the college is doing a very good job and acts as a total institution.

Because of the Federal Government's program under the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), in which the amalgamation should take place, the Victorian Government has now agreed that the VCAH should amalgamate with the Melbourne University. In broad terms, the VCAH has agreed to this proposal and there has been a very good cooperative arrangement between the Melbourne University and the VCAH in bringing about a happy marriage. While some of us are concerned about the philosophy and thesis that amalgamations are a good thing, we have to go along with the guidelines that the Government has produced from its White Paper. We do not agree that big is better, but in this particular case the amalgamation will allow the VCAH to remain as a single entity, with its six campuses providing a variety of programs. As I said, the Victorian Government has agreed to this proposal, provided that the Federal Government agreed to the changes in the funding programs which this Bill will allow to take place.

The key element is that the funding arrangements now make the VCAH compatible with other tertiary institutions around Australia. As the honourable member for Forde quite rightly indicated, the qualifications and the comparisons between the other tertiary institutions will be of similar vein. Those qualifications that the VCAH offers in Victoria will be acceptable throughout Australia. This will just tidy up some of the loose ends in the relationship between the college and the Commonwealth in terms of funding.

In very simple terms, without going into too much detail--the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) has been good enough to apprise me of the details--the total funding for the higher education component is $8.4m, but there has been a transfer of approximately $4.4m from the Commonwealth to the college, which will take over a similar amount of money that the State historically paid to the college. I note in the transfer that there was an allowance for superannuation at 14 per cent--a fairly high figure compared with that in the private sector. There is a contribution from the HECS program which is fairly significant from the student body. That has been taken into account in the calculations.

I and the college are pleased that these arrangements will be coming into place on 1 January 1992 so that the college can proceed with full confidence that in the second half of the financial year funding will become available and in the following years that funding will proceed within the normal guidelines. It is a wonderful breakthrough and a great triumph for the Department and for those of us who have been advocating this change for a number of years.

Finally, primary industry is suffering particularly difficult times in the wheat and wool industries, the cattle industry is not looking so bright, and the dairy industry is holding its own. The VCAH is providing qualified and trained people in the industry, although at this stage there is a major downturn in one or two of our major industries. It is very important that the college continue to provide these trained personnel in the farming, pastoral, agricultural and horticultural industries. The horticultural industries are providing a number of trained people who are working in the urban sector. A number of people tend to overlook the contribution of horticulturalists in parks and gardens, racecourses and a number of urban areas where there is certainly a demand from people in the cities to beautify them. These trained people are finding a number of jobs in this area out of the traditional agricultural-horticultural arena.

In my view, the college has done a very good job in providing these trained people at the higher education level and at the TAFE level. It has provided skills, experience and some further on-the-job training so that the farmers of the future can provide the necessary skills to handle the next upturn, whenever it might come. Hopefully, by the year 2000 there will be trained personnel in Victoria and around Australia to guide the farming community through better times than we are now presently enjoying, so that Australia can feed and clothe the world population of 5.5 billion.

I finish on that note: with the proper funding, attitudes and curriculum, these trained people will come to a new era of prosperity with some skills and abilities that will make Australia a contributor to both the food and the fibre of the world with its ever-increasing population. I am sure that with the contribution of the VCAH, Victorian farmers and horticulturalists, in turn, will be able to make their contribution. The funding arrangements that have been put in place by the present Government are much appreciated. The changes that have been brought about are the end of a long saga going over many years. I thank the Government and appreciate the changes that have taken place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to take the opportunity afforded by the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill to make some comments on the question of federalism and the way in which government is organised in our Commonwealth. Australia has a three-level system of government, with Commonwealth, State and local government all sharing the responsibility of administering the various services and facilities and governing the various aspects of our way of life.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Constitution really refers to only two levels of government, Federal and State, and this Bill deals fundamentally with the distribution of funds between the Federal Government and the States. At the time of our Federation, though, it was the Commonwealth that was added to our system of government and not the other tiers. Local and State government had existed for quite some time. So every power that was granted to the new Commonwealth Government was in fact a power that had been ceded by one of the other levels of government.

I think this provides something of the history of our federalism over the years. It seems that there has been a continuing debate, probably ever since 1901 and certainly prior to then, over what is an appropriate mix of powers between the various levels of government and then, perhaps also importantly, how those powers are to be matched with the taxing system that our country has available to it. That has always, I guess, been a matter of some controversy and, of course, in the context of Premiers Conferences the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the various State Premiers, with a representative of local government, are again looking at the whole question of the distribution of powers, discussing the interchange of powers between the various tiers. They are also looking at future taxing arrangements.

Many of those changes are likely to require some amendments to our Federal Constitution by way of referendum. I guess the history of referendums is such that no-one can be filled with any confidence that any change, even if it is agreed at the Premiers Conference, will be finally approved by the Australian people. I think it is somewhat unfortunate that our system of referendums has fallen into some degree of disrepute or suspicion as a result perhaps of past events. It seems there is a degree of suspicion about every referendum. They are always perceived as being yet another Commonwealth grab for power, that there is a secret agenda that is going to deliver things that the Australian people did not expect at the time that the question was being considered.

A lot of that suspicion goes back to the referendum in relation to counting Aboriginals in the census. The vast majority of Australians supported it as a very innocent question that nobody could possibly oppose. Subsequently they learnt that, as a result of voting to count Aboriginals in the census, the Commonwealth perceived this as giving it a right to take powers in a whole new area and to make decisions and to introduce legislation in a way in which the Australian people were not really thinking about at the time that referendum was supported. So every new constitutional question faces that difficulty, a suspicion that there is a secret agenda.

With this particular proposed set of Premiers Conferences, there is always going to be the overriding suspicion that by the year 2000 a new Constitution which involves republicanism and all sorts of other things that many Australians--perhaps most Australians--are unlikely to support will be on the ALP secret agenda. I think that is disadvantaging the whole process that is currently under way.

I am not one of those who believe that the Constitution was given on Mount Sinai and should never be changed. As the years pass, we need to recognise that the circumstances envisaged by the founding fathers at the time will have changed and that history leaves those sorts of events behind. If there is an overwhelming need to change the circumstances, to change the way in which we have been behaving, the way in which we have administered and shared power in the past, then we should take that opportunity if the need is demonstrated.

I think it has been clearly demonstrated that there is needless duplication between the three tiers of government. There are some exercises of power which are shared between all three tiers. There are many instances of duplication of departments between Federal and State. Any effort that we can make to rationalise power sharing ought to be supported. In viewing all of those sorts of exercises, primary consideration should be given to the cheapest and most efficient way to deliver services. No-one can tell me that duplicating bureaucracies at the Federal and State levels is efficient and the cheapest possible way of operating. We clearly need to be looking at ways of rationalising that kind of activity.

One of the most important aspects as we look at the future of our federalism will be considering the mechanisms of taxing. Vertical fiscal imbalance is obviously one of the ways in which inefficiency grows and our bureaucracy becomes more costly. I have been told that, currently, the Commonwealth raises approximately double what it spends, the States about half of what they spend and local government about three-quarters of their budgets. Victoria said in a recent submission that the States raise 17 per cent of taxes but spend 50 per cent of outlays.

When there are transfers of this nature, there are always disputes about the formulas. We have the charade of the Premiers Conference; a comic opera in three acts with all of the Premiers arriving in Canberra telling us what strong cases they have, on the second day listening to the Commonwealth telling them that this is what they are going to get whether they like it or not, and then the Premiers going home complaining about being bitterly disappointed but usually with an increased share of the overall revenue.

There are naturally going to be disputes over the formulas. There are various systems of administering the funds. Some funds are administered and distributed on a per capita basis; others through systems of fiscal equalisation; others by specific applications for particular grants; and then, of course, there are special purpose grants for particular purposes. I think it has perhaps been a bit disappointing that, particularly at the Federal level over recent times, there seems to have been a particular emphasis on the development of programs where there are special purpose grants--specific grants for specific purposes. I sometimes think that many of these grants are more designed to provide photo opportunities for the Ministers and to provide handouts to particular favoured groups, rather than to do anything constructive towards achieving specific objectives. They are designed more for the publicity that they can generate rather than the good they can do in the community. Hundreds of millions of dollars of the Federal Budget are now allocated in this way.

Specific purpose grants really guarantee that there are going to be inefficiencies. The Commonwealth bureaucracy, or the government of the day, decides that it will spend money on a particular area. Then the States fight hard to get the maximum share of it, or local government looks to get as much as it can, irrespective of the merits of whether that particular task should be undertaken at all. They all fight to get their share so that they can spend the maximum amount of money. In many instances, it is not a priority of theirs and, in fact, if they had the ignominy of actually having to raise the taxes for that purpose, they would not do it at all. So we have these programs, and very rarely do we consider the merits of them and what they are able to do constructively to assist our society.

If we were to move strictly to fiscal responsibility, where we all raise what we spend, this would also create difficulties. Some States, naturally by way of their environment, have a more costly job in carrying out their business of government. Some are large in area; some have climatic difficulties; and the various population spreads certainly affect the cost of administering and providing services. That applies equally to local government. If we were to have a strict system where each tier of government raised what it spent, where each State and each local government raised only what it spent, then those who have the most would continue to get more and those who have the least would continue to do poorly. We would end up with a lack of equality amongst Australians which we would find intolerable. So there will always need to be some degree of vertical fiscal imbalance and that is going to occur regardless of what kind of system we have, if we are determined to be fair and provide equal services, or close to equal services, for all Australians.

The Federal Government itself has a great power to influence what amount of revenue the States are able to raise and which States prosper. It locates its departments in particular locations. It provides grants in specific ways. It supports industry with contracts and the like. All of those things will influence which States have a greater revenue raising capacity than others. Traditionally it has been Victoria and New South Wales, the most populous States, that have done best in that regard. Victoria and New South Wales receive most of the arts and sports funding; they get most of the departmental allocations, way in excess of their proportion of the population. I guess a lot of that happens because of the political power which rests in the most populous States. New South Wales and Victoria have provided most of the Prime Ministers and Cabinet Ministers and they have therefore exercised considerable influence when any of those decisions have been made. There is therefore a natural tendency for those States to do particularly well in that regard.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday, following the passage of a resolution by the House relating to Parliamentary Secretaries, the right honourable member for New England asked the Deputy Speaker occupying the Chair whether Parliamentary Secretaries will be able to move motions without their being seconded or whether it was still a requirement that a motion moved by any member of the House other than a Minister should be seconded. I see the right honourable member has joined us and he may want to seek a clarification, so I will anticipate that. The resolution agreed to by the House was in the following terms:

INTERJECT.PARA: That, for the purposes of the procedures of the House, any reference to Ministers shall be taken to include Parliamentary Secretaries, with the exception of references to questions seeking information (chapter XI of the Standing Orders).
House of Representatives Practice states:

Because a Minister in proposing business before the House is assumed to have the backing of the Government, it has been the continuing practice of the House that motions (and amendments) moved by Ministers do not require a seconder.

The resolution adopted by the House makes it clear that for all purposes of the procedures of the House, other than references to questions seeking information--chapter XI of the Standing Orders--Parliamentary Secretaries can now carry out similar roles to Ministers. In these circumstances motions and amendments moved by Parliamentary Secretaries need not be seconded. Does the right honourable member for New England seek further guidance on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, my concern was to know whether it was the status of the Parliamentary Secretaries that was involved in the resolution and, because the resolution specifically referred to the Standing Orders, I suspected that the answer you gave would be the way it would be presented. But I would put to you that there are some aspects of the responsibilities of a member who is not a Minister which would presumably mean that it is not just whether or not one is presumed to have the authority of the Government behind one to determine the outcome. It was for that reason that I was not sure, based on the form of the resolution, whether or not it would still be necessary when moving motions for a seconder to be presented.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I accept the ruling and, as I did yesterday, just express to you, Sir, my concern that this more than anything demonstrates that you are putting the Parliamentary Secretaries in locus standi; in other words, in the same position as a Minister. It would obviously have been easier for the Government to have expanded the Ministry, which was one of the concerns that was expressed more vocally in the House during debate yesterday.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think the reason for the statement by the Leader of the House was to clarify the issues the right honourable member addresses. I guess the outcome is that in substance what he is saying is the case, that they are to be understood as performing the role of Ministers, with the exception that they are not to be involved in taking questions.

INTERJECT.PARA: I should also add that in a sense the fact that the Chair does not call for a seconder has been a convention rather than a rule within the Standing Orders of the House. Did the right honourable member wish to rise again? I am happy to try to clarify it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I accept your ruling. The point I make is that I do not think it is just a matter of the majority. The point I would query about your advice when you say it is a matter of convention--and I am seeking your indulgence to speak on this--is that it should not just be section 44 of the Constitution that distinguishes somebody who is not a Minister from somebody who is. I can see the progressive encroachment on the status of a Minister in a way that I do not think the House necessarily foreshadowed in the debate yesterday. When the Standing Orders prescribe that something should happen, then that should be so, and I suggest it is not just a matter for the Speaker to say, `Well, because you presume that somebody has the authority, you do not need a seconder'. That is really why I raised the question yesterday, because that is not specifically in the Standing Orders and I therefore felt it was a matter that should be clarified.

—-I thank the right honourable member for his response. In a sense, what he is doing now is expressing an opinion about what has happened. There is probably some merit in further considering the matter when the Speaker returns. To be fair to the Speaker, that probably makes sense.

—-Mr Acting Speaker, could I submit that perhaps the Hansard extract from tonight be submitted to the Speaker for his consideration, as well as the question I first raised. I would appreciate it if, on his return, he might respond. It is fairly fundamental in the conduct of the affairs of this place, and it is for that reason that I raised it in the first instance. I believe it does need to be considered by Mr Speaker on his return. Thank you for your consideration.

—-Mr Acting Speaker, with your indulgence, I wish to comment on what has taken place this evening and to indicate, as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has, that the ruling you have given is the ruling that I anticipated. I join with the right honourable member for New England in his request for the matter to be further considered by the Speaker when he returns. The House is indebted to the right honourable member for New England for raising this question following the debate when the resolution was being considered to lift the status of Parliamentary Secretaries almost to the level of Ministers. As I indicated at the time, the House and the Australian public should be outraged at what the Government is doing in relation to this matter, continually whittling down the authority of Parliament. As far as the fine point of the ruling is concerned, we look forward to further advice from the Speaker when he returns.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Prior to dinner I was commenting on the distribution of powers between the Federal and State governments and, in particular, the fiscal equalisation principles which might apply in relation to the distribution of grants between the various States. I pointed out that the great bulk of political power in Australia has perhaps naturally been generated and exercised by the two most populous States and that has benefited them significantly and, I would submit, to an extent greater than their population would justify. I was going through some of the particular areas where those benefits had accrued. One obvious additional area was in relation to the tariff policies that have applied over recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: The manufacturing States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, but probably particularly Victoria, have been the major beneficiaries of that policy. EPAC, when putting forward the case for reductions in tariffs, made the point that the total output for every State in Australia would increase as a result of tariff reductions, except for Victoria. That is obviously an illustration of the fact that Victorians have benefited over the years from the existing tariff policy. Other Australians have paid dearly for cars, whitegoods, clothing, footwear and the like as a result of these particular policies.

The NFF in a study some time ago put the cost of tariffs to farmers at around $6,000 each. In other words, there has been a significant transfer through that manufacturing policy towards the State of Victoria while, on the other hand, export earnings are shared amongst the States. There are no subsidies for mining, farming and the like, so those profits are taxed and then distributed to the various States. Once more, the head offices for most of the export and mining industries, even though the industries are generally located in Western Australia and Queensland, tend to be in Sydney and Melbourne, which has boosted industry in those States, created jobs and profits, and raised their taxing base. So New South Wales and Victoria have been able to tax other States' profitability.

Just recently the Victorian Government issued a paper Fiscal Equalisation Issues for Review. In that paper the Victorian Government claims that it is subsidising other Australians to the tune of $175.16 per head. To come to that figure, the Victorian Government has had to exercise remarkable dexterity with figures. It compares the grants that would come from the Commonwealth on a per capita basis with fiscal equalisation. The paper complains that before much longer Queensland will get greater grants than Victoria. It is inevitable that, as the populations of Queensland and Western Australia continue to grow, those States will receive a greater share of the funding.

Perhaps one of the faults with the current system is that funding tends to follow the shifts of population; it comes after people have moved. It is not there in advance to provide the facilities and services that the increasing population will require; instead, we allocate it to States where the population is declining and, in a sense, waste it on buildings that will not be used.

Victoria also argued that the formula should be changed to eliminate location specific difficulties. Victoria, a tiny State with a comparatively dense population, has many cost advantages over the other States. In putting forward this philosophy, I am sure that Victoria is more interested in self-interest than in genuine equity. Its services are naturally cheaper and roads, schools and hospitals can all be provided much more efficiently and cheaply in such a compact environment.

I think that Victoria does make one valid point; that is, there is no obligation on the States to spend the extra money provided for this disability on the disability itself. That is particularly apparent at present in Queensland, which receives an allocation for location disabilities--I would argue, rightly so--while at the same time the new Goss Labor Government is viciously cutting back services to country areas. So in a sense it is receiving money from the Commonwealth to do a particular function but is choosing to spend that money in other areas.

In general, I do not think there can be any argument that the Victorian Government has prepared this paper as an attempt to smokescreen its own incompetence. Victoria's financial position is disastrous. That is clearly the fault of its Labor Government. Victorians have had to bail out failed financial institutions and their statutory authorities while their welfare bureaucracy has grown out of all proportion; and even the Melbourne public transport system requires $3m a day in subsidies. I feel sorry for ordinary Victorians. All they did was vote for Labor and now their State is in ruins.

However, Victoria is not all that far ahead of South Australia, for instance. The long suffering South Australian taxpayers are having to bail out their State Bank to the tune of $1 billion a year to keep it solvent. In Western Australia, Labor has delivered Western Australia Inc. and a bill for future generations to pick up. In Tasmania, Labor has crippled industry and commerce. It is, indeed, a tragic story.

The only difference between Queensland and the other States is 10 years of Labor Government. Sadly, Premier Goss has learnt nothing from the experiences of his Labor colleagues. He is behaving just like Cain, Burke, Bannon and Kirner; in fact, Premier Goss will live to regret the day that he made the public boast that he would do for Queensland what Cain did for Victoria. Sadly, he is delivering that promise, if few others. He inherited the best economy, balanced Budgets, an exciting development agenda and the lowest taxes. In less than two years he has put Queensland on the road to Victoria. His Public Service is burgeoning beyond belief. There have been massive tax hikes--up to 200 per cent and 300 per cent in some instances--and hidden Budget deficits already.

It is interesting to note that 50 per cent of all the new Public Service positions created by all tiers of government right around Australia over the past 12 months have been created by the Goss Government in Queensland--what an extraordinary record--despite vicious and heavy cutbacks in rural areas. The staff increases are in strange places: Premier Goss's staff has increased from 12 to 29; the staff of the Cabinet Office has gone from three to 66; and there are another 19 positions provided for in this year's State Budget. That is where the increases are occurring. Queensland is developing the same kind of Public Service bureaucracy that has been the tradition of Labor governments in other places and that has put them on the road to destruction.

If that is not bad enough, we have now heard that Premier Goss is to spend $10m refurbishing his own office. In these times of critical economic crisis the Premier of Queensland can find $10m to refurbish his own office--just one floor of the building--with marble lifts, oak panelling and the like. What a tragedy it is that last night in the Federal Parliament we were debating whether our country can afford family allowances while the Commonwealth continues to make grants to a State such as Queensland which turns around and spends $10m on oak panels and marble lifts for the Premier's office. That is one of the problems we have when it comes to distributing funds to the States. While we may have noble objectives, there is very little incentive and discipline placed on the States to ensure that those funds are spent wisely and in accordance with national objectives.

I think it is very important that we debate all of these issues associated with the distribution of powers between Federal and State. We need to look at these issues constructively and to recognise their importance to the future of Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I thank the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) for the contributions they have made to this debate on the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill. The Bill is not being opposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: There are perhaps a few comments that have been made in the course of the debate to which I should respond. I acknowledge the frustration expressed by the honourable member for Mayo in dealing with the complexities of Australia's three tiered system of government. I also acknowledge the support that he has expressed for the Special Premiers Conference process, which is designed to remove much of the duplication that exists in our system. I also acknowledge the special interest he has in problems which local government is experiencing in his area. It is a pity that the honourable member for Mayo and some of his colleagues did not support the constitutional referendum held in 1988 which would have recognised local government under the Constitution. So perhaps his concern is a little belated.

I also acknowledge his concern for the ratepayers of Stirling within his electorate. I hope that they receive good attention from him, particularly when he will have the task in the near future of explaining to them why the impact of a goods and services tax on the operations of the Stirling local government authority will lead to a rate increase. I found his comment that the Bjelke-Petersen Government had led the way in taxation reform by removing death duties rather intriguing. I would not have thought that any honourable member on either side of this House would have been holding up the late, unlamented Bjelke-Petersen Government of Queensland as any kind of example for anybody to follow in any shape or form. I simply note that, apart from death duties, the Bjelke-Petersen Government broke ground in a number of areas; but, I would suggest, opened paths along which few would choose to follow.

I note also the fascinated interest expressed by the honourable member for Mayo in the democratic processes of the Caucus. We on this side of the chamber certainly believe in discussing important questions facing Australia and discussing them in an open and democratic way. I make no apology for that.

I thank the honourable member for Corangamite for his contribution to the debate. The Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture clearly is an institution dear to his heart. He has devoted a great deal of his time to the welfare of that institution, particularly as a member of its council. If he is pleased that the amendment which I will be moving shortly on behalf of the Government will solve the problems of the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture, then I am certainly also pleased. I thank the honourable member for his generous remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 6, page 4, add at the end the following subclause:
"(2) The amount that would, but for this subsection, be payable under this section in relation to the grant year to Victoria is to be reduced by $2,428,000.".

I will not deal with the details of the amendment except to point out that it solves the problem of the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture, to which I have referred. Its effect is to reduce the financial assistance grants in the case of the State of Victoria by an amount of $2.428m. That will transfer from the State to the Commonwealth the full responsibility for funding the higher education program at the college. The amendment complements a financial adjustment as part of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 to provide for the college's higher education program to be funded through the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act 1988 as from 1 January next year.

As the amendment reduces the financial assistance grants in the case of the State of Victoria by the amount to which I referred, and increases grants to the State via the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act, the amendment means no net change to total Commonwealth outlays. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report--by leave--adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Free)--by leave--read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CARRIAGE OF GOODS BY SEA BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill has had an interesting passage through the House over the last 18 months. The Bill was originally introduced into the House last year. The Bill we debate tonight supersedes the Bill of 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been an interesting passage for the Bill because when the Bill was first introduced I recall the Minister sitting at the table tonight, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), making a fairly brief second reading speech introducing the Bill into the House. The second reading speech was so brief that I thought that it must have been a very simple and uncomplicated piece of legislation that we would be able to deal with very easily indeed. However, it rapidly became obvious to us, and to a host of other people who had an interest in this area, that the Bill was considerably more complex, considerably more difficult and more legalistic than the Government had first indicated to us.

As a result of that, the Opposition, along with members of the maritime industry, members of the insurance industry and the Law Council of Australia, expressed concern about the make-up of this Bill. Whilst appreciating, as I think all of us did at the time, the basis of the intent behind the introduction of the Bill, we all expressed considerable concern about the detail of it. We discovered that there were considerable flaws in the Bill and considerable concerns were being raised by industry. As a result, we expressed our view that this was a Bill that we would have a great deal of difficulty in supporting, and so did members of the industry. As a result, the Bill was withdrawn by the Government and the Bill that we debate today replaces it.

The Bill relates primarily to the way in which goods at sea are insured. It shifts the onus of responsibility for the insurance of goods at sea from the shipper, that is, the owner of the cargo, to the shipowner, that is, the mover of the cargo. This is a welcome piece of news for shippers throughout Australia, our exporters and our importers, because at first blush this legislation would save them the cost of the insurance component of transporting their goods from Australia to other parts of the world, or from other parts of the world to Australia.

However, as we delve further into the legislation it is not quite as simple as that. Indeed, I believe that shippers have a somewhat misguided view as to the benefits of this legislation. Later in my speech I will draw upon the advice of people who are far more experienced and wiser than I am.

I believe that, as with the previous legislation, the Bill as introduced into the House is not adequate to cover the needs of Australian shipowners and shippers and that it requires amendment. I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment following the conclusion of the second reading debate.

The Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill deals with two aspects of regulation of the carriage of goods by sea, one commonly known as the Hague Rules and the other the Hamburg Rules. The point of the legislation concerning the liability for cargoes carried by sea is that the regime should, firstly, allocate responsibility and liability for damage to cargo as simply as possible and, secondly, reduce legal disputes and the costs of those legal disputes. Therefore, the legislation should reflect current international practices. It should be equitable and it should be efficient. It should also conform with practices of our trading partners and rivals.

The Visby and SDR protocols, which amend the original Hague Convention--which I think dates back to 1924--bring the Hague Rules into line with generally accepted modern practice. Indeed, the amendments to the Hague Rules are generally well regarded in terms of bringing the language to a more modern standard and also bringing some of the measurements, such as the special drawing rights--that is, the IMF monetary unit--into more modern terms. They do not address what shippers argue is a deficiency in the Hague Rules, and that is the imbalance of the major burden of risk which is currently borne by the shipper, even though the shipowner has care of the cargo.

The Opposition is sensitive to these deficiencies in the Hague Rules and it supports in principle the fairer division of liability that the Hamburg Rules offer. It seems fair that the shipowner should be liable for the well-being of the cargo for the time that it is in his care. Shippers, that is, owners of the cargo, exporters and importers, are a very second-rate cousin when it comes to the whole transport network. It seems that the shipper is the one who ends up paying for all the costs of the inefficiencies and irresponsibilities of the other persons involved in the transport chain, whether it is on the waterfront, in the shipping industry, in the trucking industry, in the railway industry or whatever. It is always the poor old shipper who ends up meeting the cost of all the inefficiencies and irresponsibilities.

We have seen many examples in the past of owners of cargo, having deposited it in the hands of the stevedore and then the shipowner, having to foot the bill for any damage done by the shipowner in the course of transporting that cargo, even though the owner of the cargo had absolutely no direct responsibility for or care of that cargo while it was in the hands of the shipowner. That is the principle behind the amendments that we are considering tonight. The principle is to try to ensure that the person who is in possession of the cargo carries responsibility for any damage or cost, in addition to the normal cost, that may be incurred as a result of the transport of that cargo. Of course, from the point of view of the shipper, the owner of the cargo, that would be a welcome relief.

However, as the Government as admitted, the Hamburg Rules are not generally accepted and will not come into force internationally until 1 November 1992. The Hamburg Rules have only just attracted the 20 accessions required to bring the Rules into force internationally. I think Zambia was the twentieth and last country to accede to the Hamburg Rules, thus triggering their implementation 12 months later. If we have time later on I might deal with some of the countries that have signed their concurrence with the Hamburg Rules. The list sheds an interesting light on our concern.

Very few of the countries that have agreed to the Hamburg Rules could be considered our major trading partners. That is why we are concerned about the Rules. It seems rather odd that so many of the countries in the 20 accessions so far are not our major trading partners. It draws the questions: why on earth are our major trading partners not party to the Hamburg Rules? Will our being party to them put us at some trading disadvantage in the future? Indeed, of the 20 nations that have signed, very few are significant maritime nations.

If the Rules were to attract general international acceptance by our trading partners, there may be benefits to shippers. The Hamburg Rules favour shippers in the divisions of liability and therefore, if generally accepted, would be in our interests. But until they are generally accepted, Australian shippers would be placed at a disadvantage if Australia adopted rules that were in legal conflict with those applying to our trading partners and rivals. Many complexities would result from disputed claims and legal uncertainties.

The Opposition supports the principles underlying the Hamburg Rules, and it supports their adoption when an appropriate number of our trading partners and rivals have also adopted them or are prepared to adopt them. But there are already suggestions in the international shipping, insurance and legal fraternities that the Hamburg Rules are in the process of being overtaken by further developments and may not, in any event, deliver the savings that shippers are assuming they will deliver. Shippers may not have taken into account added insurance costs to carriers, which will inevitably be passed back in increased freight rates. If the onus of insuring goods at sea is to be carried by shipowners, it is somewhat naive to expect that at some stage down the track the increased cost of that insurance to them will not be reflected in the form of increased freight rates for the cargo carried. So it stands to reason that, one way or another, shippers will end up paying for the costs of insurance, no matter which way the issue goes.

The Insurance Council has predicted that a flight of insurance business from the country of consignment is likely as the onus of insurance passes from the shipper to the carrier, who is more likely to insure with international brokers or in the flag country. I am reliably informed that it is estimated that the value of the business that could be lost as a result of this legislation is of the order of $60m per annum. That is not an insignificant amount. Certainly that estimate draws concern from the insurance fraternity in Australia. However, the Government has been quick to emphasise the benefits that flow to shippers from this legislation.

The Government may be exaggerating these benefits, as it does with so many of its so-called reforms. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is not backward in coming forward when it comes to espousing the benefits of the Government's legislation or reforms. He certainly has been caught on many occasions in the past for exaggerating the benefits of reforms. Indeed, in another area in which I have an interest, the waterfront--an area of considerable interest for the Government and the Opposition--the Minister has on a number of occasions exaggerated the benefits, the pace and the extent of reform. We need go back only a couple of weeks to when the Minister was speaking to a port authorities conference in Brisbane. He claimed that the number of waterside workers had been reduced to the extent that there were now only 5,000 left. In fact, at the time there were 6,212 waterside workers, not the 5,000 that the Minister claimed.

In May of last year, in an adjournment debate Senator Collins claimed that some 1,100 to 1,200 waterside workers had left the waterfront as a result of the Government's waterfront reform program. Indeed, that figure was not achieved until nearly the end of September. But that did not stop the Minister making that claim on several other occasions during the year. That highlights just how easy the honourable senator finds it to exaggerate the benefits of reform--as he has done, I think, in respect of this legislation we are debating tonight. He is exaggerating to shippers--that is, the owners of cargo--the benefits of this reform.

Of course, Senator Collins is not the only one. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), also in exaggerating waterfront reform, claimed a 70 per cent gain in productivity on the waterfront in November of last year when he made the world's greatest micro-economic reform statement. That claim of 70 per cent productivity gain on the waterfront was made even before one wharfie had left the waterfront. So we are aware of the exaggerations that are taking place. I think this legislation is a victim of the exaggerations of the Minister and the Government, and I just hope that shippers are aware of that and do not fall into the trap of believing everything that the Government and Minister tell them.

The chairman of the international conference that agreed to the Hamburg Rules back in 1978, Professor Rolf Herber, said at the Attorney-Generals' Eleventh International Trade Law Seminar in Canberra in 1984:

The expectation of a possible decrease in overall transportation in costs for shippers all over the world, however, does not seem to be justified. On the other hand, fears of an increase in these costs seem to be exaggerated as well. . . it is--and I would be the last to deny this--a good convention. The best one could obtain in view of the divergent views and interests of all the countries of the world. Their--
that is, the Hamburg Rules--
coming into force would improve the legal situation considerably. But it would certainly not meet expectations as to a decrease in overall costs.

Those are the words of the gentleman who was responsible for the establishment of the Hamburg Rules, which the Minister claims will decrease the costs of insurance to shippers. The man who created the Hamburg Rules is saying that this is not necessarily so. He concluded that, in view of the background of a long maritime tradition and practice and the importance attached to the legal changes, the implementation of the Hamburg Rules may still require considerable time. Not only is this uncertainty expressed by the gentleman responsible for introducing the Hamburg Rules; it is also being reflected by others involved in the Australian shipping industry. I quote from a letter written to me only this week by the Australian Chamber of Shipping. It said:

During the debate on this Bill in the Senate, a key issue was not raised viz, that unless the Hamburg Rules become acceptable internationally by a large number of trading nations, the different liability arrangements applying will result in increased insurance premiums for shippers and shipowners.

That is what the Australian Chamber of Shipping has to say about the Hamburg Rules. Its comment is precisely in line with the Opposition's concerns, which are reflected in the amendment that we will move later tonight.

Shipping Conferences Services Ltd, another major player in shipping services to and from Australia, also wrote a letter to me this week expressing a similar degree of concern about the nature of this legislation. I shall read the following couple of paragraphs from this letter:
The main issue which was not raised during that debate--
that is, the debate on the Hamburg Rules in the Senate--

was that unless the Hamburg Rules become acceptable internationally by a considerable number of major trading nations, then the different liability regimes applying will result in increased insurance premiums for shippers, both large and small, and shipowners.

The major reason is that the insurance interests will need to respond by recovering the costs of possible claims under different liability regimes applying which under the Hamburg Rules will be for the choice of the shipper. Compounding the problem will be the uncertainty of new rules compared to the old rules, and the difficulty of interpreting new rules without clear legal precedent. This interpretation problem will obviously be made worse if only a few countries are applying the Hamburg Rules.

The letter goes on to highlight a number of things. It also included an article from the Daily Commercial News, which is the daily newspaper that specialises in transport news. It referred to an article by David Roylance, a partner in Middletons solicitors who practises transport and trade law. I think this is the key comment about these Hamburg Rules in David Roylance's article:

There would seem no compelling reason for the Australian government to move to a Hamburg regime . . . The 20 nations which have accepted the Hamburg Rules are thought to represent only three per cent of world trade (and a lesser proportion of Australian trade) and to account for the same percentage of the world's tonnage. Accordingly, the coming into force of the Hamburg Rules in the near future is unlikely to have the impact its proponents sought.

On the issue of insurance, it is clearly the case that cargo owners will still require adequate insurance. If cargo owners do not carry insurance but rely on the carrier to meet liabilities there are significant risks to the cargo owner.
There is no guarantee that sea carriers will settle claims promptly, or at all for that matter, as there is no effective mechanism for cargo owners to pursue the sea carrier's P& association.

Furthermore, cargo insurance is likely to still be necessary for sale and letter of credit purposes and to cover "gaps" in any liabilities the sea carrier may have or to provide cover above any limit of liability that the sea carrier may establish.

It follows that any savings on insurance which result from shifting the balance to the sea carrier may be illusory. Such savings would only mean increased costs for sea carriers and would quickly work their way through to increased freight rates.

They are the views of another expert in the area. He quite obviously indicates to the readers of the Daily Commercial News that he does not think the Government is taking the right course of action in this legislation.

This uncertainty about the Hamburg Rules prompted the Opposition to move an amendment in the Senate which would have enabled the updating of the Hague Rules without prejudice, pending the wider acceptance of the Hamburg Rules. It would have forced the reconsideration of the provisions in the Bill relating to the Hamburg Rules after three years if nothing had been done in the meantime. I thank my colleague Senator Macdonald for his efforts in moving the amendments and leading the debate on this legislation in the Senate. He did an excellent job in proposing some of the concerns that the Opposition has. Our proposal would not have allowed the introduction of the rules without further examination of the situation and consultation with the interested parties.

So, despite attempts to reach an agreed position on this with the Government--whose broad intentions and those of the Opposition are not at odds--the Government opposed the amendment that was moved by the Opposition and introduced its own amendment, which was very disappointing because we believed that we had reached an understanding in a Senate committee which would have enabled us to move the amendment that we were proposing and that the amendment would have been supported by the Government. Even the Australian Democrats indicated that they would support our amendment.

The Government's legislation leaves it possible for the Hamburg Rules to come into effect through oversight or under circumstances in which the situation has not been properly assessed. The Government's amendment in the Senate put into the Bill a provision where the Hamburg Rules would come into effect automatically if nothing further were done or if no agreement were reached regarding the appropriateness of their introduction, which is to say that they can enter into force for Australia by accident, by default or by stealth. The Opposition will introduce an amendment in committee to correct this, to ensure that entry into force is the result of a considered decision that the time is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is not right.

—-The Minister at the table disagrees with the intent of the Opposition's amendment, but I make the point that the Government's amendment will ensure that if nothing happens, if there is no trigger for the implementation of this legislation, after three years the legislation will automatically be implemented. That means that it could happen simply by oversight. It could mean, for example, that the Parliament has been prorogued and an election has been called and there is no opportunity for the Parliament to consider the matter before the three-year trigger occurs, when it is automatically implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: These are all consequences of the Government's amendment. However, the Opposition notes that the Government has included a requirement for consultation with shippers, cargo owners, carriers and shipowners before proclamation of the Hamburg Rules. It welcomes this adoption of the Opposition's initial proposal in this regard but also notes that the reference to `and given due consideration' is a rather non-specific prescription.

The Opposition certainly claims that before this legislation is implemented there needs to be very comprehensive and broad consultation with industry to ensure that our other major trading partners have also agreed to the Hamburg Rules so that this does not put us at a trading disadvantage and does not incur a multitude of complexities in insurance matters. It must ensure that Australian exporters and importers, the owners of those cargoes, are not put at any trading disadvantage. We believe that the contribution that has been made by the Opposition, be it in the House or in the Senate, has added to the strength of this legislation. It still needs further strengthening. That is why we moved our amendment and that is why we have expressed our concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) has said, the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill has had an interesting passage. I remember putting my name down to speak on this Bill about 18 months ago. It stayed on our noticeboard, but I thought everything had gone to seed; nevertheless, we are debating it tonight. I listened with interest to what the honourable member for Gilmore said. He quoted some of the experts. I suppose we all select our experts to get the quote we want. It seemed to me that he was doing a bit of that this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said, the purpose of the Bill is to reform Australia's marine cargo liability legislation which is concerned with legal responsibility for loss or damage occurring to seaborne cargo. The new Bill replaces the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill 1990, which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 12 September 1990 following a review of Australia's marine cargo liability regime. The earlier Bill resulted in a number of representations being received from shippers, ocean carriers and the legal profession expressing concern about certain technical aspects of the proposed legislation. These concerns, as I understand it, focused on the use of modern language instead of the original text of international conventions, the need to clarify the Bill's application to contracts of carriage other than those evidenced by documents of title such as bills of lading, and the scope of coverage of Australian law.

I did think it was a bit ripe for the honourable member for Gilmore to claim that it was some great initiative of the Opposition that had led to this change. As I understand it, there was a lot of representation made about it and I suppose, as always happens, some of these people may have contacted the Opposition as well as contacting the Government and others.

There have been extensive consultations between the Commonwealth and the parties concerned. This has been necessary because of the complex legal nature raised. There is broad industry support for the reforms proposed in this Bill. I must say that, while one welcomes the fact that conventions have been developed by the international community to determine liability when seaborne cargo is lost or damaged, it is a great pity that the same concern is not expressed for the loss of life. The international community is concerned about the legal responsibility for loss or damage occurring to seaborne cargo, but who cares about the loss of life? Over 200 seamen were drowned, killed or are missing from bulk carriers alone in 1990. Twelve ships were lost. These ships were lost in the main through structural faults. In the first four months of 1991, a further six of these ships have gone missing with an additional loss of life, the numbers unknown. All the ships were carrying iron ore, and some of them sailed from Australian ports after loading ironstone in north-west Australia.

The mining industry has always been most vocal about the need for the cheapest ships possible, and says that the OECD standard is not one for valid comparison with Australian shipping. The seaworthiness of international vessels should be an issue of growing international concern. As I have said, over recent years we have seen the disappearance of increasing numbers of ships at sea and the sinking of vessels crewed in the main by seafarers from Third World countries. It is a matter that demands much greater attention by the world's trading nations.

I have spoken in this House before about the condition of some of the ships, especially flag of convenience ships visiting Australia. I have inspected ships at Port Kembla on which bans have been placed. In many cases, these ships are nothing more than rust buckets. All the insurance legislation in the world will not save these rust buckets. I have listened to the wails of members of the Opposition as they rail against the Waterside Workers Federation and the Seamen's Union. Time and time again, I have challenged members of the Opposition to visit Port Kembla with me the next time bans are placed on a ship there to inspect that ship with me. So far none of them has accepted my invitation.

Cargo is important and so, I would suggest, are human lives. The proliferation of flag of convenience ships in countries which do not apply proper standards, shows a disdain for seamen's lives. Maybe the owners and users of these ships do not care, but seafarers and the world organisations certainly do and will continue the fight to expose and reject flag of convenience registrations and substandard ships.

Under the plans that the Opposition has for shipping, flag of convenience crews and flag of convenience ships infesting the Australian coast spell low wages, lack of maintenance, under or untrained personnel, disregard for safety, a hazard to other ships, and a danger to the environment.

An exceptional number of bulk carriers have disappeared in the past 18 months. An examination of their registers show either flag of convenience or countries with notorious safety records being the country of registry. Poorly trained crews, inadequate certification of officers and seamen and low safety standards all mean higher insurance premiums as countries become more responsible about the type of ships which visit their ports. The effect on passenger ships sinking and civilian lives lost will also engender greater control. Exposure of shippers who use substandard ships will go a long way to help eliminating them. There are substandard ships visiting the Australian coast and Australian ports. This legislation will not do a lot about them.

At this stage it is not clear because of the lack of information just how many of the sunk vessels were lost due to the unseaworthiness of the vessels alone, as a result of inadequately trained crews and poor seamanship or as a result of a combination of both. Vessels in bad seas need well-qualified, expert crews and attendants to handle them. We have a situation where on many of the flag of convenience vessels there may be only one or two certified or qualified officers on board, and there is often a language difficulty as well--a language difficulty between the officers and between the crew. The rest of the crew who are being paid poverty wages are effectively seagoing labourers. No tears are being shed by the trading nations of the world for those hundreds of Third World seamen who have disappeared without trace or who have lost their lives at sea.

It is clear that in recent years we have seen a re-emergence of the coffin ships of past centuries when ships were sent to sea in an unseaworthy condition or in a condition that was likely to result in the loss of these vessels or their crews. The development of international maritime conventions and of proper standards for the construction and maintenance of vessels, crewing and training of crews developed out of these malpractices of centuries gone by. For years, seafarers of the world have been pointing to the deplorable condition of many of the vessels that operate as flag of convenience ships. For their efforts, they have generally been portrayed as people crying wolf, people who did not want to work, people who were drawing undue attention to the safety aspects of ship operation. We are now seeing the results of the continued neglect of this major safety issue by the shipping nations of the world.

The irony is that attention has now been drawn to this practice of using coffin ships, not because of concern about the loss of lives at sea, but because of concern about the marine and global environment. That environment is a matter of major concern. However, I should have thought that priority would have been given to the needless loss of lives of sailors at sea.

We have a concern in this nation about the risk posed to our coastal marine environment by oil spillages from poorly crewed vessels and from unseaworthy vessels in the event of their being wrecked. Recently, the near sinking of a Greek owned tanker off the Western Australian coast focused our attention on the risk to Australia's fishing grounds and to our coastal environment.

In the past 18 months, 39 large overseas bulk carrying vessels suffered serious structural damage, were lost at sea or just went missing. We know that 21 of these ships sunk. Six of them were loaded in north-western Australian ports. They were loaded in Australian ports by Australian persons, sailed, and were never to be seen again--ships that disappeared, ships that sank without trace.

I commend the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) for recognising the seriousness of this situation and for his determination to initiate an international campaign to address this problem. But I repeat, all members of parliament should take the opportunity to visit some of these ships on which bans are placed at Australian ports. I doubt whether members of the Opposition would continue with some of their comments if they, like me, had the opportunity to inspect these rust buckets.

Naturally, I do not object to this legislation as in areas it streamlines aspects of the shipping industry, especially in relation to documentation. The coverage of the Bill also extends on a voluntary basis to contracts of carriage evidenced by non-negotiable transport documents. These non-negotiable transport documents fulfil a similar function to bills of lading, that is, they are evidence of the contract of carriage of the goods between the carrier and the shipper, with the exception that they do not carry title to the cargo.

The extension of the Bill's coverage in this regard recognises the increasing use of non-negotiable transport documents in Australia's interstate and international sea trades, and also resolves the question as to whether the Hague-Visby-SDR regime can be applied where such documents are used.

There has been much discussion over recent months about waterfront reform and I note that the honourable member for Gilmore could not resist having another go at it again this evening. One area that is rarely mentioned is the need for reform in regard to the paper chase that is so much of importation in Australia today. I hope that this legislation can do something about this.

There is a chaotic system of paperwork. For example, the steaming time for a ship from, say, Singapore to Fremantle is often only four days. Time and time again, the ship will arrive at Fremantle before the paperwork because of the antiquated paperwork system that we have. When the paperwork arrives, an endless paper chain then has to be gone through before the goods can be cleared. Of course, this delays the ship and delays the unloading of the cargo or its removal from the port. When honourable members opposite and others criticise, they never mention this endless paper chase. It is always the poor old wharfie who gets the blame and, time and time again, it has absolutely nothing to do with the Waterside Workers Federation.

I noted that the honourable member for Gilmore said that Senator Collins had been exaggerating in his claims about reform on the waterfront. He said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had exaggerated a bit as well. They have no monopoly on exaggeration. Many on this side would claim that the honourable member for Gilmore has been known to exaggerate a little in his claims about what has not happened on the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Never have I heard him exaggerating.
—-Order! The honourable member for Bruce will not interject whilst walking into the chamber. If he does so again, I will name him.

—-Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. If one wanted an example of this exaggeration, as I mentioned in the chamber the other night, one need only look at a disgraceful article in the October issue of the Reader's Digest. There was a similar article, I think in the Canberra Times, on Tuesday or Wednesday of this week. Again, as with our experts, we are very selective when we blame people for exaggeration.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not overlook that good old industrial relations term `the deliberately engendered dispute'. I have received a lot of evidence about deliberate delays on the wharf--not caused by the wharfies, but by businesses. I relate this to what the honourable member for Gilmore said about costs when there are delays on the waterfront. We all know that there are costs when there are delays on the waterfront. But businesses often delay for their own reasons. Again, who inevitably gets the blame but the wharfies?

The honourable member for Gilmore spoke about costs imposed on shippers. We hear a lot about this and we hear a lot about, say, the subject of demurrage. It is quite evident that at times consignors or consignees will choose to leave their containers at a terminal or depot because it suits their business requirements. Commercial interests, we are told, are supreme, irrespective of the demurrage charge applying.

One example I was recently given in Adelaide was that of a refrigerated container with cargo that had come in from Europe. The shipping line wanted to turn that refrigerated container around because it needed it--and we always have a problem in Australia with getting empty containers. The shipping line wanted to use this container rather than have to ship an empty box across from some other part of Australia. The demurrage for that container started off at $25 a day. This was after the third day because, as we know, the first three days are free. It was then escalated to $75 a day because the shipping line wanted it moved. The cargo remained there in that refrigerated container, not because the documentation was lost but because a particular client, a particular business, had a need to leave it there and it was cheaper for it to pay $75 a day demurrage to leave it at the waterfront. But again, who gets the blame? Again, it is the wharfie. This incident had absolutely nothing to do with the wharfies, and this sort of nonsense is repeated time and time again.

Another interesting point about the changes relating to demurrage is that, for example, it is a common practice, as I have said, for a depot to apply a daily charge to the shipping line for boxes that are held after a three-day period. When these charges are then passed on to the shipper, the consignor or consignee, they are considerably increased. This does not show in the invoice that the shipper receives for the goods, so profits can be significantly increased by delays. If, rather than a dollar value, we use a unit ranging from one to 25, a shipping line can be charged one to leave the cargo there but it may be recovering, say, 25. This is passed on and, of course, again, the waterside workers always get the blame.

The legislation before the House gives effect to major changes to Australia's marine cargo liability regime. It will update Australia's maritime cargo liability regime to take account of international developments since 1924. Now that we have taken care of the cargo, perhaps we can turn our attention to saving the lives of seafarers who go to sea in some of the rust buckets that too often visit our shores. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Deputy Speaker, you might be surprised that, before my speech is over, I will have some words of agreement with the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), but I wish to take this opportunity to make some remarks of a broader nature relative to the carriage of goods by sea. In opening, I would like to draw people's attention to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), which seem to be infinitely sensible.

SPEECH.PARA: Goods are carried by various means. For many years, I had substantial amounts of goods carried by road transport, sometimes in other persons' vehicles and often in my own. But I always preferred to have the right to insure my own goods for the simple reason that, firstly, I knew they were insured and, secondly, I had the choice. Today, I run a substantial breeding stud of racehorses and, except for the valuable stallion with the unusual name of O'Connor, I do not insure any of those animals. In fact, I have come to the conclusion I either insure the lot or I insure none--and I insure none. But the point I make is that that is my choice. If one of those horses dies, I do not have anybody to claim on.

I would imagine that, were I shipping containers of goods from Europe or somewhere else, I would be much happier about having insured the contents of one of those shipments myself and I would deal with a reputable firm whose financial credentials I would have established rather than have some owner of a rust bucket, as the honourable member for Throsby called it, act on my behalf, because, unfortunately, if his rust bucket sinks, it might be his only asset and, if he has forgotten to make the appropriate arrangements with Lloyds or someone of repute, I am going to have difficulty resurrecting his rust bucket.

So, in simple terms, it appears the old fashioned way is the best, and I would be concerned if we had this piece of legislation visited upon us in three years time because someone forgot we had it. I remind the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) that these sorts of things happen. In Victoria some years ago, it was decided to put sunset clauses on all regulations. There was due notice given to all the government departments and a process was put in place of writing out of the statute books all the old regulations so that on a certain day they literally expired and, consequently, all government departments in Victoria had to come up with new ones or reinstate the old. It was singularly successful, with only one group forgetting to get its regulations in place--and that was the Supreme Court of Victoria. But, hopefully, in three years time the Minister will not have forgotten that we have this bit of legislation, as the honourable member for Gilmore has suggested he might, and that it is visited upon us when in fact we may not want it.

The reason for my entering the debate is to talk about rust buckets and to talk about the marine environment and the massive resources of our marine environment and how they may be particularly affected by the activities of larger ships at sea. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, in your speech of a moment ago, mentioned the oil tanker that broke apart off the Western Australian coast. It was a ship called the Kirki. It lost its bow. It had a very large cargo of light crude aboard and, at the time of its losing its bow, as I recollect, it was some 60 kilometres of the Western Australian coast and almost within the lobster province of Western Australia--all of which I happen to represent.

At that time, there was gigantic concern as to the long term dangers that were being presented to that industry--an industry of substantial economic value to Australia, particularly in times when demand for many of our commodities is very low. For days, the people in my office were on the phone contacting the fishing people and the local authorities in that area--for what reason I am not really sure, because we were desperately hoping everything, as it turned out, would be okay. As members of parliament we were powerless, and all the fishing folk and others felt powerless too. A disaster sat there and little by little we got around it. Admittedly, during the process, there were times when one wondered who was in control of the situation, but eventually it was all right.

During those conversations, I spoke with a very responsible crayfisherman of the area, Gary Snook, who is also the Shire President of the Dandaragan Shire, and we talked about the condition of this ship. He said that certain fishermen had managed to get on board at one stage and had got hold of a piece of deck plate which was one-eighth of an inch thick. He informs me--and I believe he would know--that when that ship was constructed, the plate would have been in excess of half an inch thick. As with our modern motor cars, large ships today have integral construction. They are not built as the old wooden ships were with ribs and a framework to which planks were attached. Every part of a modern ship is part of its integral strength. Once the deck plates had rusted down to that thickness, clearly the ship was not viable to operate in anything other than a millpond. On this particular journey it had confronted some very rough seas.

The other matter of concern to me is that when one considers the straight line from its port of loading to Fremantle, one wonders what it was doing a couple of hundred kilometres north of Perth and within 60 kilometres of the coast. It certainly was not travelling in a straight line. There are arguments that there are some tidal movements in those areas which ships masters try to utilise; in other words, they come in and try to pick up the tide.
