They do not take a direct line course, but they gain some speed and fuel economies by picking up those tides. I do not know whether that is significant to warrant that particular course.

There are other suggestions that some use those particular courses and go down into those crayfishing areas so they can drop off contraband to be picked up by some of the smaller ships--the fishing boats. I do not know whether that is true, but I know that it is not worth the risk having them--rust buckets or better--that close to such a hugh resource of export income for Australia.

Amongst other things, I ask the Government to consider whether it is time, considering the massive damage we know can be done, to have proscribed areas where, unless there is good economic reason, very large ships carrying environmentally unfriendly cargoes do not operate. There is another aspect to all this because my fishermen in these areas tell me of the massive hazards many of these ships represent to their lives. They say that these ships are not crewed as they travel; they bung them on auto pilot, and away they go--20,000, 30,000, 50,000 or 100,000 tonnes of ship steaming through the night with everybody on board asleep.

My crayfishermen, who operate to distances sometimes 100 kilometres off shore--they do not commute backwards and forwards each day--tell me that while they are out there they cannot sleep. They would not dare anchor for fear of being run over because these ships operate in these areas without anybody on watch, putting the crayfishermen in extreme danger.

It is interesting to note that, just outside my electorate, the Sanko Harvest also ran onto a reef in recent times. Maybe it was not a rust bucket. It was very poorly crewed because the master apparently took a channel which he was ill-advised to be sailing in. He ended up putting his shipload of fertiliser on a reef. Eventually the bunker crude on that ship became a major environmental hazard. On this occasion, the activities of those charged with cleaning up the mess and protecting the beaches around the Esperance area also came under some criticism from locals. It is worth putting that on record.

For a start, this happens to be a bit endemic. If there is a problem of this nature and there is public exposure, then the people involved make sure that they get the best. So they had a helicopter flying around at hundreds of dollars an hour trying to spread dispersant on the water, which I understand it did very ineffectively. Yet in that area there are literally dozens of fishing boats, and literally thousands of spraying rigs on the properties of farmers which would have done the job better and cheaper. It is a great pity that on so many of these occasions these facilities are not used.

I argued about this many years ago on the far north-west coast of Western Australia. When we put together some of these various civil defence organisations, they started sending us four-wheel drives and aluminium dinghies with two outboards on the back--when the north-west was full of four-wheel drives, and of course we had a substantial fishing industry with boats large and small. I might add that the original boat came up with only one outboard and the local civil defence officer immediately lodged an argument for a second one because it was unsafe to go fishing in the damn thing with only one engine on it.

The point is that, amongst our responsibilities to civil defence and environmental defence, we should have a list of what is locally available. Why should we not know whether there are plenty of four-wheel drives in the district and plenty of small boats? Before we had all this Government assistance, I experienced a major flood in Carnarvon--in the north-west. I became part of the local civil defence organisation because there were only about 50 of us left in the town; the rest had been evacuated. Our first job was to steal a dinghy and an old, tiny, black outboard--a Penguin. We found that we could not drive that against the tide in the river, so we had four blokes paddling. We managed to get out--I do not know whether `rescued' is the proper word--and supplied food to the people who were stranded on their properties. We all did that and thought it was a lot of fun. Later on, we were able to get beer for the town to about three or four miles away, and we used the same boat to get a bit into town because we were out of that as well. The point I am making is that we used the local resources.

When the Sanko Harvest was creating environmental problems on the south coast close to my electorate, before someone went to the expense of hiring a reasonably ineffective helicopter, he should have looked at some of the more local facilities available, which I think would have done a better job.

There are a couple of things I want to talk about, but let us get back to the rust buckets. Mr Deputy Speaker, you said that you have inspected them. I have not, but I rely on the advice of the people who I represent and their skills as fishermen, et cetera. I am also reminded--one does not read about it much in the papers these days--that in years gone by we had an adequate inspection service of seagoing ships in Australia. We always seem to read about how they have gone on board and managed to knock a couple of holes in a lifeboat. I do not say that should not be done and, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have made the point, quite properly, that protection of lives at sea is as important as anything else.

On the other hand, surely it is time that Australia inspected the ships that visit our country. It is pretty easy to establish their age. I would imagine that with an ordinary battery drill we could soon find out whether the deck plate was only one-eighth of an inch thick. My recollection of the old inspection service--Mr Deputy Speaker, no doubt you would spring to its defence--is that it was seen more as a means of gaining work for the painters and dockers than the proper protection of the public and, if you like, the environment. That is a pity. I think that brings discredit upon a necessary service.

Consequently, I would suggest that if boats come to this shore and are demonstrated to be structurally unsound, they should be unloaded and not tied up. They should not be allowed to reload and should be told to leave our country. It should be made clear that if they ever come again they will not be unloaded. I guess that this happened a lot before we stopped the inspection service. Over time I think the message would get out amongst shipowners that it is unwise to send this type of ship to Australia. Added to that, there should be some proscribed sensitive areas. That is a point that we should consider.

Generally, we should make it clear to the international shipping community that Australia is not going to be the recipient of rust buckets for all the reasons I have given. I guess that might be reflected in the freight rates we are charged and we would have to do something about that. I reject the argument, nevertheless, that the removal of cabotage should be associated with the treatment of these boats. I believe that we can have highly competitive international ships sailing around Australia that are not rust buckets.

We have to look at the industry overall. The Minister wanted to mount a case for the waterfront and the waterside workers. I think that they do contribute to the problems we have in shipping from Australia. I think that the principal problem is not that they are particularly nasty but that they have a monopoly over the labour component of the wharf. I think we should be mature enough to know that no monopoly gives good service. The simple solution to the waterfront is to tell the wharfies to stay around, start a few more companies, as they have in Queensland, and get into business themselves--I would welcome it--and compete with other people who want to give service on the wharf.

Recently in my electorate we had a very large mobile container crane; I think it would lift 250 tonnes. It could be driven up and down the wharf. Why cannot some group own one of those cranes and offer a service anywhere along the waterfront where it can operate competitively? Why does it need to have a member of the waterfront union to do the job? I cannot see why. It does not make any sense to me, and I am not sure that it is in the financial interests of the wharfies. Although there would be fewer of them, they could do what those who have incorporated themselves up in northern Queensland are doing. They are doing famously. Probably the first thing they did was sack a few of their mates. I do not know, but I bet they are efficient if they are paying the wages. That is human nature at work. I am a big believer in that.

We also have to recognise something else. The new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean)--I worry a little bit about him--has a background in the labour movement. His solution for primary industry is value added. All that primary industry is interested in is a little bit of value. We are told that the harvesting and distribution costs for a bale of wool today are $320 and it is selling for $500. That does not leave much for the wool grower. We, as legislators, have a substantial responsibility to see that those are costs reduced, if only to keep one of our major export products competitive.

Every time I think about value added, I think the simplest form of value added is to ship goods from Australia--be they bulk cargo or containers--in our own ships. That is value added. What is the invisible cost to our current account of freight paid to foreign countries? Why are we not in the business? Okay, we would have to compete with rust buckets. But we are also very silly about the way we try to run shipping. We have this rather stupid belief that because we go to sea in a ship, we only work six weeks on and six weeks off. If, however, we are sent to some remote area of Australia working for the Government, we do not get that sort of privilege. But we are equally remote, and we never get the chance to visit foreign destinations.

I used to sit next to these seamen when they also had the right to travel first class. They would tell me about their couple of cray boats and how they were anxious to get back into business. I used to see them in Carnarvon working on prawn trawlers. They were not home cuddling up to mum in their spare time; they were out with a second job, probably taking it off some poor unemployed person who needed it. Why can we not design Australian ships that have accommodation that is like a flat? Why can we not take mum and the kids to sea, but work 11 months a year consequently? It makes a lot of sense to me. As the kids start to grow up and go to school, we would make the sort of judgments that other people in remote areas do. Maybe they would be sent to boarding school; maybe mum would get a job on the boat as well, so that the family would be a two-income family. Why do we not think about these things?

We surely should have a very large shipping industry in Australia. We are an island continent. We ship huge quantities of goods, and we throw that away as a form of value added. We have to do it competitively. We will not do it while we stick to a lot of the stupid rules we have.

Nevertheless, I welcome this legislation. I hope that it is not forgotten in three years. I support the honourable member for Gilmore and his amendment. I trust that over time some of my remarks might sink in. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I welcome a number of the remarks made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). This is a rare occasion, because I will try to help him support some of the arguments that are before us. Some of them I will reject, but others have considerable substance, and it is very welcome to hear them coming from the other side of the chamber after this long time. It is true that the standard of some ships arriving in Australia is low. The reality is that we inspect only 25 per cent of all foreign-flag ships that visit Australian ports. When I as Minister introduced that system, it was objected to strongly by shippers, their argument being that it would add to costs, it would deter ships from coming to Australia and it would increase freight costs. Therefore, the comments of the honourable member for O'Connor, coming from the constituents he represents, are very welcome. At least he now understands the overall picture.

SPEECH.PARA: Of the 25 per cent of foreign ships that were inspected in the past 12 months, 60 per cent had serious structural difficulties or deficiencies in lifesaving equipment. When there is a ship on which the lifeboat davits do not work or on which the crew does not know how to launch the lifeboat, or on which the lifeboat has no provisions or is itself not seaworthy, the lives of the crew are put at risk. Those on the other side of the chamber might grin and smile about it. But when the crew are out there in a force 7 gale and their ship is breaking up, it is a matter of some pertinence that they know that their lifesaving equipment does work and that they have a chance to survive.

The point made by the honourable member for O'Connor is absolutely right: we are a shipper nation, not a shipowning nation. Some 4 per cent of our cargo is carried in Australian-flag ships. The argument just put by the honourable member for O'Connor is an argument that I have put on many occasions, as have other supporters of Australian-flag shipping--that is, that use of competitive and efficient Australian-flag shipping is value adding; it is a legitimate downstream activity of the development and extraction of our primary resources. Every other country in the world takes a longer and a broader view. If we look at it from the purchaser's point of view, we should ask ourselves: why is it that 95 per cent of the iron ore purchased by Japan travels to Japan in ships controlled by the Japanese? Those ships are not always cheaper; in many cases they carry cargoes at more expensive freight rates than Australian-flag ships do. When it comes to negotiation time, the buyer, with the control of the shipping, exerts a great degree of market muscle over the poor seller of primary resources in this country.

History shows that in the past, particularly in the north west of Australia, as the time came around for negotiation of iron ore prices, by some quirk of fate ships were late arriving, iron ore stockpiles built up, the cash flow of the iron ore companies slowed down, but miraculously, once the iron ore rates were negotiated, the ships all speeded up again and the stockpiles were cleared. That is because the buyers are smarter, more clever and look further down the line than do Australian exporters.

I want to hear more from the Opposition and more speeches like that from the honourable member for O'Connor, extolling the use of efficient and competitive Australian ships. He is not in the chamber now, but I mention to him that enormous progress has been made in improving the training, equipping and crewing of Australian vessels. We are now down to crewing levels--at this stage they are not a major factor in ship operation--comparable with those in the OECD countries. We are one of the first countries in the world with general purpose crewing, and we have abolished the class society on ships. We have done away with the white tablecloths, saloon and silver service--the class structure of the old ships. The suggestion that mums and dads go to sea is a very welcome one. We have several certificated female officers, such as female captains, on the Australian-flag ships. The idea of husbands and wives going to sea is already implemented fairly extensively around the world and ought to be encouraged all the more in this country.

I refer now to the Kirki. We have to go back to the source of the issue. It is not just about a ship arriving here in poor or almost unseaworthy condition. We have to look further back and ask: why is this happening? It is because there are tax regimes or financial incentives in the countries of origin of those ships--not the country in which they are registered, but the country in which they are owned, where there are tax regimes that encourage the use of old ships. If we look at what has happened off the Australian coast in recent times, we are in the main looking at old ships--ships over 15 years of age.

Whilst the plate on the Kirki might have been more than half an inch thick at the time of manufacture, there was plate in the bow of that vessel that was one millimetre thick--not an eighth of an inch. There was one millimetre of steel on the bow of that vessel crashing into the seas in the heavy weather at the time that the bow fell off.

Another point made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) concerned ships being on autopilot. Of course! In opposition we made that point repeatedly to members of the Fraser Government. We made the point time and time again that largely the flag of convenience vessels coming into this country--with the poverty freight rates that were available, and called for by the Opposition and by many exporters--were ships that could have one certificated officer on board, maybe two, with the rest of the crew being seagoing labourers.

It was common practice at that time, and it probably still occurs now, that ships sail the night off the Australian coast with everybody on board sound asleep, the engine room on automatic and the bridge on autopilot. Sure, there should be someone up on the bridge, awake, but that does not always happen. It does happen that they are asleep. So the points made by the honourable member for O'Connor are valid ones. They are extremely important. But the irony of all of this is that we are not talking about this now because lives are being lost, but because of possible damage to the fishing grounds and our marine environment.

Let me say something to the families of the seafarers who go down on those coffin ships. We are going back to the seventeenth, eighteenth or nineteenth century practices when vessels were sent to sea in an unseaworthy condition and the insurance collected. What do honourable members think Lloyds surveys all developed from? They developed from those malpractices and abuses, that effective murder of seafarers in centuries gone by. We are not far short of a return to those circumstances today.

I might mention that, even though the Bill that is before the House picks up new provisions with regard to the liability of cargo damaged in sea transit, there is no requirement upon the ship operator to ensure that the vessel is in a seaworthy condition when it departs port. We are looking at who bears the liability and the level of liability, and under what circumstances, but there is no requirement that the ship's operator have a seaworthy ship.

A lot of hypocrisy has been spoken around this country about the plight of seafarers and obtaining the best international freight rate we can. As the honourable member for O'Connor said, he does not want to see the use of those freight rates. He is prepared to see people pay more, have seaworthy vessels and not endanger lives or our marine environment.

The Carriage of Goods by Sea Act is based on an international convention, as has been mentioned in earlier contributions, known as the Hague Rules. They came into effect in 1924. But the Act does not incorporate the two more recent international protocols which update the original Hague Rules. A carrier's liability under the original Hague Rules was limited to $A200 per package or unit, which could have been interpreted as meaning a total container. The 1968 Visby Protocol makes it clear that the term `package or unit' applies separately to each of the packages in the container. So we are increasing the level of liability. In addition, the liability limits incorporated in the original Hague Rules are based on the gold standard, which no longer exists. So we have updated that to SDRs, or special drawing rights, which are equivalent to about $A1.72 at the moment.

The amended Hague Rules will cover the contracts of carriage evidenced by a bill of lading or similar document of title, including bills of lading issued pursuant to a charter party as provided for in the Hague Convention and its two protocols. In addition, parties to contracts evidenced by non-negotiable transport documents such as sea waybills can, on a voluntary basis, agree to apply the amended Hague Rules to their contracts.

The Hamburg Rules apply to contracts of carriage by sea evidenced by documents, including bills of lading, issued pursuant to a charter party. I want to make a very important point. Mr Deputy Speaker, you are a member of this House's Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and a member of the subcommittee inquiring into the efficiency and performance of the interface between seaports and land transport. You know, as do our colleagues on the Committee, that bills of lading--the paperwork, the paper trail--are, in many cases, a serious impediment to more efficient operation of the waterfront and to a lower cost delivery of goods from destination land-side to ship-side.

Neither the amended Hague nor Hamburg rules will apply to electronic data interchange contracts--EDI contracts--as both regimes were designed to apply to paper based transactions. There are international problems and there are international discussions going on now. How does one deal with electronic bills of lading? This is fundamental. If we are going to move away from the paper based bill of lading, document of title or rendering of ownership of that cargo, we have to make provision for EDIs. I have said many times that what we are really dealing with is a system that derives from sailing ships, but it almost goes back further than sailing ships.

The requirements for writing, especially in common law countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia, have their basis in legislation from the United Kingdom dating back to 1677 which was designed to guard against the peril of perjury. It should also be noted that the statutes prescribing writing did so for the purpose of defining the type of evidence a court would accept rather than prescribing a form for legal agreements. In other words, it was about having evidence of ownership and of title to the cargo in a form that the court would accept. Here we are today, 314 years later, sticking still to hard copy pieces of paper for passing ownership in an electronic age when we transmit information by satellite. We are sticking to that, and we are talking about progress.

I would have welcomed from the Opposition greater reference to and support for the Hamburg Rules, and I will come to that in a moment. But what we are dealing with tonight does not recognise EDI. All members of the Committee know, and the industry knows, that we are not going to get the best out of the total journey from factory gate or farm gate to ultimate destination, or from ultimate origin to destination, unless we move with the times. Provision needs to be developed internationally and within this country for acceptance of electronic data interchange--or EDI--bills of lading. There are ways of doing that. The discussions are going on. I will not belabour that now; it is for another occasion. However, I make the important point that we think we are catching up. In the legislation that is before us, we are making a couple of short steps along the way.

As I said, the amended Hague Rules or Hamburg Rules do not cover EDI. They deal only with paper based transactions. The process of updating Australia's marine cargo liability regime included consideration of both the amended Hague Rules and the Hamburg Rules. For a number of reasons it was decided that the most appropriate regime to meet Australia's need at this time is the amended Hague Rules. They have been in force for a considerable period of time and they are included in the legislation of many maritime trading nations.

In comparison, the Hamburg regime is relatively new. It will come into force in 12 months. Up until a couple of weeks ago, it had only 19 countries. The twentieth country, Zambia, has now acceded to the Hamburg Rules and to the Hamburg Convention. That means that the Hamburg regime will come into operation 12 months from the date of accession.

The point has been made that our major trading nations are not parties to the Hamburg convention. We understand that. The Government's position in respect of the Hamburg Rules has been made very clear. The Bill leaves consideration of the implementation of the Hamburg Rules to some future time by providing for the future proclamation of those parts of the Bill dealing with the Hamburg Rules which cannot be made before the Hamburg convention enters into force in respect of Australia--in other words, until the government of the day in Australia so decides. I like the remarks of the member for O'Connor, because he assumes that we will be the government in three years. I welcome that comment. It is great, and he is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He's wrong.

—-He is right. That act of accession, that decision of the Australian Government at that time, has to take place. There has to be recognition by the Australian Government of that decision before it will happen. The inclusion of the Hamburg Rules in the Bill is a recognition of the interests of Australian exporters. The Hamburg Rules benefit exporters to the detriment of shippers, but it will work itself out. It fascinates me that the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), a member of the National Party, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, took the case of foreign shipping companies. He was arguing against the Hamburg Rules, raising a number of phoney excuses. What is he doing? He is grovelling to the foreign shipping companies who have fed off this country for centuries.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member is turning his back on the exporters who will benefit from the Hamburg Rules when they come into operation in the major trading nations. To cut it right down, that is what it is about. The Hamburg Rules favour exporters to the detriment of shipping companies. I have no doubt that in time that will sort itself out. I simply make that point. It amazes me that we can have a member of the National Party arguing for foreign shipping companies against the interests of Australian exporters.

We mentioned how such a small amount of our goods goes out in Australian flag ships. I want to say something about cost, insurance and freight and f.o.b. The work that has been done on what cargoes go out on a c.i.f. or f.o.b. basis is meagre; it is hard to find. But back as far as 1984, 25 per cent of Australian exports were being sold on a cost, insurance and freight basis; in other words, the exporter included in his price the cost of freight and insurance and had control. He selected the ships to carry it. He had control of the cargo from its origin to the ultimate destination.

As I said in respect of iron ore: whoever has control of the cargo has a bit more muscle. Not nearly enough has been done in this country to pursue the c.i.f. basis of selling. It provides greater muscle to the seller, a profit can be made from managing the shipping requirements, quality control is generally directly in the hands of the exporter and there is greater ability to take advantage of spot markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How do you do that in a competitive market?

—-They can try that. It is included in the price, because at the end of the day the buyer has to take into account the cost of getting goods across to the ship side. The ship side and the selection of the ship are critical points, as well as getting it to the destination and the rates.
—-But he can go elsewhere.

—-If he looks at the market he will find he can contract over a period, or he can contract spot. But if he a good businessman, as I know the honourable member was, he will make sure that he negotiates a total rate that will put him in the best selling position. Other countries in the world do it, or are we saying that Australian exporters just are not good enough--it is all too complicated and it involves overseas organisation. That is really what is being said and that is really what we have hidden behind in this country. Here is an opportunity to get a better deal for Australia and to add to our invisibles.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor asks: what does it cost us? Shipping freight payable on exports in 1987-88 cost $4.4 billion; shipping freight payable on imports in 1987-88 cost $2.096 billion. The invisible credits for shipping freight in 1990-91 were $593m; the invisible debits for shipping freight in 1990-91 were $3,024m--a deficit of $2,431m. That is the cost of neglect and the cost of inaction, and that indicates the opportunities that are there. We do not want to get all of it, but we should be looking, as Australians and as competent Australian business people and exporters, to get a share of that business.

I welcome this legislation; it is a step in the right direction. I hope that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), as I have mentioned in a notice of motion before this chamber to be debated on 14 November, will do something about stepping up the inspection rate of foreign vessels in this country and I hope we are going to see a great deal of support from the Opposition, as suggested by the honourable member for O'Connor, to achieve greater use of Australian ships.

In my concluding seconds, I also want to mention the closure of the BHP shipping office in Newcastle, which was transferred to Melbourne. I want to recognise the wonderful work of BHP staff members over 70 years, from a peak fleet of 58 vessels to a current fleet of 19 vessels. Times and circumstances have changed, but Captain Iain Steverson and all his colleagues--men and women--at the BHP shipping office in Newcastle have done a wonderful job over those 70 years. They have been a great credit to the Australian shipping industry and to Australian industry generally. I wish them well in their careers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is with a great deal of pleasure that I speak on the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill. Whilst I was not in the House when the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) was speaking, I was very impressed with his deep concern for this aspect of his shadow portfolio, and I was very interested, as I always am, in the words of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who always comes up with something new. It is nice to hear him getting some praise--I do not know whether it is a good thing or not--from the Government side. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) also had some interesting things to say. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), is a person I have known for many years and he also spends quite a bit of time by the sea; I know he has a deep interest in anything to do with the sea, but in this particular case it is the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members would know, I represent a very beautiful electorate, and people may be asking the question: why am I speaking on a Bill regarding the carriage of goods by sea?

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Nepean River.

—-That is right. The honourable member for Bruce has studied things very well. The interesting thing about it, of course, is that whilst it is a most magnificent electorate--I have often mentioned that--the Nepean-Hawkesbury River, of course, was one of the major water traffic lanes in this colony right from the word go. Shipbuilding actually took place at Windsor. We have a ship called the Lady Hawkesbury, a fairly new tourist vessel of magnificent proportions, which goes on trips up and down the Hawkesbury River. I commend the Lady Hawkesbury and those magnificent holiday packages to anybody who may be interested in having a very relaxing and smooth trip. It runs right up to Windsor both on weekends and through the week. It is a magnificent 5- or 6-class ship.
—-It goes past the five Macquarie towns.

—-That is right, past the five Macquarie towns. Of course, the Hawkesbury-Nepean system is often referred to as the Rhine of Australia, another good reason why I believe anybody listening to this debate ought to experience the magnificent Lady Hawkesbury.

SPEECH.PARA: The Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill 1991 provides an updated set of rules for the shipping industry regarding the responsibilities and liabilities of those who carry goods by sea and those who consign them. Each year approximately 70 million tonnes of cargo are discharged onto Australian wharves and approximately 300 million tonnes of cargo are loaded. With the advent of containerisation and other technological advances, defining legal responsibility and liability for goods damaged or lost in transit has become increasingly difficult, and the shippers of goods are finding it increasingly expensive to insure cargo for that area of responsibility and liability that is not clearly defined.

This Bill seeks to overcome these insurance difficulties by incorporating the Hamburg Rules, a recent convention which will assist shippers in clarifying areas of liability. Such clarification is welcomed by shippers, as the carriage of goods by sea has some very real risks--risks which are not always recognised by the general public.

Under the old convention, that is, the Hague-Visby Protocol, there was a small area of responsibility that clearly lay with the shipper, a small area of responsibility that lay with the carrier and a large area that had become very grey in its legal interpretation. Unlike the Hague-Visby convention, the Hamburg Rules apply to intrastate trade and liability and that is also extended to include time that the cargo is on the wharf.

When the Hamburg Rules were originally drafted, all areas of difficultly appeared to be eliminated. However, as time goes on, their effectiveness does seem to be diminishing. This diminishing effect comes as a result of further, more recent technological advances in shipping methods--although there is no doubt they still represent an improvement over the older Hague-Visby Protocol. In addition to clarifying areas of responsibility, the Hamburg Rules represent a shift of responsibility. With the incorporation of the Hamburg Rules into this Bill, the shipper now has a smaller area of responsibility, the middle, grey area is slightly smaller and the carrier has a slightly larger area of responsibility. The increase in carrier responsibility comes largely as a result of legal clarification of some of that previously grey area and, of course, by virtue of increased responsibility for cargo held by the carrier on the wharf.

Although the Hamburg Rules provide some distinct advantages over the Hague-Visby Protocol, a major weakness in this Bill is that the international acceptance of the Hamburg Rules is still very limited and, until support increases, shippers may see little in the way of benefit from reduced insurance costs. At present, only 19 of the requisite 20 signatories have accepted it. There are few significant maritime nations represented among that 19 signatories. I believe the twentieth has signed?

TALK.START.PARA: —-That's right, Zambia.
—-That is pleasing to hear. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the inclusion of the Hamburg Rules in the Bill is a signal that Australia intends to accept this convention when its international standing is such that it can demonstrably provide a viable basis for new cargo liability arrangements for international seaborne trade between Australia and its trading partners. As long as the Hamburg Rules have not come into force internationally, it is inappropriate to seek a proclamation.

It is indeed wise to withhold proclamation. However, the open-ended nature of this future proclamation did concern me, so I am pleased that recent amendments to the legislation lock us into reviewing the situation in three years. Without this provision the legislation could have ended up lying in the bottom of a drawer indefinitely.

Such a review will afford us the opportunity of, firstly, reassessing the international acceptance of the Hamburg Rules; secondly, assessing the effectiveness of the Hamburg Rules in the light of technological changes; and, thirdly, consulting with a broad range of industry representatives.

I am delighted with the lead Australia appears to be taking in improving international shipping standards. This Bill is certainly a move in the right direction. I am also delighted with the lead that Australia is taking in maritime environmental responsibility and safety standards. An article that appeared in the Sunday Age on 28 July 1991 highlighted the work presently being carried out by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in its inspection of shipping in Australian waters for seaworthy defects. According to the article, approximately 2,500 foreign ships use Australian ports each year. In the first six months of this year 178 of 315 foreign ships inspected were found to have defects. This is very interesting, especially in the light of the environmental tragedy caused by the Greek oil tanker Kirki when 15,000 tonnes of its 85,000-tonne cargo spilt into the sea.

I was pleased to read in the Senate Hansard of the debate on this Bill that there was considerable recognition by honourable senators of the tragic loss of human life through shipping accidents. The most alarming aspect in this regard is that ships are putting to sea without adequate lifesaving equipment. Senator Collins, in his contribution to the debate, drew senators' attention to the fact that hundreds of seamen have lost their lives in shipping accidents in the past two years--a fact that can be so easily overlooked. Largely, the loss of life has been due to inadequate safety precautions. I was pleased also that the senator indicated that, once the report on the Kirki incident is finalised, the matter of shipping safety will be brought before the Parliament for further consideration.

Should future Treasury finances permit, I would like to see Australia's efforts in policing the safety requirements of ships in Australian waters stepped up. It would be very encouraging if, on relative scale, we could match the efforts of the United States authorities. Although I realise that this is not possible at the moment, I do want to place on record my appreciation of the work currently undertaken by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority.

As the Deputy Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I am also interested in Australia's lead in maritime environmental issues. In many ways this is tied in with the effects of this Bill. It is staggering to note that during 1989 there was a total of 177 oil pollution incidents in Australian waters--although it is encouraging to see that worldwide the incidence of oil spillage is decreasing. No doubt this decrease is as a result of a combination of a greater awareness of environmental issues by the international community and the good work of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, known as MARPOL.

MARPOL deals with a number of different pollutants including oil, noxious liquid substances, harmful substances carried in package form, sewage and garbage. However, in our case one of the greatest threats to the Australian coastal environment comes by way of the discharge of ballast water. Some 58 million tonnes of ballast water discharged into Australian waters has its origin in other parts of the world. Most of this water is discharged from bulk carriers. When ballast water is pumped into the ships, any sediment it contains is also pumped in, together with organisms present in the water and sediment.

Organisms found in ballast water include live fish, crustaceans, molluscs, polychaete worms, arrowworms, coelenterates, toxic and non-toxic dinoflagellates, bacteria and a host of micro-organisms, to name just a few. There are at least 14 established species known, with reasonable certainty, to have arrived in Australia in ballast water. The impact of exotic species upon human health, commercial fishing--including marine aquaculture--and the natural environment cannot be underestimated. Unfortunately, large quantities of ballast water are discharged close to marine aquaculture areas; therefore, the risks associated with the discharge of ballast water in Australia are significant and the scientific task of controlling introductions is quite daunting. The coastal areas most under threat from discharge are those areas around Abbot Point, Gladstone, Newcastle, Sydney, Port Kembla, Fremantle, Dampier and Port Headland.

In view of these facts, I was greatly encouraged to read a press release by the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) concerning moves by the International Maritime Organisation to introduce a system of voluntary guidelines over the discharge of ships' ballast water, based largely on the system introduced in Australia in February last year. These guidelines were introduced by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service as voluntary measures in response to investigations undertaken in Tasmanian waters.

The guidelines give shipping companies a range of options to avoid the uptake and discharge of ballast water and sediment that may contain exotic organisms. These guidelines include reballasting at sea, not discharging ballast in Australian waters and taking on ballast in agreed clean ports. Australia, along with Canada, is leading the world in this area and, as I mentioned before, it is through the Australian guidelines that the international maritime community is now taking a greater responsibility.

I have spent some time drawing honourable members' attention to these areas to highlight the most positive contribution Australia can make in developing internationally acceptable attitudes and procedures. Although the Hamburg Rules are not widely accepted in the international community, it is important that Australia promote those conventions that it believes will ultimately benefit the international community.

Our task, once this Bill is passed, is to keep abreast of trends and developments that take place in maritime shipping--changes that will have a bearing on the effectiveness or otherwise of the Hamburg Rules. Therefore, as I mentioned earlier in this speech, it is important that the legislation be reviewed regularly to enable it to remain flexible enough to accommodate changing circumstances. I have much pleasure in supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I do not want to take a lot of time in responding to the debate, except to indicate our appreciation for the contributions that have been made by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), who led for the Opposition in responding to this legislation, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster).

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Gilmore observed to me a short time ago, the debate has been wide-ranging and clearly honourable members have taken the opportunity to raise a number of issues of concern to them. I was interested, and pleased, to see the tendency of members to concentrate on the importance of safe shipping and safe ships for the crews. Whilst the ships are of enormous importance in moving freight around the world, particularly for major commercial nations like Australia, the bottom line, of course, is the safety with which those men and women who serve on ships are able to carry out their responsibilities.

Of particular concern to the Government is the amendment which will be moved by the Opposition. I am sure it does not come as any surprise to the Opposition that the Government will not be endorsing or supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am surprised. I am disappointed too--very disappointed.

—-The honourable member would have been more disappointed, I know, because of his interest and concern regarding these matters, had the Government supported the Opposition. I am absolutely convinced that the honourable member sitting at the table would not personally support this proposition. If he has been locked into supporting it as a result of an Opposition decision, that is perfectly appropriate, but I will emphasise the reason that proposal is not appropriate. This point was taken up, of course, by the honourable member for Shortland, who has an enormous depth of understanding of transport issues.
—-That is why you dumped him. Why did you dump him?

—-No. The honourable member for Shortland, as we all know, is fulfilling an extremely important function as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. He emphasised that the amendment being moved by the Opposition quite clearly has been inspired by overseas shipping companies because it is really the shipping companies which would support that proposition. The honourable member for Shortland indicated that only 4 per cent of our exports are carried on Australian flagged vessels, so any legislation which is supportive of shipping companies necessarily is supportive of overseas shipping companies. I do not say that by way of any prejudice against overseas shipping companies. They are perfectly legitimate, of course, and they are extremely important so far as Australia is concerned. But it does benefit them.

SPEECH.PARA: Why, then, would the Opposition seek to ingratiate itself with overseas shipping companies at the expense of our shippers? It is at the expense of our shippers because our shippers have clearly indicated their support for this legislation and for the proposal that we have that if, at the end of that three-year period, the legislation has not been proclaimed it will automatically come into effect. With its amendment the Opposition seeks to ensure that, at the end of that three-year period, if it is not proclaimed it will be repealed.

But the Opposition says that it supports the legislation. That is incongruous. It is contradictory. The honourable member for Gilmore knows it is really quite an absurd position for the Opposition to adopt. We do not support that view; I do not believe honourable members opposite support it. They are simply seeking, for whatever reasons, to ingratiate themselves with overseas shipping companies and at the same time--and this is the danger that they run--to indicate some lack of adequate concern for Australian shippers.

There was a suggestion made that few of Australia's trading partners at this stage have indicated their accession to the Hamburg Rules. But the number increases all the time. The last one mentioned, the twentieth country, was Zambia. It provided the trigger for the Hamburg Rules to come into effect 12 months hence--in November 1992. But there are other countries as well. Some of the most recent countries which have indicated that they are considering acceding to the Hamburg Rules once they are in force in November 1992 include Italy, Switzerland, France and Czechoslovakia. This legislation clearly indicates Australia's willingness to accede to those rules as soon as it has been indicated to us that a sufficient number of Australia's trading partners have done so. There is no question that that will occur.

There are a couple of other points that I want to make mention of. The Opposition, as I say, has suggested that somehow the Government itself has convinced the shippers--and, of course, the shippers principally are our exporters--of the benefits of the Hamburg Rules. On the contrary: during the review of the cargo liability legislation, and ever since, shippers have strongly pressed the Government for early adoption of the Hamburg Rules. In many ways this legislation now responds to the needs of shippers as perceived and argued by the shippers themselves. Our contact with shippers indicates that they are even more committed to the Hamburg Rules than they have ever been.

I emphasise to the honourable member for Gilmore that that does indicate an incongruity between the position adopted by the Opposition and the declared position, the preferred position, of our shippers--not the overseas shipping companies but of our shippers, our exporters. Consultations have been held between Commonwealth officers and organisations representing shippers, carriers and the legal profession. Carriers and the legal profession raised concerns about the 1990 Bill. Those concerns have now been resolved in the 1991 revised Bill and there is broad industry support for the way in which the replacement Bill has been drafted.

I also want to emphasise that shippers argue that the Hamburg Rules are more equitable than the amended Hague Rules. They transfer the burden of liability from the shipper to the shipowner while the shipowner has care of the cargo, and they increase the liability limits. Quite clearly, then, shippers would find it in their interests to support this legislation, and they have done so. In fact, to a very large extent, the legislation responds to the concerns of Australian shippers.

If this Government has to make a judgment about whether or not our preference will lie with overseas shipping companies or with Australian shippers, with Australian exporters--and that means Australian industries, Australian employees, Australian income earners, Australian business men and women; the interests of Australia as a nation--there is no doubt about which side we will come down on. That is the side we have come down on, at the same time recognising and respecting the legitimate rights of overseas shipping companies which, in so many different ways and with some reservations, have served Australia's overseas trade so well. But we come down on the side of Australia and Australians. I would appeal to the Opposition to do the same.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 2, lines 1-15, omit subclauses (3) to (5), substitute the following subclauses:

"(3) If a Proclamation under subsection (2) is not made within 3 years after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, Part 3 and Schedule 2 are taken to have been repealed at the expiration of those 3 years, unless, before the expiration of those 3 years, each House of the Parliament passes a resolution:
(a) that Part 3 and Schedule 2 are to commence; or
(b) that the question of the commencement of Part 3 and Schedule 2 be reconsidered, in accordance with this section, after a further period of 3 years.
"(4) If a resolution is passed in accordance with paragraph (3)(a) Part 3 and Schedule 2 commence on the day on which the resolution is passed by the second of the Houses to pass it.

"(5) If a resolution is passed in accordance with paragraph (3)(b), the period of 3 years referred to in subsection (3) is taken to commence on the day on which the resolution is passed by the second of the Houses to pass it.".

I wish to commence, as did the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) in his response just a few moments ago, by thanking honourable members who participated in the debate. They were, from our side, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and, on the other side, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and, of course, the Minister for Land Transport, who is at the table.

Most of the speakers on this Bill tonight have taken the opportunity to speak on a wide range of issues relating to the maritime industries and, in particular, the issue of safety. It is a very important issue--one which I have spoken on and made statements about on previous occasions. I think all of us in this House--and it is evident from the speeches that we have had tonight--agree that there is a need for us to improve the safety standards on board ships that sail within Australian waters and into and from Australian ports. It is an issue involving human lives, the safety of our environment and the safety of the very precious cargoes that are transported at sea. So I think there is a universal feeling within this House of the need to upgrade the safety standards. The Opposition has stated on past occasions that, whenever reasonable proposals to achieve this end are put forward by the Government, we will give them wholehearted support.

In response to the points made by the honourable member for Throsby, looking back over the years there have been initiatives taken by the Liberal and National parties when in Government. In fact, it was Ralph Hunt who, as Minister, introduced the inquiry chaired by Sir John Crawford in 1982 which represented, I think, one of the most important changes of direction for the Australian shipping industry. It has led to other inquiries, such as the MIDC, which has brought newer and safer ships onto Australian waters. I think we need to recognise the history, fairly recent though it may be, of attempts undertaken by the coalition Government back in 1982 and subsequently in 1985 by this Government to try to improve the age and safety standards of Australian ships.

I also make the point that we have on past occasions drawn attention to the delays that occur on Australian wharves. It is not just the responsibility of the Waterside Workers Federation or the Seamen's Union. It is quite well known that for various reasons shippers use the wharves as a convenient warehouse or storage place. As the honourable member for Throsby has suggested, we do not blame the Waterside Workers Federation or the Seamen's Union for that. In fact, there will be very little criticism from me about the Seamen's Union. I have a tremendous amount of time and respect for its senior officers, people who I think are outstanding Australians.

When talking about the issue of safety, we need to recognise that safety will not necessarily be enhanced by the maintenance of cabotage. Safety on Australia's waters and on international waters will be enhanced by multilateral negotiations between maritime nations around the world. I urge the Government to enter into more negotiation with other maritime nations to ensure that we can have safer shipping around the world, because over the last few years we have seen an extraordinary increase in the number of vessels disappearing and the number of lives lost at sea. This can really be solved only by getting all the maritime nations of the world together to have those multilateral negotiations to enforce proper standards.

Even though Australia is a very small maritime nation, I think we are leading the way in professionalism. I am sure that the honourable member for Shortland, who has taken a great deal of interest in some of these areas, will agree that the Australian Maritime College is something that we can be proud of. It is probably the leading maritime college in the world. I think that professionalism manifests itself in the fact that Australian ships--which I have taken the opportunity to travel on--are some of the most professional sailing ships in the world today.

I also wish to address the point that the honourable member for Shortland, and indeed the Minister, tried to make. The Opposition, in moving this amendment, is not kowtowing to the shipowners of the world; we are indeed expressing the very reasonable concerns held by no less an authority than the gentleman who was responsible for the creation of the Hamburg Rules. I quoted from his comments earlier tonight. That gentleman was Professor Rolf Herber. He was the chairman of the diplomatic conference at Hamburg which agreed to the conventions in 1978. Professor Herber highlights to us that the implementation of the Hamburg Rules is no guarantee that there will be cheaper insurance rates. He also draws to our attention the fact that, as a result of the Hamburg Rules being implemented in the way that it appears they may well be under this Government's proposals, the increased complexities that will occur in international shipping may indeed add to the cost of insurance for shippers and shipowners. In moving this amendment we are highlighting the concerns of no less an authority than the gentleman responsible for the creation of the Hamburg Rules himself.

We are not kowtowing to the shipowners. I totally reject the statements made by the honourable member for Shortland and the Minister. Many of those shipowners are foreigners. The people that we believe we are representing in this House are the shippers. Australia is a shippers' nation, not a shipowners' nation. Whilst we are representing their best interests and taking into account the advice of the good Professor and of David Roylance--I referred to his article from the Daily Commercial News of just a few days ago--we believe that shippers may well be misled into believing that this legislation, when implemented, will provide them with large savings when they transport their goods on sea. It would appear that that is not going to be the case.

The Government has tried to suggest that we are opposing this legislation. Let me make it very clear what we are proposing to do. The Opposition supports the basic thrust of this legislation. We all recognise the benefits that should accrue from this legislation if our like-minded trading nations were to agree to it and implement the Hamburg Rules at a similar time. We recognise the merits of that. However, we are concerned that after the Government's changes we will see the legislation automatically implemented at the conclusion of three years, no matter what happens. We believe that that is wrong. We believe that the appropriate way to handle this is to have the legislation available to be implemented for three years and, if at the end of three years it has not been implemented, it should come back to the Parliament for reconsideration; if the Parliament wants to renew the legislation it can do so. If the Parliament chooses not to renew the legislation then it can choose not to renew it and allow it to lapse.

That is the basic difference between the Opposition's position and the Government's position. It would seem to some that this is not a huge difference. In fact, it is not. But it is an important principle. We believe that if this amendment is not carried there is a risk involved that in three years time the legislation will automatically be implemented even if events have changed in such a way that its implementation disadvantages Australian shippers and, indeed, Australian shipowners. We believe that the Parliament should have priority consideration in these matters. It is for this reason that I have moved this amendment. If this legislation is not implemented in three years time, we want to see it come back to the Parliament for reconsideration, and the Parliament may then choose to do with it as it wishes. But we believe that the Parliament should have the right to make the decision in three years time. It is for that reason that I have moved the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to pick up a few of the points made by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). When in opposition we had a bipartisan approach to the implementation of the Crawford recommendations when they were tabled in the chamber in February 1982. At that time we sought the cooperation of the then Government to establish port coordinating committees to improve the flow of cargo through Australian ports. Those representations went to the then Prime Minister and to the then Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt. Both rejected them; they wiped their hands of it. So we had bipartisan support for the Crawford recommendations. We built upon them and expanded them. That was the work of this Government. We would have welcomed a bipartisan approach to reform of the waterfront and the improvements there. That has not been forthcoming, but I will not dwell on that.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention the comments of the honourable member for Gilmore about Australian credentials and the Australian Maritime College. Yes, Australian marine credentials are good credentials across the world. We give considerable assistance to our Pacific neighbours. Those credentials and skills that we train in are a product that we should be doing more to market elsewhere in the world.

Turning to insurance rates, in 1985-86 the Australian insurance industry said that it was handling about $140m a year in insurance of cargoes. The reality is that the Australian insurance industry ought to have a much larger share of the business of insuring Australian cargoes, both inbound and outbound. There has not been sufficient effort by the Australian insurance industry. That also is a market that I sometimes think is too complex and difficult for Australian business people, or it is one in which the global insurance companies operating in this country are more comfortable; it suits their global objectives to have that insurance going offshore rather than developing the market here. That is something that this Parliament needs to look at.

I reject the so-called complexity of the Hamburg Rules. No matter how my friend the honourable member for Gilmore might like to squirm about supporting foreign shipowners in preference to Australian shippers and Australian exporters, that is the fact. The effect of this amendment is to prefer foreign shipowners' interests to those of Australian exporters. Going back to some of the real complexities that are involved in handling Australian cargo supports--ancient bills of lading, and complex and intricate paperwork--would be far more effective than posturing through this amendment this evening and, in a way, betraying the interests of Australian exporters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I make two observations. The first is in response to the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), who suggested that at the end of the three years it would be better that the legislation lapse rather than be proclaimed, as is provided for under the Government's legislation. It is a test of not only the Government's vigilance about legislation and provisions of this kind but the whole Parliament's. To imagine that the legislation would come into effect against the interests of the Parliament or the Government, I think, is stretching the imagination too far.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us assume that, as a result of whatever may be the circumstances, that were to happen. The Parliament and the Government are in charge of the business of government and it would be simple to introduce legislation to repeal the legislation which had come into effect. There is no question about that. The point that we emphasise again is that the purpose of the legislation is to ensure, at the end of the three years--in the absence of any deliberate decision by the Government to proclaim it--that the proclamation will take place automatically. In the Senate the Opposition was arguing that one of the reasons for its amendment was to encourage the proclamation of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They agreed to it, didn't they.

—-Agreed to it and endorsed it. The purpose of the Opposition's amendment is to encourage the proclamation of the legislation, but the amendment provides for the non-proclamation of the legislation and, in effect, the repeal of the legislation. That is absurd. I am embarrassed for the honourable member for Gilmore that his Party has locked him into that situation--one, I am sure, that he would prefer to avoid, for those reasons as well as to make it quite clear that his preference, as does the Government's, lies with Australian shippers and Australian exporters and not the major overseas shipping companies.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Sharp's) be agreed to.
