TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday the augmented Electoral Commission for South Australia reported on the objections that were put to it by the Electoral Committee for South Australia. As a result of that, changes are made to the River area and to an area concerning the electorate of Sturt, but no changes were proposed in response to the very significant objections and submissions that were made in relation to Boothby, Adelaide and Hindmarsh. Personally, as a result of that, I look forward to representing the now very different seat of Boothby which will be presented at the next Federal election for the electors to decide their representative. I must say that I welcome the op-portunity, if I am the preselected member for the Liberal Party at the next election, of representing the coastline which is a most attractive addition to the remnants of the old seat of Boothby.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that I am personally looking forward to that representation, I must say to the House that the proposal endorsed by the augmented Electoral Commission is a deeply flawed proposal. I say that on the basis that the result of the objection and the Commission's response to it makes no difference to the electoral position I might look forward to in Boothby. The result in that regard is altered by no more than 0.2 per cent at the next election. I want to make that clear.

However, I would like to read briefly to the House the record of inequality and the failure and defamation of democracy in relation to the results for the Liberal Party in South Australia over the last number of years. On the last seven occasions on which my Party has received a majority of votes in South Australia, it has received a majority of seats but once. In 1955, the two-party preferred result for my Party was 51 per cent of the votes and we received five out of the 11 seats. In 1958, we received 50.2 per cent of the votes and we got five out of 11 seats. In 1966, with the enormous vote for the Liberal and National Party coalition, we received 57.6 per cent of the votes and we got eight out of 11 of the seats. That was the last time we saw a majority of seats. In 1975, we got 55 per cent of the votes and we got half the seats. In 1977, we got 51.3 per cent of the votes and we got five out of 11 seats. In 1980, we got 50.4 per cent of the votes and we got five out of 11 seats. In 1990, we got 50.5 per cent of the votes and we got six out of 13 seats. The presentation of this report and its endorsement means, on the results of the last election of 50.5 per cent of the votes, that we will get 42 per cent of the seats.

This is a miscarriage of justice in that, once again, in South Australia my Party will have to get far beyond half the votes to get half of the seats. The Commission has produced a flawed report which perpetuates a disgraceful situation. The report is very unprofessional. It has thrust aside the lengthy evidence put to it by my Party without any refutation. It has ignored the criteria and raced to one particular criterion--to reject evidence which was put before it which was rebutted by no other party, particularly the Labor Party. It was lengthy evidence, unrebutted, and the Committee thrust it aside. In Hindmarsh and part of Boothby, it has totally ignored the continuing community of interest on the coast. Yet it has gone to the river districts and made a large change to the detail of the Committee on the basis of community of interest.

The Commission has produced a report which will make this Government very happy. Whether or not the Commission has been biased politically, it certainly appears to be biased politically. My district and the voters who have been thrust aside by this Commission's unfair report--(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The cost of access to airports will have a major impact on the level of growth of air travel in this country. I want to draw attention to the massive misinformation campaign against development of Badgerys Creek by what in effect are vested commercial interests at Mascot. Badgerys Creek was always intended to be a supplementary domestic airport with the capacity to be developed as an international airport if and when that should be needed. In my view, that `if it were to be needed', based on current technology, would be some time in the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.PARA: But Badgerys Creek would be to Mascot what Gatwick has been to Heathrow in the United Kingdom. Gatwick, in its role as a supplementary international airport, was pooh-hooed when it was built and when it was opened. But Gatwick developed and is now choked with traffic because it provides a low cost alternative to Heathrow. Badgerys Creek was to be to Mascot what Gatwick is to Heathrow in the United Kingdom.

The future growth in air travel will come from leisure and recreational travel. Where are the origins of those travellers? They are in suburbia, in metropolitan Sydney. It is not traffic that will be originating from five star international hotels in downtown Sydney. It is not traffic that will be originating from the CBD of Sydney or traffic that is destined for the CBD of Sydney. To put an accurate dimension on projections, we need to carry out accurate origin and destination studies.

If the American deregulation experience shows anything, the one thing that is indisputable is that people will accept a lower quality of air travel if the price is right. They will put up with inconvenience if the price is right. If there is a greater distance to travel, if people have to unpack their bags or be checked in on the footpath, they will put up with all of that. But we have to give them the choice, and we have never done that in this country.

Badgerys Creek is relatively cheap and curfew free. It is designed to serve the Sydney region--not, as the misinformation campaign suggests, solely the city of Sydney. The important factor in the growth of air travel that is occurring now and will continue to occur for the next four to five years is the centroid of demand. Where is the centre of demand of travel for those people? It is not in downtown Sydney. Again, we see the misinformation that surrounds the proposed development and expansion of Badgerys Creek. Badgerys Creek will open up a new market, and Mascot's commercial interests, with their high cost investments, obviously do not want a lower cost, accessible, curfew free airport less than one hour's drive away. Badgerys Creek will create jobs where they are needed--out in the western suburbs. It will generate industry and growth in that area, and it is where more and more people are going to be residing.

For all the right reasons, Badgerys Creek is the last remaining suitable site for a domestic and international airport location. It will service the residential areas of Sydney. It is a supplementary airport for the Sydney region. The sooner Badgerys Creek is in service, the better. As I said, it will provide jobs where jobs are needed. Anybody who gets in on the ground floor in Badgerys Creek will make a killing further down the track. If honourable members doubt my word, I ask them to recall what happened with Tullamarine. I repeat that Badgerys Creek was intended to be a supplementary domestic airport, with the capacity to go international if and when needed, and to service the Sydney region.

The deregulation of the airline system has brought air travel within the reach of millions of Australians--and so it should. Air travel is public transport; it is not glamour transport. There have been record numbers of air travellers in the past year, some 8 per cent increase on the previous record of 1988, which was boosted by being the year of Expo and the Bicentenary. We had an inflated record level of traffic in 1988, but we are 8 per cent up on that and we have not really started yet. As air travel is public transport, it ought to be available to as many Australians as possible.

The Opposition's two-airline agreement denied 90 per cent of Australians the ability to travel and it produced for Australians a high quality service at a relatively high price. This Government will provide people with a choice of a less convenient form of travel, safe but at a lower price. As I said, the American experience has shown one thing: people will put up with inconvenience if the price is right. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It may come as a surprise to honourable members to note that the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), would be refused registration as a tax agent under the present interpretation of the Income Tax Assessment Act by the Tax Agents Board. No doubt many ordinary Australians, including the almost one million unemployed, would cheer if equal restraint had been shown about public finances. After all, it was the honourable member for Blaxland who showed such fiscal rectitude that only in one year of his treasurership was the total public sector account in the black. Overall, he presided over a total deficit of close to $70 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: But many people would be surprised to learn that the Commissioner of Taxation, the man responsible for the administration of our complex and archaic tax system, probably would not qualify as a tax agent either. Why? Because section 58CA of the Act, as interpreted by the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, requires a person to have been engaged in relevant employment on a full time basis for not less than a total of 12 months in the preceding five years in order to be registered.

Consider the case of Chenouda v. Tax Agents Board of New South Wales, which was decided on 13 May this year. Mr Chenouda sought registration as a tax agent. The Board refused to register him because it was not satisfied that he had the prescribed academic and practical qualifications. He had the relevant academic qualifications--a Bachelor of Business degree from the New South Wales Institute of Technology. However, the Board formed the view that he did not have the prescribed practical experience. He would have had that experience only if he had been engaged in relevant employment on a full time basis for not less than a total of 12 months in the preceding five years. So far as he was concerned, this meant that he would have had to have been employed by a person or a partnership and must have had a substantial involvement in income tax matters, including the preparation of a broad range of income tax returns. His employment would have had to have been supervised employment. He did not have this experience.

It did not matter that he had had over eight years experience in the Australian Tax Office and five years of employment as a tax manager in private industry. More recently, he had been employed as taxation manager of the Caltex Oil Australia Ltd group. Since Caltex is part of an international group, Chenouda had experience in a wide range of income tax matters. Although he had been responsible for the preparation of only one income tax return, the preparation of that return involved consideration of some 13 businesses on an international scale.

He sought registration to allow his employer to benefit from the tax return lodgment extension arrangements available to tax agents. He said that many people also wanted him to prepare their personal income tax returns and he would do that on the weekends and in his spare time if he was registered. But the Board refused to register him. He sought a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and it upheld the Board's decision. The Tribunal said:
The Board does not purport to examine general competence. It merely administers the Income Tax Act and Regulations.
A similar interpretation of the Act was given by Justice Pincus in the earlier case of the Tax Agents Board of Queensland v. Seymour.

As one of my constituents has pointed out, even though he has been a qualified accountant for 32 years, the holder of an authorised dealer's licence approved by the Australian Securities Commission allowing him to advise people on how and where to invest their moneys, to advise on retirement benefit limits and how to structure their finances in accordance with taxation regulations, he could not be registered as a tax agent. As this effect of the legislation does not appear to have been contemplated when it was passed by Parliament, I ask the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) whether he would examine this matter. After all, either the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) or the current Treasurer (Mr Kerin) may well be in need of a job soon.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Service of Australian Forces in Korean War

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In 1950, just five years after the Allied victory in World War II, Australia suddenly became engaged in another great struggle for freedom. On 25 June of that year communist forces of North Korea launched a brutal attack against the free Republic of Korea. The invasion was condemned by the United Nations, and a United Nations command was formed to repel the aggressor. Soldiers, sailors and airmen of Australia, many of whom had seen active service during World War II, joined with those of 17 other nations in the conflict which would become known as the Korean War.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian forces saw active services in the United Nations operations in Korea from 1950 until 1953. The total number of Australian participants in the Korean War was as follows: Army, 5,087; Royal Australian Navy, 3,320; and Royal Australian Air Force, 1,241. As a result of the Korean War, 340 Australians died and 1,230 Australians were wounded.

The actions of Australian service personnel serving in the Korean War were marked by many conspicuous acts of heroism. I place on record tonight the heroism of one Australian soldier in particular. Many years ago I served in the Citizen Military Forces, as it was then known, with Major Kevin Thomas, a former member of the 3rd Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment. Corporal Thomas, as he then was, was a rifle section commander in A Company, 3rd Battalion. He was awarded a Military Medal for bravery during fierce action in the Songgok area east of Samichon River during early September 1952. His citation reads as follows:

Corporal Thomas has been a rifle section commander in A Company, 3rd Battalion, The Royal Australian Regiment, for the past six months. Throughout this period he has demonstrated the highest qualities of a junior non-commissioned officer, both in command of his section as a leader of fighting and reconnaissance patrols.

In particular he distinguished himself on the night of 3rd September 1952, as second in command of a fighting patrol of one officer and 15 men which successfully ambushed an enemy patrol about 40 strong. During this action, Corporal Thomas personally killed three of the enemy and his section a further nine. When the Officer Commanding the patrol was severely wounded, he took command and judging the object of the patrol to have been achieved, ordered its withdrawal to the patrol firm base positioned to the rear.

He himself, having first organised the evacuation of the wounded, stayed behind with a small group to cover the move back. Shortly afterwards a determined attack on this rear guard was made by about 20 enemy, but under Corporal Thomas's leadership they were successfully fought off, at least two being killed. Under heavy enemy fire the rear guard then rejoined the firm base, Corporal Thomas carrying a member who had been severely wounded.
Later when a further patrol was organised to go out and sweep the scene of action, Corporal Thomas volunteered and went out as its guide.

His courage and determination during this action were an inspiration to the patrol and his outstanding leadership was a deciding factor in the success it achieved. The constant example of fearlessness and devotion to duty set by this non-commissioned officer has been responsible for the maintenance of the very high standard of morale and efficiency among his men.

Kevin Thomas and his wife, Margaret, now living in Townsville, returned to Korea in April 1991 and visited Pusan Cemetery, where Australian soldiers are buried. Kevin's recollections of the visit are particularly poignant. He had this to say:
My wife Margaret and I visited the cemetery where I took a photograph of her standing next to the grave of her brother Keith Gardner.
He was killed during the action for which Kevin received his citation. He went on:
We were astounded by the young ages of the soldiers buried there.
Keith was 19 years old.
There are 43 other names of men who were my friends and comrades in arms from A Company, 3rd Battalion, The Royal Australian Regiment located in this cemetery.
I remember their names but not their faces.
I still ask myself the question "Why them and not me?

Kevin Thomas and his comrades in arms who served in Korea have left behind them an enduring legacy of selfless devotion to the highest ideals of mankind. I recall President Truman's words of salute to American troops in Korea; they apply no less to Australians who served there. His words were as follows:
You will go down in history as the first army to fight under a flag of a world organisation in the defence of human freedom. . .
Victory may be in your hands, but you are winning a greater thing than military victory, for you are vindicating the idea of freedom under international law.
I record the gratitude of this House to Australian Korean War heroes and their fallen comrades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Tonight I rise to bring to the notice of the House a press release put out by the NAFI expressing its disappointment in the resource security proposal. The thrust of the press release says quite clearly that this proposal relates to two propositions only, the pulp and paper industry in Tasmania and perhaps one in East Gippsland. The general thrust of its arguments says quite clearly that this proposal is nothing more than Clayton's security for the industry; it just will not happen and it is probably illegal, anyway. When we read part of this draft legislation, we see:

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement is legally binding, but the Commonwealth is not liable to pay damages for any breach.

What sort of security is that for the industry? None whatsoever. The answer is quite clear: the Government ought to take a serious look at how the industry works. We do not want security legislation that is project driven; it needs to be process driven and looking at the existing families and people who are working in that industry.

Quite frankly, the answer is simple. We do not have to go through a nonsense of gobbledegook and another several years of overlooking and reviewing the industry. Quite clearly, the Heritage Act should stop being misused for land care and used for what it was intended. The Commonwealth could quite easily have had legislation which supports the 1986 Victorian timber industry strategy, which gave 15-years licences to the industry on a sustainable yield basis, thereby giving the industry security already. If the Commonwealth had gone down that path, the problem would have been resolved today instead of having the distrust in the industry that we have got right now.

It seems to me that even in what the Government is proposing, it does not understand the term `integrated harvesting', whereby a section of timber is used for its best value. The high quality timber goes into veneers, furnishings and what have you. One step down from that we get housing, scantling and framing timber. We go one step further down and we get into pulp and paper industry, firewood and fencing posts. This is an integrated harvesting system which is saw log driven. To give security to a major project would not work in my part of the world and it is completely a nonsense.

But when we look at this process one step further, we find that the Victorian National Parks Association has had a change of heart. It cannot be trusted to keep its own word. These intellectually barren greens have gone right back on their terminology. Let me quote what Mr Morley of the pulp and paper workers' division of the Australian Timber and Allied Industries Union had to say recently in the paper:

Mr Morley described the move by the VNPA to change its Central Highlands policy as "a cynical exercise in bastardry given that the conservation movement's submissions on the creation of enlarged national parks in East Gippsland resulted in over 500 jobs being lost".

"The greenies justified the draconian curtailment of the timber industry in East Gippsland and the `locking away' of forest resource resulting from the creation of the new alpine park by claiming that it supported the harvesting of the 1926 and 1939 ash regrowth forests in the Central Highlands. . .

The fact of the matter is that 66 per cent of the eucalyptus hardwood which is used in the pulp and paper industry in my electorate comes from this particular area. So I would say to those opposite right now: quite clearly the proposed security legislation is a nonsense. What security do the families that live in and rely on the timber industry in my elecorate have? None whatsoever.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether the total sum paid per annum in Australia in insurance premiums is $12 billion.
(2) Do insurance consumers face difficulties when involved in disputes with their insurers.
(3) Do insurance consumers find resort to the courts and other means of dispute resolution to be too expensive, too slow, ineffective and lacking in real independence from the industry.
(4) Is the Minister able to say whether the UK has established an independent insurance ombudsman with powers to investigate and redress wrongs against insurance consumers by insurance companies.
(5) Is the Minister able to say whether an Australian banking industry ombudsman has been established to resolve consumer disputes concerning banking services.

(6) Are arrangements proposed by insurance companies to resolve consumer complaints (a) not independent from the industry, (b) limited in the complaints they can address, (c) inadequate in powers and jurisdiction, (d) too slow and (e) deficient in observing principles of natural justice; if so, will the Minister ensure that the insurance industry corrects these deficiencies.

(7) Will the Minister establish a statutory office of Australian insurance ombudsman with (a) genuinely independent status, (b) powers to fully investigate complaints and make binding determinations, (c) the ability to address a wide range of complaints concerning insurance sales, service and claims, (d) jurisdiction over the operations of all retail insurers, (e) the requirement that principles of natural justice will apply and each party will have the opportunity to know the case presented by the other and (f) the acceptance of both insurance consumers and insurance providers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Insurance and Superannuation Commission has advised that the total amount of premium income (ie total premium income minus reinsurance premiums and Government charges) reported by private and public general insurance companies balancing between 1 July 1989 and 30 June 1990 was $11.9 billion.
Life insurance companies balancing in the same period reported total premium revenue of $18.5 billion.
(2) Some insurance consumers may face difficulties when involved in disputes with their insurers.

(3) Court action in respect of insurance disputes may be precluded for some consumers because of the expense involved, and substantial delays can be experienced with the court process in some states. However, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs strongly refutes the suggestion that the courts lack independence from the industry. Disputes concerning general or life insurance may also be brought before Small Claims Courts or Tribunals in certain States and Territories, subject to monetary limits. The Minister is not aware of any specific criticism of the operations of the Small Claims Courts or Tribunals in respect of handling of insurance disputes.
(4) The UK Insurance Ombudsman Bureau was established in 1981 by the UK insurance industry and is funded by the industry.
(5) Yes, the banking industry has established an office of the Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman.

(6) (a) The schemes were established by the insurance industry after extensive consultation with government bodies and consumer organisations, and are funded by the industry. However, the dispute resolution panels--the Complaints Review Committee in the case of life insurance complaints and the Claims Review Panel in the case of general insurance--are able to make independent judgements and their decision is binding on participating life insurance companies for amounts up to $250 000, and on participating general insurance companies for amounts up to $100 000, but not on the consumer, who retains the right to pursue other avenues of redress if he or she considers the Committee or Panel's decision to be unacceptable. The Committee and Panel each comprise a consumer representative, an industry representative and an independent chairperson. Their operation is oversighted by an independent Insurance Industry Complaints Council which comprises two insurance industry members, two members with experience in consumer affairs, and an independent chairperson appointed by the Federal Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs after consultation with the Insurance Council of Australia (ICA) and the Life Insurance Federation of Australia (LIFA).

(c) The effectiveness of the schemes will be assessed after twelve months of operation. The review of the schemes will be conducted by the Insurance Industry Complaints Council in consultation with the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and the Treasurer, and will consider the views of the States and Territories. For the purposes of the initial twelve month trial period, the powers and jurisdiction are considered to be adequate.

(d) Appointments to the Chairs of the Committee and Panel have only recently been made. It is too early to assess whether the dispute resolution procedures will prove to be too slow. The procedures contain provisions dealing with delays in the handling of complaints.

(e) In general, the technical rules of natural justice only apply where the rights of a person are affected. Under the insurance schemes, consumers always have the option of having the dispute heard before a court. However, the schemes incorporate a number of features, including the consumer's right to present his or her case in writing and have it determined by a panel, designed to ensure procedural fairness in resolving disputes.
The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs does not believe that there is a need to change the insurance dispute resolution arrangements at this stage.

(7) The Government does not believe it appropriate to consider establishment of a statutory office of Australian insurance ombudsman at this time. It believes there should be an opportunity to assess the effectiveness of operation of the dispute resolution schemes recently put in place by the insurance industry after consultation with government bodies and other interested parties.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the answers to questions Nos. 1185 (Hansard, 1 December 1988, page 3749), 21 (Hansard, 21 August 1990, page 1210), 330 (Hansard, 8 November 1990, page 3714) and 515 (Hansard, 13 February 1991, page 555), when does he expect to put forward a request to finalise accession to the Unesco 1950 `Florence' Agreement on the Importation of Educational, Scientific and Cultural Materials and the 1976 `Nairobi' Protocol to the Agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under Article XII, paragraph 2 of the Florence Agreement, States Parties lodging an instrument of acceptance of the Agreement are required to take all necessary measures for its fully effective operation within a period of three months from the date of deposit. Also under Article XII, paragraph 3, States Parties are required, within one month of the expiration of the three month period, to submit a report to UNESCO of the measures which they have taken for such fully effective operation.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill No. 2 1991 which contains the amendments necessary to enable Australia to comply with obligations in the Florence Agreement is currently before the Parliament. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services moved the Bill's second reading, on behalf of the Minister for Small Business and Customs, on 11 September 1991.
It is proposed to recommend that Executive Council agree to Australia's acceptance of the Agreement once the above legislative action is complete.
Australia's accession to the Nairobi Protocol is dependent upon acceptance of the Florence Agreement and will occur concurrently.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 August 1991

QUESTION.PARA: Since the passage of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1984, has the Government considered the form of the oaths or affirmations of allegiance taken or made by persons to whom a certificate of Australian citizenship has been granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1986, No. 70 of 1986 amended the wording of the oath and affirmation of allegiance. That amendment removed the words `renouncing all other allegiance'. These words were removed because:
the renunciation had no effect under other countries' nationality laws,
some people believed they were required to renounce all ties with their countries of origin, and
many people from Commonwealth countries were confused when they both renounced and swore/affirmed allegiance to the Queen.
There is no consideration currently being given to further amendment of the oath and affirmation of allegiance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of wool research funds are being applied to (a) 22-25 micron wools and (b) fine wools.
(2) What proportion of research funding is being provided by (a) woolgrowers and (b) wool processors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The vast majority of projects funded by the Wool Research and Development Corporation (WRDC) are `micron neutral' with the results applicable to all wools. However, out of a total program of $48.2m and $50.2m in 1990-91 and 1991-92 respectively estimates of `micron specific' expenditure are:
(a) in wool textile research, $0.9 million in both 1990-91 and 1991-92 which is specific to wools of 22-25 micron;
(b) in wool production research, $194,000 in 1990-91, and $221,000 in 1991-92 which is specific to fine wool.
(2) (a) Woolgrowers contributed $14.3m in 1990-91 to the total WRDC program in that year. It is estimated that woolgrower contributions in 1991-92 will be $13.3m .

(b) Financial contributions of $0.62m were made by wool processors in 1990-91 to WRDC sponsored Northern Hemisphere research projects. These contributions are expected to increase to $0.86m in 1991-92.

There were no cash contributions by processors to the textile research program in Australia. However, in several cases, technologies transferred to the Australian textile industry received contributions in kind through collaborative commercialisation programs where the industry partner provided staff time, machinery, marketing etc. These contributions have not been costed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Part IV of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 establish a Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee.
(2) Does paragraph 45 (1)(d) of the Act specify that one member of the Committee shall be a person to represent the interests of consumers.
(3) Who are the current members of the Committee and when did the Committee last meet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the appointment of the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee was announced by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on 21 September 1987. The appointment of the Advisory Committee was one of the first steps taken to implement the plant variety rights legislation.
(2) Paragraph 45 (1)(d) of the PVR Act 1987 states:

`one member who, in the opinion of the Minister, is an appropriate person to represent the interests of consumers, and likely consumers, of new plant varieties or of the products of new plant varieties'.
The person who has represented consumer interests on the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee was a nominee of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations.

Consumers of new plant varieties or their products are organised into diverse interest groups. For example, consumers of grain from a new wheat variety are as diverse as animal feed manufacturers, feedlots, flour millers, bakers or the bread-consuming public. Each interest group that adds value to the product of a new variety is represented by its own (consumer) organisation with different interests in the new variety.

The diversity of consumer groups and the need for equity has prompted me to review representation on the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee specified under paragraph 45 (1)(d) of the Act referred to by the honourable member.

Dr Mick Lloyd (Chairperson)- Registrar of Plant Variety Rights

The consumer representative, Mr Richard Arthur, resigned from the Advisory Committee and a new representative was nominated by the Federation of Australian Consumer Organisations. This organisation was advised by me to withhold their nomination until I called for nominations for a new Advisory Committee which was to be appointed shortly.
All members of the PVRAC have been advised that nominations are to be called for membership of the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee under a new set of appointment guidelines.
The Committee, including the consumer representative, last met on 13 February, 1991. All members were present except Dr John Leslie.

I have developed a set of equitable appointment procedures for the PVR Advisory Committee since the Act does not make provision for this. Nominations have been called under the new appointment guidelines and the reconstituted PVRAC is expected to meet before the end of October, 1991.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Wheat: Road and Rail Freight Rates

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the comparison between (a) road and (b) rail freight rates for wheat in (i) New South Wales, (ii) Victoria, (iii) South Australia, (iv) Western Australia and (v) Queensland on (A) a basis of net tonne per kilometre, (B) average and (C) indicator rates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Use of road freight for wheat is only significant in Western Australia and South Australia. The distance that wheat is transported varies considerably between these two States, with the longest freight distance in Western Australia some 300 percent longer than in South Australia. As a result, I consider the figures for road freight charges would not be suitable as the basis for a comparison of wheat freight rates across the States as sought by Mr Hawker.

The charge on a net tonne per kilometre basis for rail freight varies according to the distance, generally decreasing as the distance increase. As well, the distance that wheat must be transported varies considerably between the States. I have therefore taken specific distances common across the States in order to illustrate the rail freight charges applicable.
In 1990-91, rail freight charges, on a cents per net tonne per kilometre basis, were:
The lowest rail freight charges in each State, on a cents per net tonne per kilometre basis, and the relevant transport distance, in 1990-91 were:

The Australian Wheat Board deducts freight costs from growers based on the rate applicable to the silo at which the wheat is delivered. Estimated average freight deductions by State for the 1990-91 season are:
These freight deductions represent the average of all freight costs, whether road or rail, from delivery silo to export terminal (or domestic end user) for Australian Wheat Board pool wheat.
In New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland these deductions are almost totally based on rail freight.

However, a small proportion of Western Australian wheat, and a significant proportion of South Australian wheat, is moved by road from delivery silos. In these States, the average deduction therefore incorporates a component of road freight costs. These are not accounted for separately by the Australian Wheat Board and so individual average freight deductions for either road or rail cannot be readily determined.

The average freight deduction of $9.91 per tonne in South Australia applies only to the tonnage delivered to country silos. However, in South Australia, because of the relatively short distances involved, a significant proportion of wheat is delivered direct to the terminals by growers rather than to country silos as occurs in other States. If calculated over the entire tonnage of wheat delivered, the average freight deduction would be $6.51 per tonne. In other States, direct grower deliveries to terminals are relatively low and so they do not significantly affect the calculated State average freight deductions.

`Indicator rates' for wheat freight are either not applicable or not widely used in the wheat industry. Because of this, the Australian Wheat Board has developed distance interval comparisons which I have drawn upon to illustrate comparative freight rates on the net tonne per kilometre basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 3 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he receive a letter from Friends of the Earth in June 1991 which provided estimates for the market for Australian uranium; if so, what differences exist between those estimates and estimates made by his Department.
(2) Does he rely entirely on the advice of his Department for estimates of future uranium demand.

(3) Did the International Energy Agency claim that nuclear energy consumption will be at 10.3 per cent of total energy consumption by the year 2000 and will stagnate at that level; if so, does this conform with his Department's estimates.
(4) Is he able to say whether (a) there are few nuclear reactors on order to be online after 1995 and (b) reactors ordered now will not come on line before 2000.
(5) Is he able to say whether Japan has 40 nuclear plants in operation and a further 15 either under construction or on order.
(6) Is he able to say whether the Japanese anti-nuclear movement presents a significant obstacle to the achievement of Japanese nuclear industry objectives.
(7) Are the estimated costs of uranium production for (a) Koongarra $US20-25 per pound and (b) Jabiluka $US25-30 per pound.
(8) Are current spot prices for uranium approximately $US9-10 per pound.
(9) Will uranium spot prices rise to $US14 per pound by 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The letter referred to various forecasts of nuclear generating capacity in WOCA (world outside centrally planned economies areas) by the year 2000. These included forecasts by my Department (320 GWe), the OECD's Nuclear Energy Agency (327-337 GWe), NUKEM (329.3 GWe), the Uranium Institute (323 GWe), Greenpeace (310 GWe) and Friends of the Earth's own forecast (302-304 GWe).

The forecast by Friends of the Earth was derived by excluding from NUKEM's forecast the nuclear capacity estimates for all reactors ordered or planned but not currently under construction, on the assumption that none of these reactors will be completed within the forecast period. While it is reasonable to expect that there could be approval problems and construction delays in a number of cases, the fact that approval and construction processes are currently continuing suggests that the validity of the Friends of the Earth forecast is questionable.
(2) No. If I required estimates of future uranium demand I would have regard to the full range of available estimates.

(3) The International Energy Agency (IEA) has forecast that nuclear energy's share of primary energy supply in OECD countries will increase from 10.1 per cent in 1989 to 10.3 per cent in 1995, and then decline to 10.2 per cent in 2000 and 10 per cent in 2005. The IEA expects primary energy supply in OECD countries to grow by an average of 1.3 per cent per annum during this period, including an expansion in the supply of nuclear power by an average of 1.2 per cent per annum. The IEA forecasts represent an expected increase in the supply of nuclear power from 410 million metric tons of oil equivalent in 1989 to a projected 495 million metric tons of oil equivalent in 2005. This underlines the fact that, while nuclear power's relative share of the total energy market is expected to remain fairly constant, the supply of energy from this source, in absolute terms, is expected to continue to grow.
My Department has made no estimates with which to compare the IEA's forecasts of nuclear power's share of total primary energy supply in the OECD.

(4) According to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO), there are, world-wide, 5 reactors currently on order and not yet under construction. There are a further 58 reactors under construction (of which 44 are scheduled to commence operation before 1996) and there are 74 reactors in the planning stage but not yet ordered.

Of the 5 reactors now on order, 2 are in Japan and 3 are in the Republic of Korea. All of these ordered reactors are scheduled to come on-line after 1995. The 2 in Japan are scheduled to enter into commercial operation in 1996 and 1997 and the 3 in the Republic of Korea in 1997, 1998 and 1999. The successful history of these countries' nuclear construction programs suggests that this timetable will largely be met.
(5) ANSTO reports that there are currently 41 operating reactors in Japan, 11 reactors are under construction, 2 have been ordered and a further 13 are in the firm planning stage.

(6) I assume that this question has been prompted by an article in Nucleonics Week of 9 May 1991 which reported the view of Moody's Investment Services Inc that `the antinuclear movement will continue to present a significant obstacle to MITI and the industry's ambitious plan to add 40 new nuclear power plants in Japan by 2010'.
The same article noted that 66 per cent of the Japanese public think that nuclear power is necessary.

A principal objective of Japanese energy planners is to meet Japan's projected increases in electricity demand without undue reliance on fossil fuels. The Japanese public's support for nuclear power is certainly not unqualified and public acceptance problems do exist. Nevertheless, there appears to be a sound appreciation by a majority of the Japanese public of the substantial role nuclear power plays in meeting Japan's growing energy requirements. On this basis, the likelihood that Japan will meet, or largely meet, its nuclear industry objectives over the next two decades cannot be dismissed.
(7) To the extent that estimated uranium production costs for Koongarra and Jabiluka are available to the Government, these are provided on a commercial in confidence basis and cannot be disclosed.

(8) The current spot price for uranium is approximately US$9.00 per pound. It should be noted, however, that all of Australia's uranium exports are currently being made under long term contracts and realise an average return substantially above the spot price level.

(9) US$14.00 per pound (expressed in 1991 US dollars) is the forecast uranium (U(3)O(8)) spot price for 1996 published by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics in its December 1990 edition of Agriculture and Resource Quarterly. As with any forecast, this estimate will be revised, up or down as warranted, in line with any changes in expectations of future market conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of senior executives employed by the ABC is as follows:

The definition of Senior Executive within the ABC was changed in July 1988. If the current definition had applied in July 1987 the number of senior executives would have been 237. The 'senior executive' category in the ABC includes lower classifications than the Australian Public Service 'senior executive service'.
(2) The following table shows completed redundancy action for 1989-90-91 and projected for 1991-92:
Some 1991-92 redundancies are expected to be redeployed within the ABC.
(3) The ABC acquired a site at 120-130 Southbank Boulevarde, Southbank, on 29 November 1988 for a purchase price of $5.75 million.

(4) The ABC has stopped work on the Southbank development because the ABC has been unable to realise funds through the sale of property in both Burwood and Melbourne. The ABC received some funds from the partial sale of the vacant land at Burwood.

(5) The Ultimo Project has not yet been formally completed. To date, and accounting for expected cost to completion, construction costs will not exceed the Limit of Costs set by the Public Works Committee. Building and equipment requirements have been reviewed at various stages of the project. All essential facilities and equipment have been included in the completed project.
(7) No. The ABC has not exceeded the borrowings limit set by the Government.

(8) The ABC entered into a co-production agreement with Law Foundation Productions Pty Ltd, a media production company, for the co-production of six, four minute segments for inclusion in `The Investigators' programs. The Law Foundation committed $24,000 to its share of expenses and a further sum of $3,000 has been requested to cover additional production costs.

(9) (a) The ABC Act contains a number of provisions designed to maintain the ABC's identity as a non-commercial broadcasting organisation. They prohibit advertising, acknowledge that the ABC as a statutory corporation is directly funded by government and carefully control the ABC's right to use external funds in the production of programs broadcast by the ABC.

The ABC is permitted by subsection 25(5)(a) of the ABC Act to accept direct external funding from public sources for the production and broadcast of particular programs or announcements. However, the ABC does not accept government funds earmarked for programs or material on conditions which infringe the editorial independence of the ABC. Nor does it accept funds for programs which are or appear to be party political.
The ABC is also authorised by subsection 25(5)(b) of the ABC Act to enter into co-productions with bona fide producers of programs, films, sound recordings, concerts and public entertainments.

(b) The Board is opposed to the ABC receiving corporate sponsorship. The Board acknowledges that independent producers and co-producers will on occasions receive funding from external sources including the corporate sector.
In news and current affairs programs the Board has determined that no funding arrangements are permitted with private co-producers or independent producers.

(10) In 1990 the Law Foundation made a gift to the ABC of $50,000 under its Charter for use by the ABC at its discretion in the production of segments on legal issues relating to home building and ownership covered by `The Home Show'.

(11) No. The ABC is not moving towards (a) the introduction of (i) spot advertising and (ii) program sponsorship and (b) reliance on outside contractors for the production of programs rather than ABC program staff. The ABC broadcasts a mixture of both internally and externally produced programs.

(13) No. The ABC will still produce approximately 40-50 per cent of its television programs in-house. A proportion of these will be co-production. While the people involved in the production of these programs are not confined to ABC staff, editorial control will remain in the hands of the ABC.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Marriage: Education, Counselling and Mediation Funding

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: How many (a) individuals attended marriage counselling, (b) couples attended marriage education programs and (c) families attended family mediation programs at agencies funded under the (i) Marriage Act 1961 and (ii) Family Law Act 1975 in (A) 1989-90 and (B) 1990-91.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1990-91, 9434 couples attended marriage education programs conducted by organisations who receive funding for these programs under the Marriage Act 1961 and the Family Law Act 1975. Statistics on couples attending marriage education programs in 1989-90 were provided to my Department in the annual reports of individual organisations. However, there was no uniform method of recording this data during the 1989-90 financial year or in previous years. Therefore I am unable to refer to this source to provide a total and accurate account on marriage education services for that year.

Statistics on the utilisation of marriage counselling and family mediation services were also provided in the annual reports of individual organisations. For the reason previously stated, I am unable to refer to this source to answer your question.
Additionally, from 1987-88 to 1990-91, service utilisation data for marriage counselling and family mediation was collected by my Department. However, it has proved prohibitively expensive to

process the data into a useable form, and much of the information sought was subject to recorder bias. During a review of this process the level of error was discovered to be so great as to render the processed data completely unreliable.

The Department has not pursued this method and has now developed a more reliable process. Agencies are now required to complete a statistical return on a quarterly basis which provides numbers of persons using services funded under the Family Services Program. The collected information will be available in the Annual Report of my Department for 1991-92.
